question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chronic cough, sinus pain, and nasal discharge. He has a history of frequent upper respiratory infections and recurrent sinusitis since childhood. He is also concerned about fertility, as he and his wife have been trying to conceive for 5 years unsuccessfully. Pulmonary examination shows crackles and wheezing throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a defect in which of the following molecular structures?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chronic cough, sinus pain, and nasal discharge. He has a history of frequent upper respiratory infections and recurrent sinusitis since childhood. He is also concerned about fertility, as he and his wife have been trying to conceive for 5 years unsuccessfully. Pulmonary examination shows crackles and wheezing throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a defect in which of the following molecular structures?
hint: The CT scan of the chest shows dextrocardia, a condition in which the heart's apex is located on the right side of the body.
learning_objective: Recognize primary ciliary dyskinesia, and recall its associated molecular defect.

answers.explanation_why: A defect in the IL-12 receptor causes IL-12 receptor deficiency, which leads to decreased Th1 cell function and thus increases the risk of developing disseminated mycobacterial, Salmonella species, and fungal infections. This defect would not explain this patient's infertility or dextrocardia.

A defect in the IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which causes recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, similar to this patient's history. However, SCID typically causes severe (and often fatal) infections within the first year of life unless the underlying defect is corrected with bone marrow transplantation, making this condition unlikely in this 31-year-old man. Additionally, this defect would not explain this patient's infertility or dextrocardia.

A defect in NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease, which manifests with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, similar to this patient's history. These infections are most often caused by catalase-positive organisms because neutrophils are unable to produce reactive oxygen species that attack these pathogens. However, chronic granulomatous disease does not cause infertility or dextrocardia.

The underlying cause of cystic fibrosis is a defective or deficient CFTR protein in the apical membrane of epithelial cells, which results in decreased secretion of chloride ions and water. This leads to hyperviscosity of fluid in the lungs that impairs mucociliary clearance and causes chronic sinusitis and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Cystic fibrosis also causes infertility (due to congenital absence of the vas deferens in men and abnormally thick cervical mucus in women). Though this patient has all of these features, cystic fibrosis does not cause dextrocardia.

A defect in axonemal dynein arms renders cilia immotile and is one cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). Impaired ciliary function reduces mucociliary clearance, resulting in bronchiectasis (due to recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, which are responsible for this patient's crackles and wheezing on examination) and chronic sinusitis. It also renders sperm immotile, which reduces fertility, and can cause dextrocardia (because cilia are responsible for the position of internal organs during embryological development). Other clinical features of PCD include chronic otitis media and conductive hearing loss. Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of PCD characterized by the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia can also be caused by defects in ciliary assembly proteins or radial spokes.

A defect in α-1 antitrypsin causes α-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which results in increased protease activity in the lungs and destruction of the pulmonary architecture. As a result, patients have an increased risk of developing recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, similar to this patient's history. However, this condition does not cause chronic sinusitis, infertility, or dextrocardia. Instead, it is associated with cirrhosis (due to aggregation of misfolded α-1 antitrypsin).

images.title: Dextrocardia in Kartagener syndrome
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)The base-to-apex cardiac axis is directed to the patient's right (dextrocardia). The right ventricle (RV) and left ventricle (LV) are reversed. This patient also presented with right to left reversal of the morphologic atria and abdominal organs (situs inversus; not shown).Dextrocardia with situs inversus is part of the triad of manifestations seen in Kartagener syndrome, which also includes chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.

question_text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-day history of poor feeding and lethargy. He was born at term and has had three episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 8 weeks. He is at the 30^th percentile for height and 20^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F) and blood pressure is 58/36 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white oral patches and confluent scaly erythematous skin lesions in the groin. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 41,300/mm^3 (92% segmented neutrophils and 8% lymphocytes) and a platelet count of 224,000/mm^3. Blood cultures at 20°C (68°F) grow catalase-positive yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-day history of poor feeding and lethargy. He was born at term and has had three episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 8 weeks. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F) and blood pressure is 58/36 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white oral patches and confluent scaly erythematous skin lesions in the groin. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 41,300/mm3 (92% segmented neutrophils and 8% lymphocytes) and a platelet count of 224,000/mm3. Blood cultures at 20°C (68°F) grow catalase-positive yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient has mucocutaneous candidiasis (e.g., white oral patches, diaper rash) and features of septic shock (e.g., fever, hypotension, tachycardia) due to disseminated Candida infection. In combination with delayed separation of the umbilical cord, these features suggest leukocyte adhesion deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: A defective CD40 ligand is the underlying mechanism of type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome, which typically manifests with recurrent infections during the first 2 years of life. However, neutropenia rather than neutrophilia is typically seen, and patients often show failure to thrive. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD1) is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in CD18 (beta-2 integrin), which prevents leukocyte migration to the site of infection. As a result, patients have recurrent mucocutaneous infections that can progress to sepsis and a characteristic absence of pus or neutrophils at the site of infection. Other features of the condition include poor wound healing with large skin ulcers, delayed separation of the umbilical cord due to omphalitis, and severe periodontitis/gingivitis. A very high neutrophil count (as high as 100,000/mm^3 during active infection) is seen because neutrophil activation and recruitment of neutrophils from the non-circulating pool occurs. However, neutrophils are unable to extravasate into tissues, causing pooling within the circulation.

LAD1 is diagnosed using flow cytometric measurement of surface molecules such as CD11b or CD18. The treatment for mild to moderate cases is mainly supportive, with early treatment of infections and prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole if needed, but severe cases require definitive therapy with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

A defect in the interleukin-2 receptor subunit gamma gene (IL2RG) is the most common mutation associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which can manifest soon after birth with recurrent episodes of otitis media, candidiasis, and sepsis. However, patients would also typically show failure to thrive and have a history of chronic diarrhea. A CBC, moreover, would reveal a low absolute lymphocyte count (< 1,000/mm^3). Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

A defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which may result in recurrent otitis media from infection with extracellular bacteria such as S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae. However, infants with B-cell defects such as XLA typically do not develop symptoms before 3–6 months because they generally retain passively acquired maternal antibodies up to this age. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected. Moreover, candidiasis is more commonly seen in defects involving T cells and granulocytes than in isolated primary defects of antibody production such as XLA.

images.title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

answers.explanation_why: Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which may manifest in infancy with candidiasis (since C. albicans is catalase-positive) and neutrophilia during episodes of infection. However, these infections tend to remain localized, and sepsis is not as common as in other primary immune deficiency syndromes. Other pathognomonic features of CGD include GI obstruction and urinary retention caused by granulomas. Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

Defective microtubules due to a loss of function of the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the underlying pathophysiology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which can result in systemic candidiasis. However, patients with CHS would have neutropenia, not neutrophilia. Features such as oculocutaneous albinism and/or ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus, nystagmus) would also be present. Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

A defectively organized actin cytoskeleton due to a mutation in the WAS gene is the underlying cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can manifest in infancy with recurrent otitis media as well as scaly erythematous lesions in the diaper area due to atopic dermatitis. However, the absence of thrombocytopenia on a CBC essentially rules out WAS. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
hint: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve lies directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe. If the artery is ligated during surgery, it may be damaged.
learning_objective: Recall the anatomy and function of the superior laryngeal nerve.

answers.explanation_why: Voice pitch limitation is caused by damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), which occurs in up to 30% of thyroid dissections. The external branch of the SLN innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for lengthening, thinning, and stiffening the vocal cords and increases the pitch of phonation. The cricothyroid muscle is the only tensor of the vocal cord, and its denervation results in an inability to increase the pitch of the voice or produce explosive sounds as well as easy voice fatigability.

images.title: Thyroid gland and surrounding structures
images.description: The thyroid gland is located in front of the trachea in the lower neck and consists of two lobes connected by an isthmus. A third pyramidal lobe extending from the isthmus is present in 50% of patients. This third lobe is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.The parathyroid glands are located posterior to the thyroid gland; they may vary in number and location. The recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN) branch off from the vagus nerve; the left RLN loops under the aortic arch, and the right RLN passes beneath the subclavian artery. Both RLNs are vulnerable to injury during thyroid surgery as they ascend to the larynx behind the thyroid gland. Unilateral RLN injury may result in hoarseness, and bilateral RLN injury may cause dyspnea and stridor.

answers.explanation_why: Perioral paresthesia after thyroid surgery is a result of hypocalcemia secondary to hypoparathyroidism, usually due to unintentional removal of one or several of the parathyroid glands. Hypoparathyroidism is the most frequent complication of total or near-total thyroidectomy. However, the superior parathyroid glands are most commonly found inferior to the superior thyroid artery and the external branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve and are thus less likely to be injured in this patient.

Ineffective cough could result from unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury. This causes the affected vocal fold to rest in the paramedian or lateralized position. Coughing, which requires transient tight glottic closure, may then become ineffective. While unilateral RLN injury can occur during thyroid surgery, the nerve is unlikely to be damaged during ligation of the superior thyroid artery. Instead, the RLN is at risk during preparation of the inferior pole of the thyroid gland, as it runs close to the inferior thyroid artery.

Weakness of shoulder shrug can occur due to spinal accessory nerve injury (cranial nerve XI). The spinal accessory nerve runs through the posterior triangle of the neck and supplies the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for shoulder shrugging. However, injury to the spinal accessory nerve would not be expected during a hemithyroidectomy. The most common causes of spinal accessory nerve injury include biopsy of the cervical lymph nodes in the posterior triangle and radical neck dissection.

Difficulty swallowing and increased risk of aspiration can occur in bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle. It also carries sensory input from the larynx below the vocal cords. The RLN can be injured during thyroid surgery because it passes close to the inferior thyroid artery on its ascent to the larynx. Unilateral damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is unlikely to cause difficulty swallowing.

Shortness of breath may be caused by bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which can be injured during thyroid surgery because it passes lateral to the thyroid gland, adjacent to the inferior thyroid artery, on its ascent to the larynx. The RLN innervates the posterior cricoarytenoids, which are responsible for vocal cord abduction. In cases of bilateral RLN injury, the vocal cords are unable to abduct, which restricts air entry into the trachea and can lead to shortness of breath. Unilateral damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is unlikely to cause shortness of breath.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in the mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year in high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of the oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in the mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year in high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of the oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The image shows two ovoid erosions with regular margins and surrounding erythema on the labial mucosa.
learning_objective: Recognize aphthous stomatitis.

answers.explanation_why: A common initial manifestation of pemphigus vulgaris is painful oral blisters that eventually ulcerate. Most patients also develop blisters on other body parts, but recurrent episodes of pemphigus vulgaris can occur without any associated cutaneous lesions (mucosal pemphigus vulgaris). However, the oral ulcers of pemphigus vulgaris typically have irregular margins, unlike the well-defined ovoid lesions seen here. Moreover, pemphigus vulgaris most commonly develops in older patients (40–60 years of age), and the lesions typically do not resolve without treatment.

images.title: Pemphigus vulgaris
images.description: Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

answers.explanation_why: Oral candidiasis typically manifests as painless, cream-white lesions of the tongue, buccal mucosa, or palate and occurs in individuals with risk factors such as immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection), antibiotic therapy, corticosteroid use, xerostomia, and diabetes mellitus. Painful erosions of the labial mucosa in an otherwise healthy adolescent suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

answers.explanation_why: Herpangina typically affects children and adolescents and can manifest as painful oral erosions surrounded by an erythematous halo, which is seen here. However, the lesions typically occur on the palate and posterior pharyngeal wall, not the labial mucosa. Moreover, patients with herpangina are typically febrile and present with throat pain. Following an episode of herpangina, individuals become immune to the infecting group A coxsackievirus strain but can develop a recurrent attack of herpangina as a result of infection by a different virus strain.

images.title: Herpangina
images.description: Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.

answers.explanation_why: Herpes of the lips or oral mucosa manifests with painful blisters that eventually ulcerate. Following the primary infection, herpes stomatitis can recur during periods of stress, which is seen here. However, the lesions of recurrent herpes stomatitis typically occur on keratinized parts of the mouth and oral cavity, such as attached gingiva, the hard palate, and the vermillion border of the lip. The location of this patient's lesions on nonkeratinized areas such as the labial mucosa suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Herpes labialis
images.description: Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

answers.explanation_why: Aphthous stomatitis is a common condition that manifests as painful, oral mucosal ulcers with regular margins, a yellow fibrinous base, and a surrounding erythematous halo. The lesions occur in parts of the oral cavity with nonkeratinized mucosa, such as the buccal and labial mucosae, the floor of the mouth, and the ventral surface of the tongue. The lesions typically resolve without treatment within 10–14 days but can recur during periods of acute stress.

Oral leukoplakia manifests as a white adherent plaque on the oral mucosa. It is a slowly growing, painless premalignant lesion and is usually seen in middle-aged or older patients with a history of tobacco use disorder.

images.title: Oral leukoplakia
images.description: Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

images.title: Aphthous ulcers
images.description: Two ulcers covered by a white membrane and surrounded by a red halo are visible on the oral mucosa.Aphthous ulcers typically begin as erythematous macules.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician with a lump on her throat that has steadily increased in size over the past 5 months. She does not have difficulties swallowing, dyspnea, or changes in voice. Examination shows a 3-cm, hard swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Thyroid functions tests are within the reference range. Ultrasound of the neck shows an irregular, hypoechogenic mass in the left lobe of the thyroid. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is inconclusive. The surgeon and patient agree that the most appropriate next step is a diagnostic lobectomy and isthmectomy. Surgery shows a 3.5-cm gray tan thyroid tumor with invasion of surrounding blood vessels, including the veins. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of the mass?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician with a lump on her throat that has steadily increased in size over the past 5 months. She does not have difficulties swallowing, dyspnea, or changes in voice. Examination shows a 3-cm, hard swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Thyroid functions tests are within the reference range. Ultrasound of the neck shows an irregular, hypoechogenic mass in the left lobe of the thyroid. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is inconclusive. The surgeon and patient agree that the most appropriate next step is a diagnostic lobectomy and isthmectomy. Surgery shows a 3.5-cm gray tan thyroid tumor with invasion of surrounding blood vessels, including the veins. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of the mass?
hint: Invasion of surrounding vascular structures by the tumor suggests follicular thyroid carcinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize follicular thyroid carcinoma, and recall its histopathological features.

answers.explanation_why: Undifferentiated giant cells are characteristic of anaplastic thyroid cancer. This type of tumor, while it may demonstrate vascular invasion, is a rare type of thyroid cancer (1–2% of cases) and would be less likely in a patient younger than 60 years of age. Additionally, anaplastic thyroid cancer would most likely manifest as a rapidly growing thyroid mass with neck pain, dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness.

Capsular and blood vessel invasion and uniform follicles are characteristic histopathologic findings of follicular thyroid cancer, the second most common type of thyroid cancer after papillary thyroid cancer. Follicular thyroid cancer is characterized by hematogenous spread (most commonly to the lungs and bones) and lymph node involvement is rare.

Further treatment in this patient will likely involve total thyroidectomy, possibly followed by radioiodine therapy. Afterward, thyroid hormone replacement therapy (i.e., levothyroxine) in the highest possible dose (according to the patient's tolerance) will be initiated to suppress TSH and thus reduce the risk of stimulating remaining malignant tissue.

images.title: Follicular thyroid carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)A partly encapsulated (capsule marked by hatched blue overlay) thyroid lesion comprised of follicles of varying size and shape (blue overlay) can be seen. Focally, this lesion displays a capsular invasion (yellow overlay), which is diagnostic of follicular thyroid carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Psammoma bodies suggest papillary thyroid cancer. Although papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid malignancy, and this patient does belong to the peak incidence age group (30–50 years), it does not cause invasion of surrounding vascular structures.

images.title: Serous papillary cystadenoma of the ovary with Psammoma bodies
images.description: Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

answers.explanation_why: Infiltration of atypical lymphoid tissue in the thyroid suggests a thyroid lymphoma (an unusual manifestation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma). Thyroid lymphoma is rather rare (∼ 2% of malignant thyroid tumors) and usually arises in patients with preexisting Hashimoto thyroiditis (clinically characterized by fatigue, constipation, weight gain, and other hypothyroidism-related features). Additionally, thyroid lymphoma would most likely manifest as a rapidly growing thyroid mass with dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness.

Orphan Annie eyes nuclei (large nuclei with a cleared-out appearance in the center and chromatin in the periphery) suggest papillary thyroid cancer. Although papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid malignancy, and this patient does belong to the peak incidence age group (30–50 years), it typically does not cause invasion of surrounding vascular structures.

images.title: Nuclear grooves and Orphan-Annie eyes in papillary thyroid carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a thyroid tumor tissue sample (H&E stain; high magnification)Cells arranged in a papillary architecture are visible (examples indicated by green overlay). Some cell nuclei appear invaginated (nuclear grooves), giving them a coffee-bean appearance (examples indicated by white lines). The nuclei in general show pale staining centrally and powdery chromatin in the periphery (Orphan Annie-eye nuclei; example highlighted by red overlay).These nuclear changes in a thyroid tumor with papillary architecture confirm the diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician with a 4-day history of sore throat and mild fever. He is on the varsity soccer team at his high school, but has been unable to go to practice for the last few days because he has been very tired and is easily exhausted. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He appears weak and lethargic. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg. Examination shows enlarged, erythematous, and exudative tonsils; posterior cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL and leukocyte count is 11,200/mm^3with 48% lymphocytes. A heterophile antibody test is positive. In addition to supportive therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician with a 4-day history of sore throat and mild fever. He is on the varsity soccer team at his high school, but has been unable to go to practice for the last few days because he has been very tired and is easily exhausted. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He appears weak and lethargic. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg. Examination shows enlarged, erythematous, and exudative tonsils; posterior cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL and leukocyte count is 11,200/mm3with 48% lymphocytes. A heterophile antibody test is positive. In addition to supportive therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Fever, fatigue, exudative tonsillitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis, and a positive heterophile antibody test in an adolescent indicate infectious mononucleosis (IM).
learning_objective: Recognize infectious mononucleosis, and choose the most appropriate non-pharmacological management.

answers.content: Write a medical note that excuses the patient from soccer practice
answers.explanation_why: A common finding in patients with IM is splenomegaly, which increases the risk of splenic rupture. Although this patient's abdominal examination shows no abnormalities, the spleen may still be or become enlarged. Since splenic rupture is most likely to occur 2–21 days after symptom onset, patients should avoid strenuous physical activity (e.g., soccer) for at least 3 weeks after initial symptoms develop and avoid contact sports (e.g., football, wrestling) for at least 4 weeks. Treatment of IM is mainly symptomatic and involves antipyretic and analgesic therapy (e.g., acetaminophen).

answers.content: Recommend avoiding public places and social gatherings
answers.explanation_why: IM spreads via bodily fluids such as saliva. Unless patients have immediate contact with other individuals such as from kissing or sharing objects that have been contaminated with another person's bodily fluids (e.g., toothbrush, drinking glass), infection is unlikely. A recommendation to avoid public places and gatherings is therefore not indicated.

Amoxicillin is indicated for bacterial tonsillitis and pharyngitis, both of which can present with fever, sore throat, enlarged tonsils with exudates, and/or cervical lymphadenopathy. However, lymphocytosis and a positive heterophile antibody test indicate EBV infection. Patients with EBV infection are often mistakenly treated with aminopenicillins because IM presents similarly to streptococcal pharyngitis and tonsilitis and these conditions are also typically diagnosed clinically. Additionally, rapid GAS antigen detection tests (rapid strep tests) can be positive in IM due to asymptomatic colonization of the pharynx with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. Administering aminopenicillin to patients with IM should be avoided to prevent the potential complication of a pruritic, macular erythematous rash developing 5–9 days later.

Steroids are not recommended for routine use in IM treatment. They may be considered in complicated disease courses, e.g. in patients with severe airway obstruction, fulminant liver failure, or autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, none of which are seen here.

Acyclovir is an antiviral agent used to treat infections with herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella zoster virus (VZV). It is not indicated for infections with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV; the cause of infectious mononucleosis), despite also belonging to the human herpesvirus family. HSV and VZV infections are commonly associated with a characteristic vesicular eruptions (e.g., herpetic gingivostomatitis, chickenpox, respectively) but not IM.

Patients with infectious mononucleosis may also present with a rash. However, the rash is usually maculopapular and most commonly occurs following antibiotic treatment with aminopenicillins (e.g., ampicillin, amoxicillin).

answers.content: Measure serum anti-viral capsid antigen antibody concentration
answers.explanation_why:
Antiviral capsid antigen antibodies (anti-VCA) are used in the diagnosis of IM. However, testing for anti-VCA is only indicated if IM is suspected but the heterophile agglutination test is negative. Considering that the heterophile antibody test has a specificity of nearly 100% for EBV infection, no further testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

In acute infection, both anti-VCA IgM and anti-VCA IgG can usually be found. The finding of IgG VCA antibodies in the absence of IgM VCA antibodies suggests past infection.

Foscarnet is an antiviral agent used in the treatment of cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus infections. While the majority of mononucleosis syndromes are caused by Epstein-Barr virus, infection with CMV accounts for ∼ 7% of cases. However, in CMV mononucleosis, symptoms are often milder, pharyngitis/tonsillitis are typically absent, and the heterophile antibody test is negative.

question_text:
A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 12 days. He was prescribed amoxicillin at another clinic and now has a diffuse rash all over his body. He was treated for gonorrhea one year ago. He has multiple sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears lethargic and thin. His BMI is 19 kg/m^2. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 94/min, blood pressure 106/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over his extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14 g/dL

Leukocyte count
13,200/mm^3

Platelet count
160,000/mm^3

Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 12 days. He was prescribed amoxicillin at another clinic and now has a diffuse rash all over his body. He was treated for gonorrhea one year ago. He has multiple sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears lethargic and thin. His BMI is 19 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 94/min, blood pressure 106/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over his extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14 g/dL Leukocyte count 13,200/mm3 Platelet count 160,000/mm3 Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm this patient's condition?
hint: A morbilliform rash appearing after the administration of an aminopenicillin for a sore throat is typical for this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize infectious mononucleosis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: A throat swab culture is indicated for streptococcal pharyngitis. Although the symptoms of fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy may suggest pharyngitis due to Streptococcus, the maculopapular rash, splenomegaly, and lack of improvement with antibiotics make this diagnosis unlikely.

The presence of anti-CMV IgM would indicate an acute cytomegalovirus infection, which can also present with fever, fatigue, and a sore throat. Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are possible, but rare. This constellation of symptoms is more likely the result of another diagnosis, meaning a different step is indicated at this time. However, if that step shows negative results, measuring serum anti-CMV IgM levels would be indicated.

The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a technique used for the screening of several diseases, including HIV. This patient has some signs of primary HIV infection (fever, sore throat, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, rash) and risk factors for HIV transmission (multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use), but splenomegaly, tonsillar exudates, and lack of diarrhea make another diagnosis more likely.

Fever, exudative tonsillitis, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis are all indicative of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is caused by an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. Although IM itself does not usually cause a rash, a morbilliform rash commonly occurs in patients with this condition who are mistakenly administered an aminopenicillin with the intent of treating a bacterial infection (e.g., streptococcal pharyngitis, which also manifests with fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy). The diagnosis of IM is typically clinical but EBV serology is the most reliable laboratory study. Anti-VCA IgM antibodies alone are sufficient to diagnose acute infection. A positive heterophile agglutination test (monospot test) can support the diagnosis but carries a high risk of false positive and false negative results and is therefore not the test of choice.

Flow cytometry is a technique employed for evaluation of patients with lymphocytosis, including those suspected of leukemia or lymphoma. Although blood cancers often present with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and low body weight (e.g., BMI of 19), the sudden onset of fever, sore throat, tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudates in this patient indicates an active infection. Additionally, a morbilliform rash (following amoxicillin intake) would not be expected.

question_text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after waking up with facial swelling and with difficulties speaking and swallowing. She states that she does not have allergies or recent insect bites. She has a 2-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with medication. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. On physical examination, she appears uncomfortable, with notable swelling of the lips and tongue. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum C4 levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after waking up with facial swelling and with difficulties speaking and swallowing. She states that she does not have allergies or recent insect bites. She has a 2-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with medication. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. On physical examination, she appears uncomfortable, with notable swelling of the lips and tongue. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum C4 levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
hint: A patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension would most likely be on angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor) therapy.
learning_objective: Recognize ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema, and recall the mechanism involving bradykinin.

answers.explanation_why: Adverse cutaneous drug reactions that are caused by type 2 hypersensitivity include drug-induced pemphigus and purpura caused by drug-induced immune thrombocytopenia. Neither of these conditions is associated with facial swelling. Additionally, drug-induced pemphigus can occur with the use of antihypertensive medications but the onset of symptoms would typically occur within a few weeks of initiating therapy. This patient appears to have been on antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications for quite some time.

T-cell mediated hypersensitivity is seen in patients with allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) and DRESS, both of which can result in swelling of the face (pseudoangioedema), and, occasionally, dyspnea due to upper airway obstruction. However, the affected region in acute ACD would be pruritic/painful and eczematous. Patients with DRESS, on the other hand, would typically have an erythematous maculopapular rash, systemic features such as fever and lymphadenopathy, as well as a history of treatment with antiepileptics or sulfonamide drugs initiated within the past 2 months. Moreover, the facial edema in both of these conditions typically develops over a few days unlike the hyperacute onset of symptoms in this patient.

IgE-mediated histamine release (type 1 hypersensitivity reaction) can cause angioedema and dyspnea. However, patients also typically have pruritus and/or hives and a history of exposure to an anaphylactic antigen (e.g., insect venom, food, penicillin injection) minutes to hours before the onset of symptoms.

Although antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications may rarely cause type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, these generally occur shortly after beginning treatment with the first few doses, rather than with long-term use.

An autosomal-dominant defect in the gene that encodes C1 esterase inhibitor is responsible for hereditary angioedema (HAE), which may result in swelling of the face and lips with consequent dyspnea. The use of ACE inhibitors can also act as a trigger for angioedema in patients with HAE. However, the onset of symptoms in HAE usually occurs during childhood or adolescence and C4 levels are typically decreased.

Anaphylactoid reactions can cause angioedema and dyspnea. However, patients with an anaphylactoid reaction would also have pruritus and/or hives as well as a history of exposure to an anaphylactoid antigen (e.g., intravenous radiocontrast, aspirin, vancomycin, opiates) minutes to hours before the onset of symptoms.

Serum sickness, which is caused by immune-complex deposition (type 3 hypersensitivity reaction), can occasionally result in facial swelling but patients would also have fever, arthralgia, as well as decreased C4 levels (due to activation of the classical complement pathway by immune complexes). Also, serum sickness typically occurs a few days after initiating therapy with bupropion, antiserum, or IVIG, monoclonal antibodies such as rituximab or infliximab, or certain antibiotics (e.g., cefaclor, cefprozil, penicillin, minocycline). There is no history of the patient having taken any of these drugs.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme is involved in the degradation of bradykinin. Therapy with ACE inhibitors increases bradykinin serum levels and can cause angioedema due to vasodilation and increased vascular permeability. Unlike angioedema due to mast cell degranulation, bradykinin-mediated angioedema does not cause pruritus or hives. Normal C4 levels in bradykinin-mediated angioedema differentiate this condition from C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency, in which C4 levels are decreased. While ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema typically occurs within the first few weeks of treatment initiation, this condition can manifest at any time during the course of treatment, even after years of uncomplicated use. Acquired angioedema is most commonly caused by ACE inhibitors and usually resolves 2–3 weeks after they have been discontinued.

images.title: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema
images.description: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema is triggered by increased levels of the proinflammatory vasodilator bradykinin, which can build up via several different mechanisms.Top left: The rare hereditary angioedema (HAE) type III (normal levels and function of C1-INH) can be caused by several different gene mutations; illustrated here is a mutation resulting in increased Factor XII activity, which leads to increased bradykinin generation.Center left: In HAE type I (low levels of normal C1-INH), HAE type II (normal or high levels of dysfunctional C1-INHI), and acquired angioedema (acquired low levels of C1-INH), the normal inhibitory function of C1-INH on the kallikrein-kinin system is reduced, resulting in increased bradykinin generation.Bottom left: In ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema, reduced bradykinin breakdown due to inhibition of ACE results in the build-up of bradykinin.C1-INH: C1 inhibitor; ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme; HMWK: high-molecular-weight kininogen; HAE: hereditary angioedema

question_text: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a dry, barking cough for 2 days that worsens at night. She has also had mild rhinorrhea and fever. Her older brother has asthma and had a cold last week. Immunizations are up-to-date. She appears to be in mild distress. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 99/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows clear rhinorrhea and a dry, hoarse cough. There is mild inspiratory stridor upon agitation that resolves with rest. The skin and oral mucosa appear normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?
content_preview: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a dry, barking cough for 2 days that worsens at night. She has also had mild rhinorrhea and fever. Her older brother has asthma and had a cold last week. Immunizations are up-to-date. She appears to be in mild distress. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 99/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows clear rhinorrhea and a dry, hoarse cough. There is mild inspiratory stridor upon agitation that resolves with rest. The skin and oral mucosa appear normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?
hint: This patient has a history of a dry barking cough that worsens at night along with fever and inspiratory stridor, indicating croup.
learning_objective: Recognize mild croup, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Racemic epinephrine is indicated for moderate-to-severe croup (i.e., inspiratory stridor at rest, subcostal retractions) in which there are concerns that the airways may be compromised. However, this patient is alert and has an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air, indicating that she has mild croup.

Ceftriaxone is appropriate empirical treatment for epiglottitis, which manifests with fever and may cause inspiratory stridor. However, fever in epiglottitis is typically higher and appears with additional features (e.g., sore throat, hoarse or muffled voice, drooling, difficulty swallowing) but not with barking cough. Furthermore, symptoms of epiglottitis usually progress over a span of hours rather than the 2 days seen here. Additionally, this patient's immunizations are up-to-date, which means infection with H. influenzae (the most common cause of epiglottitis) is unlikely. This patient has croup, a condition typically caused by viral pathogens, for which antibiotics are not indicated.

Emergency intubation is used only for severe respiratory distress with signs of impending respiratory failure and is not warranted since this patient's stridor resolves with rest, and she is alert and has an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. However, if her clinical condition were to deteriorate and the airway became compromised, emergency intubation would be a life-saving option.

Albuterol is a short-acting β_2 agonist used in the treatment of asthma to relieve bronchospasms of the lower airways. Although this patient has a family history and signs consistent with asthma (e.g., dry cough), a 2-day fever, inspiratory stridor, and rhinorrhea would not be expected. Beta agonists are not effective for croup, which is caused by subglottic edema rather than lower airway bronchospasms.

A chest x-ray, which is likely to show subglottic narrowing (steeple sign), may be considered in mild cases of suspected croup to rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., foreign body asthma, obstructive bronchitis, aspiration, pneumonia). However, croup is primarily a clinical diagnosis and this patient has mild respiratory distress that requires another urgent step in management.

This patient is alert and has stridor that resolves with rest, an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air, and no subcostal retractions, all of which indicate mild croup. Because croup is commonly caused by viruses (e.g., parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus), symptomatic relief is sufficient for mild cases. This includes keeping the patient calm and minimizing distress. In addition, all patients with croup should be treated with (oral or parenteral) dexamethasone, which reduces airway swelling within hours. Mild croup can quickly progress to moderate or severe croup, which can compromise the airway and manifest with stridor and dyspnea at rest, subcostal retractions, and cyanosis. Racemic epinephrine is the treatment of choice for severe croup.

Humidified air, both in the hospital and as a home remedy (e.g., steam inhalation), has been used to treat croup, but there is no evidence that it is effective.

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. It is used in hypercapnic respiratory failure caused by lower airway disease and is commonly attempted before intubating a patient. This child is active, has a saturation of 98%, and has inspiratory stridor, suggesting an upper airway pathology. Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation would not be a suitable treatment modality.

question_text:
A 66-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a severely painful right ear with discharge for 10 days. The ear pain was acute in onset and is constant. She has been using over-the-counter eardrops but her symptoms have continued to worsen. Her only medication is insulin, which she uses inconsistently. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination of the right ear shows a swollen pinna and lobule and malodorous purulent discharge; the ear is tender to touch. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. There is mild hearing loss of the right ear. Otoscopic examination shows a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL

Hemoglobin A_1c

12.2%

Leukocyte count
18,300/mm^3

 Segmented neutrophils
76%

 Eosinophils
1%

 Lymphocytes
20%

 Monocytes
3%

Serum

 Glucose
212 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL

A CT scan of the head shows severe thickening and enhancing of the soft tissue of the external auditory canal with patchy destruction of the temporal bone. Culture results of the ear drainage are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a severely painful right ear with discharge for 10 days. The ear pain was acute in onset and is constant. She has been using over-the-counter eardrops but her symptoms have continued to worsen. Her only medication is insulin, which she uses inconsistently. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination of the right ear shows a swollen pinna and lobule and malodorous purulent discharge; the ear is tender to touch. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. There is mild hearing loss of the right ear. Otoscopic examination shows a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.3 g/dL Hemoglobin A1c 12.2% Leukocyte count 18,300/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 76% Eosinophils 1% Lymphocytes 20% Monocytes 3% Serum Glucose 212 mg/dL Creatinine 1.7 mg/dL A CT scan of the head shows severe thickening and enhancing of the soft tissue of the external auditory canal with patchy destruction of the temporal bone. Culture results of the ear drainage are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: Severe ear pain, otorrhea, otoscopic findings of granulation tissue, and ear canal edema as well as evidence of bone destruction on CT scan suggest malignant otitis externa, which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for malignant otitis externa.

answers.explanation_why: Metronidazole is a drug with both antibacterial and antiprotozoal activity, which offers coverage against anaerobic bacteria. Although anaerobes may cause chronic suppurative otitis media, they are not involved in malignant otitis externa. While chronic suppurative otitis media may also manifest with ear discharge and hearing loss, this condition does not manifest with ear pain or swelling of the external auditory canal.

images.title: Chronic suppurative otitis media
images.description: Otoscopic image of the middle earThe tympanic membrane is completely perforated and the tympanic cavity can be seen. The mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity is edematous and covered by clear secretions.These findings are diagnostic of chronic suppurative otitis media, which can develop from acute otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation.

answers.explanation_why: Amoxicillin-clavulanate is used as first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumoniae, the main cause of AOM. While AOM can also manifest with acute onset of ear pain, fever, and mastoiditis, this patient lacks a red and bulging tympanic membrane. In addition, AOM typically affects infants and young children between 6–24 months of age. Malignant otitis externa is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, for which amoxicillin-clavulanate is not effective.

Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that is, e.g., used to treat acute otitis media (AOM) in patients with severe allergies to penicillin. While AOM may also manifest with acute onset of ear pain, fever, and mastoiditis, this patient, however, lacks a red and bulging tympanic membrane. Also, a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue suggests an external ear infection and AOM is much more common in infants and young children between 6–24 months of age.

images.title: Acute otitis media
images.description: Otoscopic image of the tympanic membraneThere is bulging and erythema of the tympanic membrane, which appears dull and thickened. The light reflex is visible in the posterior upper quadrant (should normally appear in the anterior lower quadrant) and appears widened and heterogeneous due to bulging of the membrane.

answers.explanation_why: Clotrimazole eardrops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which may also manifest with ear pain, scaling, discharge, and mild hearing impairment, and is a common complication in patients with diabetes due to immunodeficiency. However, the condition is mainly characterized by excessive ear itching, which this patient lacks. Moreover, findings such as fungal filaments and spores (which would resemble mold on spoiled food) are usually seen upon otoscopy.

images.title: Otomycosis
images.description: Otoscopy of the left earThe external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane show multiple small white to yellowish appearance of fungal debris and fruiting bodies. They are partly confluent and involve the entire visible area of the auditory canal. Hyphae and fungal spores are visible at the top and bottom of the meatus.These findings are usually caused by Aspergillus spp. or Candida spp. and are typical for otitis externa mycotica.

answers.explanation_why: Eardrops containing ciprofloxacin and hydrocortisone have potent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and are the first-line treatment for uncomplicated otitis externa. In this patient, however, the infection has already spread to the mastoid bone, indicating a severe and complicated course that would not be treated adequately with topical drugs.

images.title: Otitis externa
images.description: There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.These findings are consistent with otitis externa.

answers.explanation_why: The initial empiric therapy for malignant otitis externa should include high-dose IV ciprofloxacin, which is usually combined with another antipseudomonal agent from a different class (e.g., cefepime, ceftazidime, or piperacillin/tazobactam). Malignant otitis externa most frequently occurs in older patients with poorly controlled diabetes or individuals with immunosuppression. Complications include facial nerve palsy and osteomyelitis of the skull base, possibly leading to extradural abscesses, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, and paralysis of other cranial nerves. Surgical debridement is indicated for abscess drainage and removal of bony sequestrum.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the pharmacotherapy of choice for cutaneous nocardiosis, which typically occurs in older or immunocompromised patients (e.g., individuals with diabetes). Cutaneous nocardiosis may affect the facial skin and manifests with signs of cellulitis (pain, swelling, erythema, warmth), ulceration, and local lymphadenopathy. However, nocardiosis is a rare infection that typically affects the lungs (pulmonary nocardiosis). Malignant otitis externa is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, for which TMP-SMX is not effective.

question_text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a lump on her neck. The lump is mildly painful. She appears healthy. Examination shows a swelling on the left side of her neck that moves on swallowing. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her TSH is 3.6 μU/mL. Ultrasound shows a 0.4-cm (0.16-in)  hypoechoic mass in the left thyroid lobe. Fine-needle aspiration of the mass shows neoplastic follicular cells. Molecular analysis of the aspirate shows a mutation in the RAS gene. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a lump on her neck. The lump is mildly painful. She appears healthy. Examination shows a swelling on the left side of her neck that moves on swallowing. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her TSH is 3.6 μU/mL. Ultrasound shows a 0.4-cm (0.16-in) hypoechoic mass in the left thyroid lobe. Fine-needle aspiration of the mass shows neoplastic follicular cells. Molecular analysis of the aspirate shows a mutation in the RAS gene. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a hypoechoic thyroid nodule, the combination of neoplastic follicular cells on fine-needle aspiration (FNA) and a mutation in the RAS gene on molecular analysis should raise suspicion for follicular thyroid carcinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize follicular thyroid carcinoma, and choose the most appropriate surgical management.

answers.explanation_why: Chemotherapy drugs such as doxorubicin and lenvatinib are approved for thyroid cancers that are poorly differentiated, recurrent, or refractory to other standard treatments. Because this patient's FNA findings are concerning for well-differentiated thyroid cancer, she should receive standard first-line management.

Watchful waiting is not appropriate in a patient with an FNA that is concerning for well-differentiated thyroid cancer. Treatment delays may lead to cancer growth and invasion into the surrounding structures. This patient, therefore, requires immediate management.

Thyroid lobectomy (hemithyroidectomy) is the preferred treatment for patients with well-differentiated intrathyroidal cancers < 1 cm without nodal or distant metastasis or high-risk features (patient age > 45 years, family history of cancer, and history of head or neck radiation). In these patients, hemithyroidectomy allows for definitive diagnosis (via histological analysis showing invasion of the basement membrane) and definitive management with a high probability of cure. Preservation of the contralateral lobe decreases the need for thyroid hormone replacement therapy and mitigates surgical risks associated with thyroidectomy (e.g., hypoparathyroidism).

In patients with intrathyroidal tumors > 4 cm, extrathyroidal spread, metastasis, or high-risk features, hemithyroidectomy is contraindicated and total thyroidectomy should be performed.

External beam radiation is used in residual or unresectable thyroid cancers with invasion into the adjacent structures (e.g., esophagus, trachea, great vessels). Well-differentiated thyroid cancers are generally not treated with external beam radiation because it is not as effective as radioiodine therapy and does not target thyroid tissue as selectively, posing a risk to nearby structures in the head and neck. Because this patient has no evidence of locally advanced disease and has not yet received a definitive diagnosis, external beam radiation is not indicated.

In TSH suppression therapy, synthetic T_4 hormone (levothyroxine) is used to decrease TSH release from the pituitary via a negative feedback loop. TSH suppression reduces stimulation of malignant thyroid tissue and therefore decreases the probability of cancer growth. After initial surgical management, patients with follicular thyroid cancer may require thyroid hormone replacement therapy to prevent hypothyroidism and to minimize the risk of TSH stimulation of any residual tumor cells. However, thyroid hormone therapy is not used as initial therapy in patients with well-differentiated thyroid cancer.

Radioiodine therapy is an effective treatment option for well-differentiated thyroid cancers, as the malignant cells take up iodine, resulting in ablation. However, radioiodine therapy is an adjuvant treatment and is not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient. Radioablative therapy may be used later if there is reason to suspect remaining thyroid tissue.

Total thyroidectomy is an appropriate initial treatment option for patients with an intrathyroidal tumor > 1 cm, a tumor with extrathyroidal extension, and/or metastasis, or if the patient has high-risk features (age > 45 years, history of head or neck radiation, family history of cancer). While a total thyroidectomy would offer definitive management and is potentially curative for this patient, another treatment is preferred in this patient with a small (< 1 cm) intrathyroidal tumor.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours at a time and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. She has no history of serious medical conditions. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F) pulse is 76/min respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. Motor strength is 5/5 in all extremities, and sensory examination shows no abnormalities. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing are normal bilaterally. Weber test shows lateralization to the left ear. The Rinne test is positive bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours at a time and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. She has no history of serious medical conditions. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F) pulse is 76/min respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. Motor strength is 5/5 in all extremities, and sensory examination shows no abnormalities. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing are normal bilaterally. Weber test shows lateralization to the left ear. The Rinne test is positive bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The triad of vertigo, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss associated with ear fullness is classic for Meniere disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Meniere disease, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Dislodged otoliths can cause the severe vertigo attacks seen in benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). When otoliths become displaced into one of the semicircular ducts, they can disrupt the endolymph and thus lead to stimulation of the hair cells on the cupula. This stimulation sends signals to the brain that suggest motion even if the patient is not moving, thus triggering the sensation of vertigo. Although this patient has vertigo, she also has cochlear symptoms (tinnitus and hearing loss), which are typically absent in BPPV. Additionally, contrary to this patient's presentation, vertigo in BPPV lasts only for a few seconds and is triggered by movement.

images.title: Anatomy of the inner ear
images.description: The inner ear consists of a bony labyrinth with a membranous labyrinth inside it, separated by a space containing perilymph fluid. It contains the cochlea and vestibular system. The cochlea (on the right) is responsible for the conversion of sound waves into neuronal signals, which are transmitted via the cochlear nerve (depicted by a cartoon DJ). The vestibular system (on the left) consists of three semicircular canals, the saccule, and the utricle. Semicircular canals detect angular acceleration in three planes: the superior or anterior semicircular canal in the sagittal plane, the posterior semicircular canal in the coronal plane, and the lateral or horizontal semicircular canal in the transverse plane. The saccule and utricle contain cells that detect linear motion in the vertical and horizontal planes, respectively. The neuronal signals from the semicircular canals are transmitted via the vestibular nerve (depicted by a dancing cartoon).

answers.explanation_why: Plaques of demyelination are a typical MRI finding in multiple sclerosis. Some patients may present with vertigo (in the case of cerebellar or brainstem involvement), but hearing loss and tinnitus are very rare symptoms. A common first manifestation of MS is impaired vision (due to retrobulbar neuritis), and as the disease progresses other neurological deficits, such as sensory or motor deficits, or fatigue typically appear.

answers.content: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes Wallenberg syndrome. Symptoms include vertigo and nystagmus, but not ear fullness, tinnitus, or hearing loss. In addition, patients with Wallenberg syndrome generally present with dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, none of which are present in this patient.

Reduced resorption of endolymph leads to the accumulation of fluid in the endolymphatic sac and causes Meniere disease.

If an audiometry was performed, it would typically show low-frequency hearing loss, which can be a helpful finding in differentiating Meniere disease from other conditions that manifest with hearing loss in other frequency ranges (e.g., acoustic neuroma).

A patient with a cerebellopontine angle tumor (e.g., acoustic neuroma) would also present with some of this patient's symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. In addition, the results of Weber and Rinne tests would be similar. However, acoustic neuromas grow slowly, and the CNS is capable of compensating the imbalances from the injured vestibular system, making severe vertigo attacks unlikely. Furthermore, an acoustic neuroma does not manifest with ear fullness.

answers.content: Obstruction of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Obstruction of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery could cause lateral pontine syndrome, which would cause vertigo, nystagmus, and hearing loss. However, it does not explain this patient's ear fullness and tinnitus. Additionally, the condition manifests with ataxia, hemiplegia or hemiparesis, and unilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, none of which this patient has.

question_text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of white lesions in his mouth for 4 days. He also has pain while chewing food. He was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma around 8 months ago. He is undergoing chemotherapy and is currently on his fourth cycle. He was treated for herpes labialis 4 months ago with acyclovir. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy is present. Oral examination shows white plaques on his tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off with gauze. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of white lesions in his mouth for 4 days. He also has pain while chewing food. He was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma around 8 months ago. He is undergoing chemotherapy and is currently on his fourth cycle. He was treated for herpes labialis 4 months ago with acyclovir. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy is present. Oral examination shows white plaques on his tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off with gauze. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: White plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off are suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Further common findings include pain when eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth. Candida albicans infections most commonly affect immunocompromised individuals, e.g., patients with hematologic malignancies.
learning_objective: Recognize oropharyngeal candidiasis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Systemic fluconazole therapy can be used to treat patients with moderate to severe oropharyngeal candidiasis. However, oral rather than intravenous fluconazole is recommended for these patients. Intravenous fluconazole therapy is usually reserved for patients with esophageal candidiasis who cannot tolerate oral therapy or patients with systemic candidiasis.

Although culture of the lesions can be performed to diagnose oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is only used in recurrent or refractory disease to determine possible resistances as results usually take time. This is the patient's first episode of oral thrush and there are no indicators of unusual or resistant Candida species.

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., troches, mucoadhesive buccal tablets, pastilles) is considered first-line for most patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis. Preferred topical agents include clotrimazole, miconazole, and nystatin. Oral fluconazole is also used, most commonly in patients with moderate to severe symptoms.

The diagnosis of oropharyngeal candidiasis is most often clinical. KOH test and/or tissue culture are usually reserved for patients with inconclusive clinical findings. HIV testing should be performed in patients with no identifiable risk factors for oropharyngeal candidiasis.

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

answers.explanation_why: A biopsy of the lesion would be indicated in the case of suspected oral leukoplakia, a precancerous lesion, in which malignancy should be ruled out. While the white lesions of leukoplakia resemble oropharyngeal candidiasis and are common in tobacco users, they are usually asymptomatic and cannot be scraped off.

images.title: Oral leukoplakia
images.description: Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Topical corticosteroids are used in the treatment of severe aphthous stomatitis, a disease that manifests with painful oral ulcers covered by a yellow fibrinous pseudomembrane. White plaques that can be scraped off are not typical of the disease, making oral candidiasis more likely.

images.title: Aphthous stomatitis
images.description: Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.
