question_text:
A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of nasal congestion and fatigue for 12 days. During this period, he has had a fever and severe pain around his cheeks. His nasal discharge was initially clear but it has turned yellowish over the past couple of days. He has no visual complaints. He has been taking an over-the-counter nasal decongestant and acetaminophen without much relief. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He underwent an appendectomy 23 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and enalapril. He appears tired. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows purulent discharge in the nose and pharynx and normal-appearing ears. The left maxillary sinus is tender to palpation. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL

Leukocyte count
10,800/mm^3

Platelet count
263,000/mm^3

ESR
22 mm/hr

Serum

 Glucose
112 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of nasal congestion and fatigue for 12 days. During this period, he has had a fever and severe pain around his cheeks. His nasal discharge was initially clear but it has turned yellowish over the past couple of days. He has no visual complaints. He has been taking an over-the-counter nasal decongestant and acetaminophen without much relief. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He underwent an appendectomy 23 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and enalapril. He appears tired. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows purulent discharge in the nose and pharynx and normal-appearing ears. The left maxillary sinus is tender to palpation. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14.6 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,800/mm3 Platelet count 263,000/mm3 ESR 22 mm/hr Serum Glucose 112 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's initial symptoms (watery nasal discharge, fever, headache, and facial pain) are consistent with acute viral rhinosinusitis (AVRS). AVRS usually resolves within 7–10 days; however, the development of mucopurulent discharge with a clinical course greater than 10 days is highly suggestive of bacterial superinfection.
learning_objective: Recognize acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, and choose the most appropriate antibiotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the sinuses would most likely show sinus opacity and air-fluid levels in a patient with bacterial sinusitis. However, x-rays of the sinuses are usually not recommended in acute sinusitis because the results do not help to differentiate between etiologies and rarely influence the choice of treatment.

Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used to treat and prevent severe fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, coccidioidomycosis, mucormycosis, and histoplasmosis. Fungal sinusitis (e.g., caused by Aspergillus species) is rare and usually only occurs in immunocompromised patients. Although diabetes mellitus is a risk factor, there is no indication that his diabetes is poorly controlled, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, fungal sinusitis due to Aspergillus is usually accompanied by asthma and other atopic manifestations. A different treatment is more appropriate at this time.

Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis can develop following AVRS and is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae. Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is a penicillin antibiotic combined with a β-lactamase inhibitor that is used to treat a number of bacterial infections, particularly respiratory tract infections. This antibiotic is considered the first-line treatment for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis and, therefore, initiation of amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is the most appropriate next step for this patient.

A third-generation cephalosporin (with or without clindamycin, doxycycline), a respiratory fluoroquinolone, or a macrolide can be used to treat patients with a penicillin allergy. In addition to antibiotic treatment, the patient should receive antipyretic and analgesic therapy and be advised to rest and drink sufficient amounts of fluid.

answers.content: CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan would most likely show soft tissue swelling, mucoperiosteal thickening, and air-fluid levels in a patient with bacterial sinusitis. However, a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses is not routinely performed in acute sinusitis. A CT scan may be performed if complications occur (e.g., osteomyelitis, orbital cellulitis) to rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., neoplasms), and preoperatively in patients with chronic sinusitis (e.g., before surgical debridement of necrotic tissue and/or removal of anatomical obstructions).

images.title: Opacified right paranasal sinuses
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (coronal plane) of a patient with acute sinusitisThe right maxillary sinus (green overlay) is completely opacified. Extensive soft tissue density material (red overlay) is also present in the ipsilateral nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus is nearly completely opacified.

answers.explanation_why: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections and urinary tract infections. However, this medication is considered a second-line antibiotic in the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis. Treatment with a second-line antibiotic (e.g., levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, cefuroxime, clindamycin) is indicated in patients who fail to respond to first-line therapy within 72 hours, have symptoms that persist more than two weeks after the initiation of therapy, or that may have been exposed to highly resistant organisms.

Reassurance and supportive treatment with antipyretics, analgesics, and nasal decongestants are usually sufficient in the treatment of patients with viral rhinosinusitis. However, because this patient has had symptoms for more than 10 days and a mucopurulent discharge suggestive of a bacterial infection, a different treatment is indicated.

question_text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and swelling of her right eye for 3 days. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had nasal congestion and a constant, mild headache. She did not visit a doctor and instead took over-the-counter naproxen and phenylephrine. Her nasal congestion has since improved, but the headache persists. She underwent a dental procedure for caries about 10 days ago. She does not recollect any recent insect bites or trauma. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill and reports occasional chills. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows proptosis of the right eye. Vision is impaired in the affected eye. Her right upper and lower eyelids are erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. Ocular movements cause severe pain. Her headache is worsened by leaning forward and improves when the patient is lying on her back. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and swelling of her right eye for 3 days. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had nasal congestion and a constant, mild headache. She did not visit a doctor and instead took over-the-counter naproxen and phenylephrine. Her nasal congestion has since improved, but the headache persists. She underwent a dental procedure for caries about 10 days ago. She does not recollect any recent insect bites or trauma. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill and reports occasional chills. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows proptosis of the right eye. Vision is impaired in the affected eye. Her right upper and lower eyelids are erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. Ocular movements cause severe pain. Her headache is worsened by leaning forward and improves when the patient is lying on her back. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: This girl has impaired vision (likely due to diplopia), proptosis, eyelid erythema and tenderness, and severe pain on ocular movement, which is indicative of orbital cellulitis.
learning_objective: Recognize bacterial orbital cellulitis secondary to ethmoidal sinusitis.

answers.explanation_why: Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to proptosis and swelling of the conjunctiva. However, cavernous sinus thrombosis also manifests with symptoms related to the damage caused to structures that pass through the sinus, such as the cranial nerves responsible for eye movement (oculomotor, CN III; trochlear, CN IV; abducens, CN VI) and the ophthalmic and maxillary branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This leads to ophthalmoplegia and loss of sensation in the upper two-thirds of the face. Since this patient does not have any cranial nerve symptoms, cavernous sinus thrombosis is unlikely.

Patients who have recently undergone a dental procedure are at risk of developing a dental abscess, which can spread to the orbit and cause orbital cellulitis. However, dental abscesses typically manifest with pain and swelling in the area of the abscess and systemic symptoms, such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty swallowing and/or speaking. This patient does not have any symptoms that indicate a tooth infection or dental abscess; therefore, her symptoms are likely due to a different underlying disorder.

Rarely, dacryocystitis can spread to adjacent areas, causing orbital cellulitis. However, this patient does not have a history of dacryocystitis and typical clinical features (e.g., localized tenderness in medial canthal region, epiphora, purulent discharge from the punctum) are absent; therefore, her symptoms are likely due to a different underlying disorder.

images.title: Dacryocystitis
images.description: Right eye of a 54-year-old male patientA solid and immobile mass can be seen in the right fossa lacrimalis. There is no discharge of pus or other secretions.These findings are typical of dacryocystitis, which can result from chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac and/or chronic stenosis of the tear duct.

answers.explanation_why: This patient may have initially had viral sinusitis. However, the persistence of this patient's symptoms for two weeks makes it more likely that she now has bacterial sinusitis. In addition, orbital cellulitis is typically due to bacterial rather than viral pathogens. Lastly, the sphenoid sinuses are located in the sphenoid bones near the optic nerve and pituitary gland. Therefore, spread to the orbit from a sphenoid sinus would be less likely than spread from a sinus that is closer to the orbits.

Orbital mucormycosis may occur due to fungal spread in patients with ethmoid or maxillary fungal sinusitis. Patients with fungal sinusitis typically have either poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, HIV, or a history of long-term steroid therapy, and are usually immunocompromised. These patients would present with palatal or nasal mucosal ulceration in addition to the other signs and symptoms of sinusitis. Since this patient is young, healthy, and is not immunocompromised, a fungal source of infection is unlikely.

Orbital cellulitis is most commonly caused by bacterial spread from ethmoidal or maxillary sinusitis, as these sinuses are most proximal to the orbits. This patient's history of recent sinusitis makes bacterial spread from the ethmoidal sinus the most likely cause of her symptoms. Sinusitis can cause orbital or preseptal (anterior to the orbital septum) cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis can be distinguished from preseptal cellulitis by the presence of pain with ocular movements and vision changes.

images.title: Orbital cellulitis
images.description: The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

question_text:
A 9-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 20 minutes after she had a seizure. She has had a fever and discharge from her right ear for the past 3 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of ear pain and fever for which her parents did not seek medical advice. Her parents gave her acetaminophen, which provided moderate relief. There is no family history of frequent infections. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F). Physical examination shows erythema and tenderness in the right postauricular region and lateral and inferior displacement of the auricle. Otoscopy shows a bulging and cloudy tympanic membrane with oozing pus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count
15,800/mm^3

 Segmented neutrophils
80%

 Eosinophils
1%

 Lymphocytes
17%

 Monocytes
2%

Platelet count
258,000/mm^3

Rectal acetaminophen therapy is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 20 minutes after she had a seizure. She has had a fever and discharge from her right ear for the past 3 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of ear pain and fever for which her parents did not seek medical advice. Her parents gave her acetaminophen, which provided moderate relief. There is no family history of frequent infections. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F). Physical examination shows erythema and tenderness in the right postauricular region and lateral and inferior displacement of the auricle. Otoscopy shows a bulging and cloudy tympanic membrane with oozing pus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 15,800/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 80% Eosinophils 1% Lymphocytes 17% Monocytes 2% Platelet count 258,000/mm3 Rectal acetaminophen therapy is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with a possible history of untreated acute otitis media (AOM), tenderness of the postauricular region, and displacement of the auricle, all of which are consistent with acute mastoiditis. The seizure episode raises suspicion for a complication.
learning_objective: Recognize acute mastoiditis with potential intracranial complications, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Topical ciprofloxacin is used to treat certain ear infections such as acute otitis externa and bilateral otitis media in children who have tympanostomy tubes. Mastoiditis cannot be treated with topical antibiotic therapy.

Myringotomy and tympanostomy tube placement are used in the early stages of mastoiditis to facilitate drainage. This patient's findings, however, require a different step in management before surgical intervention is considered.

images.title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
images.description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

answers.explanation_why: Conservative management with analgesics/antipyretics (e.g., acetaminophen) is often sufficient for patients with uncomplicated AOM as most cases are self-limiting. This patient, however, presents with findings consistent with mastoiditis, which is likely a complication of an untreated AOM. Conservative management is insufficient for patients with acute mastoiditis.

Electroencephalography (EEG) is necessary in all patients following their first seizure if the cause is unclear. This patient's seizure was most likely caused by a complication of acute mastoiditis and requires a different approach to confirm the diagnosis.

Mastoiditis is a severe complication of AOM. Mastoiditis usually manifests with persistent or recurrent symptoms of otitis media after initial improvement, profuse ear discharge, a tender and edematous mastoid, and anterolateral protrusion of the auricle. Mastoiditis is a clinical diagnosis but neuroimaging is required in patients with findings suggestive of intracranial complications (e.g., seizures, focal neurological deficits), such as brain abscess. Other indications for imaging are symptoms that do not improve after 48 hours of treatment and planned surgical interventions. MRI of the brain and temporal bone is the preferred imaging modality in children because of the lack of ionizing radiation. In adult patients, a CT scan of the temporal bone is usually the initial imaging study.

Mastoiditis is treated with analgesia and empiric intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy (e.g., ceftriaxone, ampicillin/sulbactam). Myringotomy and tympanostomy tube insertion are used to facilitate drainage in early infection. Severe or refractory cases require mastoidectomy.

images.title: Mastoiditis
images.description: Left retroauricular region of a childThere is pronounced erythema and swelling, with ventral protrusion of the pinna as a result of swelling. The features are typical of mastoiditis, which can occur as a complication of otitis media.

answers.explanation_why: Oral amoxicillin is considered the first-line empiric antibiotic therapy for patients with AOM. This patient, however, has acute mastoiditis, which is treated with empiric intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone, ampicillin/sulbactam).

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of fever and pain in the left ear for the past 3 days. The mother states that he has been rubbing his left ear repeatedly since he woke up this morning. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and his mother is concerned that the boy's ear pain may result from excessive scratching. She also notes that his latest flareup resolved several days before his birthday party, which he celebrated 1 week ago at a swimming pool. Six months ago, he had an episode of urticaria following antibiotic treatment for pharyngitis. He takes no medications. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Otoscopy shows an opaque, bulging tympanic membrane. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of fever and pain in the left ear for the past 3 days. The mother states that he has been rubbing his left ear repeatedly since he woke up this morning. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and his mother is concerned that the boy's ear pain may result from excessive scratching. She also notes that his latest flareup resolved several days before his birthday party, which he celebrated 1 week ago at a swimming pool. Six months ago, he had an episode of urticaria following antibiotic treatment for pharyngitis. He takes no medications. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Otoscopy shows an opaque, bulging tympanic membrane. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This child presents with fever, ear pain, and ear rubbing, and he has an opaque, bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy, making acute otitis media (AOM) the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate antibiotic for acute otitis media in a patient with a penicillin allergy.

answers.explanation_why: Topical hydrocortisone and gentamicin eardrops can be used to treat otitis externa (OE), which typically manifests with ear pain, itching, and otorrhea and may be associated with water exposure (e.g., from swimming). However, OE manifests with tragal tenderness and a red edematous external auditory canal on otoscopy, neither of which is seen here. Topical antibiotic therapy is not effective for AOM because it cannot reach the middle ear.

Most cases of AOM can be managed with symptomatic treatment and observation only, but systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated in children with symptoms persisting > 48 hours, bilateral AOM, otorrhea, and/or signs of severe illness (e.g., fever ≥ 39°C, vomiting, malaise). While amoxicillin is the first-line treatment option for AOM, it should be avoided in patients with a history of allergic reactions to penicillin and its derivatives. This patient likely has a penicillin allergy given his history of urticaria following a course of antibiotics for pharyngitis, for which penicillin derivatives are the first-line treatment. Macrolides like azithromycin are the recommended alternative treatment options for patients with AOM and penicillin allergy.

Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion may be considered in patients with chronic otitis media or recurrent AOM (3 episodes in 6 months or 4 episodes in 1 year), neither of which is seen in this patient.

images.title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
images.description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

answers.explanation_why: Otic ofloxacin is used to treat otitis externa (OE), which typically manifests with ear pain, itching, and otorrhea and may be associated with water exposure (e.g., swimming). However, OE also manifests with tragal tenderness and a red edematous external auditory canal on otoscopy, neither of which is seen here. Topical antibiotic therapy has no therapeutic benefit in patients with AOM, as it is unable to penetrate the tympanic membrane and reach the middle ear.
Tympanocentesis with Gram stain and culture of the middle ear fluid is indicated for patients with AOM who do not respond to initial therapy. This patient has not received treatment for AOM yet.

While amoxicillin-clavulanate can be used as a first-line treatment for AOM, it should be avoided in patients with a history of allergic reactions to penicillin derivatives. This patient likely has a penicillin allergy given his history of urticaria following a course of antibiotics for pharyngitis, for which penicillin derivatives are the first-line treatment.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, headache, earache, and sore throat that is worse when swallowing. He has not had a runny nose or cough. He had a similar problem 1 year ago for which he was prescribed amoxicillin, but after developing a skin rash, facial swelling, and dyspnea he was switched to a different medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75^th percentile for height and the 50^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 136/min, and respirations are 28/min. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a bright red tongue with prominent papillae, a red uvula, and an enlarged right tonsil covered by a whitish membrane. The deep cervical lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, headache, earache, and sore throat that is worse when swallowing. He has not had a runny nose or cough. He had a similar problem 1 year ago for which he was prescribed amoxicillin, but after developing a skin rash, facial swelling, and dyspnea he was switched to a different medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75th percentile for height and the 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 136/min, and respirations are 28/min. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a bright red tongue with prominent papillae, a red uvula, and an enlarged right tonsil covered by a whitish membrane. The deep cervical lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: A modified Centor score of 5 (age 3–14 years, swollen tonsil with an exudate, tender anterior cervical lymph nodes, temperature > 100.4°F or > 38°C, and absence of cough) indicates a high likelihood of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This patient also appears to have had a severe allergic reaction to amoxicillin in the past as suggested by the facial swelling (angioedema) and dyspnea.
learning_objective: Choose an alternative antibiotic for acute bacterial tonsillitis in patients with a severe penicillin allergy.

answers.explanation_why: S. pyogenes is the most common cause of bacterial tonsillitis and is uniformly sensitive to penicillin, making penicillin V the first-line treatment. However, given this patient's history of allergic reaction to amoxicillin (e.g., skin rash and facial swelling), penicillin antibiotics are contraindicated.

Total tonsillectomy poses a risk of postoperative bleeding. Indications for tonsillectomy include chronic tonsillitis, suspected tonsillar neoplasm, obstructive sleep apnea (due to extreme hypertrophy of the tonsils), and multiple recent recurrences of acute tonsillitis. Total tonsillectomy is not a suitable initial treatment for a child with an uncomplicated disease course, no signs of peritonsillar abscess, and only two episodes of acute tonsillitis within a year.

Subtotal tonsillectomy poses a risk of postoperative bleeding. Indications for tonsillectomy include chronic tonsillitis, suspected tonsillar neoplasm, obstructive sleep apnea (due to extreme hypertrophy of the tonsils), and multiple recent recurrences of acute tonsillitis. Subtotal tonsillectomy is not a suitable initial treatment for a child with an uncomplicated disease course, no signs of peritonsillar abscess, and only two episodes of acute tonsillitis within a year.

The whitish membrane seen covering this patient's tonsil could be a finding of oral Candida infection (i.e., thrush), which is typically treated with fluconazole. However, in a healthy child with a fever and acute tonsillitis, this whitish membrane is more likely due to tonsillar exudates. Fungal infections are more common in immunosuppressed or systemically ill individuals.

This patient presents with tonsillitis that is likely due to a bacterial infection, which is normally treated with penicillin V. However, penicillins are contraindicated in this patient because of his past severe IgE-mediated allergic reaction to another penicillin antibiotic. Macrolides, such as clarithromycin or azithromycin, are the antibiotic of choice to treat acute bacterial tonsillitis in patients with a history of a severe penicillin allergy. If local macrolide resistance rates are high, clindamycin should be considered. Before initiating antibiotic therapy for suspected acute group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis, a rapid strep test should be obtained to confirm GAS infection.

See “Recommended antibiotic regimens for acute GAS pharyngitis” table.

Cefixime is a 3^rd generation cephalosporin and up to 10% of patients with a penicillin allergy are also allergic to cephalosporins. Cephalosporins may be considered in patients with previous nonsevere reactions to penicillin (i.e., reactions without angioedema or anaphylaxis) but should not be used in patients who have had a previous severe reaction to penicillin. Moreover, when cephalosporins are used for the treatment of tonsillitis or pharyngitis, 1^st generation cephalosporins (e.g., cephalexin, cefadroxil) are preferred; 3^rd generation cephalosporins are least active among all cephalosporins against gram-positive bacteria such as S. pyogenes.

question_text: One day after undergoing outpatient percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement in the right coronary artery, a 60-year-old woman has left-sided painful facial swelling. The pain is worse when chewing. The patient has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and a multivitamin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness of the left parotid gland as well as oral erythema with scant purulent discharge upon parotid gland massage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: One day after undergoing outpatient percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement in the right coronary artery, a 60-year-old woman has left-sided painful facial swelling. The pain is worse when chewing. The patient has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and a multivitamin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness of the left parotid gland as well as oral erythema with scant purulent discharge upon parotid gland massage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This condition is generally precipitated by a reduction in the flow of saliva (e.g., in postoperative patients).
learning_objective: Recognize suppurative sialadenitis, and choose the most appropriate antibiotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Sialoendoscopy may be indicated in patients with recurrent sialolithiasis, which can also cause bacterial sialadenitis as in this patient. However, this is the patient's first episode of sialadenitis and the absence of calculi in the salivary duct on oral examination makes this etiology less likely. Sialoendoscopy is not the treatment of choice for suppurative sialadenitis if it is not caused by sialolithiasis.

Parotidectomy is used in the treatment of parotid neoplasms, salivary duct stones, and as a last resort in patients with recurrent infections of the parotid gland. This patient is only experiencing her first episode of sialadenitis. Additionally, she has no history of any conditions that would put her at risk for recurrent infections (e.g., diabetes mellitus).

A parotid biopsy is indicated if a parotid neoplasm is suspected. Although parotid tumors can also cause swelling of the gland, they are usually painless and have a much slower course (typically over months) than this patient's symptoms. Associated symptoms due to the infiltration of neighboring structures (e.g., the facial nerve) are common in patients with parotid neoplasms, while purulent discharge and fever as in this patient are rare.

Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the treatment of choice in patients with acute bacterial sialadenitis. The condition is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and typically manifests with sudden swelling of the salivary glands (most often the parotid gland), tenderness, fevers, chills, and secretion of purulent material from the salivary duct, as seen here. Targeted antibiotic therapy can be started after the purulent secretion from the duct is collected for Gram-stain and culture. In addition to antibiotics, supportive measures like gland massage, hydration, sialogogues, warm compresses, and oral hygiene should be encouraged.

images.title: Sialadenitis of the submandibular gland
images.description: There is massive swelling of the left submandibular region. The unilateral location and the marked erythema suggest bacterial sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.

answers.explanation_why: Incision and drainage may be indicated in patients with acute bacterial sialadenitis who develop complications such as a parotid abscess. This patient's presentation, although similar, is inconsistent with a parotid abscess, which is characterized by a subacute onset of symptoms and fluctuation of the parotid gland.

question_text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 10-day history of fever and sore throat that acutely worsened over the past 2 days. Her sore throat is worse on the right side. She has difficulty swallowing and opening her mouth because of pain. She has also noticed a change in the quality of her voice over the last day. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows erythematous tonsils and swelling along with a white exudate of the right tonsillar pillar. The uvula is deviated to the left. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.0 g/dL

Hematocrit
39%

Leukocyte count
12,000/mm^3

Platelet Count
200,000/mm^3

Serum

 Na^+

138 mEq/L

 Cl^-

100 mEq/L

 K^+

4.5 mEq/L

 HCO_3^-

24 mEq/L

 Urea nitrogen
14.0 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 10-day history of fever and sore throat that acutely worsened over the past 2 days. Her sore throat is worse on the right side. She has difficulty swallowing and opening her mouth because of pain. She has also noticed a change in the quality of her voice over the last day. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows erythematous tonsils and swelling along with a white exudate of the right tonsillar pillar. The uvula is deviated to the left. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL Hematocrit 39% Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3 Platelet Count 200,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 138 mEq/L Cl- 100 mEq/L K+ 4.5 mEq/L HCO3- 24 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 14.0 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A solitary swollen and erythematous tonsil with uvula deviation to the contralateral side, in a patient with features of tonsilitis (fever, sore throat, odynophagia), suggests peritonsillar abscess (PTA). Muffled speech, trismus, and ipsilateral cervical lymphadenopathy are also typically present.
learning_objective: Recognize peritonsillar abscess, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: There is inconsistent evidence for the efficacy of intravenous dexamethasone, a glucocorticoid, in the treatment of PTA. For this reason, the use of corticosteroids is not routinely recommended.

Tonsillectomy should be considered in patients with acute PTA who have significant upper airway obstruction or an abscess that does not resolve with first-line therapy. This patient shows no signs of airway obstruction (e.g., dyspnea) and has not yet received any therapy. A different step is most appropriate at this time. Tonsillectomy can also be considered in patients with recurrent tonsilitis or recurrent PTA.
Incision and drainage are recommended in patients with PTA, but they should always be combined with systemic antimicrobial therapy.

answers.content: Incision and drainage combined with intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy
answers.explanation_why: PTA is the most common deep neck infection in adolescents and young adults. This disease is caused by bacterial spread from acute tonsillitis into the potential space between the tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles. The diagnosis is usually clinical. Initial treatment typically includes incision and drainage combined with intravenous antibiotic therapy (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam) that provides coverage for Streptococcus pyogenes (most common pathogen), Staphylococcus aureus, and anaerobes. Patients may be treated with oral antibiotics once they are afebrile.

images.title: Peritonsillar abscess
images.description: Redness and swelling can be seen on the right side of the anterior palatal arch and of the soft palate. There is a slight left-sided deviation of the soft palate. The uvula shows a distinct redness and is slightly swollen.These findings are suggestive of a peritonsillar abscess on the right side.

answers.content: Needle aspiration combined with oral clindamycin therapy
answers.explanation_why: In patients with PTA, needle aspiration of the abscess may be an alternative to incision and drainage. However, patients with PTA should initially receive intravenous antibiotic therapy and may only be treated with oral antibiotics once they are afebrile.

Intravenous antibiotic therapy is indicated in all patients with PTA and should provide coverage for Streptococcus spp., Staphylococcus aureus, and anaerobes. Although ampicillin-sulbactam is appropriate to treat PTA, antibiotic therapy alone is usually not sufficient.

question_text: A 4-year old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever, painful swallowing, headache, and neck spasm that began shortly after waking up. He has had a sore throat over the last week that acutely worsened this morning. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He lives at home with his mother. His older brother has asthma. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 93/60 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is drooling from the mouth. The neck is stiff and extension is limited. Respirations appear labored with accessory muscle use. Inspiratory stridor is heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Oropharyngeal examination shows a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. Intravenous access is obtained and laboratory studies are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever, painful swallowing, headache, and neck spasm that began shortly after waking up. He has had a sore throat over the last week that acutely worsened this morning. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He lives at home with his mother. His older brother has asthma. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 93/60 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is drooling from the mouth. The neck is stiff and extension is limited. Respirations appear labored with accessory muscle use. Inspiratory stridor is heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Oropharyngeal examination shows a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. Intravenous access is obtained and laboratory studies are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with fever, odynophagia, an inability to extend his neck, and a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, all of which suggest retropharyngeal abscess.
learning_objective: Recognize retropharyngeal abscess with impending respiratory compromise, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Emergency airway management is indicated in patients with suspected retropharyngeal abscess who present with features of impending respiratory compromise (e.g., inspiratory stridor, hypoxemia, and labored breathing with accessory muscle use). The patient should be intubated for airway protection and emergency surgical drainage should be performed. If endotracheal intubation is not possible because of severe airway compromise, or if the posterior pharyngeal wall ruptures during intubation, an emergency tracheostomy should be performed to secure the airway.

Airway management to prevent respiratory compromise takes priority in the management of any infection of the deep neck spaces.

Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics like ampicillin-sulbactam and clindamycin can be used to treat retropharyngeal abscesses that present early in clinically stable patients without any airway compromise. This child has severe respiratory distress, requiring a more urgent procedure before antibiotics are administered.

Blood cultures should be drawn from patients with retropharyngeal abscesses to identify the causative pathogen. Airway management to prevent respiratory compromise takes priority in the management of any infection of the deep neck spaces.

Intravenous corticosteroid therapy may be used in combination with antibiotics to reduce inflammation and swelling of the upper airway in a patient with a retropharyngeal abscess. However, this patient is in severe respiratory distress and a more urgent procedure is required.

A CT of the neck can be used to confirm deep neck infections if a lateral neck x-ray is inconclusive. While this child may eventually need a CT of the neck to evaluate the underlying infection and its extent, he is in severe respiratory distress and a more urgent procedure is required.

Nebulized albuterol can be used in patients with respiratory distress caused by bronchospasm (e.g., asthma). This patient’s respiratory distress results from upper airway obstruction due to a retropharyngeal abscess. Therefore, albuterol is not indicated for airway management in this patient.

Lateral neck x-ray can be used as an initial diagnostic modality to confirm retropharyngeal abscess in a clinically stable child. Although the x-ray would most likely show a widened prevertebral space, this child is in severe respiratory distress and a more urgent procedure is required.

question_text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with progressive retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. The pain is severe, worsens with inspiration, and radiates to his neck. He has had a sore throat and neck pain for the past 4 days. He remained bed-bound during this time and had poor appetite. One week ago, he underwent upper endoscopy for peptic ulcer disease. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, peptic ulcer disease, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. His medications are metformin, omeprazole, pravastatin, and enalapril. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He appears in significant distress. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 88/46 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Oropharyngeal examination is limited because the patient is unable to open his mouth due to pain. His hematocrit is 42%, leukocyte count is 13,800/mm^3, and platelet count is 205,000/mm^3. The patient is intubated in the emergency department and appropriate treatment is started. Chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with progressive retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. The pain is severe, worsens with inspiration, and radiates to his neck. He has had a sore throat and neck pain for the past 4 days. He remained bed-bound during this time and had poor appetite. One week ago, he underwent upper endoscopy for peptic ulcer disease. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, peptic ulcer disease, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. His medications are metformin, omeprazole, pravastatin, and enalapril. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He appears in significant distress. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 88/46 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Oropharyngeal examination is limited because the patient is unable to open his mouth due to pain. His hematocrit is 42%, leukocyte count is 13,800/mm3, and platelet count is 205,000/mm3. The patient is intubated in the emergency department and appropriate treatment is started. Chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: The patient's history of sore throat, neck pain, and trismus in combination with fever and leukocytosis suggests retropharyngeal abscess, most likely as a complication of tonsillitis or endoscopy. The spread of infection along the deep cervical fascia has likely led to mediastinitis, as indicated by the severe chest pain and widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. Additionally, the patient is showing signs of sepsis (hypotension and elevated pulse).
learning_objective: Recognize retropharyngeal abscess and mediastinitis, and choose the appropriate empiric therapy to prevent its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam is the recommended empiric therapy for retropharyngeal abscess and would have most likely prevented the development of mediastinitis in this patient. Retropharyngeal abscess is usually a polymicrobial disease caused by streptococci, staphylococci, Haemophilus influenzae, and/or oral anaerobes, which are all covered by ampicillin-sulbactam. Clindamycin can be used as an alternative to ampicillin-sulbactam. Patients who fail to respond to antibiotic treatment or those with large retropharyngeal abscesses on CT should receive surgical drainage.

Pericardiocentesis is used to treat pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Although this patient has some symptoms consistent with cardiac tamponade such as chest pain, hypotension, dyspnea, and a widened mediastinum, he lacks several other typical symptoms such as muffled heart sounds and distended neck veins. Additionally, cardiac tamponade does not cause fever, sore throat, or trismus.

Levofloxacin may prevent complications of community-acquired pneumonia (e.g., respiratory failure). Although community-acquired pneumonia may present with some features seen in this patient (e.g., chest pain, fever, and dyspnea), it is unlikely in the absence of a productive cough and abnormal findings on lung auscultation. Additionally, community-acquired pneumonia would not cause trismus, sore throat, neck pain, or a widened mediastinum.

Administration of methylprednisolone, a glucocorticoid, is used to prevent respiratory arrest secondary to anaphylaxis. Although anaphylaxis may present with dyspnea, chest pain, and hypotension, it also usually involves the skin and mucosa manifestations, causing urticaria, pruritus, or angioedema, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, anaphylaxis does not cause trismus, sore throat, and a widened mediastinum.

Blood pressure control would help prevent aortic dissection, which is associated with hypertension and also presents with dyspnea, hypotension, fever, retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the neck, and mediastinal widening on chest x-ray. But this patient lacks asymmetrical blood pressure readings between limbs. Additionally, aortic dissection would occur suddenly and is not associated with sore throat or trismus.

question_text: Six days after admission to the hospital for treatment of infective endocarditis, a 64-year-old woman develops persistent ringing in both ears, lightheadedness, and nausea. When she turns her head, she sees the light on the ceiling swinging from side to side. She has congestive heart disease, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. She was treated for a cerebrovascular accident 7 years ago and has no residual deficits. Current medications include intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin, as well as oral aspirin, atenolol, furosemide, and lisinopril. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur along the left lower sternal border. While the patient fixates on a target, administration of brisk, horizontal head rotations to both sides results in corrective saccades to refixate back to the target. She has an unsteady gait. Muscle strength and sensation are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: Six days after admission to the hospital for treatment of infective endocarditis, a 64-year-old woman develops persistent ringing in both ears, lightheadedness, and nausea. When she turns her head, she sees the light on the ceiling swinging from side to side. She has congestive heart disease, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. She was treated for a cerebrovascular accident 7 years ago and has no residual deficits. Current medications include intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin, as well as oral aspirin, atenolol, furosemide, and lisinopril. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur along the left lower sternal border. While the patient fixates on a target, administration of brisk, horizontal head rotations to both sides results in corrective saccades to refixate back to the target. She has an unsteady gait. Muscle strength and sensation are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: This patient's tinnitus suggests cochlear dysfunction. She also has symptoms of vestibular dysfunction, including oscillopsia, an unsteady gait, and an abnormal head thrust test. The etiology of cochlear and vestibular dysfunction in this patient is the same.
learning_objective: Recognize medication toxicity as a cause of ototoxicity.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased resorption of endolymph is one of the underlying pathomechanisms of Ménière disease, which can also manifest with tinnitus and oscillopsia (due to horizontal nystagmus). However, symptoms of Ménière disease typically arise episodically for minutes to hours. Although ∼ 30% of patients with Ménière disease eventually develop bilateral involvement, it is unusual at the time of initial presentation.

If otoliths become dislodged, the semicircular canal can become sensitive to changes in head position, resulting in benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Patients with BPPV have vestibular symptoms, such as episodes of vertigo that are brought on by changes in head position, however, they usually last ≤1 minute. Also, cochlear symptoms are not a feature of BPPV.

Vertebrobasilar insufficiency can also manifest with an unsteady gait and bilateral tinnitus triggered by postural changes (due to compression of the vertebral artery) and merits consideration in this patient with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. However, symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency are typically episodic and would also include dysarthria, dysphagia, and paresthesias. Additionally, vertebrobasilar insufficiency would not cause an abnormal head thrust test.

Although suppurative labyrinthitis can also manifest with tinnitus and oscillopsia, it generally occurs following chronic otitis media or surgical procedures such as stapedectomy and typically causes unilateral dysfunction (due to localized inflammation in one ear). This condition is unlikely in this patient with both a bilaterally abnormal head thrust test and bilateral tinnitus.

Aminoglycosides, especially gentamicin, are ototoxic and cause cochlear dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, hearing impairment) by damaging cochlear cells, and/or vestibulopathy (e.g., nausea, vomiting, dizziness, vertigo, oscillopsia, ataxia) by damaging hair cells of the inner ear. Loop diuretics (like furosemide) also increase the risk of ototoxicity by affecting Na^+/K^+/2Cl^- cotransporters present in the inner ear. The vestibular dysfunction of gentamicin toxicity is typically bilateral; accordingly, there is no imbalance between right-sided and left-sided input to the central nervous system, so patients do not typically experience vertigo. However, patients can experience oscillopsia and an abnormal head thrust test in both horizontal directions.

Strategies to reduce adverse effects of aminoglycosides include once-daily dosing and monitoring of serum concentrations.

In patients with infective endocarditis, septic emboli originating from bacterial vegetations can enter the circulation and cause arterial obstruction with subsequent infarction. Arterial obstruction can lead to stroke, blindness, and limb ischemia. While a posterior circulation stroke (e.g., cerebellar stroke) could account for some of this woman's symptoms, such as ataxia, patients with stroke typically manifest with lateralized deficits. Also, this patient has been receiving intravenous antibiotic therapy, which reduces the risk of developing septic emboli.

Delirium causes acute alteration of awareness and attention and can cause hallucinations that may be interpreted as visual disturbances. Risk factors for delirium include this patient's advanced age and infection, but a key feature of delirium is the fluctuation of symptoms throughout the day. Also, delirium would not cause an abnormal head thrust test.

question_text:
A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever, progressive weakness, and cough for the past five days. He experienced a similar episode 2 months ago, for which he was hospitalized for 10 days. He states that he has never fully recovered from that episode. He felt much better after being treated with antibiotics, but he still coughs often during meals. He sometimes also coughs up undigested food after eating. For the last 5 days, his coughing has become more frequent and productive of yellowish-green sputum. He takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension and pantoprazole for the retrosternal discomfort that he often experiences while eating. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years and drinks one shot of vodka every day. The patient appears thin. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 125/90 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs shows right basal crackles. There is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
15.4 g/dL

Leukocyte count
17,000/mm^3

Platelet count
350,000/mm^3

Serum

Na^+

139 mEq/L

K^+

4.6 mEq/L

Cl^-

102 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL

An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever, progressive weakness, and cough for the past five days. He experienced a similar episode 2 months ago, for which he was hospitalized for 10 days. He states that he has never fully recovered from that episode. He felt much better after being treated with antibiotics, but he still coughs often during meals. He sometimes also coughs up undigested food after eating. For the last 5 days, his coughing has become more frequent and productive of yellowish-green sputum. He takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension and pantoprazole for the retrosternal discomfort that he often experiences while eating. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years and drinks one shot of vodka every day. The patient appears thin. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 125/90 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs shows right basal crackles. There is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 15.4 g/dL Leukocyte count 17,000/mm3 Platelet count 350,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 139 mEq/L K+ 4.6 mEq/L Cl- 102 mEq/L HCO3- 25 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 16 mg/dL Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's cough, weakness, yellowish-green sputum, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, auscultatory crackles, dullness to percussion, leukocytosis, and x-ray findings are consistent with pneumonia, which appears to be recurring given his history of a recent similar episode. Coughing during meals indicating potential aspiration and regurgitation of undigested food are both suggestive of the underlying mechanism.
learning_objective: Recognize Zenker diverticulum complications.

answers.content: Weak tone of the lower esophageal sphincter
answers.explanation_why: Weak tone of the lower esophageal sphincter causes gastroesophageal reflux, which may explain this patient's retrosternal discomfort during meals and is a predisposing factor for (recurrent) aspiration pneumonia, but it does not explain the regurgitation of chunks of undigested food. Additionally, the patient is currently taking pantoprazole, which would be expected to provide symptomatic relief of gastroesophageal reflux.

answers.content: Formation of a tissue cavity containing necrotic debris
answers.explanation_why: Formation of a tissue cavity containing necrotic debris indicates a lung abscess. Although a lung abscess would be consistent with the patient's history of recurrent pneumonia, it does not explain his retrosternal discomfort or his cough during meals. While aspiration of food or saliva may be the cause of a lung abscess, regurgitation of undigested food is not one of its symptoms.

Uncoordinated contractions of the esophagus suggest esophageal spasm. Although this may also cause retrosternal discomfort (or even severe chest pain) during meals, aspiration of food particles and resulting recurrent pneumonia is not a common complication of esophageal spasm. The regurgitation of undigested food is suggestive of another underlying etiology.

answers.content: Unrestricted growth of pneumocytes with invasion of the surrounding tissue
answers.explanation_why:
Unrestricted growth of pneumocytes with invasion of the surrounding tissue describes lung cancer. This patient presents with some features of lung cancer, such as cough, weakness, and a history of tobacco abuse – the most important risk factor. However, lung cancer is not commonly associated with regurgitation of undigested food and does not adequately explain the relationship between the cough and food intake.

Although postobstructive pneumonia, which may be a manifestation of undiagnosed lung cancer, cannot be entirely excluded in this patient, aspiration-induced pneumonia seems more likely given that food regurgitation is also mentioned.

Outpouching of the hypopharynx describes a Zenker diverticulum, the most common type of esophageal diverticula. It is seen mostly in middle-aged and older patients presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation, aspiration of undigested food, and foul-smelling breath. Zenker diverticulum is commonly complicated by recurrent aspiration pneumonia, caused by swallowed saliva, liquid, or food entering the airway, as seen in this patient.

images.title: Location of esophageal diverticula
images.description: Esophageal diverticula can be classified according to location.The upper esophageal diverticula are pharyngoesophageal pulsion diverticula. The upper esophageal diverticula at the Killian triangle, which lies between the thyropharyngeal and cricopharyngeal parts of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, are the most common type.Middle esophageal diverticula are located at the tracheal bifurcation and are traction diverticula.Lower esophageal diverticula are epiphrenic pulsion diverticula.

question_text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician for the evaluation of severe nosebleeds and two episodes of bloody vomit over the past 40 minutes. He reports that he has had recurrent nosebleeds almost daily for the past 3 weeks. The nosebleeds last 30–40 minutes. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The patient's upper body is elevated and his head tilted forward. The patient's nostrils are pinched for 15 minutes. Despite all measures, the nosebleed continues. Examination of the nose with a speculum does not show an anterior bleeding source. Anterior and posterior nasal packing fails to provide sufficient bleeding control. Endoscopic ligation of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician for the evaluation of severe nosebleeds and two episodes of bloody vomit over the past 40 minutes. He reports that he has had recurrent nosebleeds almost daily for the past 3 weeks. The nosebleeds last 30–40 minutes. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The patient's upper body is elevated and his head tilted forward. The patient's nostrils are pinched for 15 minutes. Despite all measures, the nosebleed continues. Examination of the nose with a speculum does not show an anterior bleeding source. Anterior and posterior nasal packing fails to provide sufficient bleeding control. Endoscopic ligation of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has severe epistaxis and associated hematemesis while tilting his head forward (suggesting posterior bleeding) that continues despite nasal packing. The most appropriate next step in management would be to ligate a terminal branch of the maxillary artery.
learning_objective: Recognize severe posterior epistaxis, and choose the most appropriate surgical intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Endoscopic ligation of the sphenopalatine artery is the recommended intervention in patients with posterior epistaxis that persists despite conservative treatment. The sphenopalatine artery, a terminal branch of the maxillary artery, is involved in most cases of posterior epistaxis.

images.title: Arterial supply of the nasal septum
images.description:
The nasal septum is supplied by the following arteries:
- Anterior and posterior ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery
- Sphenopalatine branch of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery
- Superior labial branch of the facial artery (not shown here), which is also a branch of the external carotid arteryThe Kiesselbach plexus is formed by the anastomoses between the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries. It is located in the anteroinferior region of the nasal septum and is the most common site of epistaxis.

answers.explanation_why: Endoscopic ligation of the lesser palatine artery would not treat this patient's epistaxis because this artery does not provide blood supply to the nasal cavity. The lesser palatine artery instead supplies the soft palate and tonsil.

The greater palatine artery provides blood supply to the hard palate as well as the anterior nasal septum and its ligation may be useful for treating refractory anterior epistaxis. However, this patient's nosebleed is associated with hematemesis and there is no visible anterior bleeding source on examination of the nose, which suggests posterior rather than anterior bleeding.

Although endoscopic ligation of the anterior ethmoidal artery is used for the treatment of epistaxis, it is only helpful in cases of anterior epistaxis refractory to conservative management. This patient's nosebleed is associated with hematemesis and there is no visible anterior bleeding source on examination of the nose, which suggests posterior rather than anterior bleeding.

Although posterior epistaxis may originate from the posterior ethmoidal artery, this is a very rare scenario. This patient's epistaxis is most likely going to stop after ligation of a different blood vessel.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the neck. She did not lose consciousness. On arrival, she has severe neck pain. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a bullet entrance wound in the right posterior cervical region of the neck. There is no exit wound. Carotid pulses are palpable bilaterally. There are no carotid bruits. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the neck. She did not lose consciousness. On arrival, she has severe neck pain. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a bullet entrance wound in the right posterior cervical region of the neck. There is no exit wound. Carotid pulses are palpable bilaterally. There are no carotid bruits. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This woman sustained a penetrating neck trauma and has stable vital signs with no signs of tracheal or esophageal injury. Nevertheless, initial evaluation of this patient involves ruling out occult injury to the trachea, esophagus, and vasculature.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate imaging modality for evaluating stable penetrating neck trauma.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical exploration is indicated in patients with penetrating neck injury who show signs of decompensation, an expanding hematoma, or tracheal/esophageal injury. Although this patient is tachycardic and tachypneic (most likely due to a sympathetic response to pain), she is normotensive and has normal oxygen saturation. She also has no signs of expanding hematoma, subcutaneous emphysema, or ongoing bleeding. Consequently, surgical exploration is not indicated at this time.

Stable patients with penetrating neck injuries should be evaluated for possible injuries to the trachea, larynx, and neck vessels. Multidetector CT angiography is the recommended imaging modality for the evaluation of these injuries. This test is fast, commonly available, highly specific and sensitive, and allows for comprehensive visualization of the neck, vascular, and nonvascular injuries.

Immediate intubation and surgical exploration are indicated in patients with hemodynamic instability, expanding hematoma, or clear signs of tracheal/esophageal injury.

A gunshot wound to the neck may require intubation, most commonly because of a tracheal injury or an expanding neck hematoma that compromises the airway. The patient, however, does not have an expanding hematoma and has no signs of tracheal injury (e.g., stridor, subcutaneous emphysema, hemoptysis) or respiratory distress. Her vital signs are stable, she is neurologically intact, and she has normal oxygen saturation, so there is no indication for endotracheal intubation at this time.

Barium swallow may be an appropriate test for the diagnosis of esophageal injury. Although penetrating neck injuries can cause esophageal injury, this patient shows none of the associated signs (e.g., dysphagia, hematemesis, subcutaneous emphysema), so a barium swallow study would not be indicated at this time. In addition, if there is high suspicion of esophageal perforation, a water-soluble contrast agent (such as gastrografin) is used instead of barium, which can cause mediastinitis.

Esophagoscopy is an appropriate test for the diagnosis of esophageal injury in patients with a negative barium swallow study or who are unable to participate in a barium swallow study. Although penetrating neck injuries may cause esophageal injury, this patient shows none of the associated signs (e.g., dysphagia, hematemesis, subcutaneous emphysema).

Laryngoscopy may be indicated for the diagnosis of occult injury to the larynx, but it is not the preferred initial diagnostic modality in a patient with penetrating neck injury. Moreover, this patient does not have any signs of laryngeal injury (e.g., stridor, dysphonia, hemoptysis).

A cricothyrotomy may be required if the patient is in respiratory distress and orotracheal intubation or supraglottic ventilation with a laryngeal mask device fails. This patient does not show any signs of respiratory distress.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He had difficulty chewing his food at breakfast. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. He is in no apparent distress. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He had difficulty chewing his food at breakfast. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. He is in no apparent distress. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Facial muscle paralysis (lagophthalmos of the left eye, drooping of the left corner of the mouth) that does not spare the ipsilateral forehead is consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.
learning_objective: Recognize peripheral facial nerve palsy, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why:
Peripheral facial nerve palsy following facial trauma is caused by temporal bone fracture or trauma. Management typically depends on symptom onset. Acute onset of symptoms following facial trauma is usually caused by nerve injury (e.g., transection); therefore, surgery (e.g., nerve repair) may be indicated. A delayed presentation (e.g., one day after trauma) is most likely secondary to edema within the facial nerve canal. In this patient, corticosteroid therapy is indicated to control swelling within the facial nerve canal. If this patient's facial nerve palsy does not improve or worsens, surgical decompression of the facial nerve canal is indicated.

Proper eye care with artificial tears and moisturizing ointments is an important part of managing lagophthalmos.
The patient presents with delayed facial nerve palsy following trauma. Given the underlying traumatic etiology and the fact that he is symptomatic, reassurance alone is not indicated.

In a patient with delayed facial nerve palsy following traumatic injury, surgical decompression is only indicated if the presenting symptoms do not improve or continue to worsen with first-line therapy (short course of high-dose steroids). Surgical decompression of the facial nerve puts the patient at risk for further injury to an already injured nerve, may prolong or prevent nerve recovery, and carries the risk of additional complications such as hearing loss, vestibular function loss, cerebrospinal fluid leaks, and meningitis.

Acyclovir therapy is appropriate for Bell palsy or facial palsy from a viral infection (e.g., herpes zoster). Although the patient presents with clinical features associated with Bell palsy (e.g. lagophthalmos, flattened nasolabial fold, drooping of a corner of the mouth), his facial palsy is likely the result of his recent trauma. In addition, the patient does not report dermatomal pain or vesicles near the external meatus, which would be expected in herpes zoster.

Primary nerve repair with good nerve approximation may reduce the degree of facial paralysis, and would be the appropriate step in management if there was direct transection of the facial nerve. However, the patient presented with delayed facial nerve palsy (one day after the traumatic event), which indicates that nerve transection is not the underlying pathology in this patient. Moreover, the CT scan does not show evidence of a transverse fracture of the temporal bone nor is there a penetrating injury near the cheek to suggest facial nerve transection.
