question_text:
A previously healthy 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging, painless neck mass. During this period, she has also experienced intermittent palpitations, hair loss, and a weight loss of 4.5 kg (10 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears anxious and fidgety. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min and irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender left anterior cervical nodule that moves with swallowing. Laboratory studies show:

TSH
0.3 μU/mL

T_4

13.2 μg/dL

T_3

207 ng/dL

Ultrasonography confirms the presence of a 3-cm solid left thyroid nodule. A thyroid ^123I radionuclide scintigraphy scan shows increased uptake in a nodule in the left lobe of the thyroid gland with suppression of the remainder of the thyroid tissue. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging, painless neck mass. During this period, she has also experienced intermittent palpitations, hair loss, and a weight loss of 4.5 kg (10 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears anxious and fidgety. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min and irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender left anterior cervical nodule that moves with swallowing. Laboratory studies show: TSH 0.3 μU/mL T4 13.2 μg/dL T3 207 ng/dL Ultrasonography confirms the presence of a 3-cm solid left thyroid nodule. A thyroid 123I radionuclide scintigraphy scan shows increased uptake in a nodule in the left lobe of the thyroid gland with suppression of the remainder of the thyroid tissue. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, hair loss, and weight loss) with decreased TSH and increased T_3 and T_4 levels. These findings, combined with the presence of a solitary hot nodule on thyroid scintigraphy with suppression of surrounding thyroid tissue, imply that this patient has a toxic adenoma.
learning_objective: Recognize a toxic adenoma, and recall its molecular pathogenesis.

answers.explanation_why: Involution of a follicular adenoma causes a thyroid cyst to form. Thyroid cysts can be painful and cause symptoms secondary to mass effect and compression (e.g., hoarseness, dysphagia). Ultrasound would show a mass filled with fluid, not a solid mass. Additionally, patients with thyroid cysts do not generally present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, nor do they have abnormal thyroid function tests.

answers.content: Thyroid peroxidase autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid tissue
answers.explanation_why: Thyroid peroxidase autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid tissue is seen in early Hashimoto thyroiditis. The initial destruction of thyroid tissue can lead to the release of thyroid hormones and subsequent transient hyperthyroidism (hashitoxicosis). However, patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis do not present with solid, solitary thyroid nodules. Additionally, the scintigraphy results are highly suggestive of a toxic adenoma.

answers.content: Gain-of-function mutations of the TSH receptor
answers.explanation_why: Toxic adenomas arise from a gain-of-function mutation in the TSH receptor gene that causes autonomous functioning of the TSH receptor independent of hypothalamic-pituitary regulation. Without negative feedback, the thyroid follicular cells become hyperplastic and eventually form a toxic adenoma. This autonomous thyroid nodule overproduces thyroid hormones, resulting in hyperthyroidism and a consequent decrease in pituitary TSH secretion. The remainder of the thyroid still responds appropriately to negative feedback, resulting in a suppressed appearance on scintigraphy.

answers.content: Persistent TSH stimulation and heterogeneous thyroid tissue hyperplasia
answers.explanation_why: Heterogenous thyroid tissue hyperplasia secondary to persistent TSH stimulation is the mechanism underlying toxic multinodular goiter. Though patients with toxic multinodular goiter also present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, they also tend to be older than > 60 years, have multiple nodules, and often have a history of iodine deficiency. In addition, scintigraphy of toxic multinodular goiter shows radioiodine uptake by multiple hyperfunctioning nodules rather than a single nodule as in toxic adenoma.

Thyroglobulin antibody production would not cause a solitary, hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule. Some patients with other thyroid diseases (Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease, cancer) can present with anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, but these antibodies are a highly nonspecific finding of both thyroid and rheumatological diseases, including Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease, thyroid cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

answers.content: Stimulation of thyroid hormone release by TSH receptor autoantibodies
answers.explanation_why: Stimulation of thyroid hormone release by TSH receptor autoantibodies is the mechanism underlying Graves disease. Although patients with Graves disease present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, decreased TSH, and increased thyroid hormone levels, they rarely present with thyroid nodules.

answers.content: Activation of oncogenes promoting cell division
answers.explanation_why: Oncogene activation and consequent cell division is seen in thyroid cancer. Though hyperfunctioning cancer nodules can cause symptoms of hyperthyroidism, most thyroid cancers are asymptomatic. On examination, carcinomas tend to be fixed in place, rather than movable, as is the case in this patient. Additionally, the majority of thyroid cancers appear as cold, not hot, nodules on scintigraphy.

Patients with excessive exogenous thyroid hormone intake would also present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism and lab values similar to the patient in this case. However, the presence of a solitary nodule with increased uptake on scintigraphy would not be expected in the case of exogenous thyroid hormone intake.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This man has blood-tinged fluid draining from his nose after trauma that shows a halo sign (rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood), indicating cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea. The most likely explanation is a basilar skull fracture of the anterior cranial fossa.
learning_objective: Recognize cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after trauma, and recall the diagnostic finding of a basilar skull fracture.

answers.explanation_why: Basilar skull fracture can be associated with cranial nerve palsies. Anterior basilar skull fracture can cause cranial nerve (CN) I palsies, as well as palsies in CN V, VI, VII, or VIII. However, CN XII exits the skull at the hypoglossal canal of the occipital bone (in the posterior fossa) and thus is associated with posterior basilar skull fractures, not anterior basilar skull fractures. Additionally, most cranial nerve palsies associated with basilar skull fracture are not present until 1–3 days after injury, because the palsy is the result of compression or contusion of the nerve, which does not occur acutely. If a nerve is transected by trauma (which is uncommon), then the palsy would be present immediately.

This patient presents with CSF rhinorrhea, which is a classic sign of anterior basilar skull fracture. The positive halo sign confirms that the leakage contains CSF. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (“raccoon eyes”) is another typical sign of basilar skull fracture involving the anterior cranial fossa. "Raccoon eyes" is not seen immediately after an injury but rather develops after 1–3 days.

If basilar skull fracture is suspected, the next best steps in management are noncontrast CT scan of the head to confirm the diagnosis and neurosurgical consultation.

images.title: Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis
images.description: Face of a 54-year-old man after a fall on the back of his head 2 days earlierBilateral, symmetrical, dark purplish discoloration around the eye sockets is visible.This appearance, also referred to as "raccoon eyes," is a typical sign of basilar skull fractures involving the anterior fossa and typically develops 1–3 days after injury. Nontraumatic causes include neuroblastoma, plasma cell proliferative disorders (e.g., amyloidosis), and hematological malignancies. Periorbital ecchymosis may occur unilaterally or bilaterally.

answers.explanation_why: Upper cheek numbness is caused by damage to the infraorbital nerve, which is a complication of orbital fracture. Basilar skull fracture can in rare cases cause facial numbness by damaging cranial nerve V, but this would be seen in middle cranial fossa fracture. This patient's CSF rhinorrhea is indicative of anterior fossa fracture.

Trismus is most commonly associated with tetanus but may also be caused by zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture. Other signs of zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture include facial paresthesias, intraoral lacerations, and orbital edema. However, this patient has signs of anterior basilar skull fracture, not zygomatic or mandibular fracture, making trismus unlikely.

Carotid artery dissection is a rare complication of basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving injury to the carotid canal. Another finding would be much more likely. Additionally, this patient's CSF rhinorrhea suggests damage to the anterior fossa, while the carotid canal is in the middle fossa.

Retroauricular ecchymosis (“Battle sign”) involves the petrous part of the temporal bone specifically and is a classic sign of basilar skull fracture. However, petrous temporal fracture would cause CSF otorrhea, not rhinorrhea.

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-week history of a foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. She also had one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this period. She has been mouth breathing in her sleep for the past 4 days. She was born at term. Her 1-year-old brother was treated for viral gastroenteritis 3 weeks ago.  She is at 60^th percentile for height and at 70^th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg. Examination shows mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Oral and otoscopic examination is unremarkable. Endoscopic examination of the nose confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-week history of a foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. She also had one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this period. She has been mouth breathing in her sleep for the past 4 days. She was born at term. Her 1-year-old brother was treated for viral gastroenteritis 3 weeks ago. She is at 60th percentile for height and at 70th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg. Examination shows mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Oral and otoscopic examination is unremarkable. Endoscopic examination of the nose confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Note that the child has strictly unilateral nasal symptoms.
learning_objective: Recognize a foreign nasal body in a child, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Transnasal puncture and stenting are used to treat choanal atresia, a congenital condition. Bilateral choanal atresia usually manifests in infancy, whereas the unilateral form manifests later in life with chronic rhinitis of the affected nasal passage. The timeframe of this patient's symptoms makes bilateral atresia unlikely, however, and unilateral atresia does not typically manifest with foul-smelling or blood-tinged nasal drainage.

Tumor embolization is used to treat juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a locally invasive vascular tumor that typically manifests with episodic epistaxis and nasal obstruction. This child only had a single episode of blood-tinged fluid. Also, these tumors occur virtually exclusively in adolescent males.

A foreign nasal body should be suspected in any young child with unilateral nasal discharge (most commonly seen in patients 1–5 years of age). The presence of unilateral symptoms can help rule out differential diagnoses, such as chronic rhinosinusitis or upper respiratory tract infection, which generally manifest bilaterally. The foreign object causes local inflammatory reactions, which can lead to foul-smelling nasal discharge, epistaxis, and may progress to secondary infection. Diagnosis is established via direct visualization of the foreign body via anterior rhinoscopy, or, if the foreign body is not visualized on anterior rhinoscopy, flexible fiberoptic nasolaryngoscopy. Removal of the foreign body is first attempted through noninvasive techniques (e.g., positive pressure techniques). If unsuccessful, instrumentation techniques (e.g., extraction with forceps) may be necessary.

A septoplasty can be used to correct a nasal septum deviation. Severe septum deviation can cause sinus infections, sleep apnea, and snoring. This patient does not have any symptoms that would suggest sinus infection (e.g., fever or headache). Although mouth breathing is reported, there is no history of snoring or apnea.

Functional endoscopic sinus surgery is used to restore sinus ventilation and function in patients with chronic sinusitis who have not responded to medical therapy. Patients with chronic sinusitis typically present with bilateral mucopurulent drainage from the nose or the nasopharynx, nasal congestion, facial pain, and/or impaired sense of smell. Because this patient's symptoms are inconsistent with chronic sinusitis, this procedure is not indicated.

images.title: Chronic rhinosinusitis
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane)The ethmoid sinuses are opacified (hatched green overlay) and there is lobulated thickening of the walls of the maxillary sinuses (green overlay). The findings indicate nasal polyps and retention cysts.

answers.explanation_why: Adenoidectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with symptomatic adenoid vegetations. While adenoid hypertrophy can manifest with mucopurulent nasal discharge and mouth breathing, the discharge is usually nonbloody and affects both nostrils. Also, the enlarged adenoids would have been visualized during oral examination.

Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy can be used to treat allergic/vasomotor rhinitis or nasal polyposis. Rhinitis generally manifests with bilateral symptoms. Nasal polyps are more common in adults and typically develop in patients with allergic rhinitis, cystic fibrosis, or asthma due to chronic inflammation. This patient has unilateral symptoms and does not have any risk factors for nasal polyps.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe right-sided temporal headache with conjunctival swelling and anterior bulging of the left eye for 1 hour. The patient has had right-sided purulent nasal discharge and nasal congestion for the past 2 days. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral ptosis. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Ophthalmic examination shows periorbital edema and chemosis of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient most likely requires treatment with which of the following?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe right-sided temporal headache with conjunctival swelling and anterior bulging of the left eye for 1 hour. The patient has had right-sided purulent nasal discharge and nasal congestion for the past 2 days. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral ptosis. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Ophthalmic examination shows periorbital edema and chemosis of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient most likely requires treatment with which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with periorbital edema, chemosis, high fever, and dysfunction of CN III (bilateral ptosis) and CN VI (impaired lateral gaze) 2 days after the onset of sinusitis. These features suggest septic cavernous sinus thrombosis.
learning_objective: Recognize septic cavernous sinus thrombosis, and choose the appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Timolol, a topical beta-blocker, is recommended for the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Although this condition would also manifest with a unilateral headache and chemosis, the headache is usually frontal rather than temporal. Acute angle-closure glaucoma primarily affects older individuals and would also cause symptoms such as eye pain and blurred vision. Additionally, acute angle-closure glaucoma does not manifest with periorbital edema, lateral gaze restriction, bilateral ptosis, or fever.

Anticoagulants support the recanalization of the dural sinuses and prevent the formation of new thrombi, which decreases the risk of septic emboli. Although some studies have shown a reduction in mortality with the use of heparin, its use remains controversial because it increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications. Because it is difficult to achieve a stable drug level, oral warfarin is generally not recommended in the acute phase of this disease.

Oral clindamycin and amoxicillin are an empiric treatment option for preseptal cellulitis (periorbital cellulitis). In preseptal cellulitis, the infection is typically restricted anteriorly by the orbital septum and characterized by unilateral ocular pain with edema and erythema of the eyelid. As most cases of preseptal cellulitis stem from a contiguous skin infection, the orbit is not involved. This patient's ophthalmoplegia, bilateral ptosis, and high fever are not characteristic of preseptal cellulitis and are more concerning for a disseminated infection involving the orbit and paranasal sinuses, for which the combination of oral clindamycin and amoxicillin would not be appropriate.

images.title: Preseptal cellulitis
images.description: The left eyelid appears swollen and erythematous.These clinical features are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis, an inflammation of tissue anterior to the orbital septum.

answers.explanation_why: Intranasal sumatriptan is indicated for the treatment of cluster headaches and migraines. Either condition can manifest with a severe unilateral headache. However, typical features of a cluster headache include short recurring pain attacks (lasting only minutes) and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nonpurulent nasal discharge, facial sweating), which this patient lacks. As for migraines, patients commonly have nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, which are also not present here. Neither condition is associated with periorbital edema, chemosis, or fever.

Surgical debridement, along with amphotericin B, is the treatment of choice for mucormycosis, which can manifest with headache, nasal discharge, fever, erythema of the skin overlying the orbit, and cranial nerve palsies, which are seen here. However, this condition is seen almost exclusively in patients who are immunocompromised or diabetic, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, which this patient does not have. Most commonly, such patients develop a rhino-orbital-cerebral infection, which is characterized by the formation of a black eschar on the palate or nasal mucosa due to extensive local tissue necrosis. In septic cavernous sinus thrombosis, endonasal surgery (e.g., sphenoidectomy, ethmoidectomy, mastoidectomy) is only indicated if first-line treatment options are unsuccessful.

Antibiotic therapy is the mainstay of treatment for septic cavernous sinus thrombosis. Empiric therapy with vancomycin (for coverage of MRSA) should be combined with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefepime) and, if the infection originated from the sinus or the teeth, metronidazole (for anaerobic coverage). Affected patients should be treated with high-dose, prolonged antibiotic therapy to reach bacteria sequestered within thrombi. Antifungal therapy (amphotericin B) is indicated in confirmed cases of fungal origin.

IV dihydroergotamine is an alternative treatment option for the acute management of cluster headaches and migraines in patients who do not respond to the preferred treatment options. Either condition can manifest with a severe unilateral headache. However, typical features of a cluster headache include short recurring pain attacks (lasting only minutes) and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nonpurulent nasal discharge, facial sweating), which this patient lacks. As for migraines, patients commonly have nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, which are also not present here. Neither condition is associated with periorbital edema, chemosis, or fever.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in the left ear. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and Raynaud syndrome. Her current medications include metformin, nifedipine, and a multivitamin. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Immediately after the patient does not hear a tone, the tuning fork is held over the left ear and she reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the right side and shows a similar pattern. The vibration tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound louder in the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in the left ear. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and Raynaud syndrome. Her current medications include metformin, nifedipine, and a multivitamin. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Immediately after the patient does not hear a tone, the tuning fork is held over the left ear and she reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the right side and shows a similar pattern. The vibration tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound louder in the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A positive Rinne test (normal conductive hearing) in combination with a Weber test showing right-sided lateralization suggests unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (of the left ear).
learning_objective: Recognize an acoustic neuroma.

answers.explanation_why: Although meningiomas are usually asymptomatic, a tumor in the cerebellopontine angle could explain the patient's sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. However, meningiomas most frequently arise from the falx cerebri and other supratentorial regions, whereas only 10% occur in the cerebellopontine angle.
Progressive sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus in an older patient are the characteristic findings of presbycusis. However, both tinnitus and hearing loss are usually bilateral.

This patient has characteristic features of a left cerebellopontine tumor, including unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. The most common brain tumors in this location are acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas), which usually arise from Schwann cells in the internal auditory meatus and may expand into the cerebellopontine angle. Later symptoms include unilateral facial weakness (due to pressure on CN VII) and unilateral facial pain and/or paresthesia (due to pressure on CN V) as well as gait instability due to vestibular deficits. Further management includes audiometry and cranial MRI with contrast to confirm the tumor. For patients with large tumors or significant hearing loss, the treatment of choice is surgical removal or radiation therapy. For patients with smaller tumors and minimal hearing loss, observation with follow-up may be appropriate.

The presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas should raise suspicion for neurofibromatosis type II.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Improper ear care (e.g., use of cotton swabs) may precipitate the formation of cerumen plugs that block the auditory canal. Cerumen impaction typically manifests as sudden (e.g., triggered by showering or bathing) rather than progressive hearing loss. Unlike in this woman, the Rinne test would be abnormal (negative) in the affected ear and the Weber test would show a lateralization to the same ear, suggesting conductive rather than sensorineural hearing loss.

The typical triad of Meniere disease includes sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo, which usually last from minutes to hours and lead to a stepwise decline in hearing, rather than the constantly progressive hearing loss described in this vignette. Also, this patient does not have vertigo.

question_text: A 64-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department with right ear pain and difficulty hearing for 2 weeks. Over the last 5 days, he has also noticed discharge from his right ear. He does not recall the last time he saw a physician. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 153/92 mm Hg. He appears dirty and is malodorous. Physical examination shows mild facial asymmetry with the right corner of his mouth lagging behind the left when the patient smiles. He experiences severe ear pain when the right auricle is pulled superiorly. On otoscopic examination, there is granulation tissue at the transition between the cartilaginous and the osseous part of the ear canal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 64-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department with right ear pain and difficulty hearing for 2 weeks. Over the last 5 days, he has also noticed discharge from his right ear. He does not recall the last time he saw a physician. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 153/92 mm Hg. He appears dirty and is malodorous. Physical examination shows mild facial asymmetry with the right corner of his mouth lagging behind the left when the patient smiles. He experiences severe ear pain when the right auricle is pulled superiorly. On otoscopic examination, there is granulation tissue at the transition between the cartilaginous and the osseous part of the ear canal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Ear pain, otorrhea, hearing loss, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal are consistent with malignant otitis externa, which has most likely progressed to osteomyelitis of the temporal bone with systemic infection (indicated by fever, tachycardia, and facial nerve palsy).
learning_objective: Recognize malignant otitis externa, and recall the diagnostic finding indicative of the most likely underlying condition.

answers.content: Malignant epithelial growth of the external auditory canal
answers.explanation_why: Although malignant epithelial growth (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma) of the external auditory canal that has extended into the temporal bone can manifest with ear pain, this is a rare location for malignancy. Also, this patient's signs of systemic infection (fever and tachycardia), and the presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal suggest an infectious, not malignant, etiology.

Condylar degeneration (e.g., in temporomandibular joint disorder) can manifest with ear pain. However, this patient's findings suggest osteomyelitis of the skull (severe pain with ear movement and facial nerve palsy) that has progressed to systemic infection (fever and tachycardia). These findings, in addition to necrotizing granulation tissue in the ear canal, are inconsistent with condylar degeneration, as the condition is a noninfectious process that is localized to the temporomandibular joint itself.

Opacified mastoid air cells can be found in patients with acute or chronic infections of the sinus or middle ear. Since the middle ear communicates with the mastoid process, otitis media can result in opacification of these air cells. However, this patient likely has an infection of the external ear, which does not communicate directly with the mastoid process and is therefore not commonly associated with opacified mastoid air cells. The mastoid can be affected if the infection spreads from the temporal bone to adjacent bones, but a different finding is much more likely in malignant otitis externa.

images.title: Mastoiditis
images.description: Left retroauricular region of a childThere is pronounced erythema and swelling, with ventral protrusion of the pinna as a result of swelling. The features are typical of mastoiditis, which can occur as a complication of otitis media.

answers.explanation_why: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial cause of acute otitis media. Acute otitis media typically manifests with ear pain and fever, but more serious complications, such as osteomyelitis of the skull and cranial nerve palsies, are rare. Otoscopy in acute otitis media shows bulging of the tympanic membrane, not granulation tissue in the canal. Also, acute otitis media most commonly affects young children. This patient has malignant otitis externa, which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Older patients with diabetes (which manifests with an elevated HbA_1c) are at the greatest risk for developing malignant otitis externa. The specific connection between diabetes mellitus and malignant otitis externa is not fully understood, but may be related to increased pH in diabetic cerumen. Given the strong association between the two conditions, this patient most likely has diabetes. Also, the patient's lack of primary care access puts him at increased risk for the development of chronic diseases, like diabetes mellitus, and their complications.

Malignant otitis externa is a severe infection with significant mortality that is most commonly caused by P. aeruginosa. This patient should undergo imaging studies (CT scan and/or MRI) to identify bone destruction and to determine the extent of intracranial involvement. Following blood cultures, intravenous antibiotic therapy (preferably with two antipseudomonal agents) should be initiated. Surgical debridement is indicated only for abscess drainage and removal of bony sequestrum.

images.title: Otitis externa
images.description: There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.These findings are consistent with otitis externa.

question_text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of severe ear pain and yellow discharge from her left ear for the past 2 days. It is also mildly pruritic. The pain started during her last day of summer camp, where she spent a lot of time outdoors hiking, horseback riding, and swimming. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination shows tragal tenderness and a red and edematous external auditory canal. A diagnostic tuning fork is placed in the middle of the patient's forehead. The patient reports hearing the sound louder in the left ear. The tuning fork is then placed on the mastoid process of the left ear. Once she can no longer hear the sound, the tuning fork is placed in front of the auricle, and she reports no longer hearing the sound. On the right side, once the sound from the mastoid process subsides and the tuning fork is placed in front of the right ear, she reports hearing the sound again. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of severe ear pain and yellow discharge from her left ear for the past 2 days. It is also mildly pruritic. The pain started during her last day of summer camp, where she spent a lot of time outdoors hiking, horseback riding, and swimming. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination shows tragal tenderness and a red and edematous external auditory canal. A diagnostic tuning fork is placed in the middle of the patient's forehead. The patient reports hearing the sound louder in the left ear. The tuning fork is then placed on the mastoid process of the left ear. Once she can no longer hear the sound, the tuning fork is placed in front of the auricle, and she reports no longer hearing the sound. On the right side, once the sound from the mastoid process subsides and the tuning fork is placed in front of the right ear, she reports hearing the sound again. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: A Weber test that lateralizes to the affected ear (the left ear in this patient) in combination with a negative Rinne test in the same ear suggests conductive hearing loss. Ear pain, otorrhea, pruritus, and an edematous, reddened external auditory canal indicate that the cause of conductive hearing loss is otitis externa.
learning_objective: Recognize otitis externa, and recall its most common pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Infections of the external ear with Aspergillus or Candida are the most common causes of fungal otitis externa. Fungal infection of the external ear accounts for < 10% of otitis externa cases and is usually associated with concurrent antibiotic use. While patients may present with tragal discomfort and ear discharge, they usually have less severe ear edema, erythema, and pain than with the more common causes of otitis externa. In addition, intense ear itching is usually the primary symptom of fungal otitis externa.

Herpes zoster oticus is caused by infection of the external ear with the varicella zoster virus. Like otitis externa, it is associated with tragal tenderness. However, herpes zoster oticus typically manifests with blisters on the external ear, face, and mouth. Patients can present with vertigo, facial paralysis, tinnitus, and dysgeusia (loss of taste). Moreover, herpes zoster oticus is associated with sensorineural hearing loss rather than conductive hearing loss.

Streptococcus pneumoniae rarely infects the external ear, but it is a common cause of otitis media. While otitis media may also manifest with discharge from the ear and conductive hearing loss, tragal tenderness and ear canal edema are usually absent. Furthermore, otitis media tends to occur in winter months and is often associated with a history of cold and congestion.

Abnormal squamous epithelial growth leads to cholesteatoma, which is often asymptomatic. Although cholesteatoma may manifest with discharge from the ear and conductive hearing loss, this condition typically affects the middle ear and is not associated with tragal tenderness or external ear edema.

Most cases of otitis externa are caused by bacterial infection; Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common pathogen (∼ 40% of cases). Risk factors include increased moisture in the external auditory canal (e.g., from swimming) and/or injury to the overlying skin of the external auditory canal. Other causes of bacterial otitis externa include infection with Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Proteus mirabilis.

images.title: Otitis externa
images.description: There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.These findings are consistent with otitis externa.

answers.explanation_why: Otosclerosis involves a pleomorphic replacement of normal bone and leads to progressive conductive hearing loss in adults. However, this condition is not associated with tragal tenderness, external ear edema, or discharge from the ear.

question_text: Following the patient's third episode of otitis externa this summer, her parents ask whether there is anything they can do to prevent the further recurrence of this condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?
content_preview: Following the patient's third episode of otitis externa this summer, her parents ask whether there is anything they can do to prevent the further recurrence of this condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?
hint: Prevention of recurrent otitis externa in children emphasizes aural hygiene, which includes keeping the auricle and external auditory canal clean and dry.
learning_objective: Recognize prevention strategies for recurrent otitis externa, and choose the most appropriate recommendation after swimming activities.

answers.content: Application of alcohol-based ear drops after swimming activities
answers.explanation_why: Application of acetic acid and/or alcohol-based ear drops helps to dry the ear and reacidify the ear canal. Patients who engage in frequent water activities are at increased risk for recurrent episodes of otitis externa; protecting the ears by keeping the auricle and external auditory canal clean and dry is the most effective prevention strategy. Other measures to prevent recurrence include carefully blow-drying the ear, wearing a bathing cap during water activities, treatment of underlying dermatological disorders, and avoiding manipulation of the ear canal.

answers.content: Remove cerumen from the ear canal regularly
answers.explanation_why: The removal of cerumen from the ear canal may be indicated to acutely evaluate and treat otitis externa. However, cerumen should only be removed by a healthcare provider to prevent damaging the ear and making it more vulnerable to infection. Patients should be counseled not to remove cerumen because it helps protect the ear canal from infection.

answers.content: Oral use of ciprofloxacin prior to swimming activities
answers.explanation_why: Oral ciprofloxacin is used to treat severe otitis externa, otitis externa in patients at risk of developing complications (e.g., immunosuppressed patients, patients with diabetes mellitus), and in patients in whom topical treatment is not possible. This patient is not presenting with any symptoms concerning for severe otitis externa and does not have any conditions that would necessitate oral treatment. Moreover, oral antibiotics are not used to prevent recurrent otitis externa.

answers.content: Topical use of hydrocortisone cream after swimming activities
answers.explanation_why: Hydrocortisone can be used after swimming to prevent the recurrence of otitis externa when combined with alcohol solutions, and as an acute treatment for edema and inflammation. However, in both instances, drops are used rather than creams, which increase moisture retention. The key to the prevention of recurrent episodes of otitis externa is keeping the ear canal clean and dry, so cream formulations are not recommended.

answers.content: Application of antibiotic ear drops after swimming activities
answers.explanation_why: Antibiotic ear drops are used to treat acute otitis externa; however, they are not helpful in preventing recurrent episodes. The antibiotics typically used in acute treatment are ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, or neomycin.

answers.content: Limit swimming activities to a maximum of 1x/week
answers.explanation_why: Limiting swimming activities can be considered for patients with acute otitis externa, but measures that limit the patient's social and physical activities are not the first line for prevention of recurrence of this condition. Ear hygiene measures are effective in reducing the risk of recurrence, so other preventative strategies should be tried first.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician with a 2-day history of fever, chills, malaise, and a sore throat. He has been otherwise healthy and receives no medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.4°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 121/71 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Examination shows discrete 1-2-mm papulovesicular lesions on the posterior oropharynx and general erythema of the tonsils bilaterally. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician with a 2-day history of fever, chills, malaise, and a sore throat. He has been otherwise healthy and receives no medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.4°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 121/71 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Examination shows discrete 1-2-mm papulovesicular lesions on the posterior oropharynx and general erythema of the tonsils bilaterally. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the cause of this patient's findings?
hint: Abrupt-onset fever, sore throat, and multiple 1-mm papules and vesicles on the posterior oropharynx and tonsils are consistent with herpangina.
learning_objective: Recognize hand, foot, and mouth disease.

answers.explanation_why: Rheumatic fever is associated with group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection, which also causes acute tonsillopharyngitis (strep throat). GAS tonsillitis is a common cause of acute tonsillopharyngitis in children between the ages of 5–15 years. As in this case, the first manifestations of GAS tonsillitis are fever, sore throat, and pharyngeal redness. However, papulovesicular lesions in the posterior pharynx are not consistent with this diagnosis. Tonsillar exudate and swollen, tender cervical lymph nodes would be expected instead.

images.title: Acute tonsillitis
images.description: Oropharynx of a child presenting with fever and sore throatThe tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and yellow-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).

answers.explanation_why: Condylomata lata is a typical manifestation of secondary syphilis (i.e., infection with Treponema pallidum). The primary lesions of syphilis (chancres) are usually found in the anogenital area but may also appear in the posterior pharynx. Pharyngeal syphilis usually manifests with papules in the oral cavity that develop into painless ulcers. While early stages are often asymptomatic, some patients may complain of a sore throat. However, infection with T. pallidum in children most commonly occurs via sexual contact or vertical transmission from mother to child (i.e., during pregnancy or at birth) and is therefore unlikely in this 7-year-old boy.

Burkitt lymphoma is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which also causes infectious mononucleosis (IM). IM may manifest with acute fever, malaise, and tonsillopharyngitis. However, patients would usually have reddened, enlarged tonsils with white and grey deposits rather than papulovesicular lesions. Additionally, generalized lymphadenopathy and/or hepatosplenomegaly can occur and last up to a month. While IM is most commonly seen in individuals 15–24 years of age, EBV infection is often asymptomatic in younger children.

images.title: Membranous tonsillitis
images.description: Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

answers.explanation_why: Infective endocarditis may be caused by Viridans streptococci, which, together with anaerobes, is responsible for Ludwig's angina (LA). Although LA may occur in children, it is more common in young adults following odontogenic infections. It is characterized by rapidly progressing bilateral cellulitis of the neck and submandibular space. While fever and oropharyngeal erythema support the diagnosis, additional complaints (e.g., mouth pain, stiff neck, difficulty swallowing), as well as an elevated/protruding tongue, and submandibular swelling, would be expected in LA. This child's oropharyngeal lesions cannot be explained by this diagnosis.

Herpetic whitlow is a common complication of herpetic gingivostomatitis, especially in young children (due to thumb sucking) and healthcare workers exposed to oral secretions (e.g., dentists). Both conditions are usually caused by herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1). Although herpetic gingivostomatitis also presents with fever, sore throat, pharyngeal redness, and multiple small vesicles, the oral lesions are typically located in the anterior pharynx and the lips, not the posterior pharynx. Moreover, it most commonly affects children 1–5 years of age.

images.title: Herpetic gingivostomatitis
images.description: Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

answers.explanation_why: Herpangina is most common in children between the ages of 3–10 years and infections occur most frequently in summer and fall. As in this case, the first manifestations of the disease are usually oropharyngeal lesions and a sore throat. Coxsackie A virus is the most common underlying pathogen, which also causes hand, foot, and mouth disease. The two conditions often occur concomitantly.

images.title: Herpangina
images.description: Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.

question_text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a dull persistent headache that began this morning. He has nausea and has vomited twice. Over the past four days, the patient has had left-sided ear pain and fever, but his parents did not seek medical attention. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 45^th percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 69/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Otoscopy of the left ear shows an erythematous bulging tympanic membrane. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a dull persistent headache that began this morning. He has nausea and has vomited twice. Over the past four days, the patient has had left-sided ear pain and fever, but his parents did not seek medical attention. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 45th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 69/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Otoscopy of the left ear shows an erythematous bulging tympanic membrane. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Headache, vomiting, and a focal neurological deficit (abducens nerve palsy) are consistent with increased intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to an intracranial abscess, most likely as a complication of acute otitis media (AOM).
learning_objective: Recognize intracranial abscess secondary to acute otitis media, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Clindamycin and cefazolin are not appropriate antibiotics for treating suspected intracranial infection because they have relatively poor CNS penetration. Metronidazole and ceftriaxone are typically used instead. Moreover, antibiotic therapy without prior surgical intervention is insufficient for the treatment of most brain abscesses because antibiotics cannot effectively penetrate the abscess cavity.

Myringotomy is not routinely indicated for AOM and is only considered if the patient has recurrent or treatment-refractory AOM or chronic otitis media. Moreover, this procedure is not the most important initial step in the management of a patient with features that suggest an intracranial abscess.

images.title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
images.description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with suspected intracranial abscess should promptly undergo cranial imaging with a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI to identify the size, location, and number of abscesses to guide further management. Treatment of an intracranial abscess consists of urgent abscess evacuation to decompress the cranial cavity and identify causative pathogens. Patients should also be given early empiric antibiotic therapy with metronidazole and ceftriaxone, and vancomycin should be added if a staphylococcal infection is suspected. Antibiotic therapy alone may be attempted in rare instances when the brain abscess is small (< 2.5 cm), uncomplicated, and has a known pathogen.

images.title: Brain lesion
images.description: Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

answers.explanation_why:
Aspiration of the abscess through a burr hole is often the definitive treatment for an intracranial abscess but before performing this procedure, more information should be obtained on the size, location, and number of the intracranial abscesses to guide management and trajectory planning for the burr hole procedure.

A secondary decompressive craniectomy, which involves creating burr holes without trajectory planning, is only performed if the patient has increased ICP that is refractory to treatment of the underlying cause as well as subsequent medical therapy (e.g., controlled hyperventilation, hyperosmolar solutions).

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with features of elevated ICP because of the risk of brain herniation. Moreover, cerebrospinal fluid analysis is often normal in patients with an intracranial abscess and only shows abnormal findings if the abscess ruptures into the ventricular system or if the patient has concomitant meningitis or encephalitis. A different diagnostic step is much more important for this patient.

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a progressive swelling of her neck for the past 6 months. She has no pain, dyspnea, or dysphagia. She is at the 60th percentile for height and the 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm cystic, nontender swelling in the midline of the neck. The swelling moves upwards with protrusion of the tongue. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.1 μU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a progressive swelling of her neck for the past 6 months. She has no pain, dyspnea, or dysphagia. She is at the 60th percentile for height and the 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm cystic, nontender swelling in the midline of the neck. The swelling moves upwards with protrusion of the tongue. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.1 μU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A nontender cystic midline swelling that moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue indicates a thyroglossal duct cyst.
learning_objective: Recognize thyroglossal duct cyst, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: While fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) may help confirm the diagnosis of a thyroglossal duct cyst or exclude differential diagnoses, other noninvasive modalities are preferred. FNA may, however, be performed in an infected thyroglossal duct cyst to obtain samples for Gram stain and culture.

answers.content: Excision of the cyst, track, and hyoid bone
answers.explanation_why: The Sistrunk procedure involves excision of the cyst, a portion of the hyoid bone, and the descending track originating from the foramen cecum and is the standard surgical treatment for thyroglossal duct cysts. This procedure is associated with the lowest risk of recurrence as compared to less extensive resections. Although early surgical excision is recommended to prevent infection of the thyroglossal duct cyst, confirmation of the diagnosis and exclusion of the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue should occur first.

This patient should first undergo ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis and location of the thyroid and localize possible ectopic thyroid tissue, which is often present in patients with thyroglossal duct cyst. As this ectopic tissue may be the patient's only functional thyroid tissue, ultrasonography should first be performed to evaluate the cyst architecture and its location in relation to functional ectopic or orthotopic thyroid tissue, to ensure that surgical excision of the cyst will not result in postoperative hypothyroidism. Thyroid function testing may be normal even if ectopic thyroid tissue is the only functioning tissue, but it may be useful if the thyroid gland has an abnormal appearance or is not visualized on ultrasound.

images.title: Thyroglossal duct cyst
images.description: Neck ultrasound (transverse section)A circular, sharply demarcated, hypoechoic lesion (green overlay) is visible dorsal to the thyroid gland.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan would detect the cyst and provide valuable information for planning the surgery, but it would also expose the child to radiation. There are other sensitive imaging modalities that allow exposure to radiation to be avoided. A CT of the neck with contrast is often the preferred imaging modality for evaluating thyroglossal duct cyst in adults. It is also recommended in the evaluation of a suspected neck malignancy or a retropharyngeal or deep neck abscess.

images.title: Thyroglossal duct cyst
images.description: CT head (without contrast; a: axial plane; b: sagittal plane)A hypodense mass (green overlay) with a fluid density value (mean 20 HU) is present anterior to the hyoid bone (arrows).

answers.explanation_why: Simple excision of the thyroglossal duct cysts is not the preferred approach to removal due to the high risk of recurrence. However, prior to any surgical intervention, the diagnosis should be confirmed and the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue excluded.

While thyroid scintigraphy can be used to rule out ectopic thyroid tissue, it is unnecessary to perform if the imaging method of choice reveals normal thyroid architecture and thyroid function testing is normal. Additionally, exposing children to radionuclide material should be avoided, if possible.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive swelling in her mouth that she first noticed 5 years ago. The swelling was initially asymptomatic, but over the past month it has caused some difficulty chewing. She appears well and has no pain. She has not undergone any dental procedures in the past 5 years. She has bronchial asthma. Her only medication is an albuterol inhaler. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 1.5-cm unilobular, bony hard, nontender mass with a smooth surface located in the midline of the hard palate. There is no cervical or submandibular lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive swelling in her mouth that she first noticed 5 years ago. The swelling was initially asymptomatic, but over the past month it has caused some difficulty chewing. She appears well and has no pain. She has not undergone any dental procedures in the past 5 years. She has bronchial asthma. Her only medication is an albuterol inhaler. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 1.5-cm unilobular, bony hard, nontender mass with a smooth surface located in the midline of the hard palate. There is no cervical or submandibular lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's findings are consistent with a common type of benign bony overgrowth.
learning_objective: Recognize torus palatinus.

answers.explanation_why: The hyperplastic type of candidiasis may manifest as a palpable nodule on the oral mucosa. However, it is usually a white lesion with a rough surface and most commonly occurs on the inside of the cheeks or on the sides of the tongue, rather than the palate.

Pleomorphic adenoma usually manifests as a painless, firm mass and may involve the minor salivary glands of the palate. However, the tumor would not be bony hard on palpation. It most commonly develops in patients 40–60 years of age with a history of ionizing radiation or environmental/occupational exposure (e.g., rubber manufacturing, cosmetologists, nickel compound exposure), and is, therefore, less likely in this young patient without any risk factors.

images.title: Pleomorphic adenoma
images.description: Oral cavity of a patient, ventral view: A protrusion of the left lateral wall of the pharynx can be seen. Further diagnostics performed on the patient confirmed a pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland, which expanded into the parapharyngeal space.

answers.explanation_why: Although necrotizing sialometaplasia may manifest as a palatal lesion, the lesion is usually concave and ulcerated. In addition, it most commonly affects patients around 50 years of age and is, therefore, less likely in this young woman.

A nasopalatine duct cyst may manifest as a midline palatal mass, most commonly in patients aged 30–60 years. However, the mass is usually fluctuant rather than bony hard, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

An abscess of the oral cavity is most commonly caused by the spread of an odontogenic infection. Although a palatal abscess commonly manifests as a localized swelling lateral or in the midline of the palate, it is usually fluctuant and painful rather than bony hard and nontender.

The presence of a bony hard, nontender mass in the midline of the hard palate is consistent with torus palatinus, a benign bone tumor that most commonly occurs in adolescents or young adults. The overgrowth is typically asymptomatic, but it may lead to difficulties with chewing food or speaking once it reaches a certain size. The diagnosis of torus palatinus is usually made based on clinical presentation. Surgical removal should be considered if the mass interferes with speech or eating.

images.title: Torus palatinus
images.description: A bony protrusion covered with normal mucosa is visible as a bump in the midline of the hard palate.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is in a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate (CICV) scenario with increasing hypoxemia.
learning_objective: Recognize a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario, and choose the most appropriate emergency airway management.

answers.explanation_why: Video laryngoscopy allows for visualization of the oropharynx and is commonly used to facilitate orotracheal intubation in patients with a difficult airway. Although video laryngoscopy could have been used earlier in the management of this patient, several intubation attempts have been unsuccessful. Furthermore, his oxygen saturation is acutely dropping despite attempts at maintaining ventilation and oxygenation through bag-valve and laryngeal masks. If establishing an alternative airway via video laryngoscopy is unsuccessful, hypoxic brain injury may occur. Another step is more appropriate in an emergency setting.

This patient has just suffered major trauma, and his preferred code status is unknown. It would be highly inappropriate to change his code status to comfort measures only in the absence of an advance directive, a health care proxy, and before all possible treatment modalities have been exhausted.

Although an emergency tracheostomy may be performed in a CICV scenario, this approach is usually not the first-line option because it is more complex and time-consuming, and causes more bleeding than other emergency surgical airway procedures.

A nasotracheal approach can be attempted to achieve intubation in patients with a difficult airway and limited oral access (e.g., due to oropharyngeal obstruction). However, this technique is usually performed electively in the operating room under direct visualization of the pharynx with laryngoscopy. Nasopharyngeal intubation is time-consuming and is therefore inappropriate in a CICV scenario with declining oxygen saturation, which requires an emergency airway.

This patient has just experienced major trauma and presents with signs of respiratory distress (respiratory rate of 10/min, oxygen saturation of 84%), neurological compromise (lethargy, sluggish pupils), and a compromised airway (decreased breath sounds over left hemithorax, rapid decrease in oxygen saturation). After unsuccessful attempts at securing the airway and ventilation via orotracheal intubation, laryngeal mask placement, and bag-mask ventilation, immediate action is required to prevent hypoxia. A surgical airway with cricothyrotomy should be established in patients who cannot be intubated and oxygenated. Cricothyrotomy is the preferred method in an emergency when rapid airway control is needed, especially in cases where intubation is unsuccessful, and other supraglottic airway devices are ineffective.

images.title: Cricothyroidotomy
images.description: Diagram showing an emergency cricothyroidotomy, which is typically performed if attempts to intubate have been unsuccessful. An incision is made through the cricothyroid membrane, and a cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted through the incision site. Cricothyroidotomy allows ventilation of the patient until a more definitive airway is placed.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of sore throat for the past 2 days. During this period, he has had intermittent nausea and has vomited once. The patient has no cough, hoarseness, or rhinorrhea. He had similar symptoms at the age of 5 years that resolved spontaneously. He is otherwise healthy. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Head and neck examination shows an erythematous pharynx with grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. There is no lymphadenopathy. A rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococcus is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of sore throat for the past 2 days. During this period, he has had intermittent nausea and has vomited once. The patient has no cough, hoarseness, or rhinorrhea. He had similar symptoms at the age of 5 years that resolved spontaneously. He is otherwise healthy. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Head and neck examination shows an erythematous pharynx with grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. There is no lymphadenopathy. A rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococcus is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This child presents with a sore throat and grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils, which is suggestive of acute tonsillitis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute tonsillitis with a negative rapid strep test, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the infection.

answers.explanation_why: Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer measurement is part of the workup for sequelae of streptococcal infection (e.g., rheumatic fever). ASO titer is not useful in diagnosing acute streptococcal infection because antibody levels take about 2 weeks to rise, and do not peak until 3–5 weeks after infection; antibody levels reflect past, rather than current infections. This patient has only been symptomatic for 2 days, therefore an ASO titer would likely be negative, even if his symptoms were due to streptococcal infection.

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated for patients with typical symptoms of viral tonsillitis (e.g., rhinorrhea, oral ulcers, hoarse voice, and/or cough). This patient has a nonspecific presentation that requires further testing to rule out bacterial tonsillitis. If left untreated, bacterial tonsillitis increases the risk of rheumatic fever, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, and the spread of infection (e.g., peritonsillar abscess).

answers.content: Measurement of antiviral capsid antigen IgM antibody
answers.explanation_why: Measurement of antiviral capsid antigen IgM antibodies is used as a confirmatory test in patients with clinical suspicion of infectious mononucleosis. While patients with IM often have tonsillitis/pharyngitis, this patient lacks further symptoms such as cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly. Moreover, symptoms typically occur in adolescents and young adults.

Penicillin V is the treatment of choice for patients with acute group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and no penicillin allergy. However, this patient requires further testing before antibiotic treatment is indicated. The American College of Physicians recommends empiric antibiotics in patients with a modified Centor score of ≥ 4. This patient's score is 3 (< 15 years of age, tonsillar exudates and swelling, no cough). The Infectious Diseases Society of America and The American Academy of Pediatrics recommend treatment only in patients with confirmed group A streptococcal pharyngitis. In patients with penicillin allergy, macrolides like clarithromycin or azithromycin are first-line options.

This patient has acute tonsillitis with no specific signs of viral illness (e.g., conjunctivitis, hoarseness, cough, stomatitis). The gold standard for diagnosing bacterial tonsillitis is a throat culture, which can identify the underlying pathogen and determine its antibiotic sensitivity. The rapid strep antigen test has poor sensitivity but high specificity. Children and adolescents with a negative rapid strep test should have a throat culture to rule out bacterial infection; up to 30% of infections are missed with rapid antigen detection testing. If the rapid strep antigen test is positive, antibiotic therapy can be started without confirmatory throat culture. If bacterial infection is ruled out (i.e., both antigen testing and culture are negative), observation and symptomatic management (e.g., acetaminophen, NSAIDs) are indicated.

question_text:
An obese  52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 8 hours. Two months ago, he noticed a mass on the right side of his neck and was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 27 years. He drinks two pints of rum daily. He appears ill. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Examination shows a 9-cm, tender, firm subglottic mass on the right side of the neck. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. His breathing is labored and he has audible inspiratory stridor but is able to answer questions. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.36

P_CO2
45 mm Hg

P_O2

74 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

He has no advanced directive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An obese 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 8 hours. Two months ago, he noticed a mass on the right side of his neck and was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 27 years. He drinks two pints of rum daily. He appears ill. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Examination shows a 9-cm, tender, firm subglottic mass on the right side of the neck. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. His breathing is labored and he has audible inspiratory stridor but is able to answer questions. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.36 PCO2 45 mm Hg PO2 74 mm Hg HCO3- 25 mEq/L He has no advanced directive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has untreated laryngeal carcinoma and presents with respiratory distress with stridor and respiratory acidosis.
learning_objective: Recognize laryngeal carcinoma causing respiratory distress, and choose the most appropriate airway management.

answers.explanation_why: A tracheal stent may be used to maintain tracheal patency following surgical resection of this patient's laryngeal cancer. Tracheal stents do not provide a controlled airway and are not used to treat acute respiratory distress.

Tracheostomy is indicated in patients who will require long-term mechanical ventilation and/or in patients with upper airway obstruction causing respiratory distress. This patient will likely need long-term airway management while his laryngeal cancer is managed. Therefore, (percutaneous or open) tracheostomy is the preferred intervention because it will provide an airway that bypasses the tumor and can be used for long-term mechanical ventilation. Although endotracheal intubation would correct this patient's acute respiratory distress, it is not appropriate for long-term airway management (i.e., > 3 weeks), because of the associated risk of complications (e.g., tracheal stenosis, subglottic mass). If this patient were endotracheally intubated, he would eventually need a tracheostomy.

Intramuscular epinephrine is used for acute airway compromise due to anaphylaxis. This patient has not been exposed to a trigger for anaphylaxis (e.g., medication, food allergy, insect bite), however, and he lacks other symptoms of anaphylaxis (e.g., urticaria, itching, angioedema).

Comfort care measures may be appropriate later on in the management of this patient's cancer, if further care is deemed futile or he requests palliative care. However, this patient presents with acute respiratory distress and has no advanced directive, so treatment is indicated.

Cricothyroidotomy is indicated in patients who require emergency temporary airway management and cannot be intubated (e.g., contraindication or failure of endotracheal intubation). While this patient requires urgent airway management, he is conscious, responsive, and hemodynamically stable. Furthermore, he will likely need long-term (> 3 weeks) mechanical ventilation given the chronic nature of his airway obstruction and cricothyroidotomy is not indicated for long-term mechanical ventilation. Finally, because this patient's laryngeal mass is in the subglottic region (i.e., the area where an endotracheal tube would be inserted in a cricothyroidotomy), a cricothyroidotomy is contraindicated.
