question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of throat pain and increasing difficulty swallowing food for the past 5 months. He has also had episodic left ear pain for the past 3 months. He has hypertension. His only medication is amlodipine. His father died of laryngeal cancer at the age of 55 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. He drinks 2–3 beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows left cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows a 3-cm ulcerating left tonsillar mass. Examination of both auditory canals is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of throat pain and increasing difficulty swallowing food for the past 5 months. He has also had episodic left ear pain for the past 3 months. He has hypertension. His only medication is amlodipine. His father died of laryngeal cancer at the age of 55 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. He drinks 2–3 beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows left cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows a 3-cm ulcerating left tonsillar mass. Examination of both auditory canals is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: An ulcerating tonsillar mass and cervical lymphadenopathy in a heavy smoker raise concern for oropharyngeal cancer, in particular squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
learning_objective: Recognize suspected oropharyngeal cancer, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Esophagoscopy would be used to assess for any concurrent masses in the esophagus. However, it would not help further evaluate this patient's tonsillar mass. Other potential primary sites of SCC should be identified as well, but these may not be limited to the esophagus.

Nasopharyngoscopy would help further evaluate this patient's tonsillar mass and assess for other nasopharyngeal masses. However, it would not help identify other potential primary sites of cancer outside of the nasopharynx.

Panendoscopy allows for comprehensive evaluation of the entire upper airway and digestive tract and is indicated in all patients with suspected oropharyngeal cancer and a high risk for second primary tumors (e.g., due to heavy smoking, family history of oral cancer). Biopsies of any masses would also be taken during or following the panendoscopy for histological evaluation.

images.title: Tonsillar cancer
images.description: Exophytic lesion of the left tonsil

answers.explanation_why: A barium swallow is used to evaluate gastroesophageal reflux, assess a fistula or hiatal hernia, or identify the cause of persistent vomiting or dysphagia. However, the cause of this patient's dysphagia has already been identified (a tonsillar mass). As this patient has cervical lymphadenopathy and known risk factors for oropharyngeal SCC, further workup of the tonsillar mass and assessment for other masses in the head and neck region are indicated.
Laryngoscopy would help assess any concurrent masses in the larynx, but it would not allow for evaluation of this patient's tonsillar mass nor any other potential primary sites outside of the larynx.

question_text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a whistling sound during respiration for the past 3 weeks. He reports that the whistling is becoming louder, and is especially loud when he exercises. He says the noise is frustrating for him. Two months ago, the patient underwent outpatient treatment for an uncomplicated nasal fracture after being hit in the nose by a high-velocity stray baseball. Since the accident, the patient has been taking aspirin for pain. He has a history of asymptomatic nasal polyps. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following would have prevented the whistling during respiration?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a whistling sound during respiration for the past 3 weeks. He reports that the whistling is becoming louder, and is especially loud when he exercises. He says the noise is frustrating for him. Two months ago, the patient underwent outpatient treatment for an uncomplicated nasal fracture after being hit in the nose by a high-velocity stray baseball. Since the accident, the patient has been taking aspirin for pain. He has a history of asymptomatic nasal polyps. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following would have prevented the whistling during respiration?
hint: This patient presents with a nasal whistling sound 2 months after sustaining a nasal fracture, suggesting nasal septal perforation.
learning_objective: Recognize nasal septal perforation due to untreated hematoma, and choose the appropriate preventive measure.

answers.explanation_why:
Nasal septal perforation may develop as a sequela of septal hematoma secondary to a nasal fracture. The hematoma disrupts blood flow to the septal cartilage, resulting in ischemia, necrosis, and subsequent perforation. Analgesics with antiplatelet activity such as aspirin should be avoided 48 hours after nasal trauma or surgery as they may precipitate the development of septal hematoma. This patient's prolonged pain after nasal injury may also be a sign of complications such as nasal hematoma and perforation. If a nasal septal hematoma is present, aspiration and drainage should be performed immediately to reduce pressure on the cartilage and prevent complications.

Whistling typically resolves with the placement of a silicone button prosthesis.

images.title: Hematoma of the nasal septum
images.description: Bilateral, firm, balloon-like swelling of the nasal mucosa.

answers.explanation_why: Although the patient has a history of nasal polyps, polyp resection is unlikely to have prevented the whistling. Surgical removal of nasal polyps is only indicated if the patient is symptomatic and a trial with topical or systemic glucocorticoids is unsuccessful. Symptomatic nasal polyps typically manifest with a postnasal drip, bilateral nasal obstruction, and frequently hyposmia or anosmia; their presence is not associated with a whistling sound.

images.title: Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane) of patient with history of asthmaExtensive soft tissue opacification of the ethmoid sinuses (E; outline) and nasal cavity (NC; outline) shows some lobulation (black arrowhead) and evidence of bony erosion (dashed outline). Lobulated soft tissue is also present along the maxillary sinus walls (white arrowheads).

answers.explanation_why: Antibiotic therapy in combination with incision and drainage is indicated in patients with septal abscess. A septal abscess most commonly develops secondary to a septal hematoma (e.g., due to a facial trauma, as seen in this patient) and can also lead to septal perforation. However, septal abscess is a rare complication of nasal injury and would usually manifest with nasal swelling and obstruction, which this patient does not report.

Rhinoplasty may be performed for aesthetic or functional reasons, such as obstructed breathing due to congenital nasal deformities or trauma. However, rhinoplasty is not indicated for the prevention of nasal septal perforation and may even cause the condition if septal hematoma occurs postoperatively.

Septoplasty is indicated to correct nasal septum deviation in patients with pronounced clinical findings such as difficulty breathing, headaches, or facial pain. Septoplasty is also used in the treatment of nasal septal perforation, but it is not used in the prevention thereof. As septoplasty may precipitate the development of septal hematoma, it can in fact contribute to subsequent septal perforation.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of an increasing right-sided cheek swelling for 2 years. He has had recurrent right-sided oral ulcers for the past 2 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks a beer every night. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/83 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the right jaw. There is no overlying erythema or induration. There are multiple shallow ulcers on the right buccal mucosa and mandibular marginal gingiva. There is no lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound shows a soft tissue mass in the parotid gland. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A right-sided total parotidectomy is scheduled. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following early complications?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of an increasing right-sided cheek swelling for 2 years. He has had recurrent right-sided oral ulcers for the past 2 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks a beer every night. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/83 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the right jaw. There is no overlying erythema or induration. There are multiple shallow ulcers on the right buccal mucosa and mandibular marginal gingiva. There is no lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound shows a soft tissue mass in the parotid gland. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A right-sided total parotidectomy is scheduled. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following early complications?
hint: The facial nerve runs through the parotid gland and is most likely to be damaged during a total parotidectomy.
learning_objective: Recognize parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma, and recall complications of parotidectomy.

answers.content: Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe
answers.explanation_why: The sensation of the ear lobe is provided by the greater auricular nerve. Hypoesthesia, not hyperesthesia, of the greater auricular nerve is a common complication of parotidectomy due to nerve transection during surgery.

Hyperacusis can be a symptom of facial nerve dysfunction (e.g., Bell palsy) due to consequent weakness of the stapedius muscle. The nerve to the stapedius branches off from the facial nerve before the facial nerve exits the skull, which means that stapedius dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

The parotid gland produces ∼ 40% of the saliva and is stimulated by eating. The total amount of saliva is therefore likely to be slightly decreased after parotidectomy. However, given the continued production of saliva from the remaining salivary glands, xerostomia is not a common complication of the procedure.

answers.content: Paralysis of the right lower lip
answers.explanation_why:
Facial nerve palsy is the most common early complication of parotidectomy, and the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve, which provides motor control of the lower lip, is one of the most commonly injured branches of the facial nerve. Most cases of post-parotidectomy facial nerve palsy resolve within one month.

Because parotid adenoid cystic carcinomas of the parotid gland grow along nerve sheaths, the facial nerve cannot always be preserved during parotidectomy.

images.title: Examination findings in facial nerve palsy
images.description: Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

answers.content: Impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
answers.explanation_why:
Taste and sensation in the posterior third of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve. Glossopharyngeal nerve damage is not a complication of parotidectomy.

The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve is responsible for taste of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, it joins the facial nerve inside the facial canal (thus inside the skull), which means that chorda tympani dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

answers.content: Flushing and sweating of the right cheek while eating
answers.explanation_why: Flushing and sweating of the cheek while eating is characteristic of Frey syndrome, which is a common complication of parotidectomy that results in surgical injury of parasympathetic nerve fibers. However, Frey syndrome manifests late (up to one year after surgery) because of the slow regeneration of the affected parasympathetic fibers and is thus unlikely to cause symptoms earlier than one month after surgery.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is unable to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. This patient should be counseled that she is at greatest risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is unable to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. This patient should be counseled that she is at greatest risk for which of the following?
hint: Hearing loss and impaired balance in combination with tumors in the cerebellopontine angles raise concern for acoustic neuromas. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
learning_objective: Recognize neurofibromatosis type 2, and recall its associated nervous system tumors.

answers.explanation_why:
In addition to bilateral acoustic neuromas, which occur in almost all individuals with NF2 by the age of 30 years, NF2 can cause multiple tumors of the nervous system, such as intracranial and spinal meningiomas, schwannomas of other cranial nerves, and ependymomas. Most meningiomas are slow-growing and patients may therefore be asymptomatic for a prolonged period of time. If symptoms do occur, they usually include general symptoms of CNS tumors (e.g., seizures) or more specific symptoms that are determined by the location of the tumor (e.g., paraparesis and/or uncontrolled micturition if the tumor arises from the falx cerebri). Other typical clinical findings of NF2 include early-onset bilateral cataracts, seizures, skin nodules, and café au lait spots (see “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table).

The clinical features of acoustic neuromas are caused by compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) as a result of the tumor expanding into the internal acoustic meatus. Sensorineural hearing loss, which is the most common presenting symptom, and tinnitus are due to cochlear nerve involvement, whereas dizziness, unsteady gait, and disequilibrium indicate vestibular nerve involvement.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why: Optic gliomas are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Other tumors that may occur in patients with NF1 include benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors originating from neural crest cells (neurofibromas), pheochromocytomas, and nephroblastomas. The presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas, however, is not associated with NF1. Moreover, patients with NF1 usually present with typical skin findings (due to melanocyte dysfunction) such as café au lait spots and axillary/inguinal freckling, as well as musculoskeletal findings (e.g., scoliosis, tall stature, and bone involvement) and Lisch nodules of the iris, none of which are seen in this patient.

Telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae are typical findings in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Other manifestations include progressive cerebellar ataxia (due to atrophy of the cerebellar vermis), athetosis, immunodeficiency (e.g., increased susceptibility to ear infections, sinusitis, and pneumonia), and increased sensitivity to radiation resulting in a higher risk of malignancies (e.g. non-Hodgkin lymphoma, leukemia). However, the finding of bilateral acoustic neuromas is not typical in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Furthermore, symptoms typically manifest during early childhood.

Vascular malformations of the choroid and the central nervous system such as ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas are a typical feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome. These malformations may result in seizures, early-onset glaucoma (due to increased intraorbital pressure), and intellectual disability. Patients also often present with a facial nevus flammeus (port-wine stain). However, acoustic neuromas are not associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

images.title: Sturge-Weber syndrome
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with Sturge-Weber syndromeMarked, leptomeningeal contrast enhancement along the right parieto-occipital gyri and sulci can be seen (green overlay).

answers.explanation_why: The occurrence of (bilateral) renal cell carcinoma is associated with von Hippel‑Lindau disease. This neurocutaneous syndrome is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors, including hemangioblastomas (highly vascularized in the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine), pheochromocytomas, and renal and pancreatic cysts. Bilateral acoustic neuromas, however, are not a typical feature.

Giant cell astrocytomas are frequently associated with tuberous sclerosis. Other benign growths that frequently manifest in patients with tuberous sclerosis include hamartomas of the brain, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal cysts, renal angiomyolipomas, and ungual fibromas. The brain lesions typically result in infantile spasms (head bobbing, flexor or extensor spasms in children < 3 years of age), seizures, and intellectual disability. Furthermore, skin manifestations, such as adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, and a Shagreen patch are commonly seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis. However, acoustic neuromas are not a feature of tuberous sclerosis and the condition is usually diagnosed before the age of 10.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month. The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes, she feels as though she is spinning. Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position. They also sometimes happen when she suddenly turns her head to look at something. She has no nausea. Last month, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month. The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes, she feels as though she is spinning. Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position. They also sometimes happen when she suddenly turns her head to look at something. She has no nausea. Last month, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The Epley maneuver can correct this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

answers.explanation_why: Patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) experience sudden, brief attacks of vertigo that usually last for less than a minute. These symptoms are caused by a dysfunction of the semicircular canal. Patients typically have no cochlear symptoms, such as hearing loss or tinnitus. This patient reports common triggers to these episodes, including lying down or reclining, and quickly turning her head. The Dix-Hallpike test is used to quickly diagnose BPPV and the Epley maneuver is used to treat BPPV. In refractory cases, patients can undergo surgical obliteration of the affected semicircular canal.

Persistent postural-perceptual dizziness (PPPD) typically worsens with movement, but the episodes are characterized by nonrotational dizziness (feeling faint, lightheaded, or unsteady) over a period of at least 3 months. This patient presents with true vertigo, which manifests as dizziness with a rotational component. Also, PPPD is often associated with anxiety or depression disorder, which this patient lacks.

Unlike this patient's episodes, symptomatic episodes of Meniere disease last from minutes to hours and are not triggered by position. In addition, typical features of Meniere disease include tinnitus and hearing loss, which this patient lacks.

Patients with cerebral ischemia in the vertebrobasilar region might present with dizziness. Although this patient has risk factors for a stroke, such as age and hypertension, symptoms of vertebrobasilar cerebral ischemia usually last longer than seconds, are not typically triggered by movement, and are often accompanied by other neurological deficits.

Acoustic neuromas can lead to an insidious onset of dizziness, but true spinning vertigo is uncommon, because of the slow-growing nature of the tumor (the CNS can usually compensate for gradual peripheral vestibular input loss). Also, her episodes are recurrent, and brief, rather than the chronic, gradual time course of acoustic neuromas. Other typical features of acoustic neuromas, such as unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, are missing.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Vestibular neuritis presents with an acute onset of vertigo and is sometimes associated with a history of preceding upper respiratory tract infection, as seen in this patient. The vertigo is typically accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and gait instability, which this patient lacks. Also, her symptoms occur in paroxysmal, positionally-elicited episodes that are too brief to be consistent with a diagnosis of vestibular neuritis, in which episodes usually last for 1–2 days.

question_text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased hearing in his right ear for the past 4 months. During this period, he has also had multiple episodes of dizziness and a constant ringing noise in his right ear. Over the past 5 weeks, he has also noticed scant amounts of right-sided ear discharge. He has a history of multiple ear infections since childhood that were treated with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a white pearly mass behind the right tympanic membrane. Placing a 512 Hz tuning fork in the center of the forehead shows lateralization to the right ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased hearing in his right ear for the past 4 months. During this period, he has also had multiple episodes of dizziness and a constant ringing noise in his right ear. Over the past 5 weeks, he has also noticed scant amounts of right-sided ear discharge. He has a history of multiple ear infections since childhood that were treated with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a white pearly mass behind the right tympanic membrane. Placing a 512 Hz tuning fork in the center of the forehead shows lateralization to the right ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with unilateral hearing loss, otorrhea, tinnitus, vertigo, and a past history of multiple ear infections. These symptoms, in combination with lateralization to the affected ear (indicating conductive hearing loss) in Weber test and otoscopic finding of a pearly mass in the middle ear, are indicative of a cholesteatoma.
learning_objective: Recognize cholesteatoma, and choose the most appropriate therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Topical quinolone antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin) are indicated in the treatment of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) or uncomplicated otitis externa. Although both conditions may also lead to hearing loss, otorrhea, and tinnitus, the patient's otoscopic finding of a pearly mass in the middle ear indicates a more aggressive condition. Topical antibiotics would not be helpful.

images.title: Chronic suppurative otitis media
images.description: Otoscopic image of the middle earThe tympanic membrane is completely perforated and the tympanic cavity can be seen. The mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity is edematous and covered by clear secretions.These findings are diagnostic of chronic suppurative otitis media, which can develop from acute otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation.

answers.explanation_why: Radiation therapy can be used in the treatment of jugulotympanic paragangliomas. Jugulotympanic paragangliomas frequently manifest as pulsatile tinnitus with or without conductive hearing loss. However, this patient's description of tinnitus is constant rather than pulsatile. Also, physical examination would more likely reveal a bluish pulsating mass behind the tympanic membrane.

Corticosteroids are used for the treatment of hearing loss secondary to granulomatosis with polyangiitis. In the early stages, this condition often manifests with symptoms of chronic sinusitis, rhinitis, or otitis media. Although this patient's complaints are consistent with chronic otitis media, granulomatosis with polyangiitis would likely manifest with pneumonia-like symptoms, sinusitis, polychondritis, ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia), and/or skin lesions. Also, this condition does not typically manifest with a pearly mass in the middle ear.

Hearing aids may be useful for many causes of hearing loss (e.g., tympanosclerosis). Tympanosclerosis typically occurs after frequent episodes of otitis media and can also manifest with unilateral conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, tympanosclerosis would manifest as a flat white lesion rather than a pearly white mass. Hearing aids are not appropriate for a cholesteatoma. If left untreated, the cholesteatoma would likely continue to grow and put the patient at risk for complications.

images.title: Tympanosclerosis
images.description: Otoscopy of a right earA white, grape-shaped, calcified plaque (green overlay) is visible in the 3^rd quadrant of the tympanic membrane.This is the typical appearance of tympanosclerosis.

answers.explanation_why:
Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for cholesteatoma. Spontaneous resolution is rare and complications are common. If left untreated, patients are at risk for serious complications such as erosion of the temporal bone, permanent hearing loss, facial weakness, paralysis of the facial muscles, meningitis, and brain abscesses.

This patient most likely has a secondary acquired cholesteatoma based on his otoscopy finding of a pearly mass in the middle ear. In secondary acquired cholesteatoma, epithelium migrates inwards through a perforated tympanic membrane. The defect in the tympanic membrane often heals and is no longer visible on diagnosis.

images.title: Cholesteatoma
images.description: Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane.Encrustation and darkening of the epithelium can be seen in the posterior upper quadrant marginal to the pars flaccida (arrow). The localization and findings indicate a cholesteatoma.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Over the past 8 months, his mother reports difficulty understanding the boy's speech. On occasion during this period, she has noticed that he does not respond when called by name and cannot follow 1-step instructions. He has a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics since birth. He is at the 60^th percentile for length and 50^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. His speech is quiet and difficult to understand. Otoscopic examination shows retracted tympanic membranes bilaterally that are immobile on pneumatic otoscopy. Nasopharyngoscopy shows mild adenoid hypertrophy. Pure tone audiometry shows a conductive hearing loss of 26 dB on the right side and 28 dB on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Over the past 8 months, his mother reports difficulty understanding the boy's speech. On occasion during this period, she has noticed that he does not respond when called by name and cannot follow 1-step instructions. He has a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics since birth. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 50th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. His speech is quiet and difficult to understand. Otoscopic examination shows retracted tympanic membranes bilaterally that are immobile on pneumatic otoscopy. Nasopharyngoscopy shows mild adenoid hypertrophy. Pure tone audiometry shows a conductive hearing loss of 26 dB on the right side and 28 dB on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A history of recurrent ear infections, language developmental delay, and conductive hearing loss with retracted tympanic membranes that do not move briskly on pneumatic otoscopy is diagnostic of otitis media with effusion (OME).
learning_objective: Recognize otitis media with effusion, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Decongestants are not recommended for the treatment of OME in children because studies have shown no effect on the time it takes OME to resolve, the prevention of complications such as recurrent otitis media or hearing loss, or the need for surgical intervention.

Topical antibiotics are used for the treatment of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). While CSOM can also present with hearing loss, painless otorrhea is a key feature that is missing in this patient. Also, CSOM can be diagnosed by the presence of a perforated tympanic membrane on otoscopy. This patient presents with OME, for which antibiotic therapy is not recommended. While studies have shown modest, transient benefits in improving symptoms of OME, potential adverse reactions (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting, and allergic reactions) outweigh the benefits of topical antibiotic therapy.

While this boy has mild adenoid hypertrophy on physical examination, adenoidectomy is not recommended for the management of OME in children younger than 4 years of age unless there is an independent indication for adenoidectomy such as airway obstruction, chronic sinusitis, or chronic adenoiditis, which this patient does not have. Adenoidectomy has only been shown to improve the resolution of middle ear effusion in children ≥ 4 years and may be performed as first-line therapy in this age group.

While OME resolves spontaneously in most cases and can be managed conservatively in older patients, this 3-year-old child has hearing loss at a point in time that is critical for speech and language development; it, therefore, requires prompt surgical intervention with the placement of a tympanostomy tube (also known as grommet tube, ear tube, or ventilation tube). The tube allows for the removal of fluid from the middle ear, decreases conductive hearing loss, and helps maintain an air-filled middle ear space.

Follow-ups should continue until the tympanic membrane is fully healed and normal eustachian tube function, as well as normal hearing, are achieved. Possible complications include otorrhea, occlusion of tubes, premature extrusion of tubes, persistent perforation, tympanosclerosis, and cholesteatoma.

images.title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
images.description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

answers.explanation_why: Antihistamines are not recommended for the treatment of OME in children, since studies have shown no effect on the time it takes OME to resolve, the prevention of complications such as recurrent otitis media or hearing loss, or the need for surgical intervention.

Corticosteroid therapy is not generally recommended for the treatment of OME in children. The risk of adverse effects (e.g., growth retardation) is thought to outweigh the benefits of corticosteroid therapy. Studies have shown minimal efficacy in resolving OME and there is no evidence demonstrating improvements in hearing.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of bleeding from his lips earlier that day. He has a history of recurrent nosebleeds since childhood. His father has a similar history of recurrent nosebleeds. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows multiple, small dilated capillaries over the lips, nose, and fingers. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of bleeding from his lips earlier that day. He has a history of recurrent nosebleeds since childhood. His father has a similar history of recurrent nosebleeds. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows multiple, small dilated capillaries over the lips, nose, and fingers. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
hint: This patient's recurrent episodes of epistaxis and telangiectasias of the lips, nose, and fingers are consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), an autosomal dominant condition that is associated with vascular malformations.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and recall its cardiac complications.

answers.explanation_why: HHT is not associated with an increased risk of glaucoma. Early-onset glaucoma is seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS). Affected patients also present with vascular anomalies, but they instead take the form of a port-wine stain (usually unilateral in the V1–V2 facial dermatomes) and vascular malformations of the choroid and CNS (e.g., leptomeningeal angioma, usually ipsilateral to the port-wine stain). SWS is not associated with telangiectasias or recurrent epistaxis.

The risk of hematological malignancies such as acute leukemia is not increased in HHT but in ataxia-telangiectasia (AT). Patients with AT usually develop oculocutaneous telangiectasias; epistaxis due to telangiectasias in the mucous membranes of the nose is rare with AT. Moreover, the earliest manifestations of AT are progressive cerebellar ataxia, ocular movement abnormalities, and other motor disorders (e.g., chorea, myoclonus); these neurological features precede the onset of telangiectasias by several years.

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) and tuberous sclerosis (TS) have an increased risk of RCC. Neither VHL nor TS is associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasis. VHL is associated with mucocutaneous cavernous hemangiomas and hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS. The mucocutaneous manifestations of TS are adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, Shagreen patch, and skin hamartomas.

Patients with HHT are at increased risk of developing large arteriovenous shunts (especially pulmonary and hepatic), and subsequently high-output cardiac failure due to hyperdynamic circulation. Other complications associated with HHT include paradoxical emboli (emboli passing through a pulmonary arteriovenous shunt into the systemic circulation, bypassing the lungs) and anemia due to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from telangiectasias in the gastrointestinal tract.

The risk of gastrointestinal polyps is the highest with hereditary polyposis syndromes (e.g., familial adenomatous polyposis, Gardner syndrome, Turcot syndrome, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, juvenile polyposis syndrome, Cowden syndrome). HHT is commonly associated with gastrointestinal telangiectasias but only rarely with gastrointestinal polyps (a subtype of HHT is associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome). A different complication of HHT is much more common.

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytomas are seen in patients with multiple hereditary disorders, including multiple endocrine neoplasias types 2A and 2B (MEN 2A, MEN 2B), von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL), and neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). None of these conditions are associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasis. VHL is associated with mucocutaneous cavernous hemangiomas and hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS. The cutaneous findings of NF1 are cutaneous neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait spots, and Lisch nodules. Patients with MEN 2B present with oral/intestinal neuromas and marfanoid habitus.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for the past 5 days. He has a history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections and sinusitis treated with oral antibiotics. He frequently has loose stools that do not flush easily. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and the neonatal period was complicated by meconium ileus. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 15^th percentile for height and at the 5^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 38/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination shows bilateral nasal polyps. There are scattered inspiratory crackles heard in the thorax. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for the past 5 days. He has a history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections and sinusitis treated with oral antibiotics. He frequently has loose stools that do not flush easily. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and the neonatal period was complicated by meconium ileus. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 15th percentile for height and at the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 38/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination shows bilateral nasal polyps. There are scattered inspiratory crackles heard in the thorax. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Pancreatic insufficiency in cystic fibrosis (CF) leads to malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
learning_objective: Recognize cystic fibrosis, and recall its associated laboratory findings.

answers.explanation_why: Recurrent pulmonary infections and chronic bronchitis in CF lead to obstructive lung disease with increased air trapping and lung hyperinflation, resulting in increased, not decreased, residual volumes.

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency arising from hyperviscous secretions in CF leads to malabsorption, steatorrhea, and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K). Vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy and an elevated prothrombin time.
Patients with CF may lose an excess of chloride in their sweat (due to defective chloride channels), resulting in chloride-dependent metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.

Cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA) are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, or formerly Wegener granulomatosis). GPA may cause recurrent sinusitis and persistent, pneumonia-like symptoms (cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, wheezing). However, GPA is not associated with steatorrhea or meconium ileus and is rare in childhood (peak incidence: 65–74 years).

Glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) autoantibodies are present in type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM). CF may cause diabetes later in life (CF-related diabetes) due to destruction of pancreatic islet cells from chronic pancreatic duct obstruction. CF is not, however, associated with T1DM or the presence of GAD autoantibodies.

Aganglionic rectum is seen in Hirschsprung disease, which may be associated with Down syndrome. The patient's recurrent respiratory infections, steatorrhea, and history of meconium ileus in childhood is suggestive of CF, which has no association with Hirschsprung disease.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of persistent fever and cough. Three days ago, he was diagnosed with pneumonia and acute otitis media. He was started on ampicillin-sulbactam and clarithromycin, but his symptoms did not improve. The mother reports that her son has been hospitalized 3 times due to pneumonia. He was first diagnosed with pneumonia at the age of 10 months. She also reports several episodes of bilateral otitis media and recurrent respiratory tract infections. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and 20^th percentile for weight. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Otoscopic examination shows purulent otorrhea bilaterally. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields. The palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of persistent fever and cough. Three days ago, he was diagnosed with pneumonia and acute otitis media. He was started on ampicillin-sulbactam and clarithromycin, but his symptoms did not improve. The mother reports that her son has been hospitalized 3 times due to pneumonia. He was first diagnosed with pneumonia at the age of 10 months. She also reports several episodes of bilateral otitis media and recurrent respiratory tract infections. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Otoscopic examination shows purulent otorrhea bilaterally. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields. The palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient presents with recurrent, severe pyogenic infections (pneumonia, otitis media) and lymphoid tissue hypoplasia. His first episode of pneumonia occurred > 6 months after birth. These features suggest X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia.
learning_objective: Recognize X-linked agammaglobulinemia, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Defective NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which can also lead to recurrent infections. However, patients with CGD often have skin manifestations (recurrent skin infections and an eczematous rash) and symptoms due to granulomas of the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts (e.g., abdominal pain, bladder distention).

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD) results from a deficiency of beta-2 integrin, a protein responsible for leukocyte chemotaxis. Although LAD also causes recurrent infections, they tend to be nonsuppurative skin and soft tissue infections. In addition, there is no reported history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord, which is a common feature of LAD.

An impaired IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Children with SCID appear normal at birth but progressively develop recurrent, severe infections (including bacterial, fungal, viral, or protozoal) and show failure to thrive. SCID typically causes more severe infections than those seen in this patient and often causes death within the first year of life if not diagnosed and treated during infancy.

A defect in the ATM gene is the cause of ataxia-telangiectasia, a neurocutaneous disorder that can cause immunodeficiency in children. However, in a 3-year-old child, it would also typically present with ataxia and telangiectasias of the face and conjunctiva. In addition, this condition would not explain this patient's hypoplastic lymphoid tissue, making it an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

A mutation in the WAS gene causes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can cause recurrent infections. Unlike this patient, however, children with WAS present with eczema and thrombocytopenic purpura in addition to recurrent infections. Moreover, WAS would not explain this patient's hypoplastic lymphoid tissue.

X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is caused by a defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, a signal transduction molecule found on B cells. Without this molecule, proper B-cell maturation cannot occur, resulting in a severe reduction in plasma cells and immunoglobulins. Although recurrent infections can be a feature of many immunodeficiency disorders, tonsillar hypoplasia (due to low B-cell volume) is suggestive of XLA. The diagnosis is confirmed with flow cytometry showing reduced levels of B cells and normal levels of T cells. Treatment for XLA consists of IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics.

images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

question_text: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The newborn's condition is associated with CHARGE syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral choanal atresia, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.content: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray are seen in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). NRDS is typically seen in premature infants due to impaired synthesis and secretion of surfactant. Affected newborns have tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and cyanosis immediately following birth. However, auscultation of the lungs in newborns with NRDS shows decreased breath sounds, and breathing would not normalize after crying.

Acrocyanosis (blue extremities and a pink trunk) is common in neonates and is not necessarily a sign of a concerning pathology. In premature infants, even transient apnea is not unusual, as their regulatory functions are not yet fully developed. However, this patient shows signs of central cyanosis and intermittent dyspnea, which are unusual, especially for a full-term infant.

A boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray is a typical finding in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease. In addition to persistent mild cyanosis, patients with TOF may develop recurrent episodes of cyanosis and hypoxia during feeding and crying. However, these tet spells are more common between the ages of 2 and 4 months rather than immediately following birth. In addition, this patient's cyanosis worsens with feeding rather than during a physiologic stressor and improves with crying, which is unlikely in patients with TOF.

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

answers.content: Inability to pass a gastric catheter through the mouth
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a gastric catheter through the mouth would be impossible in patients with esophageal atresia (EA), in which the upper and lower esophagus are not connected. This congenital defect is often associated with a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) between the lower esophagus and trachea. Patients develop cyanotic attacks, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth, and coughing spells immediately after birth. Normalization of breathing after crying suggests another diagnosis.

answers.content: Inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavity
answers.explanation_why: This patient is presenting shortly after birth with difficulty breathing and cyanosis that worsens when feeding and improves when crying, which are typical symptoms of bilateral choanal atresia. Patients with this condition have complete blockage of both nasal cavities and, therefore, are only able to breathe through their mouths, which results in cyanosis when the mouth is blocked during feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavities supports the presumptive diagnosis of choanal atresia. Confirmatory testing by CT scan or contrast rhinography in the supine position should follow. Unilateral choanal atresia is twice as prevalent as its bilateral counterpart. However, the bilateral type is most frequently associated with other congenital anomalies, most commonly CHARGE syndrome.

images.title: Choanal atresia
images.description: Retropalatal endoscopic viewUnilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

answers.explanation_why: A scaphoid abdomen and barrel-shaped chest are typical findings in patients with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). In CDH, herniation of bowel contents into the chest cavity results in pulmonary hypoplasia, and patients develop tachypnea, respiratory distress, and cyanosis. However, in patients with CDH, an absence of breath sounds would be present on auscultation of the ipsilateral chest, and if on the left side (most common), bowel sounds would be present, unlike the normal auscultatory findings in this patient. In addition, the degree of cyanosis would not change during feeding and crying.

question_text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of fever for the past 3 days. They also state that he has been less active and has been refusing to eat. The patient has had two episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. He was born at term and had severe respiratory distress and sepsis shortly after birth that was treated with antibiotics. Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 33 days. The patient appears pale. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 195/min, and blood pressure is 60/40 mm Hg. He is at the 25^th percentile for height and 15^th percentile for weight. Examination shows a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Oral examination shows white mucosal patches that bleed when they are scraped off. There is bilateral mucoid, nonpurulent ear discharge. Several scaly erythematous skin lesions are seen on the chest. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 38,700/mm^3 with 90% neutrophils and a platelet count of 200,000/mm^3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 33 days. The patient appears pale. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 195/min, and blood pressure is 60/40 mm Hg. He is at the 25th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Examination shows a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 38,700/mm3 with 90% neutrophils and a platelet count of 200,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with signs of septic shock (fever, hypotension, tachycardia, decreased peripheral perfusion), bilateral nonpurulent otitis media, mucocutaneous candidiasis (white mucosal patches that bleed when scraped), and a history of recurrent bacterial infections. This presentation in combination with delayed umbilical cord separation (> 30 days postpartum) suggests a specific congenital phagocyte disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1, and recall its genetic defect.

answers.explanation_why: A defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which may result in recurrent otitis media from infection with extracellular bacteria such as S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae. However, delayed umbilical cord separation is not expected. Moreover, candidiasis is more commonly seen with defects involving T cells and granulocytes rather than in isolated primary defects of antibody production such as XLA.

images.title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

answers.explanation_why: A defective CD40 ligand is the underlying mechanism of type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome. The onset of type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome is in the first 2 years of life and the condition would result in recurrent infections. However, neutropenia rather than neutrophilia is typically seen, and patients often show failure to thrive. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

A defect in the interleukin-2 receptor subunit gamma gene (IL2RG) is the most common mutation associated with severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID), which presents soon after birth with sepsis, recurrent episodes of otitis media, and mucocutaneous candidiasis. However, failure to thrive and a history of chronic diarrhea would typically be present, and a CBC would reveal a low absolute lymphocyte count. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD1) is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in CD18, a subunit of beta-2 integrin, which results in an inability of leukocytes to migrate to the site of infection. Patients subsequently have recurrent infections and a characteristic absence of pus with infection. Other characteristic features of the condition include poor wound healing with large skin ulcers, omphalitis, and severe periodontitis/gingivitis. A very high neutrophil count (as high as 100,000/mm^3 during active infection) is seen as neutrophil activation and recruitment of neutrophils occurs, but neutrophils are unable to extravasate into tissues, causing pooling within the circulation.

Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which may manifest during infancy with candidiasis (since C. albicans is catalase-positive) and neutrophilia during episodes of infection. However, recurrent pneumonia, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and/or perianal abscesses caused by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus are far more common than recurrent otitis media. Moreover, these infections tend to remain localized and sepsis is not as common as in other primary immune deficiency syndromes. Other pathognomonic features of CGD are GI obstruction and urinary retention caused by granulomas. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

A loss of function of the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the underlying pathophysiology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which results in recurrent infections such as S. aureus pneumonia. However, patients with CHS would have neutropenia, not neutrophilia. Other features would also be present, such as oculocutaneous albinism and/or ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus, nystagmus). Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

A mutation in the WAS gene is the underlying cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can present during infancy with recurrent otitis media as well as scaly erythematous lesions due to atopic dermatitis. However, the absence of thrombocytopenia on a CBC essentially rules out WAS. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

question_text:
A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of intermittent blood-tinged urine for several months. Four months ago, he had an episode of fever and sore throat that resolved without treatment after 5 days. During the past 2 years, he has also had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His brother died of a progressive kidney disease at the age of 23. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows a conical protrusion of both lenses. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11 g/dL

Serum

 Urea nitrogen
40 mg/dL

 Creatinine
2.4 mg/dL

Urine

 Blood

2+

 Protein

1+

 RBC
5–7/hpf

 RBC casts
rare

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of intermittent blood-tinged urine for several months. Four months ago, he had an episode of fever and sore throat that resolved without treatment after 5 days. During the past 2 years, he has also had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His brother died of a progressive kidney disease at the age of 23. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows a conical protrusion of both lenses. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11 g/dL Serum Urea nitrogen 40 mg/dL Creatinine 2.4 mg/dL Urine Blood 2+ Protein 1+ RBC 5–7/hpf RBC casts rare Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's recurrent edema of the face and feet, hypertension, elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine, and urinalysis that shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria are suggestive of nephritic syndrome. The combination of intermittent gross hematuria, nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus in a patient with a family history of renal disease is indicative of Alport syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Alport syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may manifest with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness and lenticonus seen here.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions caused by antibodies against intrinsic type IV collagen antigens in the basement membrane are responsible for Goodpasture disease, which manifests with acute nephritic syndrome. However, Goodpasture disease rarely manifests during early childhood and usually progresses rapidly (unlike in this patient, who presents with a 2-year history of intermittent edema). Also, especially in younger individuals, pulmonary symptoms (e.g., hemoptysis, dyspnea) often precede the onset of nephritic syndrome.

A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor), which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, nephroblastoma typically manifests in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination.

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy typically manifests between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 12-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome.

Alport syndrome is caused by a genetic defect of type IV collagen, which is most commonly inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. Type IV collagen is found in the glomerular basement membrane, the cochlea, and the lens of the eye. Thus, a defect of type IV collagen may result in hematuria and nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus leading to vision problems (patients with Alport syndrome “can't pee, can't see, can't hear a bee”).

The diagnosis of Alport syndrome is confirmed via skin biopsy (showing the absence of type IV collagen alpha-5 chains in the basement membrane) or, if skin biopsy is inconclusive, kidney biopsy. Patients with proteinuria, such as this boy, should receive ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers to slow the progression to end-stage renal disease.

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient had an episode of febrile pharyngitis 4 months ago that could be due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness and lenticonus in this patient.

Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 12-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy as well a family history of early death due to end-stage renal disease might suggest a diagnosis of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which is a cause for multiple bilateral kidney cysts. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness and lenticonus. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

In about 15% of cases, Alport syndrome may be the result of an autosomal-recessive mutation. However, the majority of affected patients have an X-linked mutation.

question_text:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his urine has been pink since this morning. During the past 2 days, he has had a sore throat and difficulty swallowing. He also reports having a low-grade fever. He has no pain with urination or changes in urinary frequency. He has had two similar episodes involving a sore throat and pink urine over the past 2 years. His older sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Oral examination shows an erythematous pharynx and enlarged tonsils. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Leukocyte count
20,000/mm^3

Serum

 Urea nitrogen
8 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL

Urine

 Blood
3+

 Protein

1+

 RBC

15–17/hpf with dysmorphic features

 RBC casts

numerous

Ultrasonography of the kidneys shows no abnormalities. A renal biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his urine has been pink since this morning. During the past 2 days, he has had a sore throat and difficulty swallowing. He also reports having a low-grade fever. He has no pain with urination or changes in urinary frequency. He has had two similar episodes involving a sore throat and pink urine over the past 2 years. His older sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Oral examination shows an erythematous pharynx and enlarged tonsils. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 20,000/mm3 Serum Urea nitrogen 8 mg/dL Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL Urine Blood 3+ Protein 1+ RBC 15–17/hpf with dysmorphic features RBC casts numerous Ultrasonography of the kidneys shows no abnormalities. A renal biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria that are always associated with pharyngitis. His urinalysis findings are consistent with a glomerular origin of the blood (RBCs with dysmorphic features and RBC casts). This combination suggests Berger disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Berger disease (IgA nephropathy), and recall its characteristic renal biopsy findings.

answers.explanation_why: Capillary wire looping, which is characterized by diffuse subendothelial glomerular deposits, is a typical light microscopy finding in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN). DPGN is most common in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and can manifest with gross hematuria, increased serum creatinine concentration, and nephritic sediment following an upper respiratory infection. The patient does have a family history of SLE. However, he does not have any findings of SLE, such as a rash, photosensitivity, or joint pain, nor does he have symptoms of any other systemic disease that would predispose him to develop DPGN, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Lupus nephritis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a renal cortex biopsy specimen (PAS stain; 250x magnification)Sections of numerous tubules and vessels and three centrally located renal glomeruli (blue outlines) are visible. The latter show a partially increased mesangial cell density (examples indicated by black outlines), thickened capillary loops (due to subepithelial immune complex deposits; examples indicated by blue overlay), extracapillary epithelial proliferation (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and diffuse glomerulosclerosis (examples indicated by arrowheads).These findings are characteristic of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, the most common form of lupus nephritis, in which more than half of the glomeruli are affected.

answers.content: Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane
answers.explanation_why: Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane suggests Alport syndrome, which typically manifests with episodes of gross hematuria that are often precipitated by upper respiratory infections. As the disease progresses, findings may include nephritic sediment on urinalysis and a decrease in kidney function (increased serum creatinine and urea nitrogen concentrations). However, in almost all males with Alport syndrome, hematuria is first detected during infancy, making the diagnosis unlikely in a boy who has not had any episodes until adolescence. In addition, affected individuals often have a personal or family history of sensorineural hearing loss and/or ocular findings (e.g., lenticonus).

images.title: Alport syndrome
images.description: Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

answers.content: Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins
answers.explanation_why: Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins in the glomeruli are characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Breaks in the glomerular capillary wall (due to any kind of severe injury) lead to an accumulation of plasma products (e.g., fibrinogen) within the Bowman capsule and result in fibrin formation. RPGN can manifest with gross hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), increased serum creatinine and urea nitrogen concentrations, and nephritic sediment on urinalysis. However, renal insufficiency is usually more pronounced at diagnosis, with a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL), decreased urine output, hypertension, and edema.

images.title: Crescent formation in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
images.description: Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

answers.explanation_why:
IgA nephropathy most frequently manifests during the second or third decade of life with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually during or immediately following an infection. Between these episodes, patients typically have asymptomatic urinary abnormalities, such as microhematuria. The most likely explanation for these findings is an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies, the synthesis of which is triggered by mucosal infections (e.g., pharyngitis). These IgA antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in the mesangium of the renal glomerulus, leading to glomerulonephritis (type III hypersensitivity reaction).

The treatment of IgA nephropathy includes monitoring of kidney function and initiation of treatment if the disease progresses (e.g., ACE inhibitors for hypertension and/or proteinuria). Immunosuppressive therapy may be indicated in more severe cases. Even with the appropriate treatment, up to 50% of the patients progress to end-stage renal disease within 20–25 years. This patient's increased serum creatinine concentration is concerning for severe or progressive disease and warrants further evaluation with renal biopsy.

images.title: IgA nephropathy
images.description: Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

answers.explanation_why: Effacement of the foot processes is a typical finding on electron microscopy in minimal change disease (MCD). Though MCD typically occurs following a viral infection, such as viral pharyngitis, it manifests with nephrotic syndrome rather than nephritic syndrome. This patient does not have any features of nephrotic syndrome, such as heavy proteinuria (3.5 g/24 h), hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or thromboembolism, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, this disease most often affects children < 6 years of age.

images.title: Podocyte foot processes fusion in minimal change disease
images.description: Electron micrograph of kidney tissueThe effacement of the podocytes foot processes is visible (examples indicated by green outline) as well as swelling of podocyte bodies (example indicated by red overlay).This finding, together with unremarkable light microscopy, is typical of minimal change disease.

answers.content: Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement
answers.explanation_why: Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are typically seen on immunofluorescent microscopy of a kidney biopsy sample in patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). PSGN can manifest with gross hematuria following an episode of pharyngitis. However, PSGN usually manifests 1–3 weeks after an acute infection. Furthermore, this diagnosis is most common in young children and older individuals and is uncommon in adolescents. In addition, it does not result in recurrent episodes of hematuria. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical findings of PSGN, such as hypertension and edema.

images.title: C3 deposits in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
images.description: Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.
