question_text: A 26-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding and lethargy for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had a raspy cry. The child was delivered at term at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. He is at the 90^th percentile for head circumference, 50^th percentile for length, and 60^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows scleral icterus and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 26-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding and lethargy for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had a raspy cry. The child was delivered at term at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. He is at the 90th percentile for head circumference, 50th percentile for length, and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows scleral icterus and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: If left untreated, this child is likely to develop intellectual disability.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital hypothyroidism due to thyroid dysgenesis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has features consistent with congenital hypothyroidism (poor feeding and lethargy, a raspy/hoarse cry, prolonged newborn jaundice, umbilical hernia, increased head circumference, muscle hypotonia, macroglossia). The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions is thyroid dysgenesis (i.e., thyroid hypoplasia, dysplasia, or aplasia). Early initiation of thyroxine supplementation is essential to prevent the patient from developing permanent intellectual disability. If the mother has clinical or subclinical hypothyroidism, the manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism may be apparent at birth; if the mother is euthyroid, the manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism develop a few weeks to months after birth because the placenta supplies the fetus with maternal thyroid hormone. Therefore, neonatal screening for thyroid deficiency is indicated even if the neonate is asymptomatic; screening is mandatory in the US and typically performed by measuring TSH levels 24–48 hours after birth.

Acid maltase deficiency leads to Pompe disease, which may present with macroglossia, poor feeding, and muscle hypotonia during the first few weeks to months of life. However, affected patients usually also have signs of cardiomyopathy (e.g., shortness of breath, tachypnea, tachycardia, jugular venous distention), which are absent here. Also, Pompe disease would not account for this patient's jaundice, raspy cry, umbilical hernia, and increased head circumference.

Trisomy 21 (i.e., Down syndrome) can also manifest with muscle hypotonia, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. However, the absence of classic clinical features of Down syndrome such as brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, hypertelorism, flattened nose), Brushfield spots, a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal toes, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Biliary atresia may present with delayed neonatal jaundice that becomes apparent at around 2 weeks of life. While this patient presents with scleral icterus, biliary atresia would not account for this newborn's raspy cry, umbilical hernia, macrocephaly, muscle hypotonia, and macroglossia.

A deficiency of α-L-iduronidase causes Hurler syndrome. While patients with Hurler syndrome may also present with abdominal distention (due to hepatosplenomegaly) and umbilical hernia, they generally do not become symptomatic until 6 months to 1 year of age. Hurler syndrome can cause a broad range of clinical symptoms, including musculoskeletal abnormalities (joint contractures, spinal deformity), developmental delay, coarse facial features, and corneal clouding. However, muscle hypotonia, macroglossia, and a raspy cry just 2 weeks after birth would not be expected.

An alteration of the short arm of chromosome 11 can cause Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), which can manifest with macroglossia, abdominal distention (due to organ enlargement), and umbilical hernia. However, other classic findings of BWS such as macrosomia, hemihyperplasia, and hypoglycemia are not present in this patient.

question_text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of increased irritability, continual crying, and fever for 1 day. His mother has noticed that he refuses to lie down on his right side and keeps tugging at his right ear. One week ago, he had a runny nose that has since improved. He was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months of age and is currently bottle-fed with some solid foods introduced. He has been attending a daycare center for the past 5 months. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and pulse is 144/min. Otoscopic examination in this child is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of increased irritability, continual crying, and fever for 1 day. His mother has noticed that he refuses to lie down on his right side and keeps tugging at his right ear. One week ago, he had a runny nose that has since improved. He was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months of age and is currently bottle-fed with some solid foods introduced. He has been attending a daycare center for the past 5 months. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and pulse is 144/min. Otoscopic examination in this child is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Ear pain, often suggested by excessive crying and ear tugging, in combination with irritability, fever, and a recent upper respiratory infection (URI) is the classic presentation of acute otitis media (AOM) in infants. In this age group, bottle feeding, inadequate breastfeeding, and attending a daycare center are risk factors for AOM.
learning_objective: Recognize acute otitis media (AOM), and recall its otoscopic findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Otoscopic examination in AOM typically shows a bulging erythematous tympanic membrane (TM) due to the accumulation of purulent secretions in the middle ear. Other common findings include TM opacification and loss of light reflex. AOM may cause rupture of the TM, which leads to purulent or serosanguinous otorrhea.

In otherwise healthy children aged > 6 months with uncomplicated, unilateral AOM, as seen here, pain relief and observation are the mainstays of treatment. Systemic antibiotic treatment should be considered if symptoms do not improve within 48–72 hours.

A retracted opacified tympanic membrane is a typical finding in otitis media with effusion (OME). OME is most common in toddlers and typically occurs after an episode of AOM. However, OME is usually painless and does not cause fever.

images.title: Otitis media with effusion (OME)
images.description: Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane (TM)There is no noticeable bulging of the TM and the light reflex is visible in its normal position in the anterior inferior quadrant, indicating the TM is in a neutral position. The TMs yellow color and slight opacity suggest a serous effusion. There is no erythema.

answers.explanation_why: An erythematous external auditory canal is seen in otitis externa (OE), which manifests with ear pain, fever, and possible “ear tugging” in a child (due to pruritus). However, this child does not have any risk factors that are typically associated with OE (i.e., injury to the skin of the external auditory canal and/or exposure to water). Moreover, the absence of otorrhea and auricular erythema/tenderness makes OE an unlikely diagnosis.

answers.content: Yellow mass behind the tympanic membrane
answers.explanation_why: A yellow or white mass behind the tympanic membrane is consistent with congenital cholesteatoma. However, cholesteatoma manifests with foul-smelling otorrhea and does not cause ear pain or fever.

Vesicles in the ear canal can be seen in herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with ear pain, fever, and irritability. However, the vesicles typically also involve the outer ear and additional neurological features (e.g., vertigo, facial nerve paralysis) are expected. Furthermore, herpes zoster oticus is much less common than AOM.

answers.content: Brown mass within the ear canal
answers.explanation_why: Cerumen impaction would be seen as an irregular brown mass within the ear canal that can also cause ear discomfort in an infant, but it would not cause fever.

images.title: Cerumen impaction
images.description: Otoscopic image of the external auditory canalThe auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive difficulty breathing through his nose and a 2-week history of recurrent severe nosebleeds. When he holds the right nostril shut, he is unable to breathe nasally and his sense of smell is reduced. He has a 6-year history of asthma, which is well controlled with inhaled albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal inspection shows a pink, lobulated mass filling the left nasal cavity. The septum is deviated to the right side. The mass bleeds on touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive difficulty breathing through his nose and a 2-week history of recurrent severe nosebleeds. When he holds the right nostril shut, he is unable to breathe nasally and his sense of smell is reduced. He has a 6-year history of asthma, which is well controlled with inhaled albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal inspection shows a pink, lobulated mass filling the left nasal cavity. The septum is deviated to the right side. The mass bleeds on touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: The combination of a pink nasal mass, septum deviation, nasal obstruction, and recurrent epistaxis in an adolescent boy is highly suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).
learning_objective: Recognize juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Coagulation tests are indicated for patients with suspected bleeding disorders, which frequently manifest with recurrent epistaxis. However, patients with bleeding disorders typically have additional features, e.g., petechiae in platelet disorders, hemarthrosis in coagulation defects. Coagulation tests are likely necessary in this patient with suspected JNA to exclude a concurrent bleeding disorder; however, another step is required to confirm his diagnosis.

A sweat chloride test is indicated in suspected cystic fibrosis (CF), which may manifest with nasal polyposis. However, CF most commonly manifests in infancy with gastrointestinal features (e.g., meconium ileus) or in early childhood with respiratory symptoms such as recurrent pneumonia or bronchitis (not asthma). Moreover, polyps in CF are usually bilateral, pale, and greyish and do not typically cause bleeding.

The NSAID challenge test is indicated in suspected NSAID-exacerbated respiratory disease, which manifests with asthma and nasal polyposis. However, this patient does not have a history of NSAID use, and recurrent rhinosinusitis would be expected, rather than epistaxis.

Punch biopsy is an important test in the workup of unilateral nasal masses to determine malignancy (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma). However, biopsy is contraindicated in JNA because the tumor is highly vascular, so biopsy will cause massive bleeding. If the diagnosis is inconclusive after further evaluation, a biopsy can be considered. However, the procedure should only be performed by a specialist in an operating room where adequate airway protection and blood products can be ensured.

A foreign nasal body may cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis. However, the presence of a foreign nasal body is commonly associated with unilateral, foul-smelling, and purulent nasal discharge due to local inflammation and infection, and it is more common in very young children and individuals with developmental impairment.

answers.content: CT scan of head with contrast
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan is the preferred method to confirm the diagnosis of JNA and to assess the extent of the tumor. These rare, benign, but rapidly expanding tumors occur exclusively in boys and manifest with a mass arising from the roof of the nasopharynx on a cranial CT scan. JNAs typically show strong contrast enhancement on CT scan due to their increased vascularity, which is the cause for recurrent epistaxis. The tumors also induce pressure necrosis on adjacent structures (e.g., the orbits, the intracranial cavity). Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for symptomatic JNAs, because they are locally aggressive and have a high recurrence rate. Radiosurgery (i.e., with a stereotactic gamma knife) is reserved for recurrent JNAs and/or JNAs with intracranial extension.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for coughing, nasal congestion, and intermittent wheezing for the past 2 months. The child has a history of eczema. Since birth, he has had three upper respiratory tract infections that resolved without treatment, and one episode of acute otitis media treated with antibiotics. His family moved into affordable housing 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for coughing, nasal congestion, and intermittent wheezing for the past 2 months. The child has a history of eczema. Since birth, he has had three upper respiratory tract infections that resolved without treatment, and one episode of acute otitis media treated with antibiotics. His family moved into affordable housing 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This boy with eczema likely has a reversible condition triggered by allergens in his new home.
learning_objective: Recognize new-onset asthma in the context of atopy, and choose the initial diagnostic test for a patient ≥ 6 years old.

answers.explanation_why: Flow cytometry showing absent or low B cell levels can diagnose Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Although this patient has had one episode of likely bacterial acute otitis media, patients with Bruton agammaglobulinemia tend to have recurrent and severe pyogenic infections, which is not consistent with this boy's history.

images.title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

answers.explanation_why: This patient likely has new-onset asthma, given his history of atopy (i.e., eczema) and chronic cough and wheezing after moving to a new home with possible allergen exposures (e.g., dust mites, cat dander). His prolonged nasal congestion suggests allergic rhinitis, which would complete the atopic triad. Spirometry is the initial test of choice in patients with suspected asthma ≥ 6 years of age. The presence of an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV_1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation confirms a diagnosis. Spirometry may be attempted in children < 6 years of age, but results are often unreliable. Therefore, diagnosis is largely dependent on a detailed history and the response to a trial of asthma medication. If the diagnosis is still nonconclusive, a methacholine challenge test may be attempted.

Skin prick testing can be performed to identify allergens that may exacerbate this patient's cough and wheezing. However, he should first undergo a test that confirms his diagnosis. Skin prick testing can be performed for this patient in the future.

Throat culture would be appropriate for a suspected bacterial upper respiratory tract infection (e.g., Group A streptococcus). Although this patient presents with cough, nasal congestion, and wheezing, his symptoms have been present for 2 months, making an infectious etiology less likely. Instead, his symptoms can be better explained by a condition aggravated by repeat allergen exposure.

Serum IgA levels < 7 mg/dL with normal IgM and IgG levels are diagnostic of selective IgA deficiency. Most patients with selective IgA deficiency are asymptomatic, but some can have recurrent sinusitis or respiratory infections. Although this patient has had several upper respiratory tract infections since birth, the frequency is within normal limits.

Dihydrorhodamine 123 test can diagnose chronic granulomatous disease. Although this patient has had several infections, the frequency is within normal limits. Also, there is no evidence of infections with catalase-positive organisms.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His parents are concerned that he has not had his growth spurt yet. As a child, he was consistently in the 60^th percentile for height; now he is in the 25^th percentile. He has a normal diet but says that “food often has no taste”. His classmates make fun of his short stature and high-pitched voice. As an infant, he had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism and a cleft palate repair. He is otherwise healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, axillary and pubic hair is sparse. His genital development is at Tanner stage 1. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His parents are concerned that he has not had his growth spurt yet. As a child, he was consistently in the 60th percentile for height; now he is in the 25th percentile. He has a normal diet but says that “food often has no taste”. His classmates make fun of his short stature and high-pitched voice. As an infant, he had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism and a cleft palate repair. He is otherwise healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, axillary and pubic hair is sparse. His genital development is at Tanner stage 1. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's altered sense of taste is likely a result of an impaired sense of smell.
learning_objective: Recognize Kallmann syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperprolactinemia does manifest with hypogonadism in male individuals, which could explain the poor genital development in this patient. However, the associated lack of testosterone in this condition would typically cause gynecomastia, which is not seen in this patient. Furthermore, hyperprolactinemia is most commonly caused by a prolactinoma and therefore would likely manifest with additional features such as symptoms of mass effect (e.g., headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia).

Craniopharyngioma could cause delayed onset of puberty. However, this patient has none of the classic symptoms associated with this diagnosis, such as visual field defects, hyperprolactinemia, or central diabetes insipidus.

Hypothyroidism could cause delayed onset of puberty. However, it is associated with typical features such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and hair loss, none of which are present in this patient.

Klinefelter syndrome can manifest with delayed puberty in a male patient. However, a patient with Klinefelter syndrome would characteristically have a tall, slender frame and gynecomastia. Moreover, the additional features in this adolescent (impaired sense of smell, a history of cryptorchidism, and cleft palate) are not explained by Klinefelter syndrome, suggesting another diagnosis.

Primary hypogonadism would cause a delay in the development of secondary sexual characteristics in a male adolescent. It would also explain this patient's poor genital and testicular development. However, this patient's impaired sense of smell and history of cryptorchidism and cleft palate are not explained by this diagnosis.

Kallmann syndrome is a rare, congenital form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism that develops as a result of deficient hypothalamic GnRH secretion. Patients typically present with delayed onset of puberty, an impaired sense of smell (due to disrupted neural migration from the olfactory bulbs to the hypothalamic preoptic nuclei), and a history of cryptorchidism and/or cleft palate. Diagnosis is clinical and further supported by findings of decreased GnRH, FSH, LH, estrogen or testosterone. Treatment consists of hormone replacement therapy during puberty and gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH for the management of infertility in adults.

Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is a common cause of delayed puberty and would explain the delayed development of sexual characteristics in this adolescent. However constitutional delay of puberty is often associated with a similar history in the parents, which is not mentioned in this case. Moreover, impaired sense of smell and history of cryptorchidism and cleft palate would not typically be seen in constitutional delay and suggest another diagnosis.

question_text: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, a 40-year-old man has retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated before arrival to the unit. He received 0.5 L of lactated Ringer solution intraoperatively. The patient was given morphine and ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago when the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and hypertension. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Wheezing is heard in both lungs. Breath sounds are decreased. The patient's face appears flushed. Watery nasal secretions and conjunctival injection are present. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, a 40-year-old man has retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated before arrival to the unit. He received 0.5 L of lactated Ringer solution intraoperatively. The patient was given morphine and ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago when the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and hypertension. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Wheezing is heard in both lungs. Breath sounds are decreased. The patient's face appears flushed. Watery nasal secretions and conjunctival injection are present. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma together constitute Samter triad.
learning_objective: Recognize a pseudoallergic reaction.

answers.explanation_why:
The use of non-selective beta-blockers can result in bronchospasm due to the inhibition of β_2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta-blocker that selectively inhibits β_1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.

All beta-blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta-blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

Hyperinflation of the lungs in a patient with emphysema can result in iatrogenic alveolar rupture; a 20-pack-year smoking history and the recent mechanical ventilation (intubated patient!) are therefore risk factors for alveolar rupture. Alveolar rupture would result in a pneumothorax, which presents with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds on the side of the pneumothorax. This patient developed wheezing and decreased breath sounds bilaterally after an infusion of ketorolac, making alveolar rupture unlikely.

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause flushing and bronchial inflammation.

A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another cause more likely.

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin by inhibiting the enzyme bradykinin dehydrogenase. Increased levels of bradykinin typically result in a dry cough or angioedema, neither of which is seen in this patient. Bradykinin does have some bronchoconstrictor effect, especially if the patient has an underlying airway hyperreactivity (bronchial asthma). However, Samter triad and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different mechanism for bronchospasm.

question_text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend for a nosebleed. Pinching the nose for the past hour has not stopped the bleeding. For the past several months, he has had recurring nosebleeds that resolved with pressure. He has no history of hypertension or trauma. He has asthma that is well controlled with an albuterol inhaler. He has intermittent tension headaches for which he takes aspirin. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 160/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows active bleeding from both nostrils. Pupil size is 6 mm bilaterally in bright light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The hemoglobin concentration is 13.5 g/dL, prothrombin time is 12 seconds, partial thromboplastin time is 35 seconds, and platelet count is 345,000/mm^3. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend for a nosebleed. Pinching the nose for the past hour has not stopped the bleeding. For the past several months, he has had recurring nosebleeds that resolved with pressure. He has no history of hypertension or trauma. He has asthma that is well controlled with an albuterol inhaler. He has intermittent tension headaches for which he takes aspirin. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 160/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows active bleeding from both nostrils. Pupil size is 6 mm bilaterally in bright light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The hemoglobin concentration is 13.5 g/dL, prothrombin time is 12 seconds, partial thromboplastin time is 35 seconds, and platelet count is 345,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: Mydriasis, tachycardia, and hypertension indicate increased sympathetic stimulation.
learning_objective: Recognize cocaine use as a cause of recurrent nosebleeds.

answers.explanation_why: Hypertension can increase the severity of a nosebleed, but it would not cause a nosebleed on its own. Combined with an underlying condition such as a bleeding disorder, it might lead to recurrent nosebleeds.

Digital manipulation and dry air are the most common causes of epistaxis and may have also played a role in this patient's nosebleed. However, given this patient's hypertension, tachycardia, and mydriasis, a different explanation is more likely.

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT; Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome) is an autosomal dominant systemic vasculopathy. Although epistaxis is the most common presenting symptom of this condition, HHT would not explain this patient's acute hypertension, tachycardia, and mydriasis. Moreover, the patient would be expected to have other features of HHT, e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding, iron deficiency anemia, and mucocutaneous telangiectasia.

Some studies have suggested a correlation between aspirin use and epistaxis. However, it would not explain this patient's acute hypertension, tachycardia, or mydriasis. If taken in excess, aspirin can cause acute salicylate poisoning, which commonly manifests with nausea, vomiting, tinnitus, tachypnea, and hyperpnea (due to acid-base disturbances).

Cocaine causes tachycardia, hypertension, anxiety, and mydriasis, which are all present in this patient. Because the drug is usually snorted, it can cause damage to the fragile nasal vessels, especially with repeated use, resulting in nosebleeds.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JVA) is a rare, benign, locally aggressive tumor that occurs virtually exclusively in adolescent males. Although recurrent, uncontrolled epistaxis is characteristic of this condition, JVA would not explain this patient's acute hypertension, tachycardia, and mydriasis. The tumor manifests instead with facial swelling, recurrent headaches, nasal obstruction, impaired breathing, or anosmia.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of concerns about his behavior during the past year. His parents report that he often fails to answer when they call him and has regular unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming. At kindergarten, he can follow and participate in group activities but does not follow his teacher's instructions when these are given to him directly. He is otherwise cheerful and maintains eye contact when spoken to but does not respond when engaged in play. He gets along well with friends and family. He started walking at the age of 11 months and can speak in two-word phrases. He often mispronounces words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of concerns about his behavior during the past year. His parents report that he often fails to answer when they call him and has regular unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming. At kindergarten, he can follow and participate in group activities but does not follow his teacher's instructions when these are given to him directly. He is otherwise cheerful and maintains eye contact when spoken to but does not respond when engaged in play. He gets along well with friends and family. He started walking at the age of 11 months and can speak in two-word phrases. He often mispronounces words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's condition can be congenital or acquired.
learning_objective: Recognize hearing impairment in children.

answers.explanation_why: Selective mutism is a response to intense anxiety that may appear oppositional and often presents with social phobia. This patient often fails to respond when called and does not follow instructions consistently, but he does not fail to speak in any specific setting, nor does he show signs of anxiety in social situations.

Undetected hearing impairment in children can cause delays in speech, language, and cognitive development. This patient's presentation with apparent inattentiveness and difficulty following directions when directly spoken to, delayed language development (at 4 years, he should be able to speak in at least 4-word sentences), mispronunciation of words (due to poor speech discrimination), and symptoms of frustration (apparently unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming) warrants a thorough evaluation for hearing impairment.

Routine screening for hearing loss in children is recommended for newborns and then periodically throughout childhood. Hearing tests should also be performed in all children with behavioral problems.

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) may also manifest with problems at home and school/kindergarten, difficulties of following orders/instructions, and frequent outbursts (e.g., unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming). However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of ODD such as excessive arguing, revenge-seeking behavior, and aggression towards figures of authority (e.g., teachers, parents). Instead, he presents with delayed language development, which would be atypical for ODD.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can manifest with impaired language development and deficits in social interaction and communication at home and in school, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of ASD such as poor eye contact and repetitive, stereotyped patterns of behavior. Instead, he presents with features of well-adjusted social and emotional behavior (e.g., getting along with friends and family, participating in group activities), which make this diagnosis unlikely.

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can manifest with symptoms of inattention and impulsivity as seen in this patient (i.e., unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming, not responding when directly spoken to). However, delayed language development is atypical for ADHD and makes a different diagnosis more likely.

Specific learning disorders (e.g., dyslexia, dyscalculia, impairment of written expression) typically manifest with poor performance at school, failure to follow instructions, and difficulties in completing tasks. However, this patient only shows impaired attention when directly spoken to and delayed language development (only uses two-word phrases and often mispronounces words), which is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

This patient presents with inattention and difficulty following directions when directly spoken to for more than 6 months that severely impairs his language development and affects his behavior as well as social interaction. Such behavior is not age-appropriate and requires full evaluation by a doctor.

question_text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of excessive daytime sleepiness and fatigue. She says she has difficulty concentrating and has fallen asleep at work on numerous occasions. She also reports having frequent headaches during the day. She has no difficulty falling asleep at night, but wakes up gasping for breath at least once. She has always snored loudly and began using an oral device to decrease her snoring a year ago. She has occasional lower back pain, for which she takes tramadol tablets 1–2 times per week. She also began taking one rabeprazole tablet daily 3 weeks ago. She does not smoke. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 119 kg (262 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m^2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.35

P_CO2
51 mm Hg

P_O2

64 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

29 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
92%

An x-ray of the chest and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's blood gas abnormalities?
content_preview: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of excessive daytime sleepiness and fatigue. She says she has difficulty concentrating and has fallen asleep at work on numerous occasions. She also reports having frequent headaches during the day. She has no difficulty falling asleep at night, but wakes up gasping for breath at least once. She has always snored loudly and began using an oral device to decrease her snoring a year ago. She has occasional lower back pain, for which she takes tramadol tablets 1–2 times per week. She also began taking one rabeprazole tablet daily 3 weeks ago. She does not smoke. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 119 kg (262 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.35 PCO2 51 mm Hg PO2 64 mm Hg HCO3- 29 mEq/L O2 saturation 92% An x-ray of the chest and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's blood gas abnormalities?
hint: This patient's condition is named after Charles Dickens's "Pickwick Papers,” which features a character named Joe who is notable for his obesity and tendency to fall asleep.
learning_objective: Recognize obesity hypoventilation syndrome, and recall its characteristic blood gas findings.

answers.content: Apneic episodes with obstructed upper airways
answers.explanation_why: Apnea due to obstructed upper airways is characteristic of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). This patient's history and clinical features are consistent with OSA, in which obstruction to the upper airways results in apneic episodes that in turn cause hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis. However, these abnormalities are typically absent when the patient is awake, which is not the case here.

Central respiratory depression due to deceleration of rhythmic impulses from the respiratory center in the CNS can occur secondary to opioid overdose. The resulting hypoventilation would cause abnormalities in arterial blood gas analysis similar to those seen in this patient, who is taking tramadol. However, tramadol is generally considered safer than most opioids with regard to respiratory depression and this patient's occasional tramadol use is not enough to cause respiratory depression. In this obese patient, another diagnosis is more likely.

answers.content: Reduced oxygen carrying capacity of blood
answers.explanation_why: Reduced oxygen carrying capacity of the blood is characteristic of anemia, which is an important differential diagnosis in patients with chronic fatigue and nonspecific symptoms. However, other features such as pallor and palpitations would be expected. Furthermore, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient shows hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis, which is not a finding associated with anemia.

answers.content: Skeletal abnormality of the chest wall
answers.explanation_why: Skeletal abnormalities of the chest wall (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, pectus excavatum) can restrict respiratory excursion, resulting in hypoventilation and arterial blood gas findings similar to those seen in this patient. However, chest wall abnormalities that would be severe enough to cause such symptoms would be obvious on clinical examination and/or on imaging.

Chronic inflammatory airflow limitation is the mechanism of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The main findings are chronic cough with expectoration, dyspnea, early inspiratory coarse crackles, and wheezing, as well as a prolonged expiratory phase and decreased breath sounds. Arterial blood gas analysis will show findings similar to what is seen in this patient: decreased pO_2 and daytime hypercapnia due to air trapping as a result of expiratory collapse of small airways. However, chest x-ray would likely show signs of hyperinflation (e.g., horizontal ribs and widened intercostal spaces, increased anteroposterior diameter, flattened diaphragm). Furthermore, COPD predominantly affects patients with a history of smoking, making it unlikely in this nonsmoker.

Thickening of alveolar membranes with impaired gas exchange is characteristic of interstitial lung disease, which manifests with exertional dyspnea that progresses to dyspnea at rest, persistent nonproductive cough, and fatigue. Arterial blood gas analysis will show low partial oxygen pressure and respiratory acidosis due to impaired gas exchange, but only in the late stages of disease. Given the absence of pulmonary symptoms, this patient is unlikely to have advanced interstitial lung disease. Furthermore, chest x-ray in interstitial lung disease is likely to show an increase in reticular opacities, indicating fibrosis, whereas this patient's x-ray findings are normal.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is characterized by awake alveolar hypoventilation resulting in daytime hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis. Metabolic compensation (elevated HCO_3^-) is usually also present and indicates that the hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis is chronic. Obesity reduces inspiratory muscle strength and restricts respiratory excursions, resulting in alveolar hypoventilation. Moreover, obesity is associated with increased production of CO_2 as a result of the larger body surface area, further contributing to hypercapnia. OHS can be diagnosed in patients with BMI ≥ 30 kg/m^2 with symptoms similar to OSA (excessive daytime sleepiness, restless sleep, snoring with apneic episodes) and evidence of daytime alveolar hypoventilation on arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis that cannot be otherwise explained.

90% of patients with OHS also have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and distinguishing the two conditions can be challenging because the risk factors and symptoms are very similar. The main difference between the two conditions is that the ABG abnormalities are diurnal in OHS and nocturnal in OSA.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent throbbing headaches over the past year. The headaches are worse when he wakes up and are not accompanied by other symptoms. The patient also reports trouble concentrating on daily tasks at his office job. His wife recently started sleeping in their guest bedroom because “I just couldn't take it anymore. His sinusitis has been acting up at night and I was not able to catch any sleep.” The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic sinusitis, and an allergy to dust mites. Medications include enalapril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. His pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 120 kg (265 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m^2. Neurologic examination is normal. Cardiac examination shows a normal S_1 and S_2 and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. His skin is warm and well perfused. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent throbbing headaches over the past year. The headaches are worse when he wakes up and are not accompanied by other symptoms. The patient also reports trouble concentrating on daily tasks at his office job. His wife recently started sleeping in their guest bedroom because “I just couldn't take it anymore. His sinusitis has been acting up at night and I was not able to catch any sleep.” The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic sinusitis, and an allergy to dust mites. Medications include enalapril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. His pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 120 kg (265 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Neurologic examination is normal. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. His skin is warm and well perfused. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
hint: A questionnaire is used to screen for this patient's condition and polysomnography is used to confirm the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea, and recall its effect on blood pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Low circulating free thyroxine levels, seen in hypothyroidism, could explain this patient's hypertension, impaired concentration, and obesity. However, he lacks other characteristic features of hypothyroidism, such as cold intolerance, constipation, hyporeflexia, bradycardia, and skin changes (e.g., cold, dry skin, myxedema, hair loss).

The collapse of pharyngeal muscles during sleep leading to transient nocturnal upper airway obstruction is the main mechanism underlying obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Typical features of this disease include nocturnal snoring, morning headaches, poor concentration, daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and depression. Nocturnal apneic episodes in individuals with OSA result in nocturnal hypercapnia, which, in turn, causes an increased sympathetic response that leads to secondary hypertension. Obesity, especially around the neck, is the most important risk factor for developing OSA, and weight loss will often improve symptoms.

images.title: Obstructive sleep apnea
images.description: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

answers.explanation_why: Hypophyseal or pituitary adenomas can cause a mass effect leading to headaches. Secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH secretion from a functional pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) could also explain this patient's hypertension, poor concentration, and obesity. However, pituitary adenomas usually cause visual field defects (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia), which are not reported on neurological examination. In addition, hyperpigmentation and cutaneous features of Cushing syndrome (e,g., thin skin, striae, buffalo hump) would be expected in patients with Cushing disease.

Pheochromocytoma, a usually benign tumor of the chromaffin cells in the adrenal gland, could explain this patient's hypertension and intermittent headaches. However, the headaches associated with pheochromocytoma are typically paroxysmal and accompanied by significant sweating, tachycardia, and pallor. Early morning headache, difficulty concentrating, and obesity suggest a different underlying cause for this patient's hypertension.

Primary hyperaldosteronism can manifest with treatment refractory hypertension and headaches. However, hyperaldosteronism would not explain this patient's difficulty concentrating or obesity. The presence of these features suggests a different diagnosis.

Low synaptic serotonin levels are associated with depression, which can manifest with weight gain, inability to concentrate, and chronic headache (e.g., migraine), but it would not cause hypertension.

question_text: The patient undergoes polysomnography, which shows around 10 apneic episodes that cease on arousal, confirming a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea. The physician recommends therapy with a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device at night and counsels the patient on the importance of losing weight, maintaining proper sleep positioning, and avoidance of alcohol and medications that affect the central nervous system. At a follow-up visit one month later, the patient reports a sensation of claustrophobia while wearing the CPAP device's mask and refuses to adhere to the CPAP therapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the treatment of this patient's condition?
content_preview: The patient undergoes polysomnography, which shows around 10 apneic episodes that cease on arousal, confirming a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea. The physician recommends therapy with a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device at night and counsels the patient on the importance of losing weight, maintaining proper sleep positioning, and avoidance of alcohol and medications that affect the central nervous system. At a follow-up visit one month later, the patient reports a sensation of claustrophobia while wearing the CPAP device's mask and refuses to adhere to the CPAP therapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the treatment of this patient's condition?
hint: Positive airway pressure (e.g., CPAP) is the first-line treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). If the patient is unable to tolerate positive airway pressure therapy, a second-line treatment for OSA should be considered. The occurence of 5–15 apneic or hypopneic episodes during sleep consistent with mild OSA.
learning_objective: Recognize intolerance to CPAP in obstructive sleep apnea, and choose an alternative treatment option.

answers.explanation_why: In the adult population, enlargement of the uvula, soft palate, and retrolingual tissue are the primary causes of OSA and uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is a second-line treatment for moderate to severe OSA. Adenotonsillectomy is indicated for OSA caused by adenotonsillar hypertrophy, which is a cause of OSA primarily in children.

Nocturnal oxygen therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for certain patients with central sleep apnea (e.g., central sleep apnea related to heart failure) but is not used to treat OSA. A treatment that relieves obstruction in the upper airway is required for patients with OSA.

The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides motor innervation only to the stylopharyngeus muscle, which dilates the nasopharynx during breathing. CN IX stimulation has no role in OSA treatment because OSA is primarily caused by obstruction at the level of the oropharynx rather than the nasopharynx. Instead, stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII), which opens the oropharynx and lower pharyngeal airway by protruding and depressing the tongue, can be used as a second-line treatment for patients with moderate to severe OSA.

Oral appliances and positional therapy devices are second-line treatment options for patients with mild to moderate OSA. A mandibular advancement device worn during sleep is the most commonly recommended oral appliance for OSA patients and works by maintaining an anterior-inferior mandibular advancement to prevent airway collapse. Positional therapy devices keep patients in a lateral as opposed to supine sleeping position. For patients with moderate to severe OSA, upper airway modification procedures (e.g., uvulopalatopharyngoplasty, maxillomandibular advancement surgery, radiofrequency ablation of oropharyngeal tissue, hypoglossal nerve stimulation) can be considered.

images.title: Mandibular advancement device
images.description: The device is worn during sleep to treat mild to moderate obstructive sleep apnea or primary snoring. It pushes the lower jaw forward, leading to a wider opening of the upper airway and preventing airway collapse.

answers.explanation_why: Atomoxetine, which has noradrenergic effects that reduce upper airway collapsibility, has been proposed as a potential therapy for OSA. However, no pharmacological agent has yet been proven to be effective against OSA, so atomoxetine therapy would not be the most appropriate initial treatment.

question_text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blisters on her forearm that appeared 3 days ago. She also reports pain in her left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. She has not been sick for the past 6 months. She has started hiking in the woods on the weekends with her son a couple of months ago but has been careful to avoid poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She recently started taking captopril and stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. She has a family history of pernicious anemia and Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple, flaccid blisters over the volar surface of the forearm and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. The total body surface area involvement of the blisters is estimated to be 10%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blisters on her forearm that appeared 3 days ago. She also reports pain in her left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. She has not been sick for the past 6 months. She has started hiking in the woods on the weekends with her son a couple of months ago but has been careful to avoid poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She recently started taking captopril and stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. She has a family history of pernicious anemia and Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple, flaccid blisters over the volar surface of the forearm and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. The total body surface area involvement of the blisters is estimated to be 10%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's condition is confirmed via biopsy, which would show acantholysis and deposition of IgG in the intercellular spaces of the epidermis.
learning_objective: Recognize pemphigus vulgaris.

answers.explanation_why: Lichen planus typically affects patients 30–60 years of age and may manifest with lesions on the skin as well as the mucous membranes of the oral cavity and/or genitalia. Antihypertensive drugs have been known to trigger lichen planus-like eruptions. However, lichen planus usually manifests as firm, shiny, reddish-purple, polygonal papules that are intensely pruritic, and the enanthem would typically appear as white streaks forming a lace-like network (Wickham striae) or fixed white plaques. Blister formation is not usually seen in patients with lichen planus.

images.title: Cutaneous lichen planus
images.description: Photograph of the left wristMultiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated. This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

answers.explanation_why: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), which can be induced by therapy with oxicam NSAIDs such as meloxicam, would result in blisters of the skin and mucous membranes as well as a positive Nikolsky sign. However, TEN usually occurs within 8 weeks of initiating therapy with the drug, whereas this patient had presumably been on meloxicam for a longer period. Moreover, patients with TEN typically have widespread involvement of the skin surface (> 30% of the body surface area) and systemic features such as fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.

images.title: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)
images.description: The trunk and arm show generalized, widespread, extensive necrosis with purple and red erythema, as well as yellow-white exudation. Spots of hemorrhagic, subepidermal tissue can also be seen.These characteristic findings are distinctive for TEN, a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

answers.explanation_why: Behcet disease can cause painful oral and genital ulcers as well as cutaneous lesions. However, the cutaneous manifestations of Behcet disease typically appear as papulopustular lesions or lesions resembling erythema nodosum; blisters are not characteristic. Moreover, Behcet disease typically occurs between 20–40 years, and clinical features of uveitis such as eye pain and redness, decreased vision, and/or hypopyon are often present.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) can manifest with painful blisters and a positive Nikolsky sign. However, SSSS typically occurs in children below the age of 6 years and blisters would be accompanied by erythema of the surrounding skin and features of systemic toxicity such as fever and/or malaise. Also, mucosal involvement does not occur in SSSS, and the onset of blisters would be preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo, staphylococcal diarrhea).

Dermatitis herpetiformis can cause blistering of the skin. However, dermatitis herpetiformis typically affects the extensor surfaces of elbows, knees, and buttocks, and patients usually present with intense pruritus. Mucosal involvement does not typically occur.

images.title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
images.description: Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

answers.explanation_why: Bullous pemphigoid can be caused by captopril and would manifest with cutaneous blisters. However, the blisters are typically tense and occur symmetrically, with a predilection for intertriginous areas, while Nikolsky sign is typically negative. Moreover, bullous pemphigoid usually manifests with a prodromal phase, which is characterized by pruritus and papules/urticarial lesions/skin excoriations. Lastly, mucous membranes (especially those of the genitalia) are typically spared in patients with bullous pemphigoid.

images.title: Bullous pemphigoid
images.description: Erythematous skin with a solitary tense blister (unknown localization) is visible in the center of the image.This appearance is typical of bullous pemphigoid.

answers.explanation_why:
Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1. Thiol-containing drugs (e.g., captopril, penicillamine) and phenol-containing drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, rifampicin, phenobarbital, aspirin) can induce the formation of these autoantibodies. Since desmosomal adhesion proteins enable keratinocyte adherence, damage to these proteins causes intraepidermal bullae formation and a positive Nikolsky sign. The lesions typically occur first on mucous membranes and can become confluent or erode to form painful ulcers. PV is treated with high-dose systemic corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., azathioprine, IVIG, rituximab). Severe PV can be fatal, as it can lead to bacterial superinfection, fluid loss, and/or electrolyte imbalance.

See “Overview of blistering diseases” table.

images.title: Pemphigus vulgaris
images.description: Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

question_text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurring fever and night sweats. The fevers persist for 7 to 10 days and then subside completely for about a week before returning again. During the past 6 months, has had a 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss and has also noticed painless lumps on his neck that have gradually increased in size. Two years ago, he had a severe sore throat and fever, which was diagnosed as infectious mononucleosis. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He does not drink alcohol. His job involves monthly international travel to Asia and Africa. He takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlarged, nontender, fixed cervical lymph nodes on each side of the neck. A photomicrograph from a biopsy of a cervical lymph node is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely present in this patient?
content_preview: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurring fever and night sweats. The fevers persist for 7 to 10 days and then subside completely for about a week before returning again. During the past 6 months, has had a 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss and has also noticed painless lumps on his neck that have gradually increased in size. Two years ago, he had a severe sore throat and fever, which was diagnosed as infectious mononucleosis. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He does not drink alcohol. His job involves monthly international travel to Asia and Africa. He takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlarged, nontender, fixed cervical lymph nodes on each side of the neck. A photomicrograph from a biopsy of a cervical lymph node is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely present in this patient?
hint: Regional nontender lymphadenopathy, B symptoms with a Pel-Ebstein fever pattern, and the lymph node biopsy finding of typical Reed-Sternberg cells on an inflammatory background indicate a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.
learning_objective: Recognize Hodgkin lymphoma, and recall its characteristic cell surface markers.

answers.explanation_why: A proliferation of monomorphic lymphocytic cells is a characteristic feature of some non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs), in contrast to the heterogeneous morphology of classic Hodgkin lymphoma. NHLs can cause lymphadenopathy and B symptoms but histopathology is unlikely to show Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, NHLs often cause extranodal disease, most commonly involving the gastrointestinal tract, skin, thyroid, and CNS, but the patient has no complaints relating to any of these organs.

answers.content: IgG and IgM antibodies against a viral capsid antigen
answers.explanation_why: Primary Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, i.e., infectious mononucleosis (IM), would result in the presence of both IgG and IgM antibodies against the EBV-associated viral capsid antigen (VCA). Because of this patient's past IM, he would test positive for IgG anti-VCA antibodies but IgM anti-VCA antibodies typically disappear 3 months after the primary EBV infection.

Lymph node biopsies in cases of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) can show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD15/30-positive, polynuclear giant cells that originate from B cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for HL and confirm the diagnosis.

Past primary infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), i.e., infectious mononucleosis, is a risk factor for HL. The most common histological types of EBV-associated HL are mixed cellularity HL and lymphocyte-depleted HL, and the median time to the onset of EBV-associated HL is approx. 3 years after the primary infection.

Auer rods on a peripheral smear are characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML causes bone marrow failure, resulting in anemia and an increased risk of bleeding and infections. Although the fever in this patient could indicate an infection, he lacks pallor and petechiae. Additionally, lymphadenopathy is not a typical feature of AML, and Reed-Sternberg cells would not be expected.

Extreme leukocytosis (> 500,000/mm^3) is typical in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a disease that causes B symptoms. However, lymphadenopathy is not a typical initial finding in CML, and the patient does not have splenomegaly, another characteristic finding in CML. CML would also not cause Reed-Sternberg cells.

answers.content: Acid fast bacilli in the sputum
answers.explanation_why: The presence of acid-fast bacilli in the sputum is consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). Active pulmonary TB can cause B symptoms, and the incidence of TB is high in Africa and Asia, where this patient frequently travels. However, the most important finding in active pulmonary TB would be a productive cough and dyspnea, and histopathology would show caseating granulomas. Reed-Sternberg cells would not be expected.

images.title: Reed-Sternberg cell
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

question_text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of muscle weakness. During this period, the patient has had low energy, intermittent nosebleeds, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He also reports progressive hearing and vision problems. He has a history of pins-and-needles sensation, numbness, and pain in his feet. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable liver tip 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. There is nontender lympadenopathy in the groin, axillae, and neck. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
8.8 g/dL

Leukocyte count
6300/mm^3

Platelet count
98,000/mm^3

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
70 mm/h

Serum

 Na^+

136 mmol/L

 K^+

3.6 mmol/L

 Ca^2+

8.6 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL

 AST
32 U/L

 ALT
36 U/L

 Alkaline phosphatase
130 U/L

 Lactate dehydrogenase
220 U/L

A serum protein electrophoresis exhibits a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of muscle weakness. During this period, the patient has had low energy, intermittent nosebleeds, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He also reports progressive hearing and vision problems. He has a history of pins-and-needles sensation, numbness, and pain in his feet. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable liver tip 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. There is nontender lympadenopathy in the groin, axillae, and neck. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 8.8 g/dL Leukocyte count 6300/mm3 Platelet count 98,000/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 70 mm/h Serum Na+ 136 mmol/L K+ 3.6 mmol/L Ca2+ 8.6 mg/dL Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL AST 32 U/L ALT 36 U/L Alkaline phosphatase 130 U/L Lactate dehydrogenase 220 U/L A serum protein electrophoresis exhibits a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A bone marrow biopsy in this patient would show intranuclear inclusions of IgM deposits in plasma cells, also known as Dutcher bodies.
learning_objective: Recognize Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) primarily occurs in older patients (> 70 years) and could explain this patient's fatigue, weight loss, generalized painless lymphadenopathy, anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperviscosity syndrome (as indicated by progressive vision and hearing loss), and hepatomegaly. However, CLL is associated with further features, such as lymphocytosis, a history of recurrent infections (e.g., necrotic erysipelas, candidiasis, and/or herpes zoster), and polyclonal gammopathy (i.e., broad-based peak representing a polyclonal increase in immunoglobulins) rather than monoclonal gammopathy (i.e., single spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin).

Hairy cell leukemia affects middle-aged men and causes anemia and thrombocytopenia. However, B symptoms and lymphadenopathy are typically absent. Also, usually massive splenomegaly dominates, recurrent infections occur (due to leukopenia), and the B cells do not lead to monoclonal protein production.

Multiple myeloma (MM) can manifest with weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome (as indicated by progressive vision and hearing loss), and bleeding susceptibility along with a monoclonal spike on electrophoresis in older individuals. However, enlarged lymph nodes are not a typical finding in MM. Moreover, this condition is typically associated with excess production of IgG or IgA, not IgM. In addition, the CRAB symptoms (hypercalcemia, renal disease, anemia, and bone lesions) are classically present to varying degrees. This patient is normocalcemic with adequate renal function and has not reported any bone pain, making MM a less likely diagnosis.

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is an indolent type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is caused by abnormal production of IgM antibodies by monoclonal plasma cells. This condition usually manifests in older patients with impaired platelet function (nosebleeds), anemia, and mild thrombocytopenia, progressive neuropathy (history of pain and numbness in the feet, muscle weakness), and hyperviscosity syndrome (vision and hearing loss). Lymph node enlargement, as well as increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, lactate dehydrogenase, and alkaline phosphatase can also be present. Serum protein electrophoresis demonstrating a dense, monoclonal IgM band is essential for diagnosis. Treatment includes administration of CD20 antibodies (e.g., rituximab) and plasmapheresis in case of hyperviscosity syndrome.

Hyperviscosity syndrome is present in about 30% of patients with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. This condition is not caused by an increase in hematocrit but rather from the clumping effects induced by the pathologically elevated serum IgM concentrations (i.e., IgM act as cold agglutinins).

This patient's age (> 45 years old) and abnormal production of monoclonal immunoglobulins are consistent with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS). However, MGUS is, by definition, not associated with any accompanying clinical symptoms.

Mantle cell lymphoma also affects older males (65–70 years) and causes painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, increased lactate dehydrogenase, and constitutional symptoms. However, mantle cell lymphoma is usually also associated with extensive splenomegaly and gastrointestinal discomfort and pain due to stomach and colon involvement. Simultaneous vision and hearing changes are not typically seen and monoclonal proliferation is very rare. Although this condition cannot be ruled out completely in this case, another option is much more likely.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of white lesions in her mouth that she first noticed 5 days ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy. She has asthma treated with theophylline, inhaled β-adrenergic agonists, and corticosteroids. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Oral examination shows white plaques on the buccal mucosa and hard palate that are firmly adherent and cannot be scraped off. She has no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of white lesions in her mouth that she first noticed 5 days ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy. She has asthma treated with theophylline, inhaled β-adrenergic agonists, and corticosteroids. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Oral examination shows white plaques on the buccal mucosa and hard palate that are firmly adherent and cannot be scraped off. She has no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has white plaques of the oral mucosa that cannot be scraped off, which is typical of leukoplakia. Cigarette smoking is a known risk factor for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize leukoplakia, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why:
Biopsy of the lesions is the next best step in the management of leukoplakia, which most commonly affects the oral cavity. While leukoplakia is by itself a benign lesion, it predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma. Up to 30% of leukoplakia lesions progress to carcinoma depending on appearance, demography, and follow-up time. Because of this, it is important to biopsy leukoplakia lesions to check for signs of dysplasia.

Treatment consists of smoking cessation, cryotherapy, laser ablation, or surgical excision if the lesion persists.

images.title: Oral leukoplakia
images.description:
Oral cavityWell-defined white plaques with irregular borders can be seen bilaterally on the mucosa of the soft palate.
These patches cannot be scraped off with gauze.

answers.explanation_why: Topical nystatin is the first-line therapy for oropharyngeal candidiasis. This patient uses inhaled corticosteroids, which are a known risk factor for developing oral candidiasis. However, candidiasis is identified by its ability to be easily scraped off. The lesions in this patient's mouth are strongly adherent, making leukoplakia a more likely diagnosis. Additionally, this patient lacks other common symptoms of candidiasis, including pain while eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth.

A culture of the lesions would be appropriate if there was a concern for oropharyngeal candidiasis. However, candidiasis can be identified by its ability to be easily scraped off. The lesions in this patient's mouth are strongly adherent, making leukoplakia a more likely diagnosis. Additionally, this patient lacks other common symptoms of candidiasis, including pain while eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth.

Topical corticosteroids would be useful for the management of aphthous stomatitis. These “canker sores” have a round to oval, crater-like appearance on yellowish-grey base and erythematous margins, unlike this patient's presentation of white plaques.

Smoking cessation is indicated in the long-term health maintenance of this patient. However, it would not directly help with the diagnosis or management of leukoplakia, and more immediate steps need to be taken.
Surgical excision may be needed if the lesions persist following more conservative treatment. It would not be the first-line therapy or diagnostic tool.

Monospot test would be used to test for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which can cause oral hairy leukoplakia. This condition also manifests as white painless plaques that cannot be scraped off. However, they tend to occur on the lateral edges of the tongue as opposed to the buccal mucosa and hard palate as seen in this patient.

Note that the EBV serology test is the diagnostic test of choice for EBV infection, as the monospot test has a high risk of false positive and false negative results.
