question_text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough with blood in the sputum for 1 day. She also reports a sharp pain under her ribs that is worsened by taking deep breaths. Over the past 2 years, she has had repeated episodes of sinusitis, for which she used over-the-counter medication. She has recently started a new job at a wire-mesh factory. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows palpable nonblanching skin lesions over her hands and feet. Examination of the nasal cavity shows ulcerations of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and a small septal perforation. Pulmonary examination shows stridor on inspiration. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL

Leukocyte count
10,300/mm^3

Platelet count
205,000/mm^3

Serum

 Urea nitrogen
24 mg/dL

 Creatinine
2.4 mg/dL

Urine

 Protein

2+

 RBC

70/hpf

 RBC casts

numerous

 WBC
1–2/hpf

A chest x-ray shows multiple cavitating, nodular lesions bilaterally. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
content_preview: A 50-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough with blood in the sputum for 1 day. She also reports a sharp pain under her ribs that is worsened by taking deep breaths. Over the past 2 years, she has had repeated episodes of sinusitis, for which she used over-the-counter medication. She has recently started a new job at a wire-mesh factory. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows palpable nonblanching skin lesions over her hands and feet. Examination of the nasal cavity shows ulcerations of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and a small septal perforation. Pulmonary examination shows stridor on inspiration. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,300/mm3 Platelet count 205,000/mm3 Serum Urea nitrogen 24 mg/dL Creatinine 2.4 mg/dL Urine Protein 2+ RBC 70/hpf RBC casts numerous WBC 1–2/hpf A chest x-ray shows multiple cavitating, nodular lesions bilaterally. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
hint: This patient has the classic triad of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA): necrotizing vasculitis (palpable purpura), upper/lower respiratory tract manifestations (chronic sinusitis, nasal ulcers, hemoptysis, and pleuritis), and glomerulonephritis (elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria with red blood cell casts).
learning_objective: Recognize granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and recall its associated antibody.

answers.explanation_why:
Increased c-ANCA titers are present in approximately 90% of patients with active GPA and 60–70% of patients with inactive disease, due to antibodies against proteinase-3. A biopsy of affected tissue (e.g., nasopharynx) should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis, which would show necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis.

Inspiratory stridor in this patient should be urgently evaluated because it could be the result of a severe case of subglottic stenosis, the most common tracheobronchial manifestation of GPA. Over time, nasal cartilage destruction can lead to saddle nose deformity.

Serum IgA titers may be increased in patients with IgA vasculitis, which can manifest with fever (prodromal), palpable purpura, nephritic syndrome, and, rarely, hemoptysis. However, IgA vasculitis typically occurs in children, and features such as pleuritic chest pain, ulceration of nasopharyngeal mucosa, septal perforation/deformities, recurrent sinusitis, and multiple cavitating, nodular lesions on a chest x-ray would not be seen. Instead, patients usually have a history of colicky abdominal pain.

p-ANCA titers are increased in less than 10% of patients with GPA. Instead, p-ANCA titers are commonly elevated in patients with microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), which can manifest with involvement of the lungs (hemoptysis due to pulmonary vasculitis), the kidneys (glomerulonephritis), and the skin (palpable purpura). However, involvement of the nasopharynx (septal perforation, sinusitis, ulceration) is much more common in GPA (90%) than in MPA (35%). Although MPA cannot be entirely excluded in this patient without histopathologic examination, the extensive upper respiratory tract involvement makes GPA the more likely diagnosis.

Increased levels of p-ANCA are also commonly seen in patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which can manifest with fever, hemoptysis, hematuria, and chronic rhinosinusitis (allergic). However, septal perforation is rare, and features such as pleuritic chest pain, ulceration of the nasal mucosa, and nodular cavitating lesions on chest x-ray would not be seen. Instead, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically present with a history of bronchial asthma, multifocal mononeuropathy, and/or evidence of eosinophilia.

Asbestos bodies in sputum are seen in asbestosis, which can manifest with hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, and nodular lesions on a chest x-ray. A history of working in a wire-mesh factory would have been a risk factor for asbestosis before the ban of spray-on asbestos products, but no longer today. Moreover, symptoms of asbestosis have a chronic onset and usually develop 10–15 years after continuous exposure to asbestos. This patient has had a hyperacute onset of respiratory symptoms and only recently started work at a wire-mesh factory. Furthermore, nephritic syndrome, palpable purpura, nasopharyngeal ulceration, and septal deformities/perforation are not expected in patients with asbestosis.

Anti-GBM antibodies are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which can manifest with fever, hemoptysis, chest pain, and nephritic syndrome. However, inspiratory stridor and cavitating nodular lesions on chest x-ray would not be seen. Instead, patients have diffuse infiltrating opacification of the lung fields (due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage). Furthermore, palpable purpura, recurrent sinusitis, ulceration of nasopharyngeal mucosa, and septal perforation/deformities are not features of Goodpasture syndrome.

Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is more common among women, and can manifest with fever, nephritic syndrome (due to lupus nephritis), hemoptysis (due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage), pleuritis, palpable purpura (due to cutaneous vasculitis), ulceration of the nasal mucosa, and, rarely, septal perforation/deformities. However, a history of malaise, weight loss, myalgia, arthralgia, and/or photosensitivity are usually present. Also, cavitating, nodular lesions on a chest x-ray would not be seen in SLE.

A positive tuberculin skin test can be seen in patients with tuberculosis, which can manifest with fever, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, and multiple, nodular, cavitating lesions on chest x-ray. Rarely, septal perforation (due to destruction of the septal cartilage by granulomatous lesions), hematuria (due to genitourinary tuberculosis), and cutaneous manifestations (scrofuloderma or lupus vulgaris) can also occur. However, the onset of respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, fever) is usually subacute to chronic unlike the hyperacute presentation in this patient, and other symptoms such as weight loss, malaise, and/or night sweats would be present. Also, patients with disseminated tuberculosis would usually have a history of immigration from an endemic region, and/or an immunocompromised state (e.g., HIV infection, therapy with anti-TNF-α drugs).

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

question_text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of malaise and dark urine for the past 5 days. He has also had recurrent episodes of sinus congestion, productive cough, and fever for 3 months. Additionally, he has noticed a rash on his arms and feet. He has seasonal allergic conjunctivitis treated with ketotifen eye drops. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several erythematous and necrotic papules on his arms and feet. He has inflamed nasopharyngeal mucosa and a perforated nasal septum. The nasal bridge is collapsed. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11.3 g/dL

Leukocyte count
12,000/mm^3

Platelet count
270,000/mm^3

ESR
55 mm/h

Serum

 Urea nitrogen
28 mg/dL

 Creatinine
2.9 mg/dL

 Anti-DNA antibodies
negative

 Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

positive

Urine

 Protein
2+

 Glucose
negative

 RBC
35–37/hpf

 RBC casts

numerous

A biopsy specimen of the affected tissue is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of malaise and dark urine for the past 5 days. He has also had recurrent episodes of sinus congestion, productive cough, and fever for 3 months. Additionally, he has noticed a rash on his arms and feet. He has seasonal allergic conjunctivitis treated with ketotifen eye drops. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several erythematous and necrotic papules on his arms and feet. He has inflamed nasopharyngeal mucosa and a perforated nasal septum. The nasal bridge is collapsed. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.3 g/dL Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3 Platelet count 270,000/mm3 ESR 55 mm/h Serum Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL Creatinine 2.9 mg/dL Anti-DNA antibodies negative Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies positive Urine Protein 2+ Glucose negative RBC 35–37/hpf RBC casts numerous A biopsy specimen of the affected tissue is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with nephritic sediment (hematuria, RBC casts, moderate proteinuria), elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and a productive cough. Simultaneous involvement of the kidneys and the lungs is characteristic of pulmonary-renal syndrome. A history of chronic sinusitis, saddle nose deformity, and necrotic skin lesions indicate a type of vasculitis that typically presents with elevated c-ANCA titers.
learning_objective: Recognize granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and recall its tissue biopsy findings.

answers.explanation_why: Tissue eosinophilia with granulomatous reactions is a typical finding in patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). This condition can manifest with malaise, elevated ANCA-titers (positive for p-ANCA), elevated ESR, skin lesions, seasonal allergic conjunctivitis, and pulmonary-renal syndrome, including upper airway symptoms (e.g., sinusitis) and glomerulonephritis (RBC casts, elevated creatinine). However, this patient lacks other typical features of EGPA such as severe allergic asthma attacks (usually the chief complaint), gastrointestinal involvement, and CNS involvement (e.g., mononeuritis multiplex).

answers.content: Nongranulomatous fibrinoid necrosis with infiltration of neutrophils
answers.explanation_why: Nongranulomatous fibrinoid necrosis with infiltration of neutrophils is a typical finding in patients with microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). This condition can manifest with malaise, elevated ANCA titers (positive for p-ANCA), elevated ESR, skin lesions, and pulmonary-renal syndrome, including glomerulonephritis. However, this patient lacks other typical features of MPA, such as palpable purpura and hemoptysis. Furthermore, there is usually no nasopharyngeal involvement in patients with MPA.

answers.content: Immunoglobulin and complement deposits at the dermoepidermal junction
answers.explanation_why: Immunoglobulin and complement deposits at the dermoepidermal junction are typical findings in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE can manifest with malaise, elevated ESR, and anemia, as well as skin lesions and pulmonary-renal syndrome. However, this patient lacks other typical features of SLE, such as malar rash, photosensitivity, pleuritis, joint pain, positive testing for anti-DNA antibodies, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. SLE also does not explain this patient's perforated nasal septum.

answers.content: Granulomatous vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels
answers.explanation_why: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, previously known as Wegener granulomatosis) is a systemic vasculitis that affects both small and medium-sized vessels. Diagnosis is based on laboratory testing (positive for c-ANCA), imaging, and biopsy of affected tissue, which demonstrate necrotizing granulomatous inflammation. GPA is treated with immunosuppressive drugs, typically glucocorticoids combined with methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, or rituximab.

answers.content: Transmural necrotizing arteritis and fibrinoid necrosis in muscles
answers.explanation_why: Transmural necrotizing arteritis and fibrinoid necrosis in muscles are typical findings in patients with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN can present with malaise, elevated ESR, anemia, leukocytosis, and skin and kidney involvement, as seen here. However, PAN would neither explain why the patient tested positive for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) nor the nasopharyngeal and pulmonary involvement (PAN usually spares the lungs). Moreover, patients with PAN often have a history of hepatitis B or C infection.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent buzzing in both ears and difficulty hearing. She says she sometimes has episodes of mild dizziness that resolve spontaneously. She has a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and episodes of low back pain. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and aspirin. She works as a trombonist for a symphony orchestra. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Bone conduction is greater than air conduction in both ears. Weber test shows no lateralization. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent buzzing in both ears and difficulty hearing. She says she sometimes has episodes of mild dizziness that resolve spontaneously. She has a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and episodes of low back pain. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and aspirin. She works as a trombonist for a symphony orchestra. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Bone conduction is greater than air conduction in both ears. Weber test shows no lateralization. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A negative Rinne test (i.e., bone conduction > air conduction) indicates conductive hearing loss. In the case of unilateral conductive hearing loss, the Weber test would lateralize to the affected ear. The absence of lateralization on Weber test indicates bilateral conductive hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize otosclerosis as a cause of bilateral conductive hearing loss.

answers.explanation_why: Musicians are at increased risk for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL), which is often accompanied by tinnitus. However, NIHL typically manifests with sensorineural rather than conductive hearing loss; therefore, a Rinne test would be positive (normal). Moreover, NIHL is not typically associated with dizziness.

Paget disease of bone can lead to low back pain, and involvement of the skull can result in bilateral conductive hearing loss due to ankylosis of the ossicles, as seen here. However, most cases of Paget's disease of bone manifest in older patients (> 55 years) and skull involvement would classically result in other symptoms such as headache and/or skull enlargement (e.g., a poorly fitting hat).

Chronic aspirin use can cause reversible tinnitus, vertigo (often described by patients as “dizziness”), and hearing loss. However, hearing loss due to drug-induced ototoxicity is sensorineural rather than conductive; therefore, a Rinne test would be positive (normal).

Meniere disease (endolymphatic hydrops) can manifest with vertigo (often described by patients as “dizziness”), hearing loss, and tinnitus. However, vertigo in patients with Meniere disease is very severe, usually accompanied by nausea and/or vomiting, and typically the predominant symptom. Hearing loss in patients with Meniere disease is usually episodic; it typically begins before and during the attack of dizziness and abates afterward. Furthermore, hearing loss in Meniere disease is typically unilateral and sensorineural rather than conductive; therefore, a Rinne test would be positive (normal) and a Weber test would show lateralization to the healthy ear.

Otosclerosis is the most likely diagnosis in patients 20–40 years of age who present with the constellation of tinnitus and insidious bilateral conductive hearing loss. About 25% of patients with otosclerosis also report mild vertigo (often described by patients as “dizziness”). Patients with otosclerosis are commonly able to hear better in noisy rather than quiet surroundings (paracusis of Willis) and characteristically develop a soft, monotonous speech. Occasionally, a reddish hue can be seen through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign) reflecting an active otosclerotic focus.

Treatment of otosclerosis consists of surgical replacement of the stapes with a prosthesis (stapedotomy or stapedectomy). A cochlear implant may be indicated in advanced cases.

images.title: Otosclerosis audiogram
images.description: Audiogram of a patient with otosclerosis in the right ear.Air conduction is reduced in the affected ear by approx. 35dB. Bone conduction shows a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2000Hz (Carhart notch). These are characteristic findings of otosclerosis, a condition that causes conductive hearing loss due to the fixation of the stapes to the oval window.

question_text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of right-sided jaw pain over the past 3 months. The patient describes the pain as dull. He says it worsens throughout the day and with chewing, and that it can also be felt in his right ear. He also reports hearing a cracking sound while eating. Over the past 2 months, he has had several episodes of severe headache that improves slightly with ibuprofen. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening and facial muscle spasm. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of right-sided jaw pain over the past 3 months. The patient describes the pain as dull. He says it worsens throughout the day and with chewing, and that it can also be felt in his right ear. He also reports hearing a cracking sound while eating. Over the past 2 months, he has had several episodes of severe headache that improves slightly with ibuprofen. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening and facial muscle spasm. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with unilateral jaw pain, ear discomfort, headache, limited jaw opening, and trismus. These features are suggestive of a condition that is usually due to musculoskeletal, psychological, and/or neuromuscular factors.
learning_objective: Recognize temporomandibular joint dysfunction.

answers.content: Chronic inflammation of large and medium-sized arteries
answers.explanation_why: Chronic inflammation of the large and medium-sized arteries is seen in giant cell arteritis. This condition can also manifest with jaw pain associated with chewing and severe headaches. However, the dull pain is usually localized in the temporal region and would typically manifest with a hardened temporal artery and constitutional symptoms like fever and weight loss. Giant cell arteritis also fails to explain this patient's muscle spasms and cracking sound heard with jaw movement.

images.title: Giant cell arteritis
images.description: The superficial temporal artery is prominent, which is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.

answers.explanation_why: An abscess at the root of a tooth can result in pain that localizes to the mouth and seems to worsen with chewing. Pain can also localize near the ear and limit jaw opening. A dental abscess can cause fever and swelling near the affected area, neither of which is seen in this patient. This condition also fails to explain the cracking sound and headaches that this patient is experiencing.

Trigeminal nerve compression, which is typically caused by an aberrant loop of the superior cerebellar artery, causes trigeminal neuralgia. While muscle spasms and unilateral pain that worsens with chewing are commonly seen in trigeminal neuralgia, patients classically describe the pain as 'electric shocks' that last a few seconds at a time and occur up to 100 times per day. Trigeminal nerve compression also fails to explain the cracking sound that this patient is experiencing.

images.title: Trigeminal neuralgia
images.description: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

answers.explanation_why: Osteomyelitis of the jaw bone can manifest with difficulty opening the jaw and pain that localizes to areas similar to those seen in this patient. However, this patient's vital signs are stable, and there has been no mention of fever, swelling, or poor dentition, which would predispose him to this condition.

Temporomandibular joint dysfunction is a syndrome that is diagnosed clinically and most commonly affects young adults. Symptoms resolve spontaneously in ∼ 40% of patients. The initial treatment consists of pharmacotherapy with NSAIDs and/or muscle relaxants (e.g., cyclobenzaprine) and conservative measures such as a soft diet, warm compresses, physical therapy exercises, behavior modification (e.g., stress reduction, avoiding excessive opening of the mandible when yawning), and occlusal splints.

Chronic sinusitis is defined as inflammation of the sinuses for > 12 weeks. Individuals with this condition can also present with severe headaches, ear discomfort, and facial pain. However, with no history of fever, mucopurulent drainage, or nasal congestion, this diagnosis is unlikely. It also fails to explain the muscle spasms and cracking sound that this patient is experiencing.

images.title: Chronic rhinosinusitis
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane)The ethmoid sinuses are opacified (hatched green overlay) and there is lobulated thickening of the walls of the maxillary sinuses (green overlay). The findings indicate nasal polyps and retention cysts.

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized pruritus and raised, erythematous plaques on the skin over his hands, chest, and legs for 6 hours. He reports having clear liquid discharge from his nose and sneezing. He says that his symptoms began suddenly the previous night, 30 minutes after he had dinner at a seafood restaurant. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past as well. Four months ago, he had an episode of narrow-angle glaucoma. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows clear, serous secretions, with edematous and erythematous mucosa and turbinates. Paranasal sinuses are not tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized pruritus and raised, erythematous plaques on the skin over his hands, chest, and legs for 6 hours. He reports having clear liquid discharge from his nose and sneezing. He says that his symptoms began suddenly the previous night, 30 minutes after he had dinner at a seafood restaurant. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past as well. Four months ago, he had an episode of narrow-angle glaucoma. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows clear, serous secretions, with edematous and erythematous mucosa and turbinates. Paranasal sinuses are not tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient presents with generalized pruritus, urticaria, rhinorrhea, and sneezing after intake of a specific food, all of which are consistent with a food-based allergic reaction. The patient's medical history should be taken into account before prescribing a medication.
learning_objective: Recognize contraindications of first-generation antihistamines, and choose an appropriate alternative for allergic reactions.

answers.explanation_why: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine commonly used to treat allergies (e.g., hay fever), pruritus, and nausea. While it would also be effective in treating this patient's food allergy, first-generation antihistamines have anticholinergic side effects that can cause mydriasis and trigger an acute attack in patients with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Therefore, diphenhydramine is contraindicated in this patient.

In an individual with rhinitis, amoxicillin can be indicated if underlying infectious rhinosinusitis is suspected. This patient, however, presents with symptoms indicating an allergic reaction and shows no further symptoms of a bacterial sinus infection (e.g., fever, purulent rhinitis, tenderness of paranasal sinuses).

Chlorpheniramine is a first-generation antihistamine commonly used to treat allergies (e.g., hay fever), as well as sinus congestion and rhinitis caused by upper respiratory infections. Although it would also be effective in treating this patient's food allergy, first-generation antihistamines have anticholinergic side effects that can cause mydriasis and trigger an acute attack in patients with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Therefore, chlorpheniramine is contraindicated in this patient.

First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) are largely used for the management of allergic reactions. However, this group of agents has anticholinergic side effects, such as mydriasis, which can induce acute angle-closure glaucoma in patients like this one with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Since first-generation antihistamines are contraindicated in this patient, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy is a second-generation antihistamine such as fexofenadine, which is similarly effective but has fewer sedative and anticholinergic side effects.

Calamine lotion is used for the topical treatment of mild to moderate pruritus in individuals with skin conditions such as varicella, sunburn, and xerosis. While it may alleviate some of this patient's pruritus, it is not effective in treating the underlying allergic reaction.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of worsening difficulty swallowing food and retrosternal chest discomfort. She reports that she sometimes has a feeling of “food getting stuck” in her throat and hears a “gurgling sound” from her throat while eating. She says that she occasionally coughs up pieces of undigested food. She has noticed a bad taste in her mouth and bad breath. She has not had fever or weight loss. She has been visiting Mexico every year for the past 7 years. She has Raynaud disease treated with nifedipine. Her father died because of gastric cancer. She smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9800/mm^3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm^3. ECG shows sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of worsening difficulty swallowing food and retrosternal chest discomfort. She reports that she sometimes has a feeling of “food getting stuck” in her throat and hears a “gurgling sound” from her throat while eating. She says that she occasionally coughs up pieces of undigested food. She has noticed a bad taste in her mouth and bad breath. She has not had fever or weight loss. She has been visiting Mexico every year for the past 7 years. She has Raynaud disease treated with nifedipine. Her father died because of gastric cancer. She smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9800/mm3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm3. ECG shows sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: The patient's symptoms of dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation, and coughing up of undigested food as well as her retrosternal pressure and the gurgling sound while eating are most likely caused by symptomatic Zenker diverticulum (ZD).
learning_objective: Recognize symptomatic Zenker diverticulum, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why:
ZD is a false diverticulum (herniation of mucosa and submucosa only) that typically herniates through the Killian triangle at the dorsal hypopharynx. The best confirmatory test in patients with ZD is barium esophagram with dynamic continuous fluoroscopy. The characteristic outpouching in the posterior pharyngoesophageal wall confirms the diagnosis.

Patients presenting with symptomatic ZD should undergo open surgical or endoscopic treatment.

images.title: Zenker diverticulum
images.description: Barium swallowThe contrast-enhanced mass in the upper esophagus is most likely a Zenker diverticulum.

answers.explanation_why: Esophageal manometry is useful to identify esophageal motility disorders, such as achalasia. This patient presents with some typical features of achalasia including dysphagia and regurgitation. However, achalasia often causes weight loss, which is not the case here, and it would not explain the bubbling sounds while eating. Esophageal manometry is also useful for detecting esophageal involvement in systemic sclerosis (SSc), which often manifests with Raynaud disease, as seen here. The absence of other characteristic findings of SSc, such as thickening and hardening of the skin or sclerodactyly, however, makes this diagnosis less likely.

A CT scan of the neck is indicated in the diagnostic staging of esophageal cancers. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor, for which her smoking history and family history are risk factors. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Also, a CT scan of the neck and chest would not be the confirmatory test in the diagnosis of esophageal cancers. Larger outpouchings can be an incidental finding on CT scans of some individuals with ZD. However, a CT scan is not routinely used to confirm or exclude this diagnosis.

Serology and PCR can be used to detect Trypanosoma cruzi, the pathogen that causes Chagas disease. Chagas disease may present with achalasia (megaesophagus), which typically leads to dysphagia and regurgitation, as seen in this patient. This patient's visits to Mexico, which is endemic for Chagas disease, increase her risk for this condition. However, megaesophagus typically occurs in the chronic phase of Chagas disease (approx. after 10–20 years), which is inconsistent with her travel history. Moreover, the chronic phase of Chagas disease would usually manifest with other symptoms including arrhythmias due to cardiomyopathy (ECG shows no abnormalities) and/or abdominal complaints due to involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, neither of which is the case here.

Upper endoscopy is used for the diagnosis of various esophageal conditions including esophageal cancer. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor, for which her smoking history and family history are risk factors. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Upper endoscopy of the esophagus can be used for the detection of diverticula, such as ZD. However, it is not the most sensitive diagnostic method for this condition and may lead to small openings in the esophageal wall being missed.

Esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis of nonerosive reflux disease (NERD), which may also manifest with regurgitation and dysphagia, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of typical features of NERD such as retrosternal burning pain with meals, chronic nonproductive cough, and/or nocturnal cough make ZD a more likely diagnosis.

Endoscopic ultrasound of the esophagus is used in the staging of esophageal cancer to determine tumor infiltration depth and register regional lymph node disease. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor, for which her smoking history and family history are risk factors. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

question_text: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. He has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports hearing the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. He has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports hearing the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This older patient presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss and difficulty hearing in noisy, crowded environments. These features together with bilateral positive Rinne test and no lateralization on Weber test are suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize presbycusis as a cause of sensorineural hearing loss.

answers.explanation_why: Cerumen impaction is a buildup of tightly packed cerumen in the outer ear. It often manifests with unilateral conductive hearing loss and earache, and is easily diagnosed by direct visualization by otoscopic examination. This patient has bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and clear tympanic membranes on examination.

images.title: Cerumen impaction
images.description: Otoscopic image of the external auditory canalThe auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

answers.explanation_why: Ototoxicity typically manifests with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as seen in this patient. However, the patient does not report being exposed to any classic ototoxic drugs such as aminoglycosides, furosemide, cisplatin, or aspirin. Furthermore, ototoxicity often manifests with additional symptoms like tinnitus, nystagmus, and dizziness, which are absent in this patient.

Otosclerosis predominantly affects women aged 20–40 years and leads to conductive hearing loss, usually ultimately bilateral, which presents with a negative Rinne test as opposed to the sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient. Additionally, patients also develop tinnitus and usually hear better in noisy rather than quiet surroundings.

Cholesteatoma manifests with conductive hearing loss, which would lead to a negative Rinne test, and if unilateral, lateralization to the affected ear on Weber test. In addition, it typically leads to painless otorrhea and a brownish, irregular mass on otoscopy, none of which is seen in this patient.

Although a vestibulocochlear nerve lesion presents with sensorineural hearing loss, it also leads to vestibular symptoms such as vertigo or horizontal nystagmus, none of which are present in this patient.

Presbycusis is a form of sensorineural hearing loss that affects more than half of adults by the age of 75 years, most adults over 80 years of age, and nearly all adults ≥ 90 years of age. It is a multifactorial process caused by gradual degeneration of the organ of Corti over the course of years, often first identified by difficulty hearing in crowded spaces. Although there is no definitive treatment, hearing aids and cochlear implants can provide symptomatic relief and improve hearing function in affected individuals.

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that often lead to sensorineural hearing loss, and could become bilateral in cases of neurofibromatosis type 2. However, hearing loss would typically initially be asymmetric and also often present with tinnitus and vestibular nerve involvement, resulting in dizziness, unsteady gait, and disequilibrium. These findings are not seen in this patient.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

question_text: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the last month. During this time he has not been able to eat more than one bite without coughing immediately and sometimes he regurgitates food through his nose. His symptoms are worse with liquids. One month ago he had a stroke in the right middle cerebral artery. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Examination of the oropharynx, chest, and abdomen shows no abnormalities. Neurological examination shows facial drooping on the left and decreased strength in the left upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the last month. During this time he has not been able to eat more than one bite without coughing immediately and sometimes he regurgitates food through his nose. His symptoms are worse with liquids. One month ago he had a stroke in the right middle cerebral artery. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Examination of the oropharynx, chest, and abdomen shows no abnormalities. Neurological examination shows facial drooping on the left and decreased strength in the left upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Dysphagia early in the swallowing process that worsens with liquids, coughing, and nasal regurgitation indicate oropharyngeal dysphagia. Oropharyngeal dysphagia commonly affects patients with neuromuscular dysfunction, such as this patient who recently had a stroke.
learning_objective: Recognize oropharyngeal dysphagia post-stroke, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: A videofluoroscopic modified barium swallow is considered the test of choice for evaluating oropharyngeal dysphagia. It involves direct visualization of the entire swallowing process using continuous x-rays and barium contrast. This diagnostic test evaluates the patient's risk of aspiration and determines whether the patient might benefit from supervised feedings, swallow rehabilitation therapy, and/or enteral nutrition.

images.title: Modified barium swallow
images.description: Videofluoroscopy of the neck (lateral view)The video shows the oral preparatory and propulsive stages followed by the pharyngeal and esophageal stages. No abnormalities are noted.

answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the neck is used as part of the staging process for esophageal cancer. While esophageal cancer can also present with weight loss and dysphagia, this patient developed dysphagia early in the swallowing process, coughing, and nasal regurgitation after a recent stroke, which is indicative of a neuromuscular cause of his symptoms. Furthermore, a staging CT is only indicated after confirmation of esophageal cancer.

Esophagram via barium swallow classically involves ingestion of barium contrast and acquisition of a single static x-ray image as contrast enters the stomach. Barium swallow is indicated in patients with esophageal dysphagia, most commonly after an upper endoscopy is unrevealing. This patient presents with oropharyngeal, rather than esophageal, dysphagia. A standard barium swallow does not evaluate the oropharynx and is therefore not the preferred initial diagnostic test for this patient.

Esophageal manometry is indicated in patients with esophageal dysphagia who are believed to have an esophageal motility disorder. Because this patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with oropharyngeal dysphagia than esophageal dysphagia, esophageal manometry is not indicated.

Transnasal laryngoscopy can be used to visualize the oropharynx, to assess pharyngeal swallowing, and especially to assess possible aspiration and retention of food in the pharynx after swallowing (fiberoptic endoscopic examination of swallowing). However, it is not the preferred initial test as it does not allow visualization of the food bolus beyond the oropharynx.

Upper endoscopy is the appropriate step in management for most patients that present with esophageal dysphagia and/or odynophagia as it can be both diagnostic and therapeutic. Unlike this patient, who reports swallowing problems immediately after taking a bite, patients with esophageal dysphagia report food “getting stuck” in their chest and do not have difficulty initiating swallowing. Upper endoscopy is not the initial test of choice for this patient with suspected oropharyngeal dysphagia.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple episodes of dizziness over the past 3 months. Episodes last between 20 minutes and 1 hour. During the episodes, she experiences a sudden onset of spinning sensations and imbalance, associated with a ringing in her left ear. She also reports fluctuating left-sided hearing loss and is unable to follow conversations in noisy surroundings. She has had an upper respiratory infection for the past 5 days. She is otherwise healthy. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Pure tone audiometry shows a low frequency sensory hearing loss of the left ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple episodes of dizziness over the past 3 months. Episodes last between 20 minutes and 1 hour. During the episodes, she experiences a sudden onset of spinning sensations and imbalance, associated with a ringing in her left ear. She also reports fluctuating left-sided hearing loss and is unable to follow conversations in noisy surroundings. She has had an upper respiratory infection for the past 5 days. She is otherwise healthy. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Pure tone audiometry shows a low frequency sensory hearing loss of the left ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: The triad of vertigo, unilateral tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss is characteristic of Meniere disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Meniere disease, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why:
As there is no definitive cure for Meniere disease, treatment is directed toward symptomatic management and prevention of recurrence. Lifestyle modifications such as stress reduction, a low-sodium diet, and identification and avoidance of triggers (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, nicotine) are part of the initial nonpharmacological treatment for this condition. Further treatment options include vestibular rehabilitation therapy as well as chronic pharmacotherapy (e.g., diuretics) for patients with frequently recurring episodes. Interventional therapy (e.g., chemical vestibular ablation with intratympanic gentamicin, intratympanic steroids) and surgical vestibular ablation (e.g., labyrinthectomy, vestibular neurectomy) are reserved for patients with intractable symptoms that significantly impact their quality of life.

Acute episodes of Meniere disease can be treated with vestibular suppressants (e.g., benzodiazepines, first-generation antihistamines).

Topiramate is used in the treatment of migraines. Vestibular migraines generally manifest with acute vertigo lasting anywhere from 5 minutes to 72 hours, and are associated with other symptoms of migraine (headache, visual disturbances, photophobia, nausea, vomiting). This patient does not have any reported history of migraine, nor does she have any other features consistent with this diagnosis. Additionally, vestibular migraines do not cause cochlear symptoms (e.g., tinnitus and hearing loss).

Radiation therapy is used in the treatment of acoustic neuroma, which usually manifests with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness. Although this patient has unilateral symptoms, the episodic and subacute nature of her symptoms makes acoustic neuroma unlikely.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: The Epley maneuver is used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is characterized by motion-triggered, brief (< 1 min) episodes of vertigo. BPPV does not typically cause cochlear symptoms (e.g., hearing loss, tinnitus).

Prednisone is used to treat vestibular neuritis, a disease characterized by persistent vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and gait instability. Vestibular neuritis is thought to be viral in etiology and usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection (URI). Although this patient currently has a URI, the time course of her presentation is not consistent with this etiology and her cochlear symptoms (e.g., sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus) suggest another diagnosis.

Systemic and/or intratympanic glucocorticoids can be used to treat patients with Meniere disease who do not respond to first-line treatments.

question_text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 6-month history of persistent rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. She works in retail and notices her symptoms worsen anytime she is exposed to strong perfumes. Her symptoms have worsened since winter began 2 months ago. She has not had fever, nausea, wheezing, itching, or rash. She has no history of serious illness or allergies. She takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows congested nasal mucosa, enlarged tonsils, and pharyngeal postnasal discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 6-month history of persistent rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. She works in retail and notices her symptoms worsen anytime she is exposed to strong perfumes. Her symptoms have worsened since winter began 2 months ago. She has not had fever, nausea, wheezing, itching, or rash. She has no history of serious illness or allergies. She takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows congested nasal mucosa, enlarged tonsils, and pharyngeal postnasal discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Chronic rhinorrhea and nasal congestion in association with a known trigger (strong odor) without symptoms of allergic rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, itchy eyes/nose) strongly suggest vasomotor rhinitis, a type of nonallergic rhinitis. The symptoms are often worse during the winter months (due to the cold, dry air).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for vasomotor rhinitis.

answers.explanation_why: A radioallergosorbent test (RAST) can be used to identify allergen-specific IgE in patients with allergic rhinitis who do not respond to empirical therapy and if cutaneous testing is unavailable or inconvenient. Allergic rhinitis can manifest with persistent rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. However, patients with allergic rhinitis typically present with prominent ocular symptoms (itchy, and watery eyes), sneezing, and an itchy nose and throat. Moreover, symptoms are typically worse in springtime and examination would show normal or pale greyish nasal mucosa. In contrast, vasomotor rhinitis is not the result of an IgE-mediated process; performing allergy testing is therefore not necessary at this point.

Topical phenylephrine is a nasal decongestant that can be used for additional symptomatic relief in patients with vasomotor rhinitis who are already on primary therapy. This patient should receive adequate first-line treatment before adding adjunctive therapies. Chronic or excessive use of topical decongestants can lead to rhinitis medicamentosa, and, therefore, they are only used intermittently on an as needed basis.

Oral antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine, are used as adjunctive therapy in patients with allergic rhinitis that is not adequately controlled with intranasal steroids or intranasal antihistamines. Allergic rhinitis can manifest with persistent rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. However, patients with allergic rhinitis typically present with prominent ocular symptoms (itchy, and watery eyes), sneezing, and an itchy nose and throat. Moreover, symptoms are typically worse in springtime and examination would show normal or pale greyish nasal mucosa. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with vasomotor rhinitis, which does not respond to treatment with oral antihistamines.

Topical antihistamines, such as intranasal azelastine, are a first-line treatment option for vasomotor rhinitis (VR). In addition to blocking H_1 histamine receptors, azelastine also stabilizes mast cells, prevents eosinophil activation, and inhibits proinflammatory cytokine production, thereby relieving the symptoms of rhinorrhea and nasal congestion of VR. This patient should also be encouraged to avoid known triggers of VR, which include certain medications (e.g., NSAIDs) and strong odors (e.g., perfume). Intranasal glucocorticoids (e.g., fluticasone) are further first-line treatment options for VR. Saline nasal irrigation and nasal decongestants (e.g., oxymetazoline) may be added as adjunctive therapies.

Referral for percutaneous allergy testing is indicated in patients with allergic or nonallergic symptoms of chronic rhinitis who do not adequately respond to appropriate empiric medication. This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with vasomotor rhinitis; a trial of empiric therapy can therefore be initiated without performing allergy testing.

Resection of nasal turbinates (turbinectomy) to relieve chronic nasal obstruction can be performed in patients with allergic and nonallergic rhinitis that is refractory to treatment with multiple medications. Turbinectomy is not an appropriate first-line treatment for vasomotor rhinitis.

question_text: A 27-year-old man with asthma comes to the office because of a 5-week history of nasal congestion, watery nasal discharge, and frequent headaches. During this time, he noticed increased mouth breathing and his wife told him that he started snoring. He has also had several episodes of a dry cough that have kept him awake at night. One year ago, he had an asthma exacerbation while being treated for an ankle sprain. Two weeks ago, he had another asthma exacerbation after taking ibuprofen for his headaches. Current medications are a combined budesonide-formoterol inhaler and an over-the-counter nasal decongestant. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild tenderness over the forehead bilaterally. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man with asthma comes to the office because of a 5-week history of nasal congestion, watery nasal discharge, and frequent headaches. During this time, he noticed increased mouth breathing and his wife told him that he started snoring. He has also had several episodes of a dry cough that have kept him awake at night. One year ago, he had an asthma exacerbation while being treated for an ankle sprain. Two weeks ago, he had another asthma exacerbation after taking ibuprofen for his headaches. Current medications are a combined budesonide-formoterol inhaler and an over-the-counter nasal decongestant. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild tenderness over the forehead bilaterally. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's history of asthma exacerbations after taking NSAIDs is highly suggestive of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).
learning_objective: Recognize nasal polyposis in aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).

answers.explanation_why: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma also manifests with symptoms of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. However, patients with this condition most commonly present with recurrent severe epistaxis, which is not seen here. Moreover, this condition is almost exclusively seen in adolescent males.

images.title: Nasal angiofibroma
images.description: Endoscopic view of the inside of the right nasal cavity of a young patientA large smooth and vascular mass is obstructing the entire nasal cavity.This is the typical appearance of a nasal angiofibroma.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's presentation is consistent with AERD, which commonly manifests with the Samter triad: asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and hypersensitivity to aspirin or other cyclooxygenase-1 inhibitors. Patients with nasal polyps typically present with symptoms of postnasal drip (e.g., dry cough when lying supine) and nasal obstruction (e.g., mouth breathing, new-onset snoring). Diagnosis is confirmed by nasal endoscopy; in cases of unilateral nasal polyps, a biopsy is performed to exclude malignancy. A CT scan can be performed to exclude other causes of nasal obstruction. Nasal polyps can also be seen in individuals with chronic rhinosinusitis, even in the absence of asthma or aspirin sensitivity.

Intranasal corticosteroids are the first-line therapy for nasal polyposis. In patients who do not respond to topical steroids, other treatments might be indicated (e.g., systemic steroids, monoclonal antibodies, surgery). Aspirin desensitization may also be performed in patients with AERD.

images.title: Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane) of patient with history of asthmaExtensive soft tissue opacification of the ethmoid sinuses (E; outline) and nasal cavity (NC; outline) shows some lobulation (black arrowhead) and evidence of bony erosion (dashed outline). Lobulated soft tissue is also present along the maxillary sinus walls (white arrowheads).

answers.explanation_why: Systemic vasculitis such as ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) can manifest with nasal congestion, nasal discharge, and cough. Moreover, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically present with asthma. However, since ANCA-associated vasculitis usually affects multiple organ systems, patients typically have concomitant findings suggestive of multi-organ involvement (e.g., glomerulonephritis, skin manifestations, pulmonary symptoms), which are not seen here.

Bacterial rhinosinusitis manifests with nasal discharge, congestion, postnasal drip, headache, and facial tenderness, all of which are seen in this patient. However, patients with bacterial rhinosinusitis typically present with more severe symptoms such as fever and thick, purulent nasal discharge, rather than watery discharge. This patient's history of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease makes a different diagnosis much more likely.

Intranasal foreign bodies can cause symptoms of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge, as seen here. However, the nasal obstruction and discharge caused by intranasal foreign bodies is typically mucopurulent rather than watery. Moreover, intranasal foreign bodies are most commonly seen in children.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) can manifest with nasal discharge and nasal congestion, as seen here. However, patients with NPC usually present with bloody rather than watery nasal discharge. Moreover, this condition is more commonly seen in older individuals (peak incidence 50-59 years of age), and this patient has no known risk factors for it (e.g., tobacco consumption, alcohol use).

question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
hint: This patient has manifestations of acute bacterial sinusitis (e.g., fever, headache, foul-smelling nasal discharge). Periorbital edema and abducens nerve palsy suggest the development of cavernous sinus thrombosis, a rare but dangerous complication of acute bacterial sinusitis.
learning_objective: Recall neuroanatomy of the trigeminal nerve and cavernous sinus.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the abducens nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Patients present with the inability to abduct the eye, medial strabismus, and diplopia, all of which are seen in this patient. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

Compression of the oculomotor nerve can result from cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, oculomotor nerve palsy also causes ptosis, mydriasis, and a down-and-out pupil. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

images.title: Bilateral complete oculomotor palsy
images.description: Eyes and forehead of a 20-year-old female patient with tubercular meningitisImage A shows bilateral ptosis, due here to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. To open her eyes, the patient must contract the frontalis muscle, resulting in the forehead wrinkles seen in image B. Both eyes deviate outwards (exotropia) and downwards (hypotropia) from the primary gaze position. This occurs due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are the only unaffected extraocular muscles. Mydriasis indicates involvement of the parasympathetic portion of the oculomotor nerve.Ptosis, mydriasis, exotropia, and hypotropia are the classic signs of complete oculomotor palsy. Complete oculomotor palsy is more commonly unilateral than bilateral.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the trochlear nerve can occur due to cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, trochlear nerve palsy also causes extorsion with an inability to adduct and depress the eye simultaneously. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

Compression of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Affected patients present with an absent corneal reflex and/or impaired sensation in the upper face. Progression of the thrombus results in cavernous sinus syndrome, causing compression of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), and abducens nerve (CN VI).

images.title: Pituitary gland and cavernous sinuses
images.description: The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is surrounded by the left and right cavernous sinuses and the intercavernous sinuses connecting them. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of each cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerves are located towards the lateral wall of the sinuses.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve can be due to cavernous sinus thrombosis, which causes loss of sensation of the midface. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

question_text: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with features of nephritic syndrome, including hematuria, hypertension, and recurrent edema of the face and feet, and other signs of renal damage (elevated BUN, elevated creatinine). Sensorineural hearing loss in a patient with renal disease and a positive family history is indicative of Alport syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Alport syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Type IV collagen, which forms a component of basement membranes, plays an important role in the function of glomeruli and inner ear structures (particularly the organ of Corti). An X-linked defect in type IV collagen is responsible for most cases of Alport's syndrome, which results in progressive sensorineural hearing loss (with high-frequency sounds affected first) and hematuria. Episodes of gross hematuria are sometimes preceded by upper respiratory tract infections. Patients with Alport's syndrome also commonly develop an anterior lenticonus since type IV collagen is the predominant collagen fiber in the lens capsule. A family history of renal disease among males is common in patients with Alport's syndrome.

images.title: Alport syndrome
images.description: Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of Wilms tumor, which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, Wilms tumor would manifest in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

An autosomal-recessive gene defect in fibrocystin is the cause of autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which leads to the development of multiple bilateral kidney cysts. Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 10-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy and a positive family history might suggest a diagnosis of ARPKD. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy, which typically presents between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 10-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient could have had an episode of febrile pharyngitis due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness in this patient.

Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may present with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness in this patient.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of hearing loss. To test her hearing, the physician performs two tests. First, a vibrating tuning fork is held against the mastoid bone of the patient and then near her ear, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on both sides when the tuning fork is held near her ear. Next, the physician holds the tuning fork against the bridge of her forehead, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on the right side than the left. The patient's examination findings are most consistent with which of the following conditions?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of hearing loss. To test her hearing, the physician performs two tests. First, a vibrating tuning fork is held against the mastoid bone of the patient and then near her ear, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on both sides when the tuning fork is held near her ear. Next, the physician holds the tuning fork against the bridge of her forehead, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on the right side than the left. The patient's examination findings are most consistent with which of the following conditions?
hint: In this patient, the results of the Rinne test are positive, indicating normal conductive hearing. In combination with a Weber test that lateralized to the right, this indicates left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize acoustic neuroma presenting as unilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

answers.explanation_why: Cerumen impaction is associated with conductive hearing loss due to direct obstruction of the external acoustic canal. If cerumen impaction were present on the right side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the right and a positive test on the left. The Weber test would lateralize to the right side.

Otosclerosis is characterized by conductive hearing loss (more in the lower frequencies than in the higher), typically bilateral. It most commonly manifests in the third or fourth decade of life. If otosclerosis were present on the left side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the left and a positive test on the right. The Weber test would lateralize to the left.

Cochlear ischemia can lead to direct cochlear nerve damage and thus cause unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen here. In a patient with right-sided cochlear ischemia, the Rinne test would be positive on both sides. However, the Weber test would lateralize to the left because of right-sided nerve damage.

Acoustic neuromas, which commonly arise from the internal acoustic canal, often exert a mass effect on the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The resulting unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen in this patient, is the most common early symptom of this condition. Other symptoms include tinnitus due to pressure on CN VIII as well as dizziness/vertigo and gait instability due to vestibular deficits.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Presbycusis is the most common cause of sensorineural hearing loss, with onset most commonly occurring in the sixth decade of life. It typically manifests with difficulty hearing in noisy environments. If bilateral presbycusis were present, the patient would have positive Rinne tests on the right and left. The Weber test would not lateralize.

Cholesteatoma does not always present with hearing loss, but would cause conductive hearing loss due to erosion of the ossicles. In a case of a symptomatic cholesteatoma on the right side, this patient would have a negative Rinne test on the right and a positive test on the left. The Weber test would lateralize to the right side.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This mass will also move cranially with swallowing.
learning_objective: Recognize a thyroglossal cyst.

answers.explanation_why: A thyroglossal cyst arises if the thyroglossal duct fails to obliterate completely during embryonal development. The cyst can develop anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct and manifests as a painless, firm, midline mass of the anterior neck. Like the thyroid gland, the thyroglossal cyst is enclosed within the pretracheal fascia, which is responsible for the upward movement of these structures during swallowing. In addition, a thyroglossal cyst moves upward with tongue protrusion because the fibrous remnants of the thyroglossal duct are connected to the base of the tongue.

A ranula is a mucocele arising from the sublingual gland that manifests as a translucent, dome-shaped, blue mass below the tongue. Although large lesions can cause swelling of the neck, this would occur lateral to the midline and would not move upwards with tongue protrusion or swallowing.

Laryngocele, a saccular dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle, can herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and appear as a lateral neck swelling. The neck mass is typically a small, air-filled sac that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver.

A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system in the neck. The neck mass is typically painless, soft, and compressible, and is located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma is associated with fetal aneuploidy (e.g., Turner syndrome).

images.title: Cystic hygroma
images.description: Right lateral region of the neck(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

answers.explanation_why: Dermoid cysts are cystic teratomas that can arise anywhere in the body, including the neck. As a neck mass, they usually manifest at 10–20 years of age as a slow-growing mass in the submandibular or sublingual space.

Branchial cysts can arise if the 2^nd branchial cleft fails to obliterate completely. These neck masses are typically painless and firm, as in this patient, but located lateral to the midline and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not move with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing.
