question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 4-day history of progressively worsening pain and swelling on the right side of his face. The patient was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 8 months ago and is currently undergoing treatment. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema and swelling over the right cheek and mandible. An orofacial fistula is present. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 4-day history of progressively worsening pain and swelling on the right side of his face. The patient was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 8 months ago and is currently undergoing treatment. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema and swelling over the right cheek and mandible. An orofacial fistula is present. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's painful swelling, erythema, and orofacial fistula indicate osteonecrosis of the jaw.
learning_objective: Recognize bisphosphonate-induced osteonecrosis of the jaw, and recall its mechanism of action.

answers.explanation_why: Inhibition of angiogenesis is the mechanism of action of bevacizumab, a drug that is typically used to treat solid tumors (e.g., colorectal cancer, renal cell carcinoma) and wet age-related macular degeneration. Significant adverse effects include hemorrhage, blood clots, and impaired wound healing. Bevacizumab is not used to treat multiple myeloma and is not associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw.

Cross-linking DNA at guanine is the mechanism of action of cyclophosphamide, a drug regularly used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. Major adverse effects include hemorrhagic cystitis and SIADH. Cyclophosphamide is not associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw.

Inhibition of proteasome activity is the mechanism of action of bortezomib, a cytostatic drug that arrests cell growth at the G2-M phase and causes apoptosis. It is first-line treatment for multiple myeloma and is associated with polyneuropathy and reactivation of herpes zoster. It does not cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.

Stimulation of PTH receptors is the mechanism of action of teriparatide. Teriparatide can enhance bone resorption by stimulating osteoclastic activity, but the net increase in bone formation through upregulation of osteoblastic activity predominates. Teriparatide is associated with the development of osteosarcoma and may cause transient hypercalcemia, but it does not cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.

Binding to hydroxyapatite on the surface of bone tissue is the mechanism of action of bisphosphonates, a group of drugs used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. Bisphosphonates are pyrophosphate analogs that decrease bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity. The pathophysiology of bisphosphonate-induced osteonecrosis of the jaw is not yet fully understood. Trauma (e.g., during dental procedures) may act as a trigger. Other important adverse effects of bisphosphonate therapy include hypocalcemia, renal impairment, and esophagitis.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of headaches, facial numbness, recurrent epistaxis, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He recently immigrated from Hong Kong. Examination shows right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Endoscopy shows an exophytic nasopharyngeal mass. Histologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the mass shows sheets of undifferentiated cells with nuclear pleomorphism and abundant mitotic figures. The patient most likely acquired the causal pathogen of his nasopharyngeal mass via which of the following routes of transmission?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of headaches, facial numbness, recurrent epistaxis, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He recently immigrated from Hong Kong. Examination shows right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Endoscopy shows an exophytic nasopharyngeal mass. Histologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the mass shows sheets of undifferentiated cells with nuclear pleomorphism and abundant mitotic figures. The patient most likely acquired the causal pathogen of his nasopharyngeal mass via which of the following routes of transmission?
hint: Headaches, facial numbness (due to cranial nerve involvement), recurrent epistaxis, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy are suggestive of malignancy. The biopsy of this patient's mass shows undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which commonly occurs in adults of Southeast Asian descent. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the primary causative agent in the pathogenesis of this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and recall its association with Epstein-Barr virus transmission.

answers.explanation_why: Disease transmitted via sexual contact include human immunodeficiency virus, human papillomavirus, and herpes simplex virus. In rare cases, EBV may be transmitted through genital secretions (suggests the possibility of sexual transmission); however, this possibility is less likely when compared to more common routes of EBV transmission.

Although ticks are a vector for a number of diseases such as Lyme disease (Ixodes scapularis tick), babesiosis (Ixodes scapularis tick), and ehrlichiosis (lone star tick), they play no role in the transmission of EBV.

EBV is mainly transmitted through saliva and respiratory secretions. In addition to nasopharyngeal carcinoma, EBV is associated with the development of infectious mononucleosis (“kissing disease”), oral hairy leukoplakia, primary CNS lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and Burkitt lymphoma. Most individuals have a latent EBV infection, but malignant complications typically occur only after reactivation in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., patients with HIV).
The fecal-oral route is the primary route of transmission of many pathogens, such as helminths (e.g., ascariasis, enterobiasis), hepatitis A, and hepatitis E. EBV is not transmitted fecal-orally.

Blood transfusions carry the risk of transmitting some viruses, such as hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Although there is a risk of transfusion-related EBV infection among some patients (e.g., stem cell transplant recipients), this risk is considerably low when compared to other more common routes of EBV transmission.

Vertical transmission (i.e., from mother to baby) can occur with many pathogens, such as human immunodeficiency virus, hepatitis B virus, Group B streptococcus, and Listeria monocytogenes. Although some studies suggest the possibility of EBV transmission in utero or during delivery, other modes of transmission are more likely.

question_text: A previously healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 8 days. She also has a diffuse rash that started yesterday. Three days ago, she took amoxicillin that she had at home. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 99/min, blood pressure 106/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over her trunk and extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy are present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with > 10% atypical lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 8 days. She also has a diffuse rash that started yesterday. Three days ago, she took amoxicillin that she had at home. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 99/min, blood pressure 106/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over her trunk and extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy are present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with > 10% atypical lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm this patient's condition?
hint: This 16-year-old girl with fatigue, sore throat, mild splenomegaly, and a history of rash after administration of amoxicillin is likely suffering from a viral infection common in this age group.
learning_objective: Recognize infectious mononucleosis, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.explanation_why: The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a technique used for the screening of several diseases, including HIV. This patient has some signs of primary HIV infection (fever, sore throat, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, rash) and risk factors for HIV transmission (multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use), but splenomegaly, tonsillar exudates, and lack of diarrhea make another diagnosis more likely.

Flow cytometry is a technique employed for evaluation of patients with lymphocytosis, including those suspected of leukemia or lymphoma. Although blood cancers often present with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and fatigue, the sudden onset of fever, sore throat, tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudates in this patient indicates an active infection. Additionally, a morbilliform rash following amoxicillin intake would not be expected.

images.title: Flow cytometry
images.description:
Flow cytometry is a technique for the identification, quantification, and sorting of single cells in a cell suspension, often with the use of fluorescent-tagged antibodies to detect the presence of specific target antigens (as illustrated here).Inside the nozzle, a fluid (sheath fluid) focuses the cells into a narrow stream, causing them to pass across the laser beam in single file. As the laser hits each cell, the light scattered varies in accordance with its size, shape, and intracellular and cell surface molecules. Cells containing the target antigen also have the fluorescent-tagged antibody bound to them, which emits light of a specific wavelength when activated by the laser beam (yellow and blue, in this image).
A detector directly opposite the laser beam measures the amount of forward scatter, and detectors placed perpendicular to the laser beam measure side scatter and fluorescence.The collected data can then be plotted as a histogram (yellow graph and blue graph) or a scatter plot (bottom right graph). Histograms measure a single parameter, displaying a large number of events (cells) as a spike. Scatter plots measure two parameters simultaneously, representing each event (cell) as a single point and clustering events with similar fluorescence intensities. In the case illustrated, the gray cells do not possess the target antigens and are marked as events at low fluorescence intensity on both axes in the scatter plot. By contrast, green cells possess two target antigens and are represented as high fluorescence intensity events on both axes.

answers.explanation_why: The presence of anti-CMV IgM would indicate an acute cytomegalovirus infection, which can also present with fever, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and a sore throat, as seen in this patient. However, splenomegaly and a morbilliform rash after administration of an aminopenicillin are not consistent with a CMV infection.

A throat swab culture is indicated for streptococcal pharyngitis. Although the symptoms of fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy may suggest pharyngitis due to Streptococcus, the maculopapular rash and splenomegaly make this diagnosis unlikely.

Fever, exudative tonsillitis, (generalized) lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis are all indicative of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is caused by an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. The atypical lymphocytes on this patient's peripheral blood smear are reactive CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. The diagnosis of IM is typically clinical but EBV serology is the most reliable laboratory study. Anti-VCA IgM antibodies alone are sufficient to diagnose acute infection. A positive heterophile agglutination test (monospot test) can support the diagnosis but carries a high risk of false positive and false negative results and is therefore not the test of choice. Although IM itself does not usually cause a rash, a morbilliform rash commonly occurs in patients with this condition who are mistakenly administered an aminopenicillin with the intent of treating a bacterial infection (e.g., streptococcal pharyngitis, which also manifests with fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy).

question_text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and blood-tinged sputum. He has also had a productive cough for 1 year and has had 3 episodes of sinusitis during this time. Physical examination shows palpable erythematous skin lesions over his hands and feet that do not blanch on pressure. There are ulcerations of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and a perforation of the nasal septum. His serum creatinine is 2.6 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows acanthocytes, 70 RBCs/hpf, 2+ proteinuria, and RBC casts. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple, cavitating, nodular lesions bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and blood-tinged sputum. He has also had a productive cough for 1 year and has had 3 episodes of sinusitis during this time. Physical examination shows palpable erythematous skin lesions over his hands and feet that do not blanch on pressure. There are ulcerations of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and a perforation of the nasal septum. His serum creatinine is 2.6 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows acanthocytes, 70 RBCs/hpf, 2+ proteinuria, and RBC casts. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple, cavitating, nodular lesions bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient shows the classic triad of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA): necrotizing vasculitis (palpable purpura), upper/lower respiratory tract manifestations (chronic sinusitis, nasal ulcers, hemoptysis, nodular cavities), and glomerulonephritis/nephritic syndrome (elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria with RBC casts).
learning_objective: Recognize granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and recall its associated antibody titers.

answers.explanation_why: Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE, which can also cause fever, nephritic syndrome (due to lupus nephritis), hemoptysis (due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage), palpable purpura (due to cutaneous vasculitis), ulceration of the nasal mucosa, and, rarely, septal perforation/deformities. However, a history of malaise, weight loss, myalgia, arthralgia, and/or photosensitivity would usually be present. Also, cavitating, nodular lesions on a chest x-ray would not be seen in SLE.

Serum IgA titers may be increased in patients with IgA vasculitis, which can also manifest with fever (prodromal), palpable purpura, nephritic syndrome, and, rarely, hemoptysis. However, IgA vasculitis typically occurs in children, and it would not explain the patient's other clinical features. Instead, patients usually have a history of colicky abdominal pain.

Titers of p-ANCA are increased in < 10% of patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). Instead, p-ANCA titers are commonly elevated in patients with microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), which can present very similarly to this patient, with involvement of the lungs (hemoptysis due to pulmonary vasculitis), the kidneys (glomerulonephritis), and the skin (palpable purpura). However, involvement of the nasopharynx (septal perforation, sinusitis, ulceration) is much more common in GPA (90%) than in MPA (35%). While MPA cannot be entirely excluded in this patient without histopathological examination, the extensive upper respiratory tract involvement makes GPA the more likely diagnosis.
answers.explanation_but: Increased levels of p-ANCA are also commonly seen with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA; Churg-Strauss syndrome), which can present with fever, hemoptysis, hematuria, and chronic rhinosinusitis (allergic). However, septal perforation is rare, and this patient's other features would not be seen. Instead, patients with EGPA typically present with a history of bronchial asthma, multifocal mononeuropathy, and/or evidence of eosinophilia on a CBC.

answers.explanation_why: A positive tuberculin skin test can be seen in patients with tuberculosis, which can also cause fever, hemoptysis, and multiple, nodular, cavitating lesions on chest x-ray. Rarely, septal perforation (due to destruction of the septal cartilage by granulomatous lesions), hematuria (due to genitourinary tuberculosis), and cutaneous manifestations (scrofuloderma or lupus vulgaris) can also occur. However, the onset of respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, fever) is usually subacute to chronic with an indolent course, unlike the acute, episodic presentation in this patient. Other constitutional symptoms such as weight loss, malaise, and/or night sweats would also be prominent. Furthermore, patients with disseminated tuberculosis would usually have a history of immigration from an endemic region, and/or an immunocompromised state (e.g., HIV infection, therapy with anti-TNF-α drugs).

Approximately 90% of patients with active GPA and ∼ 65% of patients with inactive GPA have increased c-ANCA titers due to antibodies against proteinase-3. A biopsy of affected tissue (e.g., nasopharynx) should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis, showing necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis. An indirect immunofluorescence of the biopsy sample would show c-ANCA antibodies as a granular pattern of fluorescence limited to the cytoplasm (hence “c”-ANCA). Over time, nasal cartilage destruction can lead to saddle nose deformity.

Anti-GBM antibodies are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which can also present with fever, hemoptysis, and nephritic syndrome. However, inspiratory stridor and cavitating nodular lesions on chest x-ray would not be seen. Instead, patients have diffuse infiltrating opacification of the lung fields (due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage). Furthermore, this patient's other clinical features are not caused by Goodpasture syndrome.

question_text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and difficulty swallowing for 5 hours. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Physical examination shows an extended neck and excessive drooling. Her voice is muffled and there is inspiratory stridor. There is tender bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and pain upon palpation of the hyoid. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 18,800/mm^3 with 85% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and difficulty swallowing for 5 hours. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Physical examination shows an extended neck and excessive drooling. Her voice is muffled and there is inspiratory stridor. There is tender bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and pain upon palpation of the hyoid. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 18,800/mm3 with 85% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: Various diseases manifest with inspiratory stridor as a main diagnostic feature, but only epiglottitis is notable for painful swallowing, head extension, excessive drooling, a muffled voice, and the absence of a cough.
learning_objective: Recognize epiglottitis, and recall its common causal organisms.

answers.explanation_why: Fever, painful swallowing, excessive drooling, a muffled voice, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy suggest epiglottitis. The introduction of the Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine in 1985 led to an overall decrease in the incidence of epiglottitis, primarily by reducing the rate of Hib infection in children. The incidence of Hib epiglottitis in unvaccinated adults has not significantly changed since the introduction of the vaccine. Now, epiglottitis is more common in adults than in children and is most commonly caused by S. pyogenes, S. pneumoniae, or S. aureus. However, Hib remains a significant causal pathogen, especially in unvaccinated individuals.

Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis, which can manifest with fever and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, lead to airway obstruction. Unlike this patient's presentation, symptoms usually progress gradually, beginning with low-grade fever, headache, and malaise, before leading to lymphadenopathy and tonsillopharyngitis. Additionally, infectious mononucleosis is uncommon in older adults because of immunity from prior exposure.

Adenovirus is a common cause of acute viral tonsillitis. Even though acute tonsillitis also manifests with a sudden onset of fever, dysphagia/odynophagia, and tender, cervical lymph nodes, it does not cause inspiratory stridor or a muffled voice. In addition, viral tonsillitis would show red, swollen tonsils with possible exudate, and the condition is usually accompanied by headache, ear pain, and/or nasal congestion.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the cause of laryngeal diphtheria, which is an important differential diagnosis in patients with inspiratory stridor, odynophagia, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient, patients with laryngeal diphtheria typically present with cough, a hoarse rather than a muffled voice, and a much slower onset of symptoms (4–5 days).

Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of croup, which is an important differential diagnosis in a patient with inspiratory stridor. However, croup typically presents with a cough, a hoarse rather than muffled voice, and no odynophagia. Furthermore, croup almost always occurs in children.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a sore throat and fever. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination shows edematous oropharyngeal mucosa and enlarged tonsils with purulent exudate. There is tender cervical lymphadenopathy. If left untreated, which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in this patient?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a sore throat and fever. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination shows edematous oropharyngeal mucosa and enlarged tonsils with purulent exudate. There is tender cervical lymphadenopathy. If left untreated, which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in this patient?
hint: This patient has an acute infection of the oropharynx with odynophagia, fever, pharyngeal edema, cervical lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar hypertrophy with exudates. These features suggest group A streptococcal pharyngitis (GAS pharyngitis).
learning_objective: Recognize group A streptococcal pharyngitis, and recall its potential complications.

answers.explanation_why: Toxic shock syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection and typically presents with fevers, diffuse rash, and shock from an overwhelming inflammatory response triggered by toxic shock syndrome toxin. Toxigenic strains of group A Streptococcus infection can cause scarlet fever or a toxic shock-like syndrome but is not associated with the development of true toxic shock syndrome.

images.title: Diffuse maculopapular exanthema in toxic shock syndrome
images.description: Multiple partly confluent macules and papules, measuring 1–5 mm in diameter, are visible on the skin of this patient's left arm.This finding is consistent with a maculopapular exanthema (a diagnostic criterium of toxic shock syndrome) caused by staphylococcus aureus.

answers.explanation_why: Polymyalgia rheumatica is an autoimmune disorder that typically presents with proximal muscle pain and stiffness (predominantly affecting the shoulders) and elevated inflammatory markers and is strongly associated with temporal arteritis. Polymyalgia rheumatica can resemble migratory polyarthritis, which is a possible complication of this patient's suspected GAS pharyngitis, but GAS pharyngitis is not associated with the development of polymyalgia rheumatica.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by polyarthritis and morning stiffness. This patient's GAS pharyngitis does increase her risk of acute rheumatic fever and migratory polyarthritis, but would not increase her risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is a potential late and serious complication of acute rheumatic fever, a type II hypersensitivity reaction that can occur within 1–5 weeks after untreated GAS pharyngitis. Rheumatic heart disease can manifest in several ways, including myocarditis, pericarditis, and valvular disease (mitral valve involvement is the most common). The development of dilated cardiomyopathy is multifactorial and usually occurs secondary to valvular disease, but can also result directly from myocarditis.

Erythema multiforme is a rash characterized by varying types of lesions, classically with target lesions (ring surrounding a dusky center). It is associated with several different infections, including Mycoplasma pneumoniae and HSV, as well as exposure to certain medications (phenytoin, NSAIDs, beta-lactam antibiotics, etc). GAS pharyngitis is associated with the development of erythema marginatum but is not a known cause of erythema multiforme.

images.title: Erythematous lesions in erythema multiforme
images.description: Lower thigh and knee of a patient after antibiotic intakeMultiple erythematous, well-demarcated lesions can be seen. The lesions vary in size and shape, and some have merged to form larger lesions. The lesions show central erythema surrounded by a pale pink ring, characteristic of target lesions.

question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and feeling like the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and usually occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which of the following findings most closely correlates with this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and feeling like the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and usually occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which of the following findings most closely correlates with this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with vertigo and nausea, which are common symptoms of a vestibular disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), and recall its association with nystagmus.

answers.explanation_why: Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. While some patients with intention tremor experience dizziness, this is due to disequilibrium secondary to cerebellar dysfunction rather than vestibular dysfunction. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

A positive Romberg test is indicative of dysfunction of the dorsal columns, which can result from conditions such as longstanding uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or syphilis. Dorsal column dysfunction leads to sensory ataxia, which may manifest with vertigo. However, vertigo due to a sensory ataxia is triggered by movement of the extremities instead of head rotation as the symptoms in this patient.

Binocular diplopia, commonly known as double vision, is a sign of dysfunction of the extraocular muscles. While visual impairment can induce vertigo, it is not triggered by head rotation as in this patient.

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. Brain lesions can cause central vertigo, but this is usually due to lesions of the brain stem or cerebellum, not the frontal lobe. This patient's vertigo is episodic rather than chronic, as would be expected in a patient with lesions of the CNS.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless growth in his mouth. He has no other medical conditions. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 38 years but recently switched to smokeless tobacco. He drinks alcohol socially on most days of the week. Physical examination shows white patches on the oral mucosa along the gums that cannot be scraped off with gauze. The lesions have a granular texture. A combination HIV-1/2 immunoassay is negative. A biopsy of the lesion shows a marked increase in the thickness of the stratum corneum and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless growth in his mouth. He has no other medical conditions. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 38 years but recently switched to smokeless tobacco. He drinks alcohol socially on most days of the week. Physical examination shows white patches on the oral mucosa along the gums that cannot be scraped off with gauze. The lesions have a granular texture. A combination HIV-1/2 immunoassay is negative. A biopsy of the lesion shows a marked increase in the thickness of the stratum corneum and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The oral cavity has both keratinized and nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. The stratum corneum, which is the superficial layer of keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is composed of anucleated keratinocytes. Increased thickness of this layer indicates hyperkeratosis, and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer indicates parakeratosis.
learning_objective: Recognize oral leukoplakia.

answers.explanation_why: The pseudomembranous (common) and hyperplastic (rare) forms of oral candidiasis manifest as white lesions in the oral cavity. Chronic smoking, which can cause xerostomia and alter the balance of oral bacterial flora, is also a minor risk factor for oral candidiasis. However, the lesions of pseudomembranous candidiasis can be scraped off, unlike this patient's lesions. Hyperplastic candidiasis lesions cannot be scraped off, but they typically appear near the labial commissure, unlike the gingival lesions in this patient. Moreover, a biopsy of oral candidiasis lesions would show hyphal structures and an infiltrate of inflammatory cells.

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: There is a distinct area of white plaque on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.This finding is characteristic oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush).

answers.explanation_why: In-situ oral squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) can appear as a white patch that cannot be scraped off. This patient also has several risk factors for oral SCC (e.g., 50–70 years of age, male sex, smoking, alcohol use). However, a biopsy in the case of carcinoma in situ would show evidence of dysplastic changes (e.g., hyperchromatism, increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio) extending to the basement membrane of the oral epithelium. This patient has a premalignant condition that can develop into oral SCC, but there is no histological evidence of SCC at this time.

Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL), which is caused by Epstein-Barr virus, manifests as white patches on the oral mucosa that cannot be wiped off with gauze, and biopsy can show marked hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis. However, the lesions of OHL are typically found on the lateral surfaces of the tongue, not the gingiva, and have a hairy or feathery rather than granular texture. Moreover, OHL lesions typically only manifest in immunocompromised patients, and there is no evidence of immunosuppression in this patient.

images.title: HIV patient with oral hairy leukoplakia
images.description: A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

answers.explanation_why: Lichen planus typically occurs in middle-aged individuals, manifests as asymptomatic white lesions of the oral mucosa, and can show hyperkeratosis and/or parakeratosis on biopsy. However, the lesions of oral lichen planus typically appear as reticular white lines (Wickham striae), and the degree of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis on biopsy is usually minimal. Moreover, lichen planus is characterized by hypergranulosis, degeneration of the stratum basale, and saw-toothed rete ridges with lymphocytic infiltration, none of which are seen here.

images.title: Oral lichen planus
images.description: Lacelike, white lesions on the oral mucous membrane that cannot be scraped off (Wickham striae) are visible.This appearance is typical for oral lichen planus.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has oral leukoplakia, a relatively common precancerous condition of the oral epithelium. Smoking and alcohol consumption are important risk factors for this condition, which manifests as single or multiple asymptomatic white plaques that cannot be scraped off. Any part of the oral cavity can be affected. If untreated, leukoplakia can undergo malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. The risk of malignant transformation is higher if the white patches are nonhomogenous in appearance and/or texture (e.g., erythroleukoplakia, verrucous leukoplakia).

images.title: Gingival leukoplakia
images.description: White patches that cannot be scraped off are visible on the gingiva of the lower labial sulcus (green overlay).This finding is typical of leukoplakia, which is most commonly found in the oral cavity.

question_text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of dizziness, tinnitus, and hearing loss on the left side for 6 weeks. These episodes last for hours at a time and are associated with the sensation that the room is spinning. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. Examination shows horizontal nystagmus to the left. Weber test shows lateralization to the right ear. The Rinne test is positive bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of dizziness, tinnitus, and hearing loss on the left side for 6 weeks. These episodes last for hours at a time and are associated with the sensation that the room is spinning. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. Examination shows horizontal nystagmus to the left. Weber test shows lateralization to the right ear. The Rinne test is positive bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The triad of vertigo, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss (normal Rinne test, lateralization to the unaffected side) is characteristic of Ménière disease.
learning_objective: Recognize endolymphatic hydrops as the cause of Ménière disease.

answers.explanation_why: Dislodged otoliths can cause the severe vertigo attacks seen in benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). When otoliths become displaced into one of the semicircular ducts, they can disrupt the endolymph and thus lead to stimulation of the hair cells on the cupula. This stimulation sends signals to the brain that suggest motion even if the patient is not moving, thus triggering the sensation of vertigo. Although this patient has vertigo, he also has cochlear symptoms (tinnitus and hearing loss), which are typically absent in patients with BPPV. In addition, contrary to this patient's presentation, vertigo in BPPV lasts only for a few seconds and is triggered by movement.

images.title: Anatomy of the inner ear
images.description: The inner ear consists of a bony labyrinth with a membranous labyrinth inside it, separated by a space containing perilymph fluid. It contains the cochlea and vestibular system. The cochlea (on the right) is responsible for the conversion of sound waves into neuronal signals, which are transmitted via the cochlear nerve (depicted by a cartoon DJ). The vestibular system (on the left) consists of three semicircular canals, the saccule, and the utricle. Semicircular canals detect angular acceleration in three planes: the superior or anterior semicircular canal in the sagittal plane, the posterior semicircular canal in the coronal plane, and the lateral or horizontal semicircular canal in the transverse plane. The saccule and utricle contain cells that detect linear motion in the vertical and horizontal planes, respectively. The neuronal signals from the semicircular canals are transmitted via the vestibular nerve (depicted by a dancing cartoon).

answers.explanation_why: Vestibular neuritis, which is caused by inflammation of the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII and most often occurs following a recent upper respiratory infection (URI) can also manifest with vertigo and nystagmus. However, this patient has no history of URI. In addition, vertigo from vestibular neuritis is usually directed at the unaffected side and continuous (rather than intermittent). Moreover, cochlear symptoms (sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) are not typically seen.

Acoustic neuroma can manifest with vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. In addition, the results of Weber and Rinne tests are similar to those seen in this patient. However, acoustic neuromas grow slowly, and the CNS is capable of compensating the imbalances from the injured vestibular system, making recurrent attacks of vertigo unlikely.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Plaques of demyelination are a typical MRI finding in patients with multiple sclerosis. Some patients can develop vertigo (in the case of cerebellar or brainstem involvement), but hearing loss and tinnitus are very rare symptoms. A common first manifestation of multiple sclerosis is impaired vision (due to retrobulbar neuritis), and as the disease progresses, other sensory and/or motor neurological deficits appear.

Endolymphatic hydrops, which results in endolymph accumulation within the membranous labyrinth, is the underlying mechanism of Ménière disease. In addition to vertigo, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss, patients often have ear fullness and nystagmus that can be directed towards the affected side (irritative nystagmus) or the healthy side (reversed nystagmus).

Infarction of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome. Symptoms include vertigo and nystagmus but not typically tinnitus or hearing loss. In addition, patients with Wallenberg syndrome generally develop dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, none of which is seen in this patient.

images.title: Wallenberg syndrome
images.description:
Wallenberg syndrome results from occlusion of either the vertebral artery or its branch, the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). Occlusion leads to lateral medullary infarction, which can affect multiple brainstem areas in the following ways:– Lateral spinothalamic tract (purple): contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk and limbs
– Trigeminal nucleus (purple): ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face
– Vestibular nucleus (red): vertigo with falling to the affected side and nystagmus to the opposite side
– Inferior cerebellar peduncle (dark blue): ataxia and dysmetria
– Nucleus ambiguus (green): dysphagia, hoarseness, and a decreased gag reflex
– Sympathetic fibers (light blue): Horner syndromeNucleus ambiguus injury and damage to sympathetic fibers can both cause persistent hiccups.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing swelling in his left cheek and recurrent oral ulcers for 1 year. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the left jaw. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A left-sided total parotidectomy is performed. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing swelling in his left cheek and recurrent oral ulcers for 1 year. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the left jaw. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A left-sided total parotidectomy is performed. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: The facial nerve runs through the parotid gland and is most likely to be damaged during a procedure such as total parotidectomy.
learning_objective: Recognize complications of parotidectomy, and recall the functions of the facial nerve.

answers.content: Hyperesthesia of the left ear lobe
answers.explanation_why: Sensation of the earlobe is provided by the greater auricular nerve. Hypoesthesia, not hyperesthesia, of the skin innervated by the greater auricular nerve is a common complication of parotidectomy due to nerve transection during surgery.

answers.content: Impaired taste of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
answers.explanation_why: Taste and sensation in the posterior third of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve, which does not run near the parotid gland but more dorsally, between the internal jugular vein and the internal carotid artery. Glossopharyngeal nerve damage is, therefore, not an expected complication of parotidectomy.
answers.explanation_but: The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve is responsible for transmitting taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, it joins the facial nerve inside the facial canal (thus inside the skull), which means that chorda tympani dysfunction is not a potential complication of parotidectomy.

images.title: Gustatory pathway
images.description: The first neuron of the taste pathway is located in the ganglia of the facial, vagus, and glossopharyngeal nerves. The afferent gustatory nerve fibers join to form the nerve tract that projects to the nucleus of the solitary tract.Second-order neurons project from the medulla oblongata in three distinct branches. Projections to the hypothalamus and amygdala transmit the emotional component of taste perception. Projections to the ventral posterior nucleus (VPM) of the thalamus transmit to the gustatory cortex at the foot of the postcentral gyrus for conscious taste perception.

answers.content: Flushing of the right cheek while eating
answers.explanation_why: Flushing and sweating of the cheek while eating is characteristic of Frey syndrome, which is a late complication of parotidectomy. Frey syndrome is due to inappropriate parasympathetic nerve regrowth. However, Frey syndrome affects the ipsilateral cheek and would, therefore, affect the left cheek in a patient who underwent left parotidectomy, not the right cheek.

answers.content: Inability to wrinkle the left side of the forehead
answers.explanation_why:
Unilateral inability to wrinkle the forehead is a sign of ipsilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, the most common complication of parotidectomy. Injury to the facial nerve during parotidectomy results in an impairment of the ipsilateral muscles of facial expression, including the muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements.

Most cases of post-parotidectomy facial nerve palsy resolve within one month.

images.title: Examination findings in facial nerve palsy
images.description: Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperacusis may be a symptom of facial nerve dysfunction (e.g., Bell palsy) due to associated weakness of the stapedius muscle. The nerve to the stapedius branches off of the facial nerve before the facial nerve exits the skull, which means that stapedius dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

question_text: A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and benign prostatic hyperplasia comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of sneezing and clear nasal discharge. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past. His current medications include metformin and tamsulosin. Examination of the nasal cavity shows red, swollen turbinates. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and benign prostatic hyperplasia comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of sneezing and clear nasal discharge. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past. His current medications include metformin and tamsulosin. Examination of the nasal cavity shows red, swollen turbinates. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
hint: This man has allergic rhinitis, which causes recurrent episodes of watery rhinorrhea and sneezing. His medical history should be taken into account before prescribing a medication.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for allergic rhinitis considering comorbid conditions.

answers.explanation_why: Allergic rhinitis can be treated with H1 receptor antagonists. In this patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia who thus has an increased risk of urinary retention, second-generation H1 receptor antagonists (e.g., desloratadine, fexofenadine, loratadine, cetirizine) are preferred because they have minimal anticholinergic effects compared to first-generation H1 receptor antagonists. Second-generation H1 receptor antagonists are also less sedating because they exist in an ionized state at physiologic pH and do not cross the blood-brain barrier.

Theophylline, a methylxanthine, can be used in the treatment of asthma, which is commonly associated with other atopic conditions such as allergic rhinitis. However, this patient does not have symptoms of asthma (e.g., wheezing, breathlessness, cough). In addition, theophylline is not effective in treating upper respiratory tract symptoms such as rhinorrhea and sneezing.

Diphenhydramine, a first-generation H1 receptor antagonist, can be used to treat allergic rhinitis. However, these agents have strong anticholinergic effects and can cause urinary retention in this patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia. A different drug with minimal anticholinergic effects is preferred.

Nizatidine, an H2 receptor antagonist, is primarily used to suppress gastric acid secretion in patients with peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, and/or gastroesophageal reflux disease. H2 receptor antagonists are also used to treat anaphylaxis but are not used to treat allergic rhinitis.

Antibiotics such as amoxicillin are used to treat infectious rhinosinusitis. This patient, however, has symptoms of allergic rhinitis without clinical features of bacterial upper respiratory tract infection (e.g., purulent nasal discharge, fever).

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician with difficulty swallowing for several weeks. Examination of the oropharynx shows lesions on palate and tongue that can be easily scraped off. An image of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician with difficulty swallowing for several weeks. Examination of the oropharynx shows lesions on palate and tongue that can be easily scraped off. An image of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's findings?
hint: Curdy, white oral patches that can be easily scraped off suggest oral thrush.
learning_objective: Recognize oral thrush, and recall its association with T-cell deficiencies.

answers.explanation_why: Oral thrush is caused by Candida albicans infection. The risk of mucocutaneous candidiasis is increased in patients with T-cell deficiency, which can occur in conditions such as HIV infection (↓ CD4+ T-cell count), severe combined immunodeficiency, and DiGeorge syndrome. Other risk factors for mucocutaneous candidiasis are uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, inhalation of corticosteroids, antibiotic use, and neonatal age group (Candida infection acquired during vaginal delivery). Mild oral thrush can be treated topically with nystatin (“swish and swallow”). The odynophagia seen in this patient could suggest involvement of the esophagus (candidal esophagitis). Severe thrush or candidal esophagitis will require systemic therapy with fluconazole or echinocandins.
Inhalation of corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone in asthmatic patients) is a risk factor for oral thrush. Inhalation of salbutamol, a beta-2 agonist, is not a risk factor.

Missed childhood vaccination is a risk factor for measles, which would cause white lesions in the oral cavity called Koplik spots and possibly odynophagia in the prodromal phase. However, Koplik spots appear as pinhead-sized lesion on an erythematous base, unlike the patches seen in this patient, and they cannot be scraped off. Moreover, the prodromal phase would only last a few days before resulting in a maculopapular exanthem (unlike this patient with odynophagia for several weeks).

images.title: Koplik spots
images.description:
Numerous tiny white spots on an erythematous background (Koplik spots; examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible on the buccal mucosa.

Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles infection.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic nicotine abuse (e.g., smoking, tobacco chewing) can cause white patches in the oral mucosa (leukoplakia) due to carcinoma in situ. However, these patches cannot be scraped off, typically occur on the buccal mucosa, gingiva, lower lip, or floor of the mouth (unlike the predominantly palatal lesions in this patient), and are usually not associated with odynophagia.

images.title: Oral leukoplakia
images.description: Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: EBV can cause white patches in the oral mucosa (oral hairy leukoplakia) in immunocompromised patients. But these patches cannot be scraped off, typically occur on the sides of the tongue (unlike the predominantly palatal lesions in this patient), and are usually not associated with odynophagia. EBV can also cause acute tonsillitis (infectious mononucleosis), which would present with odynophagia and possibly white patches (exudates) that can be scraped off. However, the location of the patches on the palate and uvula instead of the tonsils, and the absence of other features of acute tonsillitis or infectious mononucleosis (e.g., fever, enlarged red tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly) indicate a different diagnosis.

images.title: HIV patient with oral hairy leukoplakia
images.description: A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

answers.explanation_why: Group A streptococcus can cause acute tonsillitis, which would present with odynophagia and possibly white patches (exudates) that can be scraped off. However, the location of the patches on the palate and uvula instead of the tonsils, and the absence of features of tonsillitis (e.g., fever, enlarged inflamed tonsils, tender cervical lymphadenopathy) indicate a different diagnosis.

images.title: Acute tonsillitis
images.description: The tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and gray-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts as well as on the posterior aspect of the tongue. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: Oral mucosa of an HIV-positive patientThere are several distinct white plaques on the soft palate and uvula.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blisters on her forearms and pain during sexual intercourse. Her only medications are metformin and glyburide. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearms and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blisters on her forearms and pain during sexual intercourse. Her only medications are metformin and glyburide. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearms and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's condition is confirmed via biopsy, which would show acantholysis and deposition of IgG in the intercellular spaces of the epidermis.
learning_objective: Recognize pemphigus vulgaris.

answers.explanation_why: SSSS can present with painful blisters and a positive Nikolsky sign, as in this patient. However, the disease typically occurs in children below the age of 6 years and blisters would be accompanied by erythema of the surrounding skin and features of systemic toxicity such as fever and/or malaise. Also, mucosal involvement does not occur in the condition, and the onset of blisters would be preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo, staphylococcal diarrhea).

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins, including desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1. Certain medications, such as captopril, glyburide, thiol-containing drugs (e.g., penicillamine), and phenol-containing drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, rifampicin, phenobarbital, aspirin), can induce the formation of these autoantibodies. Since desmosomal adhesion proteins enable keratinocyte adherence, damage to these proteins causes intraepidermal bullae formation and a positive Nikolsky sign. The lesions typically occur first on mucous membranes and can become confluent or erode to form painful ulcers.

Pemphigus vulgaris is treated with high-dose systemic corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., azathioprine, IVIG, rituximab). Severe pemphigus vulgaris can be fatal, as it can lead to bacterial superinfection, fluid loss, and/or electrolyte imbalance.

images.title: Pemphigus vulgaris
images.description: Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

answers.explanation_why: Behcet disease can cause painful oral and genital ulcers as well as cutaneous lesions, as in this patient. However, the cutaneous manifestations of Behcet disease typically appear as papulopustular lesions or lesions resembling erythema nodosum; blisters are not seen. Moreover, Behcet disease typically occurs between 20–40 years, and clinical features of uveitis such as decreased vision, eye pain, red eye, and/or hypopyon would be present.

Lichen planus can present with lesions on the skin as well as the mucous membranes of the oral cavity and/or genitalia, as in this patient. However, lichen planus usually manifests as firm, shiny, reddish-purple, polygonal papules that are intensely pruritic, and the enanthem would typically appear as white streaks forming a lace-like network (Wickham striae) or fixed white plaques. Blister formation is not usually seen in patients with lichen planus.

images.title: Cutaneous lichen planus
images.description: Photograph of the left wristMultiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated. This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

answers.explanation_why: Dermatitis herpetiformis can cause blistering of the skin, as in this patient. However, dermatitis herpetiformis typically affects the extensor surfaces of elbows, knees, and buttocks, and patients usually complain of intense pruritus. Moreover, mucosal involvement does not typically occur.

images.title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
images.description: Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

answers.explanation_why: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) would result in blisters of the skin and mucous membranes as well as a positive Nikolsky sign, as in this patient. However, patients with TEN typically have widespread involvement of the skin surface and systemic features such as fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.

images.title: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (severe Stevens-Johnson syndrome)
images.description: Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

answers.explanation_why: Bullous pemphigoid presents with cutaneous blisters, as in this patient. However, the blisters are typically tense and occur symmetrically, with a predilection for intertriginous areas. Moreover, a prodromal phase that is characterized by pruritus and papules/urticarial lesions/skin excoriations would occur, the Nikolsky sign would be negative, and mucous membranes (especially those of the genitalia) would typically be spared.

question_text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother after 2 days of fever, runny nose, hoarseness, and severe, dry cough. He appears restless. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), and his respiratory rate is 39/min. Examination shows clear rhinorrhea and a barking cough. There is a prolonged inspiratory phase with harsh stridor upon agitation. An x-ray of the neck shows tapering of the subglottic region. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother after 2 days of fever, runny nose, hoarseness, and severe, dry cough. He appears restless. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), and his respiratory rate is 39/min. Examination shows clear rhinorrhea and a barking cough. There is a prolonged inspiratory phase with harsh stridor upon agitation. An x-ray of the neck shows tapering of the subglottic region. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: This patient presents with symptoms of upper respiratory infection (e.g., fever, rhinorrhea, hoarseness), a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and tapering of the upper trachea on x-ray (the steeple sign). This constellation of symptoms and findings is characteristic of croup.
learning_objective: Recognize croup, and recall its most common causative organism.

answers.explanation_why: Adenoviruses are responsible for a variety of respiratory, gastrointestinal, conjunctival, and other types of infections, especially in young children. Although croup, the likely diagnosis here, can be caused by adenoviruses in a minority of cases, a different causal organism is much more common.

The influenza virus is responsible for annual seasonal flu outbreaks. Although croup, the likely diagnosis here, is caused by the influenza virus in a minority of cases, a different causal organism is much more common.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common causative organism of bacterial pneumonia in all age groups. Although croup, the likely diagnosis here, can be complicated by secondary infection with S. pneumoniae, a different causal organism is much more common.

Haemophilus influenzae is responsible for many pediatric bacterial infections including epiglottitis, which manifests with high fever and stridor. However, since the introduction of the HiB vaccine, other organisms have become a more common cause of epiglottitis. Furthermore, children with epiglottitis typically have odynophagia and drooling, which are not present in this patient. Finally, epiglottitis appears with supraglottic narrowing on x-ray (the thumbprint sign), in contrast to the infraglottic narrowing seen in croup (the steeple sign).

images.title: Thumb and vallecula signs (epiglottitis)
images.description: X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

answers.explanation_why: Parainfluenza virus is the most common causative organism of croup (75% of cases), the likely diagnosis here. Less common causative organisms include other airborne respiratory viruses, such as respiratory syncytial virus, adenovirus, and influenza virus. Although much less common than croup, laryngeal diphtheria can also manifest with a barking cough, so it would be important to ask about immunizations in this child.

images.title: Steeple sign
images.description: X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

answers.explanation_why: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most common causative organism of bronchiolitis and causes many other respiratory infections seen in young children, including viral pneumonia. Although croup, the likely diagnosis here, is caused by RSV in a minority of cases, a different causal organism is much more common.

Measles morbillivirus is the causative organism of measles, which primarily affects unvaccinated infants. Before the appearance of its maculopapular rash, measles classically manifests in an upper respiratory infection with a prodrome of “3 C's”: coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis, of which this child only has a cough. Koplik spots, also missing here, appear during the prodrome of measles and are pathognomic. This child's barking cough and stridor indicate laryngotracheal infection rather than measles.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and itchy, red eyes. His symptoms began while he was away at summer camp. His immunizations are not up-to-date. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the conjunctivae and posterior pharyngeal wall. There is bilateral, tender, preauricular lymphadenopathy. Further evaluation shows infection with a DNA virus. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and itchy, red eyes. His symptoms began while he was away at summer camp. His immunizations are not up-to-date. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the conjunctivae and posterior pharyngeal wall. There is bilateral, tender, preauricular lymphadenopathy. Further evaluation shows infection with a DNA virus. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
hint: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of pharyngoconjunctival fever, a classic manifestation of a specific viral infection.
learning_objective: Recognize pharyngoconjunctival fever, and recall its causal pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Adenovirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure and the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms. Conjunctivitis and febrile pharyngitis occurring simultaneously in a patient who has spent time in close proximity to other individuals (e.g., summer camp) is highly suspicious for adenovirus infection. Apart from pharyngoconjunctivitis, adenovirus may cause gastroenteritis, pneumonia, acute hemorrhagic cystitis, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

Parvovirus is a nonenveloped, single-stranded DNA virus and the causative organism of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). Fifth disease most commonly manifests with mild, cold-like symptoms, similar to this patient's presentation, after which a characteristic rash on the cheeks develops (slapped-cheek rash). The lack of rash in this patient, taken together with the simultaneous appearance of both pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, make another diagnosis more likely.

Picornaviridae comprise a heterogeneous group of viruses that are associated with a wide variety of diseases ranging from the common cold (rhinovirus) to viral meningitis (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus). However, picornaviridae are nonenveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses, whereas this patient has a DNA virus. Moreover, the picornaviridae are not specifically linked to pharyngoconjunctivitis.

Paramyxoviridae are a family of several viruses including the parainfluenza virus, mumps virus, and measles virus. Measles causes findings similar to those of this patient, including conjunctivitis, fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. Moreover, an incomplete vaccination history could support the suspicion of measles in a 10-year-old child. However, this patient does not have a rash, as a measles patient likely would. Furthermore, paramyxoviridae are RNA viruses, while this patient has a DNA virus.

Human herpes virus 6 is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure associated with the development of roseola infantum. Roseola manifests with high fever for a few days, followed by a rapid return to an afebrile state and the onset of a maculopapular rash. Affected individuals may also develop pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, which would be consistent with this patient's presentation. However, this patient's age makes roseola very unlikely, as most individuals are seropositive by the age of 3. Also, postoccipital lymphadenopathy rather than preauricular is more characteristic of roseola.

Human herpes virus 4, better known as Epstein-Barr virus, is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus and the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. The pharyngitis seen in this patient could be attributed to mono. However, individuals with mono would not be expected to present with conjunctivitis or preauricular lymphadenopathy, but rather, with hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy.

question_text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of a cough with blood-tinged sputum for 1 week. He also reports fever and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past 2 months. Over the past year, he has had 4 episodes of sinusitis. Physical examination shows palpable nonblanching skin lesions over the hands and feet. Examination of the nasal cavity shows ulceration of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and a depressed nasal bridge. Oral examination shows a painful erythematous gingival enlargement that bleeds easily on contact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of a cough with blood-tinged sputum for 1 week. He also reports fever and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past 2 months. Over the past year, he has had 4 episodes of sinusitis. Physical examination shows palpable nonblanching skin lesions over the hands and feet. Examination of the nasal cavity shows ulceration of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and a depressed nasal bridge. Oral examination shows a painful erythematous gingival enlargement that bleeds easily on contact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss), hemoptysis, upper respiratory tract manifestations (recurrent sinusitis with nasopharyngeal ulceration, septal deformity), gingival hyperplasia, and palpable purpura suggest granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis.
learning_objective: Recognize granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and recall its pathogenesis.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of the metalloprotease ADAMTS13 causes thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Patients with TTP also present with fever and purpura. However, the purpura in TTP is typically nonpalpable. TTP is not associated with recurrent sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulceration, septal deformations, or gingival hyperplasia. Instead, neurological symptoms, renal failure, and anemia would be expected.

Systemic mycotic infections, such as blastomycosis or aspergillosis, can also present with hemoptysis, fever, and weight loss. Palpable skin lesions can be present in blastomycosis but would resemble crusted plaques with ulcerations rather than the purpura in this patient. Nasopharyngeal ulceration, septal deformations, and gingival hyperplasia are not associated with systemic mycotic infections.

In ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV), aberrant epigenetic expression of proteinase-3 (PR3) and myeloperoxidase (MPO) occurs on the membranes of neutrophils. Autoantibodies formed against these proteins (PR3-ANCA, MPO-ANCA) activate neutrophils, which release inflammatory mediators resulting in damage to endothelial cells of small blood vessels. The clinical phenotype of AAV is closely correlated with the type of ANCA. GPA, which this patient most likely has, is predominantly associated with PR3-ANCA production, while eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis are predominantly associated with MPO-ANCA production. Unlike non-ANCA small-vessel vasculitis (e.g., cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, Henoch-Schonlein purpura) which are caused primarily by immune complex deposition, the vessel walls of patients with AAV have a paucity of immune complexes (“pauci-immune” vasculitis).

Apart from the typical presentation of upper respiratory tract symptoms, this patient's easily bleeding gingival hyperplasia is a unique feature of GPA, called strawberry gingivitis.

Arteriovenous malformations are seen in several conditions, including Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome. This condition can cause hemoptysis and skin lesions. However, the skin lesions are nonpalpable blanching telangiectasias, rather than palpable purpura. Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome is not associated with fever, weight loss, gingival hyperplasia, recurrent sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulceration, or septal deformities. Instead, recurrent epistaxis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and hematuria would be expected.

Immune complex deposition in the vessel wall is seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) and cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, both of which can manifest with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss) and palpable purpura. However, recurrent sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulceration, septal deformities, and gingival hyperplasia would not be expected in either of these conditions. Instead, patients present with arthralgia, renal disease, and other specific manifestations (e.g., peripheral neuropathy and Raynaud disease in cryoglobulinemia, abdominal pain in HSP). This patient most likely has an ANCA-associated vasculitis, which is not caused by immune complex deposition.

Malignant myeloid cell proliferation is seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML can also manifest with fever, weight loss, recurrent infections, gingival hyperplasia, and purpura. However, the purpura in AML is typically nonpalpable. Additionally, nasopharyngeal ulceration and nasal septum deformities are not consistent with AML.
