question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening pain with swallowing for 3 days and a dry sensation in the mouth over the past week. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled fluticasone and albuterol. Physical examination shows white plaques on the dorsal surface of the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening pain with swallowing for 3 days and a dry sensation in the mouth over the past week. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled fluticasone and albuterol. Physical examination shows white plaques on the dorsal surface of the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This woman has oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush), an infection caused by Candida albicans that manifests with painful swallowing, a dry sensation in the mouth, and white plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.
learning_objective: Recognize oropharyngeal candidiasis, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Triamcinolone is used to treat recurrent aphthous stomatitis. This condition typically manifests with lesions on nonkeratinized areas of the mouth (e.g., soft palate and inner cheeks) rather than keratinized areas such as the dorsal surface of the tongue. Triamcinolone has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

Topical antifungal drugs such as nystatin oral suspension and clotrimazole troches are first-line therapies for oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely developed due to chronic local immunosuppression from prolonged use of inhaled steroids (e.g., fluticasone). Nystatin binds to ergosterols in the fungal cell membrane and forms pores that disrupt electrolyte balance. It is too toxic for systemic use but has minimal oral bioavailability and is thus safe for treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis.

Additional risk factors for developing oropharyngeal candidiasis include immunosuppressive conditions (e.g., HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), use of dentures, xerostomia, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

answers.explanation_why: Penicillin G is used to treat various bacterial infections such as acute tonsillitis caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This condition classically manifests with painful swallowing, as seen in this patient, but also causes tonsillar exudates and tender lymphadenopathy, which are not seen here. Penicillin G has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

Valganciclovir is an antiviral medication that is used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV esophagitis typically manifests with painful swallowing but also causes linear mucosal ulcers, which are not seen here. Valganciclovir has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. Herpetic gingivostomatitis is an HSV infection that typically manifests with painful swallowing but also causes erythema and painful ulcerations on perioral skin and the oral mucosa, which are not seen here. Acyclovir has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.
Griseofulvin is an oral antifungal used to treat tinea infections (e.g., tinea pedis). Griseofulvin has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

Amphotericin B can be used to treat severe systemic fungal infections (e.g., invasive candidiasis), fungal meningitis, and fungal cystitis. Amphotericin B has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of delayed onset of speech. Over the past year, he has also had recurrent dizziness and three episodes of syncope. Examination of the ears shows clear auditory canals and intact tympanic membranes with normal light reflexes. Visual reinforcement audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural deafness. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels. An electrocardiogram of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of delayed onset of speech. Over the past year, he has also had recurrent dizziness and three episodes of syncope. Examination of the ears shows clear auditory canals and intact tympanic membranes with normal light reflexes. Visual reinforcement audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural deafness. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels. An electrocardiogram of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: A mutation in the KCNQ1 gene is the most common cause of Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, a condition associated with arrhythmias and sensorineural deafness.
learning_objective: Recognize Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, and recall its electrocardiogram findings.

answers.explanation_why: Pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST elevations in leads V_1 and V_2 are characteristic ECG findings of Brugada syndrome, which can manifest with dizziness and syncope. However, Brugada syndrome is caused by defective cardiac voltage-gated sodium channels (not potassium channels) and is most commonly seen in adults males of southeast Asian descent. Moreover, Brugada syndrome would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Brugada pattern
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼83/min
– Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
– ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V_1 and V_2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V_1 is described as “coved.”
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V_1.Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V_1–V_3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

answers.content: Slurred upstroke of the QRS complex
answers.explanation_why: A slurred upstroke of the QRS complex (i.e., delta wave) is a characteristic ECG finding of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, which may manifest with dizziness and syncope. However, WPW is caused by an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles and is not due to defective voltage-gated potassium channels. While familial forms of WPW exist, they are uncommon and are associated with mutations in the PRKAG2 gene. Moreover, WPW would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

answers.content: Epsilon wave following the QRS complex
answers.explanation_why: An epsilon wave following the QRS complex is a highly specific ECG finding for arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which may cause dizziness and syncope. However, while this condition can exhibit either autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive inheritance and is associated with various genetic mutations, it is not caused by a defect in voltage-gated potassium channels. Moreover, ARVC would not explain this patient's sensorineural hearing loss.

images.title: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy/dysplasia
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed 25 mm/s) of a patient recovering from sudden cardiac arrest- Heart rate approx. 60/min
- Regular sinus rhythm
- Left axis deviation (R > S in I, R < S aVF)
- First-degree AV block (PR interval approx. 240 ms)
- Prolonged QT interval (QTc approx. 480 ms)
- Widened QRS complexes (> 120 ms) with RBBB morphology
- Low-voltage QRS complexes in limb leads II, III, aVR, aVL, aVF (QRS amplitude < 5 mm)
- Epsilon waves in leads V_1–V_4 (best seen in V_2/V_3, examples marked in red)
- T wave inversion in leads V_1–V_4
- Slight ST depression in leads V_2–V_4Epsilon waves and T wave inversion in V_1–V_4 are highly suggestive of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (the Epsilon wave is the most specific finding in this condition).

answers.content: Progressive lengthening of the PR interval
answers.explanation_why: Progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is dropped is the characteristic ECG finding of Mobitz type I, which may manifest with dizziness and syncope. However, while heart block has many etiologies (e.g., increased vagal tone in athletes, ischemic heart disease, medications), Mobitz I is not caused by defective voltage-gated potassium channels. Moreover, Mobitz I would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Second-degree atrioventricular block: Mobitz I/Wenckebach
images.description:
ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular P waves at a rate of ∼80/min (green overlay)
– There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

answers.explanation_why: Absence of P waves and an irregularly irregular rhythm are the characteristic ECG findings of atrial fibrillation, which may cause dizziness and syncope. However, while there are many risk factors for atrial fibrillation (e.g., valvular heart disease, smoking, hyperthyroidism), it occurs almost exclusively in adults and is not caused by a defect in voltage-gated potassium channels. Moreover, atrial fibrillation would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Irregularly irregular rhythm– Average ventricular rate is ∼ 144/min (24 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)– No discernable P waves– Narrow QRS complexes– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

answers.explanation_why:
Prolongation of the QT interval (typically with a QTc > 500 ms) is seen on ECG in patients with Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, an autosomal recessive form of congenital long QT syndrome that is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the potassium channel genes KCNQ1 (90% of cases) or KCNE1. In cardiomyocytes, the defective potassium channels cause prolongation of the ventricular action potential, which can lead to dizziness, syncope, torsades de pointes, and sudden cardiac death. In the inner ear, the defect disrupts the production of endolymph, resulting in congenital sensorineural deafness.

Another congenital LQTS with a pure cardiac phenotype is Romano-Ward syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition.

images.title: Long QT syndrome
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)- Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 107/min (tachycardia)
- Normal cardiac axis (zoom-box)
- Normal PR interval (approx.160 ms)
- Negative T-wave in III (green circles), T-wave not clearly discernible in V3
- Prolonged (corrected) QT interval with approx. 494 msThese findings suggest a long QT syndrome.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of hoarseness, exertional dyspnea, and fatigue. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His pulse is 98/min and irregular. His voice is coarse in quality. Physical examination shows a liver span of 16 cm and a soft diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hoarseness?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of hoarseness, exertional dyspnea, and fatigue. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His pulse is 98/min and irregular. His voice is coarse in quality. Physical examination shows a liver span of 16 cm and a soft diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hoarseness?
hint: This patient's fatigue, exertional dyspnea, irregular heart rhythm, and hepatomegaly suggest atrial fibrillation and congestive heart failure (CHF). In this setting, the diastolic murmur at the apex is concerning for mitral stenosis, which commonly leads to left atrial dilation.
learning_objective: Recognize extrinsic impingement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

answers.content: Carcinoma arising from the mucosa of the larynx
answers.explanation_why: A squamous cell carcinoma arising from laryngeal mucosa can cause hoarseness, fatigue, dyspnea due to lung metastases and, rarely, hepatomegaly due to liver metastases. However, a laryngeal malignancy would not explain the atrial fibrillation and the diastolic murmur in this patient without risk factors for laryngeal malignancy such as smoking and alcohol consumption.

answers.content: Extrinsic impingement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
answers.explanation_why: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve winds around the arch of the aorta. Massive enlargement of the left atrium (and potentially also the pulmonary artery) in patients with mitral stenosis can compress this nerve resulting in hoarseness (Ortner syndrome). Other rare complications associated with massive left atrial enlargement are massive hemoptysis due to erosion of the bronchial arteries and esophageal compression (dysphagia megalatriensis).

images.title: Ventral view of the mediastinum (I)
images.description: Pleura and pericardium partially resected; removal of the thyroid gland reveals the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

answers.content: Bacterial infection of the vocal folds
answers.explanation_why: Infection of the vocal folds (laryngitis) with bacteria such as Moraxella catarrhalis, Hemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause hoarseness and fatigue, but the onset of symptoms would be acute, unlike in this patient, who has had symptoms for the past 5 months, and would likely include sore throat or a dry cough. Moreover, laryngitis would not cause exertional dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, or a diastolic murmur.

answers.content: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with atrial fibrillation are at increased risk for a thromboembolic stroke, and a stroke in the region of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (lateral medullary syndrome) could cause hoarseness due to nucleus ambiguus infarction and dyspnea due to dorsal vagal nucleus infarction as well as fatigue. However, hoarseness and dyspnea would have been acute and preceded the onset of fatigue by weeks to months (post-stroke fatigue). Moreover, a PICA stroke would also cause other clinical features such as dysphagia, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and decreased pain and temperature sensation in one side of the face and the contralateral half of the body.

images.title: Cranial nerve nuclei of the medulla oblongata
images.description: Transverse sectionTypically, the efferent cranial nuclei are located medially while the afferent nuclei are located more laterally.

answers.content: Laryngeal inflammation due to chemical irritant
answers.explanation_why: Laryngeal inflammation from acidic gastric contents, which occurs in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), can cause persistent hoarseness, but it would not cause exertional dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, or a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common features of GERD such as postprandial chest pain, belching, or dry cough.

Circulating acetylcholine receptor antibodies are seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG), which can cause fluctuating fatigue, hoarseness, stridor, and, rarely, dyspnea. The classic presentation of this condition includes diplopia and ptosis that worsen as the day progresses, neither of which have been reported by this patient. In addition, MG would not cause atrial fibrillation, a diastolic murmur, or hepatomegaly.

question_text: Forty minutes after undergoing nasal polypectomy for refractory rhinitis, a 48-year-old woman develops chest tightness and shortness of breath. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated. She received ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago after the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. She has a history of asthma and hypertension. Her daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. Examination shows a flushed face, watery rhinorrhea, and conjunctival injection. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Forty minutes after undergoing nasal polypectomy for refractory rhinitis, a 48-year-old woman develops chest tightness and shortness of breath. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated. She received ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago after the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. She has a history of asthma and hypertension. Her daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. Examination shows a flushed face, watery rhinorrhea, and conjunctival injection. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma constitutes Samter triad.
learning_objective: Recognize aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease, and recall its reaction mechanism.

answers.explanation_why: A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another underlying cause more likely.

Prinzmetal angina typically manifests as periodic episodes of chest tightness and ischemic ECG changes are usually present during these episodes. However, this patient's ECG is normal. Moreover, clinical features of bronchospasm (e.g., wheezing with decreased breath sounds), a history of aspirin allergy, nasal polyps, and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different diagnosis.

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause cutaneous flushing and bronchial inflammation.

The use of nonselective beta blockers can result in bronchospasm due to inhibition of β_2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta blocker that selectively inhibits β_1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.
answers.explanation_but: All beta blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta blockers are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

answers.explanation_why: ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin, which can result in a flushed face (due to angioedema) and wheezing due to the bronchoconstrictive effect of bradykinin. However, a history of aspirin allergy, nasal polyps, and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac suggest a different mechanism for bronchospasm.

question_text: A 41-year-old man comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of ringing in his ears and worsening difficulty hearing. He has had gradually increasing difficulties hearing conversations in crowded places, which he first noticed 3 years ago. He has also felt depressed, and he noticed that he regularly thinks back to his time in the military. The patient retired from the military 1 month ago when he returned from a deployment to Syria where he was involved in active combat. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a clear translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the right mastoid process. Immediately after the patient stops hearing a tone, the tuning fork is held over the right ear and he reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the left side and shows the same pattern. The vibrating tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound in the center of his head. The results of an audiogram are shown. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's impaired hearing?
content_preview: A 41-year-old man comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of ringing in his ears and worsening difficulty hearing. He has had gradually increasing difficulties hearing conversations in crowded places, which he first noticed 3 years ago. He has also felt depressed, and he noticed that he regularly thinks back to his time in the military. The patient retired from the military 1 month ago when he returned from a deployment to Syria where he was involved in active combat. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a clear translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the right mastoid process. Immediately after the patient stops hearing a tone, the tuning fork is held over the right ear and he reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the left side and shows the same pattern. The vibrating tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound in the center of his head. The results of an audiogram are shown. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's impaired hearing?
hint: A bilaterally positive Rinne test and absent lateralization of sound during the Weber test in a patient with difficulty hearing indicate bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His difficulty hearing conversations in crowded places is suggestive of high-frequency hearing loss, which is evident on the audiogram (notch between 3–4 kHz).
learning_objective: Recognize noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss.

answers.explanation_why: Ototoxic medications such as loop diuretics, aminoglycosides, vancomycin, or cisplatin can cause tinnitus and bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, which are present here. However, this patient's only current medication is hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, which is not known to be ototoxic.

Meniere disease, which is caused by endolymphatic hydrops, can lead to tinnitus and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, both of which are seen here. However, in initial stages, the hearing loss in this condition would usually have a fluctuating course, be accompanied by a sensation of ear fullness, and primarily affect low frequencies. In addition, Meniere disease typically manifests with acute episodes of severe peripheral vertigo (a component of the Meniere triad). In contrast, this patient does not report vertigo or ear fullness and has progressive high-frequency hearing loss, while Meniere disease typically causes low to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

images.title: Audiogram in Meniere disease
images.description: Audiograms of a patient with Meniere disease in the left earLeft audiogram (at first presentation): normal hearing in both earsRight audiogram (2 years later): sensorineural hearing loss to low and midfrequency signals in the left ear; normal hearing in the right earAsymmetric fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is a characteristic feature of Meniere disease.Circle: hearing threshold of the right ear; Square: hearing threshold of the left ear

answers.explanation_why: Otosclerosis, which leads to fixation of the stapes bone in the oval window, can affect both ears and cause progressive bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, as seen here. However, the hearing loss in this condition is conductive rather than sensorineural; therefore, a negative rather than positive Rinne test would be expected. Moreover, patients with otosclerosis hear better in crowded environments (paracusis willisii) and have a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2 kHz (Carhart notch) on an audiogram unlike this patient who has difficulty hearing in crowded places and a notch at 3–4 kHz. Additionally, otoscopic examination in patients with active otosclerosis would usually reveal a red-blue hue seen through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign) as opposed to a clear, translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex.

images.title: Otosclerosis audiogram
images.description: Audiogram of a patient with otosclerosis in the right ear.Air conduction is reduced in the affected ear by approx. 35dB. Bone conduction shows a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2000Hz (Carhart notch). These are characteristic findings of otosclerosis, a condition that causes conductive hearing loss due to the fixation of the stapes to the oval window.

answers.explanation_why: Presbycusis is the most common type of sensorineural hearing loss. This condition leads to progressive bilateral hearing loss with impairment of high-frequency hearing and tinnitus, both of which are seen here. However, presbycusis is usually first noticed in the sixth decade of life and the audiogram shows hearing impairment across a wide spectrum of high frequencies rather than a pronounced notch at a specific frequency.

images.title: Audiogram in presbycusis
images.description: Frequency-dependent auditory threshold, measured via air and bone conduction: In presbycusis, patients struggle to hear the higher frequencies in both air and bone conduction.

answers.explanation_why: Ear barotrauma can be caused by flying or explosions (blast injuries), both of which this patient has likely been exposed to, and can lead to bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. However, sensorineural hearing loss in this condition results from rupture of the oval window membrane and would be accompanied by nausea and vertigo. More commonly, barotrauma manifests with conductive hearing loss, which would show a different pattern on tuning fork tests and audiogram. In addition, symptom onset is sudden rather than progressive and affected patients typically present with a feeling of pressure and/or stabbing ear pain. Finally, otoscopic examination would reveal hematotympanum as opposed to a clear, translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex.

Repeated exposure to sounds above a threshold of 85 dB (e.g., motorcycle) or a single exposure to sounds above 120 dB (e.g., gunshots, jet takeoffs) can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. Sensorineural hearing loss is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of the hair cells in the organ of Corti. Deployed military personnel, like this patient, have a high occupational risk of developing noise-induced hearing loss. Such hearing loss is slowly progressive and affects high frequencies (3–4 kHz) first, which results in difficulty hearing in crowded environments. Tinnitus is often an associated symptom. There is no definitive treatment available (besides hearing aids); therefore, prevention with appropriate hearing protection is essential. In addition to sensorineural hearing loss, exposure to sudden noise louder than 120 dB can cause conductive hearing loss through rupture of the tympanic membrane.

Hearing loss is a risk factor for depressive disorders, which are common among veterans.

images.title: Audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss
images.description: Frequency-dependent auditory threshold, measured via air and bone conductionIn noise-induced hearing loss, hearing is most impaired at frequencies of 4000 Hz in both bone and air conduction.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 42-year-old man comes to the physician with progressive hearing loss for the past year and painless unilateral fluid leakage from the ear for the past month. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Otoscopic examination shows a brown, irregular mass and partial retraction of the tympanic membrane. The results of an audiogram are shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hearing loss?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 42-year-old man comes to the physician with progressive hearing loss for the past year and painless unilateral fluid leakage from the ear for the past month. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Otoscopic examination shows a brown, irregular mass and partial retraction of the tympanic membrane. The results of an audiogram are shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hearing loss?
hint: This patient's audiogram shows an air-bone gap as a result of an increased auditory threshold in air conduction with normal bone conduction, which is typical for conductive hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize a cholesteatoma.

answers.content: Infection of the external ear canal on the right
answers.explanation_why: Infection of the external ear canal (otitis externa) on the right can lead to fluid leakage from the right ear and conductive hearing loss on the right, which are seen on this patient's audiogram. However, otitis externa is typically associated with severe ear pain. Otoscopy in this condition would show an erythematous and edematous external ear canal. Furthermore, otitis externa is an acute condition, whereas this patient's presentation indicates a more chronic process.

answers.content: Accumulation of sebaceous gland secretions on the left
answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of cerumen, which is secreted by the sebaceous glands in the auditory canal, can cause cerumen impaction and lead to otorrhea and conductive hearing loss. However, cerumen impaction on the left would result in impaired air conduction of the left ear, whereas this patient's audiogram shows abnormal air conduction on the right side. Furthermore, otoscopy of a cerumen-impacted ear would show obstruction of the external auditory canal by a brownish-yellow, waxy plug; the tympanic membrane would most likely not be visible.

images.title: Cerumen impaction
images.description: Otoscopic image of the external auditory canalThe auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

answers.content: Damage to the organ of Corti on the right
answers.explanation_why: Unilateral damage to the organ of Corti can occur, e.g., as a result of labyrinthitis. However, damage to the organ of Corti manifests with sensorineural hearing loss, which would show up on audiometry as an increase in the threshold for both air and bone conduction. Furthermore, patients with labyrinthitis also typically present acutely or subacutely, unlike this patient, who has had progressive hearing loss for the past year, and labyrinthitis is usually associated with tinnitus and/or vertigo.

images.title: Sensorineural hearing loss
images.description: Pure tone audiogramBoth ears show a parallel decrease of air and bone conduction in the higher frequencies. This finding indicates cochlear or retrocochlear damage (often seen in presbycusis).

answers.content: Malignant squamous cell neoplasia on the left
answers.explanation_why: Squamous cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal can manifest with otorrhea and conductive hearing loss, as well as otoscopic findings similar to those seen in this patient. However, patients would typically have severe ear pain, which is not seen here, and this patient's audiogram shows conductive hearing loss in the right, not the left ear.

answers.content: Collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium on the right
answers.explanation_why: This patient's progressive right-sided conductive hearing loss, painless otorrhea, and irregular mass on otoscopy suggest a cholesteatoma of the right ear. This condition is characterized by keratinizing squamous epithelium growing from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or the mastoid, causing chronic inflammation and erosion of the auditory ossicles. Cholesteatomas can be congenital or acquired. Acquired cholesteatomas can be classified as primary if caused by chronic negative middle ear pressure (due to eustachian tube dysfunction without middle ear infection) or secondary if caused by past injury to the tympanic membrane (typically due to chronic otitis media). The retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane and brown, irregular mass seen in this patient's otoscopy are characteristic of primary acquired cholesteatoma. Secondary acquired cholesteatomas, on the other hand, typically appear as a pearly white mass shining through the intact tympanic membrane.

images.title: Cholesteatoma
images.description: A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium that grows from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or mastoid. The presence of abnormal epithelium triggers an inflammatory response that can destroy surrounding structures such as the ossicles.

answers.content: Tumor of the vestibular nerve on the left
answers.explanation_why: Tumors of the vestibulocochlear nerve such as acoustic neuromas can cause unilateral hearing loss, which is seen in this patient. However, a tumor on the left would be evident on an audiogram as sensorineural hearing loss on the left, characteristically showing increased auditory thresholds in both air and bone conduction. This patient's audiogram shows conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Moreover, a tumor of the vestibular nerve would likely cause further symptoms, such as vertigo and tinnitus, and would not explain this patient's otorrhea and otoscopic findings.

images.title: Conductive hearing loss
images.description: Pure tone audiogramThe diagram shows a difference of 30dB between air and bone conduction in the right ear versus the left ear. These findings are indicative of middle or external ear pathologies, such as otitis media or tympanic membrane perforation.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful left ear with discharge for the past 5 days. The ear pain is constant and slightly improves with over-the-counter ibuprofen. He has no personal history of serious illnesses. He works as a sound technician for a rock band and uses earplugs almost the entire day. He smokes two packs of cigarettes and drinks three to four beers daily. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Examination of the left ear discloses a swollen pinna and a malodorous discharge from the external auditory meatus; the tragus is tender to touch. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows a swollen ear canal. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 90 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful left ear with discharge for the past 5 days. The ear pain is constant and slightly improves with over-the-counter ibuprofen. He has no personal history of serious illnesses. He works as a sound technician for a rock band and uses earplugs almost the entire day. He smokes two packs of cigarettes and drinks three to four beers daily. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Examination of the left ear discloses a swollen pinna and a malodorous discharge from the external auditory meatus; the tragus is tender to touch. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows a swollen ear canal. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 90 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Severe ear pain, otorrhea, ear canal edema, and a tragus tender to touch are suggestive of acute otitis externa (AOE), which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. Using earplugs can cause injury to the skin and increase moisture in the external auditory canal, which increases the risk of AOE.
learning_objective: Recognize acute otitis externa, and choose the most appropriate topical therapy.

answers.content: Ear swabs, blood cultures, CT scan of the temporal bone, and systemic therapy with intravenous ciprofloxacin
answers.explanation_why: An extensive diagnostic workup and intravenous ciprofloxacin are required in patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa (MOE). Severe ear pain and otorrhea are typical manifestations of this condition. However, this patient has no risk factors for MOE (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus), and otoscopic examination shows no evidence of granulation tissue, which would be expected in this condition.

answers.content: Ear swabs and topical therapy with clotrimazole and acetic acid
answers.explanation_why: Clotrimazole ear drops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which manifests with ear pain and otorrhea. However, this condition is characterized by excessive ear itching. Antifungal therapy for AOE is indicated if the initial therapy is insufficient or if features suggestive of fungal infection (e.g., fungal filaments and spores) are seen on otoscopy. Moreover, ear swabs are only performed if the patient does not respond to initial therapy or in cases of severe AOE (i.e., completely occluded EAC, fever), whereas this patient has uncomplicated AOE.

Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenzae, the most common causal pathogens of AOM. AOM can manifest with ear pain and otorrhea. However, AOM is also characterized by a red bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the most common cause of acute otitis externa.

answers.content: Topical therapy with betamethasone and acetic acid, and systemic therapy with oral ciprofloxacin
answers.explanation_why: Topical therapy with a steroid and an antiseptic is recommended as part of the treatment for uncomplicated AOE, which this patient has. However, systemic therapy with oral ciprofloxacin is only indicated in patients with AOE and immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus, or severe otitis externa with cellulitis of the face and neck, or if topical administration is not possible or ineffective. Topical antibiotic treatment is preferred in this patient.

answers.content: Topical therapy with ciprofloxacin and hydrocortisone
answers.explanation_why:
AOE is treated with a topical preparation that contains a steroid (e.g., hydrocortisone, betamethasone) and an antimicrobial that is effective against the most common causative bacteria of AOE (e.g., aminoglycoside, fluoroquinolone). A commonly used and effective combination is ciprofloxacin and hydrocortisone. Alternatively, a combination of neomycin, polymyxin B, and hydrocortisone may be used. Further treatment includes aural toilet to remove debris and NSAIDs for pain relief. The tympanic membrane (TM) must be assessed prior to initiating therapy; if the TM is not intact or cannot be visualized, topical aminoglycosides and aural toilet are contraindicated because of an increased risk of damage to the middle ear. Ear swabs and oral antibiotic therapy should be considered if the patient does not respond to initial therapy, has severe AOE (i.e., completely occluded external auditory canal, fever, cervical lymphadenitis), or has risk factors for malignant otitis externa (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus).

In mild cases of AOE (i.e., only mild discomfort or pruritus with minimal edema of the auditory canal), a topical antiseptic preparation (e.g., acetic acid) without an antibiotic may be considered. Patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa require a more extensive diagnostic workup (e.g., blood cultures, CT scan) and intravenous antibiotic therapy in addition to topical therapy.

question_text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent nonproductive cough. She does not have shortness of breath, a rash, or joint pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Examination of the oral cavity shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. On slit-lamp examination, tear film break-up time is decreased. The results of a complete blood count show no abnormalities. Serum studies show positive antinuclear antibody titers, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers, and IgG4 antibody titers that are within the reference range. An ECG and a CT scan of the chest show no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent nonproductive cough. She does not have shortness of breath, a rash, or joint pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Examination of the oral cavity shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. On slit-lamp examination, tear film break-up time is decreased. The results of a complete blood count show no abnormalities. Serum studies show positive antinuclear antibody titers, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers, and IgG4 antibody titers that are within the reference range. An ECG and a CT scan of the chest show no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: Features of sicca syndrome (e.g., dry mouth and tongue fissures due to xerostomia; blurred vision, injected conjunctiva, and decreased tear film break-up time due to keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) in a patient without a history of another autoimmune disorder are consistent with primary Sjogren syndrome (SS).
learning_objective: Recognize primary Sjogren syndrome, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and can occur idiopathically or secondary to HIV infection, sickle cell disease, heroin use, severe obesity, and interferon therapy. The most common renal complications of primary SS are tubulointerstitial nephritis and type 1 renal tubular acidosis. Glomerular involvement in primary SS is rare and, when it does occur, typically manifests as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis or membranous nephropathy, not FSGS.

Lofgren syndrome occurs in 5–10% of patients with sarcoidosis, which occurs more commonly in women and can manifest with features of pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough), keratoconjunctivitis sicca, xerostomia, and parotid enlargement. However, in patients with sarcoidosis, chest imaging would typically show hilar lymphadenopathy, which is the earliest manifestation of pulmonary involvement. Primary SS, which is more likely in this patient, is not associated with Lofgren syndrome.

Patients with Sjogren syndrome (SS) have an increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the exocrine glands, particularly the parotid gland. The most important risk factor for lymphoma development in SS is persistent salivary gland enlargement. Although the pathophysiology of lymphoma development in SS is not entirely known, B-cell activation and chronic inflammation are thought to play a role. MALT lymphoma is the most common lymphoma in patients with SS, followed by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Other common complications in patients with SS are related to xerostomia and include gastroesophageal reflux disease, atrophic oral candidiasis, and increased risk of dental caries. Patients with SS can develop a dry cough as a result of xerotrachea and xerobronchitis (the most likely cause in this patient with a normal chest CT) or interstitial lung disease. Patients with primary SS are often positive for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, both of which are specific types of ANA.

Parotid enlargement is more common in primary than in secondary SS.

Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPF) is associated with IgG4-related disease, which can manifest with xerostomia, xerophthalmia, and parotid gland enlargement. A dry cough may also be seen in IgG4-related disease as a result of interstitial lung disease. However, positive antinuclear antibody titers are not seen in IgG4-related disease. Instead, serum IgG4 antibody titers are often well above the normal range (≥ 2 times the upper limit). RPF is not typically associated with primary SS, the diagnosis in this patient.

Libman-Sacks endocarditis (LSE) is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which typically occurs in women and can cause a dry cough (due to pleuritis or interstitial lung disease), fatigue, positive ANA titers, and, occasionally, features of secondary SS (keratoconjunctivitis sicca, xerostomia). However, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers indicate a different cause for increased ANA titers. Moreover, patients with SLE usually have a malar or discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers (rather than tongue fissures), arthralgia, and/or hematological abnormalities, none of which this patient has. Primary SS has been reported to cause autoimmune myocarditis but is not associated with LSE.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a lesion in his left nostril. The lesion has rapidly increased in size during this time and now also involves the nasal septum. Two years ago, he had a nodular lesion with central ulceration on the dorsum of his left hand that resolved spontaneously. The patient emigrated from Bolivia 1 year ago; he currently lives in California and works as a carpenter. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows left submandibular lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion on his nose is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a lesion in his left nostril. The lesion has rapidly increased in size during this time and now also involves the nasal septum. Two years ago, he had a nodular lesion with central ulceration on the dorsum of his left hand that resolved spontaneously. The patient emigrated from Bolivia 1 year ago; he currently lives in California and works as a carpenter. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows left submandibular lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion on his nose is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: The image shows destruction of the nasal mucosa with ulcerations extending to the nasal septum and skin. The causal organism is transmitted by phlebotomine sand flies.
learning_objective: Recognize mucosal leishmaniasis, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Trypanosoma brucei, which is transmitted by the tsetse fly, causes African trypanosomiasis. Following a tsetse fly bite, an ulcerating skin nodule (trypanosomal chancre) with regional lymphadenopathy would develop at the site of T. brucei inoculation, and this primary lesion would resolve spontaneously within 1–2 weeks. However, nasal ulceration is not consistent with this condition. Instead, constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, weight loss) and neurological symptoms (e.g., personality changes, altered sleep-wake cycle, ataxia, delayed hyperesthesia) would be expected. Furthermore, African trypanosomiasis is endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, not South America, where this patient emigrated from.

images.title: Chancre of African trypanosomiasis
images.description: An ulcerating swelling with an erythematous base is visible on this patient's neck.

answers.explanation_why:
Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) manifests as an ulcerating skin lesion at the site of a sandfly bite; the lesion gradually resolves without treatment. However, certain species of Leishmania (L. braziliensis, L. guyanensis, L. panamensis) can cause mucosal leishmaniasis (ML) months to years after CL resolves. The nasopharynx is typically affected in ML, which can result in nasal blockage, mucosal bleeding, and/or septal destruction. Cervical lymphadenopathy can also occur. South America (especially Bolivia, Peru, and Brazil), where the patient emigrated from, is an endemic region for Leishmania species that cause ML. ML warrants systemic therapy using amphotericin B, miltefosine, or sodium stibogluconate.

Visceral leishmaniasis, a more severe form of leishmaniasis, is primarily caused by Leishmania donovani and Leishmania infantum, both of which are also transmitted via sand flies. This form of leishmaniasis is also known as “kala-azar” (black fever in Hindi).

images.title: Cutaneous leishmaniasis
images.description: A well-demarcated, open, ulcerated wound with overlying purulent exudate is visible on the lateral aspect of the right ankle.This is the characteristic appearance of cutaneous leishmaniasis.

answers.explanation_why: Histoplasma capsulatum infection (histoplasmosis) can manifest with lymphadenopathy and skin nodules in the case of disseminated disease. However, the lesions of histoplasmosis do not resolve spontaneously, and ulcerations within the skin nodules or nasal ulcerations are uncommon. Palatal or lingual ulcers would be expected instead. Also, most patients with histoplasmosis are typically immunocompromised and present with fever, fatigue, weight loss, pulmonary symptoms (e.g., cough), and/or hepatosplenomegaly. Moreover, histoplasmosis is commonly transmitted via exposure to bird and bat droppings commonly found along the river valleys of Mississippi, not in California, where this patient lives.

images.title: Histoplasmosis fact sheet and US endemicity map
images.description: (Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

answers.explanation_why: Mycobacterium leprae infection (leprosy) can manifest with ulceration of the nasal mucosa and ulcerating skin nodules. Leprosy is also endemic in tropical regions in South America as well as South and South-east Asia. However, leprosy typically causes multiple nodules, whereas this patient had a single nodule. Furthermore, this patient lacks other typical findings of leprosy such as hypopigmented patches or plaques, nerve thickening, and neuropathy.

images.title: Leonine facies in lepromatous leprosy
images.description: 45-year-old woman with a five-year history of facial appearance changes and paresthesia of both hands and feetThe skin of the face is thickened and furrowed, with multiple areas of nodular lesions coalescing into plaques. The hair of the eyebrows has been lost (madarosis), and there is a saddle nose deformity.Leonine facies (so termed after the ostensible resemblance to a lion's face) is characteristic of lepromatous leprosy, as seen here, and Paget disease of bone, but can also occur various other conditions, e.g., mycosis fungoides, leishmaniasis, or sarcoidosis.

answers.explanation_why: Rhizopus oryzae infection (mucormycosis) can manifest with a skin lesion due to local inoculation (cutaneous mucormycosis) and ulceration of the nasal mucosa in the case of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). However, the lesions of mucormycosis do not resolve spontaneously, and ROCM would be associated with features of necrotizing rhinosinusitis (e.g., fever, severe headache, cranial nerve palsies, periorbital cellulitis). Also, patients with mucormycosis typically have uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or immunosuppression.

images.title: Mucormycosis
images.description: Bilateral edema of the eyelid and purulent exudation from both eyes is visible. There are spotted areas of necrotic eschar, especially close to the inner canthus of the right eye, on the right eyelid, and on the nose.These findings, especially in an immunocompromised patient, suggest Mucorales infection.

images.title: Mucosal leishmaniasis
images.description: There is infestation and destruction of the nasal mucosa with ulcerations extending to the nasal septum and skin.

question_text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, nasal discharge, and dry cough. He has had no dyspnea, visual changes, or painful eye movements. He has not been going to work during this time because he has been sleeping poorly. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 8 years. The patient is allergic to penicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Examination shows clear mucus in the nostrils and the posterior oropharynx. Pulmonary examination is shown. There are no focal neurologic findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Video
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, nasal discharge, and dry cough. He has had no dyspnea, visual changes, or painful eye movements. He has not been going to work during this time because he has been sleeping poorly. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 8 years. The patient is allergic to penicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Examination shows clear mucus in the nostrils and the posterior oropharynx. Pulmonary examination is shown. There are no focal neurologic findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Video
hint: This patient's rhinorrhea, fever, headache, dry cough, duration of symptoms, and physical examination findings are consistent with acute viral rhinosinusitis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute viral rhinosinusitis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Inhaled beclomethasone therapy is indicated for the maintenance treatment of asthma, which typically presents with a dry cough that affects sleep quality and is often associated with rhinorrhea. However, in asthma, rhinorrhea is usually due to chronic allergic rhinitis, and characteristic features of lower airway involvement (e.g., dyspnea and chest tightness, end-expiratory wheezes) would be expected. While inhaled beclomethasone has no benefit in patients with acute viral and bacterial rhinosinusitis, short-term application of topical, intranasal steroids (e.g., fluticasone, beclomethasone) may be indicated to reduce nasal symptoms and inflammation.

The standard of care in acute viral rhinosinusitis is reassurance and close follow-up. Uncomplicated viral sinusitis is generally self-limiting, and supportive therapy with rest, hydration, antipyretics, and oral analgesics is sufficient. In addition, topical, intranasal steroids (e.g., fluticasone, beclomethasone), nasal saline lavage, and decongestive nose drops (e.g., oxymetazoline) can provide symptomatic relief. If bacterial rhinosinusitis or bacterial superinfection is suspected, antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanate or, in this adult patient with penicillin allergy, with doxycycline, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin, is indicated for 5–10 days. Further imaging tests are generally not recommended unless a complication (e.g., orbital cellulitis) or a differential diagnosis (e.g., nasal polyps) is suspected.

A CT scan of the sinuses is the imaging modality of choice in acute sinusitis. However, a CT scan is indicated only if symptoms fail to improve within 7 days of diagnosis or worsen during the initial management of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, in the case of suspected complications (e.g., osteomyelitis, orbital cellulitis), or to rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., neoplasms). This patient has only had symptoms of acute viral rhinosinusitis for 4 days and does not have visual changes or painful eye movements that might suggest a complication. Performing a CT scan would only expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.

images.title: Opacified right paranasal sinuses
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (coronal plane) of a patient with acute sinusitisThe right maxillary sinus (green overlay) is completely opacified. Extensive soft tissue density material (red overlay) is also present in the ipsilateral nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus is nearly completely opacified.

answers.explanation_why: Levofloxacin is considered a second-line antibiotic for the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis and may also be used in patients with penicillin allergy, like this patient. However, this patient has no characteristic features of a bacterial infection (i.e., severe symptoms initial ≥ 3 days, > 39°C fever, facial pain, purulent nasal discharge) or superinfection (i.e., persistent symptoms for ≥ 10 days without clinical improvement, initially improving and then worsening symptoms after 5–6 days). Therefore, antibiotics are not indicated at this time.

Sputum gram stain and culture are indicated for the diagnostic workup of community-acquired pneumonia if symptoms are severe or persistent, or if the patient is hospitalized. This patient does not have features suggestive of typical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia often manifests with headaches and dry cough, other constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, myalgias) and dyspnea are usually present. Microbiological tests are not indicated for acute viral rhinosinusitis unless complications (e.g., orbital cellulitis, osteomyelitis) are suspected based on clinical presentation (e.g., visual changes, eye movements).

Amoxicillin, with or without clavulanate, is considered the first-line treatment for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, this patient has no characteristic features of a bacterial infection, (i.e., severe symptoms initial ≥ 3 days; > 39.0°C fever, facial pain, purulent nasal discharge) or superinfection (i.e., persistent symptoms for ≥ 10 days without clinical improvement, initially improving and then worsening symptoms after 5–6 days). Moreover, this patient has a history of penicillin allergy; amoxicillin-clavulanate should, therefore, be avoided.

A chest x-ray is commonly used to diagnose community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which typically manifests with fever and cough. However, this patient has no other features suggestive of CAP (e.g., high fever, severe malaise, tachypnea, dyspnea, purulent sputum). Moreover, his pulmonary examination is normal; no crackles or rales are present. A chest x-ray is not required for the diagnosis of acute rhinosinusitis and would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.

question_text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness in his upper extremities over the past 7 months. He initially noticed difficulty writing but now has difficulty performing his activities of daily living. He currently lives with his son. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the upper extremities and normal in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities, 4+ in the right lower extremity, and 2+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact in all extremities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a neutral affect. His speech is slightly slurred and hypernasal. Needle electromyography shows spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles, fibrillations, and positive sharp wave potentials. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% of predicted. A diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is made and treatment with riluzole is initiated. After discussion with the patient and his son, a decision to transfer the patient to hospice care is made. Before transferring the patient to hospice care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness in his upper extremities over the past 7 months. He initially noticed difficulty writing but now has difficulty performing his activities of daily living. He currently lives with his son. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the upper extremities and normal in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities, 4+ in the right lower extremity, and 2+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact in all extremities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a neutral affect. His speech is slightly slurred and hypernasal. Needle electromyography shows spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles, fibrillations, and positive sharp wave potentials. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% of predicted. A diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is made and treatment with riluzole is initiated. After discussion with the patient and his son, a decision to transfer the patient to hospice care is made. Before transferring the patient to hospice care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with features of bulbar palsy (e.g., tongue atrophy and fasciculations, dysarthria, hypernasal speech) as a manifestation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Bulbar palsy can cause a symptom that increases the morbidity of patients with ALS and should therefore be assessed.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management before transferring a patient with ALS to hospice care.

answers.explanation_why: Noninvasive ventilation is indicated in patients with ALS with respiratory failure (e.g., orthopnea, vital capacity < 50%). This patient does not have symptoms of respiratory insufficiency (e.g., tachypnea, hypoxemia).

Genetic testing for specific ALS-causing mutations is useful in identifying familial ALS, which accounts for up to 10% of all ALS cases. Genetic testing is indicated in patients with a family history of ALS or juvenile-onset ALS, neither of which have been reported here.

Amitriptyline can be used to treat patients with ALS who present with features of depression or pseudobulbar affect. This patient does not have symptoms of depression and mental status examination shows a normal affect.

ALS is characterized by concomitant upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron dysfunction and can manifest with pseudobulbar palsy and bulbar palsy, both of which result in dysphagia. Dysphagia increases the risk for aspiration and/or insufficient fluid and food intake, leading to complications in patients with ALS (e.g., aspiration pneumonia, weight loss). A bedside swallowing test should therefore be performed in all patients with ALS to screen for dysphagia. If the test is positive, a formal swallowing study (e.g., videofluoroscopic swallowing examination) is required to confirm the diagnosis. Patients with ALS who have swallowing difficulties may need specialized nutritional support (e.g., pureed food, thickened liquids, nasogastric tube, percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy). Bedside swallowing test is also performed for other neurological conditions that manifest with dysphagia, such as Parkinson disease, acute stroke, and Guillain-Barré syndrome.

In addition to the bedside swallowing test, this patient should be asked about their wishes regarding resuscitation. ALS can result in cognitive impairment in the later stages, and the patient's resuscitation wishes (e.g., do not resuscitate order) should be determined while their mental faculties are intact.
Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy is indicated in patients with ALS who have symptomatic dysphagia or significant weight loss, none of which are seen here.

question_text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of noisy breathing. Her parents state that her breathing has become progressively louder during this time. It is worse when she is lying on her back, feeding, and crying, and it improves when she is placed on her abdomen. Her mother also mentions that the girl has been regurgitating milk more than usual for the past few weeks. She was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her diet consists exclusively of formula milk. She is at the 65^th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination discloses inspiratory stridor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of noisy breathing. Her parents state that her breathing has become progressively louder during this time. It is worse when she is lying on her back, feeding, and crying, and it improves when she is placed on her abdomen. Her mother also mentions that the girl has been regurgitating milk more than usual for the past few weeks. She was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her diet consists exclusively of formula milk. She is at the 65th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination discloses inspiratory stridor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: In infants who are otherwise healthy, this condition is typically self-limited.
learning_objective: Recognize laryngomalacia in infants.

answers.explanation_why: A vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus can cause inspiratory stridor and regurgitation of food, both of which are seen in this 6-month-old patient. However, these symptoms usually manifest within the first weeks of life, especially in cases of tracheal compression. In addition, vascular ring anomalies typically also result in dyspnea, dysphagia, and choking, none of which are seen here. Moreover, the stridor caused by a vascular ring classically improves with neck extension, not by lying in the prone position.

Cow's milk allergy in formula-fed infants can manifest with features of gastroesophageal reflux, including frequent regurgitation. However, food allergies are not associated with the progressive respiratory symptoms also seen in this infant, including noisy breathing while feeding and inspiratory stridor. In addition, this patient does not have other typical symptoms of food allergy, such as abdominal discomfort and diarrhea.

Laryngomalacia is a congenital anomaly of laryngeal cartilage that causes the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration. Manifestations include inspiratory stridor that improves in the prone position and worsens in the supine position and during feeding and crying, as seen in this infant. In addition, 60–70% of children with laryngomalacia have symptoms of gastroesophageal and/or laryngopharyngeal reflux (e.g., frequent regurgitation) due to the higher intrathoracic pressures needed to overcome the inspiratory obstruction. Symptoms of laryngomalacia usually peak at 6–8 months of age, then resolve spontaneously by 2 years of age in ∼ 90% of cases as the cartilages strengthen. The diagnosis is confirmed with flexible laryngoscopy. Because laryngomalacia is a benign, self-limited condition, reassurance and close follow-up are generally sufficient.

images.title: Omega-shaped epiglottis
images.description: LaryngoscopyDuring inspiration, the lateral folds of the epiglottis curl inward, creating an omega shape. This finding may be a normal variation but is more frequently seen in laryngomalacia. Clinical correlation is required to establish a diagnosis of laryngomalacia.

answers.explanation_why: Croup is most commonly seen in children between 6 months and 3 years of age and can manifest with inspiratory stridor. However, croup is typically more acute in onset than what is seen in this patient and is associated with other symptoms, including a prodrome (e.g., rhinitis, nasal discharge, congestion, low-grade fever), barking cough, and hoarseness, none of which are seen here. In addition, lying in the prone position typically exacerbates symptoms in patients with croup.

A foreign body aspiration (FBA) can manifest with inspiratory stridor. However, FBA is typically more acute in onset than what is seen in this patient and is associated with other symptoms, including choking, coughing, dyspnea, and hoarseness, none of which are seen here. Less commonly, patients can present weeks after an initial episode of FBA; however, typical symptoms in these cases are persistent or recurrent cough with fever.

question_text: One hour after delivery, a 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) male newborn starts to cough and choke while being breastfed. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His parents refused prenatal screening. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, respirations are 51/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa. Crackles are heard throughout both lung bases. There is a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is attempted but the tube cannot be passed beyond 6 cm from the gums. An x-ray with contrast shows a blind-ended esophageal pouch; there is abundant gas in the stomach. Screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: One hour after delivery, a 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) male newborn starts to cough and choke while being breastfed. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His parents refused prenatal screening. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, respirations are 51/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa. Crackles are heard throughout both lung bases. There is a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is attempted but the tube cannot be passed beyond 6 cm from the gums. An x-ray with contrast shows a blind-ended esophageal pouch; there is abundant gas in the stomach. Screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Coughing and choking spells when feeding, in conjunction with cyanosis, crackles on lung auscultation, and the inability to pass a feeding tube, suggest esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). This diagnosis is confirmed by the x-ray findings. The harsh systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation suggests a cardiac structural anomaly.
learning_objective: Recognize esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula, and recall its associated complications.

answers.explanation_why:
Esophageal atresia with TEF is caused by a defect in mesodermal differentiation. About 50% of esophageal atresia cases are associated with other mesodermal defects, known as the VACTERL association: Vertebral anomaly, Anal atresia, Cardiac anomaly, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Esophageal atresia, Renal anomaly (including agenesis), and Limb malformation. Newborns with esophageal atresia should, therefore, undergo screening for other VACTERL anomalies. Screening typically includes echocardiography and renal ultrasonography.

Esophageal atresia with TEF to the distal esophageal segment is the most common type of esophageal atresia, accounting for > 75% of cases. A fetus with esophageal atresia is unable to swallow amniotic fluid, resulting in polyhydramnios, which can lead to premature rupture of membranes and premature labor, as seen here.

images.title: Newborn with type C esophageal atresia
images.description: X-ray (AP view with contrast): contrast agent filling a blind-ended esophageal pouch (green overlay) that ends at the level of the third thoracic vertebra. Inside the pouch, a nasogastric tube can be seen (dashed lines). There is abundant gas in the gastrointestinal tract, indicating patent tracheoesophageal fistula.

answers.explanation_why: Thymic aplasia may be seen in neonates with DiGeorge syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies, which this patient most likely has. However, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as an anomalous face (micrognathia, dysplastic ears, prominent nasal bridge) and a cleft palate. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include thymic aplasia.

images.title: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar hypoplasia can be seen in children with PHACE syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies, which this patient most likely has. However, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of PHACE syndrome, such as infantile hemangiomas and eye anomalies. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include cerebellar hypoplasia.

Iris coloboma may be seen in neonates with CHARGE syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies and bilateral choanal atresia, which can manifest immediately after birth with cyanosis associated with feeding, similar to what is seen in this newborn. However, choanal atresia does not typically manifest with coughing and choking spells. Moreover, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of CHARGE syndrome, such as genital and ear abnormalities. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include iris coloboma.

Esophageal atresia, which this newborn has, may be associated with gastrointestinal abnormalities, such as anal atresia and intestinal malrotation. Biliary atresia, however, is not a common association. Furthermore, biliary atresia typically manifests at birth with jaundice, which is not seen in this newborn.
