question_text: A female newborn delivered at 37 weeks’ gestation develops respiratory distress immediately after birth. She was delivered vaginally to a 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus treated with insulin during the third trimester. The newborn's pulse is 136/min, respirations are 57/min, and blood pressure is 60/35 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91% when the newborn is crying and a saturation of 85% at rest. Examination shows grunting breath sounds and perioral blue discoloration that improves when the patient cries. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a split S_2 during inspiration but no murmurs are heard. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. A suction catheter cannot be passed through the nares. In addition to establishing an oral airway, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A female newborn delivered at 37 weeks’ gestation develops respiratory distress immediately after birth. She was delivered vaginally to a 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus treated with insulin during the third trimester. The newborn's pulse is 136/min, respirations are 57/min, and blood pressure is 60/35 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91% when the newborn is crying and a saturation of 85% at rest. Examination shows grunting breath sounds and perioral blue discoloration that improves when the patient cries. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a split S2 during inspiration but no murmurs are heard. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. A suction catheter cannot be passed through the nares. In addition to establishing an oral airway, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's condition is associated with central cyanosis that worsens both at rest and while feeding.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral choanal atresia, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Arterial switch procedure is indicated in patients with transposition of the great vessels (TGV). TGV is associated with maternal diabetes and manifests with respiratory distress and cyanosis in the newborn immediately after birth, both of which are seen here. In patients with TGV, however, oxygenation is not affected by crying. Furthermore, this condition manifests with extreme cyanosis, progressive hypoxemia, and a loud, single second heart sound on cardiac auscultation.

answers.content: Endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum
answers.explanation_why:
Bilateral choanal atresia, a congenital condition characterized by complete blockage of the nasal cavity, typically manifests immediately after birth with respiratory distress, grunting breath sounds, and central cyanosis which improves with crying and worsens with feeding and at rest. The best initial test is the passage of a catheter through the nares, which is not possible in bilateral choanal atresia. Contrast rhinography in the supine position or CT scan of the facial bones confirms the diagnosis. After establishing an oropharyngeal airway, transnasal endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum is the most appropriate treatment to provide a permanent nasal airway. These procedures help prevent life-threatening cyanotic attacks and aspiration when the newborn's mouth is blocked during feeding. Finally, the newborn should be examined for other congenital anomalies since choanal atresia is often associated with CHARGE syndrome.

Splitting of the second heart sound, as seen in this newborn, occurs physiologically during inspiration, which leads to delayed closure of the pulmonary valve (P_2) due to increased right ventricular ejection time.

images.title: Choanal atresia
images.description: Retropalatal endoscopic viewUnilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

answers.content: Reconnection of the upper esophageal pouch with the lower esophagus
answers.explanation_why: Reconnection of the upper esophageal pouch with the lower esophagus is indicated in patients with esophageal atresia (EA). This condition may manifest immediately after birth with respiratory distress and cyanotic attacks, similar to what is seen in this patient. Since newborns with EA are unable to swallow properly, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth would also be expected. Moreover, in EA, a gastric catheter can be inserted through the nares but would be blocked at the level of the esophagus.

answers.content: Anastomosis between subclavian and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anastomosis between the subclavian and pulmonary artery is performed in newborns with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases, such as tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), when early heart surgery is not possible. Symptoms of TOF depend on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) and may fluctuate, similar to the fluctuating cyanosis seen in this infant. However, infants with TOF and episodic cyanosis (i.e., tet spells) typically have mild RVOTO and only become symptomatic at 2–4 months of age. In contrast, newborns with TOF and cyanosis immediately after birth usually have severe RVOTO with symptoms that do not fluctuate or improve with crying. Finally, cardiac examination would show a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound.

Endotracheal administration of artificial surfactant is indicated in patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), a condition caused by surfactant deficiency in preterm infants. NRDS leads to diffuse atelectasis with respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth, both of which do not improve with crying. Furthermore, NRDS typically manifests with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. This infant was born at term with mature lungs; surfactant would not improve her symptoms.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-day history of painful mouth sores and fever. He is not able to eat any solid food because of the pain but tolerates liquids. He has had no nausea, vomiting, or skin rash. He has a history of asthma treated with inhaled fluticasone, and epilepsy that has been well controlled with lamotrigine since the age 13. There is no history of a similar illness among family members or his friends at school. He is at the 75^th percentile for height and 50^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. A photograph of the oral examination findings is shown. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-day history of painful mouth sores and fever. He is not able to eat any solid food because of the pain but tolerates liquids. He has had no nausea, vomiting, or skin rash. He has a history of asthma treated with inhaled fluticasone, and epilepsy that has been well controlled with lamotrigine since the age 13. There is no history of a similar illness among family members or his friends at school. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. A photograph of the oral examination findings is shown. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's prodromal fever, dysphagia, and oral examination findings (lip erosions, vesicles over the tongue) suggest herpetic gingivostomatitis. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is most common in young children 6 months to 5 years of age, it can also develop in older patients.
learning_objective: Recognize herpetic gingivostomatitis, and choose the most appropriate antiviral therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Lamotrigine can trigger Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which can manifest with painful oral vesicles, erosions, and fever. However, SJS typically develops shortly after initiation of lamotrigine therapy, rather than years later, and manifests with cutaneous (e.g., targetoid erythematous macules), ocular (e.g., conjunctivitis, corneal ulcers), and urogenital (e.g., urethritis, erosive vaginitis) features.

images.title: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)
images.description: Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

answers.explanation_why: Oral fluconazole therapy is used to treat oral candidiasis, which is a common adverse effect associated with the use of corticosteroid inhalers, and can cause discomfort when eating. However, oral candidiasis typically manifests with white pseudomembranes in the oral cavity as opposed to lip erosions and tongue vesicles, and fever is uncommon.

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

answers.explanation_why:
Oral acyclovir can be considered in immunocompetent patients with herpetic gingivostomatitis who are unable to eat or drink because of the severe pain caused by oral lesions. Some studies suggest that oral acyclovir decreases viral shedding, which decreases the duration and severity of infection when administered within 72 hours of symptom onset. Supportive care alone is indicated in patients who present > 72 hours after symptom onset. Antiviral therapy cannot treat latent infections or prevent disease recurrence. Additional treatment measures for herpetic gingivostomatitis include adequate hydration, analgesia, antipyretics, prevention of lip adhesions through barrier creams (e.g., petroleum jelly), and antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections.

Immunocompromised patients with herpetic gingivostomatitis should receive IV acyclovir regardless of symptom duration, and hospitalization may also be required.

Supportive care alone (i.e., adequate analgesia and fluid intake) is generally only considered in immunocompetent patients with herpetic gingivostomatitis who present > 4 days after symptom onset. Patients who present within 4 days of symptom onset benefit from treatment with an agent that decreases the duration and severity of infection.

Triamcinolone cream is used in the treatment of Behçet disease, which can manifest with painful oral lesions and fever. However, patients with Behçet disease typically develop aphthous ulcers, rather than oral vesicles, and usually present with genital ulcers, ocular disease (e.g., uveitis, keratitis), skin lesions (e.g., erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), and arthritis.

images.title: Herpetic gingivostomatitis
images.description: Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

question_text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and a sensation that the room is spinning. The episodes last less than a minute and first started about 1 hour ago when she bent forward to tie her shoelaces. She reports no hearing loss or tinnitus. She has hypertension and dyslipidemia. Current medications include ramipril, amlodipine, and pravastatin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 31 years and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her father died of a stroke at 63 years of age. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus. Coordination testing is normal. Covering and uncovering of the eyes shows no gaze deviation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and a sensation that the room is spinning. The episodes last less than a minute and first started about 1 hour ago when she bent forward to tie her shoelaces. She reports no hearing loss or tinnitus. She has hypertension and dyslipidemia. Current medications include ramipril, amlodipine, and pravastatin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 31 years and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her father died of a stroke at 63 years of age. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus. Coordination testing is normal. Covering and uncovering of the eyes shows no gaze deviation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with horizontal nystagmus and short (< 1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by position change. These findings, in addition to a negative test of skew, indicate benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
learning_objective: Recognize benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Bedside provocation maneuvers (e.g., Dix-Hallpike maneuver, supine head roll test) are the best diagnostic tools for patients with BPPV. BPPV results from dislodged or abnormally adherent otoliths, leading to semicircular canal dysfunction. During the test, a set of specific sequential head positioning maneuvers are used to provoke symptoms. The presence of positional vertigo and nystagmus during the maneuvers indicates a positive test and confirms the diagnosis. Although BPPV resolves spontaneously in about half of all patients, canalith repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley maneuver) can also be performed in order to mobilize the otoliths out of the involved semicircular canals.

images.title: Dix-Hallpike maneuver
images.description:
A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

answers.explanation_why: Audiometry is a useful diagnostic tool for patients with Meniere disease or acoustic neuroma, both of which can manifest with horizontal nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting. However, symptomatic episodes of Meniere disease usually last from minutes to hours and are not triggered by positioning while symptoms of acoustic neuroma typically have an insidious onset and a chronic course; this patient's brief and recurrent episodes of vertigo suggest a different diagnosis. In addition, both Meniere disease and acoustic neuroma typically manifest with hearing loss and tinnitus, neither of which are seen here.

Ultrasound of the carotids is a useful diagnostic method for carotid artery stenosis (CAS), which, in severe cases, can manifest with vertigo. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking), which increases her risk of developing CAS. However, she has no other features of carotid stenosis, such as carotid bruit, amaurosis fugax, or focal neurologic signs. In addition, the episodic nature of her symptoms and their correlation with position change indicates BPPV.

An MRI of the brain can be used to rule out intracranial causes of vertigo (e.g., acoustic neuroma, cerebellar infarction), which can manifest with dizziness and horizontal nystagmus. However, a marked spinning sensation is uncommon in patients with central vertigo. In addition, central vertigo is characterized by constant, rather than episodic symptoms, and is usually accompanied by other findings of intracranial lesions (e.g., focal neurologic deficits), which are absent in this patient.

A caloric test can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus in patients with vertigo. However, this patient's clinical presentation (short recurrent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and vertigo upon changing position) and physical examination findings (horizontal nystagmus, negative skew test) suggest BPPV, for which caloric testing is not typically indicated. In addition, this test is not commonly used for evaluating vertigo because of the associated symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, ear discomfort) that most patients experience during the procedure.

Upright tilt table test is used to diagnose orthostatic syncope, which is characterized by prodromal vertigo and nausea with rapid loss of consciousness upon standing from a seated or prone position. Hypovolemia (e.g., due to hemorrhage, diuretic use), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diabetic autonomic neuropathy), or a history of vasodilators use (e.g., alpha-blockers) are all risk factors for developing orthostatic syncope. Even though this patient presents with episodes of vertigo and nausea that are triggered by movement, none of them are followed by rapid loss of consciousness. In addition, she lacks any of the risk factors mentioned above, making orthostatic syncope unlikely.

question_text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of hoarseness of voice and a chronic cough for the past 2 months. He has a history of hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 60 mL of whiskey every other day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Laryngoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous left posterior larynx; there is an exophytic mass arising from the left posterior true vocal cord. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of hoarseness of voice and a chronic cough for the past 2 months. He has a history of hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 60 mL of whiskey every other day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Laryngoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous left posterior larynx; there is an exophytic mass arising from the left posterior true vocal cord. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Smoking and alcohol consumption are the most important risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Leukoplakia is a hyperkeratosis of the epithelium and mucous membranes of the oral cavity. It can present with hoarseness if it involves the larynx, and tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption are important risk factors. However, leukoplakia of the vocal cords manifests with persistent white plaques that cannot be scraped off on laryngoscopy, which is not seen here.

Laryngeal papillomatosis is a benign tumor of the laryngeal epithelium that manifests with hoarseness and an exophytic lesion on the vocal cord on laryngoscopy. However, laryngeal papillomatosis is more common in children and young adults and is caused by HPV infection (HPV type 6 and 11). Moreover, a biopsy of the lesion shows hyperplastic stratified squamous epithelium with a central fibrovascular core, which is not seen here.

images.title: Laryngeal papillomatosis
images.description: Laryngoscopy showing laryngeal papillomas, appearing as multiple raspberry-like swellings on vocal cords.

answers.explanation_why: Laryngeal adenocarcinoma is very rare and is only seen in 1–2% of cases of laryngeal carcinoma. The photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen of the lesion does not show malignant adenomatous changes.

Laryngeal amyloidosis is a localized form of amyloidosis, which can manifest with hoarseness, cough, and rarely lymphadenopathy. However, laryngoscopy typically shows a firm orange-yellow to gray epithelial nodule and a biopsy of the lesion shows an extracellular deposition and aggregation of amyloid, neither of which is seen here.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx is the most common type of laryngeal carcinoma and is usually located on the glottis or vocal cords. Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx is most common in men 40–70 years of age. Affected individuals typically present with chronic hoarseness or change in voice and cervical lymphadenopathy, as seen here. Other possible clinical signs are dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Laryngoscopy provides direct visualization of the lesion and typically reveals an irregular, nodular, or ulcerative lesion. Biopsy shows moderately differentiated clusters of squamous cells with lymphovascular invasion.

A vocal cord polyp is a benign lesion of the vocal cords. It can present with hoarseness, it is usually unilateral, and it is commonly associated with chronic irritation due to voice overuse (e.g., teachers, professional singers), smoking, or GERD. However, a vocal cord polyp is typically found in the middle to anterior one-third of the vocal fold (i.e., anterior larynx), unlike what is seen here. Moreover, this patient's unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy is not consistent with a polyp of the vocal cord.

images.title: Laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a laryngeal tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)Sheet-like arrangement of the tumor cells can be seen (green overlay). The increased number of lymphocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay in zoom box) and desmoplasia in the surrounding stroma suggest inflammation.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling that developed on her right ear 3 days ago. She is a mixed martial arts athlete and has been training intensively for an upcoming tournament. The pain started soon after she received a blow to the ear during a training fight. She reports taking ibuprofen for the pain and tried “not to pay attention to it,” but the pain has worsened. Her personal and family history is unremarkable and she takes no other medications. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.0°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 113/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm mildly tender, fluctuant mass on the right antihelix with purple skin discoloration; there is a firm, irregular, nontender deformity of the left auricle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling that developed on her right ear 3 days ago. She is a mixed martial arts athlete and has been training intensively for an upcoming tournament. The pain started soon after she received a blow to the ear during a training fight. She reports taking ibuprofen for the pain and tried “not to pay attention to it,” but the pain has worsened. Her personal and family history is unremarkable and she takes no other medications. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.0°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 113/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm mildly tender, fluctuant mass on the right antihelix with purple skin discoloration; there is a firm, irregular, nontender deformity of the left auricle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: A purple, tender, fluctuant mass on the right antihelix is consistent with an auricular hematoma, which is commonly seen following a direct blow to the ear.
learning_objective: Recognize an auricular hematoma, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Needle aspiration is not routinely recommended for the management of auricular hematomas, as it may be difficult to aspirate sufficient fluid and there is a risk of reaccumulation.

While surgical excision of scar tissue could help to cosmetically improve this patient's left cauliflower ear, another intervention is required to prevent the auricular hematoma in the right ear from leading to the development of a cauliflower ear.

Antibiotic therapy with levofloxacin for 7–10 days is indicated in older adolescents and adults undergoing invasive treatment for an auricular hematoma, or in patients with signs of an infected auricular hematoma. This patient has not received any form of invasive treatment and has no signs of infection (e.g., pus, fever, severe tenderness).

Incision and drainage are indicated for auricular hematomas < 7 days old. Timely drainage of the hematoma prevents infection, relieves pressure, and preserves ear function and appearance, preventing the formation of cauliflower ear, which this patient already has in the left ear. Prophylactic antibiotics with coverage against skin flora and P. aeruginosa such as ciprofloxacin should also be considered. Patients should be followed up daily to assess for reaccumulation of the hematoma and/or signs of infection. If the hematoma does not reaccumulate, patients can return to sports after 7 days.

images.title: Auricular hematoma following trauma
images.description: There is swelling and ecchymosis of the auricle. Swelling is most pronounced in the anterosuperior aspect, where it obscures the normal anatomical landmarks.

answers.content: Analgesics, cooling, and close observation only
answers.explanation_why: Analgesics, cooling, and close observation alone are not sufficient for the management of auricular hematomas. As most individuals who develop auricular hematomas are involved in some sort of contact sport and frequently experience injury, they may not see the need to seek medical attention. Untreated auricular hematomas are associated with the formation of cauliflower ears, as the hematoma separates the perichondrium from the cartilage and removes the blood supply, leading to cartilage ischemia and necrosis with subsequent irreversible fibrosis.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of hearing loss and pain in her left ear. The symptoms appeared suddenly while she was on a flight back from a business trip to New Mexico. She has had mild nasal congestion and rhinorrhea for the past 3 days. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows mildly inflamed turbinates and purulent discharge. There is no pain to palpation over the nasal sinuses. Cervical lymph nodes are not palpable. On otoscopic examination, there is bleeding into the left tympanic cavity; the left tympanic membrane is intact. The right ear shows no abnormalities. Rinne test is negative in the left ear and positive in the right ear. Weber test lateralizes to the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of hearing loss and pain in her left ear. The symptoms appeared suddenly while she was on a flight back from a business trip to New Mexico. She has had mild nasal congestion and rhinorrhea for the past 3 days. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows mildly inflamed turbinates and purulent discharge. There is no pain to palpation over the nasal sinuses. Cervical lymph nodes are not palpable. On otoscopic examination, there is bleeding into the left tympanic cavity; the left tympanic membrane is intact. The right ear shows no abnormalities. Rinne test is negative in the left ear and positive in the right ear. Weber test lateralizes to the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Sudden-onset unilateral conductive hearing loss, otalgia, and hematotympanum during a flight suggest middle ear barotrauma.
learning_objective: Recognize middle ear barotrauma, and choose the most appropriate management for pain relief.

answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the head is performed in patients with head trauma but is rarely used in middle ear barotrauma, which is diagnosed based on history of a potentially inciting event (e.g., flying, diving) and examination findings.

Myringotomy may be considered for the treatment of ear barotrauma, as it allows for temporary pressure equalization and fluid drainage from the middle ear. However, the tympanic incision usually heals before the ear barotrauma has fully resolved. This makes the use of myringotomy controversial and it is not routinely recommended. Another step is more appropriate for this patient.

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat acute otitis media, which commonly manifests with unilateral ear pain and conductive hearing loss, and bacterial rhinosinusitis, which can manifest with unilateral facial pain and purulent nasal discharge. This patient has no otoscopic signs of otitis media (e.g., bulging tympanic membrane, loss of light reflex) or other characteristic findings of bacterial rhinosinusitis (e.g., fever, pressure pain over the sinuses). In middle ear barotrauma, antibiotics are only used if the tympanic membrane is ruptured.

Middle ear barotrauma most commonly occurs during flights or while diving in patients with nasal congestion due to the inability of the Eustachian tube to equalize the pressure between the middle ear and the external environment. The excess pressure can result in injury to the structures of the middle ear. Most cases of middle ear barotrauma and subsequent lesions (e.g., tympanic edema, hemorrhage, and rupture) are self-limited with complete hearing recovery and are managed conservatively. Analgesics, such as oral ibuprofen, can be used for pain management.

Tympanoplasty is a second-line option for the management of tympanic membrane perforation, which can develop as a complication of ear barotrauma. This patient's otoscopic examination shows an intact tympanic membrane.

question_text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of worsening shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. Yesterday, he developed a sore throat with painful swallowing. He has psoriasis and his only medication is topical calcipotriene. He appears panicked and his voice is hoarse. Temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 114/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows inspiratory stridor with retractions along the rib cage. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. There is drooling from the mouth. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of worsening shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. Yesterday, he developed a sore throat with painful swallowing. He has psoriasis and his only medication is topical calcipotriene. He appears panicked and his voice is hoarse. Temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 114/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows inspiratory stridor with retractions along the rib cage. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. There is drooling from the mouth. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's acute respiratory distress (i.e., tachypnea, inspiratory stridor, and accessory muscle breathing), sore throat, odynophagia, high fever, and drooling raise concern for epiglottitis.
learning_objective: Recognize epiglottitis, and choose the most appropriate initial management for airway obstruction.

answers.explanation_why: Administration of dexamethasone is recommended for patients with respiratory distress due to croup, which manifests in young children with hoarseness, barking cough, and inspiratory stridor; drooling, odynophagia, and severe respiratory distress would not be expected. Glucocorticoids can be used as an adjunctive treatment for epiglottitis, but they are not routinely recommended because studies have demonstrated mixed results.

Empiric IV ceftriaxone is used to treat acute epiglottitis, which is usually caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) or gram-positive cocci (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes or Streptococcus pneumoniae). Blood cultures should be obtained before administering antibiotics to tailor antibiotic therapy as needed. This patient presents with tachypnea, inspiratory stridor, and drooling, all of which raise concern for impending airway obstruction. In unstable patients, the airway should be secured to prevent respiratory collapse, before obtaining cultures or administering antibiotics.

An x-ray of the lateral neck can be obtained in a stable patient to confirm the diagnosis of epiglottitis, which can manifest as a thumbprint sign due to supraglottic narrowing. This patient's acute respiratory distress requires emergency intervention to prevent the worsening of his condition.

images.title: Thumb and vallecula signs (epiglottitis)
images.description: X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

answers.explanation_why:
Bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is the first step in the management of patients with epiglottitis who are experiencing partial airway obstruction. This measure provides respiratory support, prevents exhaustion, and serves as a bridge to endotracheal intubation. This patient has clinical features of acute respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, inspiratory stridor, accessory muscle breathing, low oxygen saturation); therefore, immediate bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is warranted. A practitioner experienced in difficult airway management should perform emergency endotracheal intubation in a controlled setting under direct visualization (using a video-assisted laryngoscopy, if available) to further secure the patient's airway.

Since the introduction of the Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine, epiglottitis no longer mainly manifests as a life-threatening illness in children and is now predominantly seen in adults, particularly those with a BMI > 25, a history of diabetes mellitus, coexistent pneumonia, or a preceding upper respiratory infection.

images.title: Two-person bag-valve-mask-ventilation technique
images.description: The left image shows the EC-clamp technique, in which the 3rd, 4th, and 5th fingers of both hands are used to lift the jaw anteriorly towards the mask (forming an “E” shape), while the thumb and index fingers press the mask onto the face (forming a “C” shape).The right image shows the thenar eminence technique, in which the thumbs and thenar eminences of both hands are placed on top of the mask, while the other fingers pull the jaw into the mask.Both techniques require a second person to perform ventilation.Two-person bag-valve-mask ventilation provides greater tidal volumes with less air leak than the one-handed EC-clamp technique.

answers.explanation_why: Cricothyroidotomy is an emergency procedure that provides airway access through an incision in the cricothyroid membrane. This alternative procedure should be considered in patients with acute epiglottitis in a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario, in which the symptoms continue to worsen (e.g., due to severe oropharyngeal edema) or the intubation attempt fails. A surgical airway is currently not indicated in this patient.

question_text: Ten minutes after starting bag-mask ventilation, the patient's respiratory distress worsens. The otolaryngologist who has been called prepares for fiberoptic endotracheal intubation. Visualization of the posterior pharynx shows a swollen, red epiglottis. An anesthesiologist attempts endotracheal intubation using a fiberoptic guide and is unable to place the tube during the first attempt. The patient's respirations are 31/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 77%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Ten minutes after starting bag-mask ventilation, the patient's respiratory distress worsens. The otolaryngologist who has been called prepares for fiberoptic endotracheal intubation. Visualization of the posterior pharynx shows a swollen, red epiglottis. An anesthesiologist attempts endotracheal intubation using a fiberoptic guide and is unable to place the tube during the first attempt. The patient's respirations are 31/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 77%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is in worsening respiratory distress despite bag-mask ventilation and needs prompt intervention.
learning_objective: Recognize a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario, and choose the most appropriate emergency airway management.

answers.explanation_why:
Emergency cricothyroidotomy is indicated in a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate (CICV) scenario, which is usually defined as the failure to intubate after three attempts or to maintain oxygenation or ventilation in between intubation attempts. In adult patients with acute epiglottitis, however, only one attempt at endotracheal intubation should be made before an emergency cricothyroidotomy is performed at the bedside. Patients with epiglottitis can develop worsening respiratory distress despite appropriate bag-mask ventilation, and they are predisposed to rapid progression to complete airway obstruction following any manipulation of the epiglottis. Therefore, as soon as epiglottitis is suspected, a physician with expertise in the management of difficult airways (e.g., anesthesiologist or otolaryngologist) should be notified and an intubation kit that includes the most advanced difficult airway adjuncts available (e.g., video laryngoscope, flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope) should be obtained.

In children under 12 years of age with epiglottitis, needle cricothyroidotomy is preferred because of the funnel shape and narrowness of the trachea at the height of the cricoid ring as opposed to adults, in whom the trachea is narrowest at the level of the vocal cords.

Tracheostomy is a complex procedure that is customarily performed as a planned procedure in the operating room. It is usually only used in emergencies after direct trauma to the airway or when the obstruction lies inferior to the cricothyroid membrane. Patients requiring an immediate surgical airway typically undergo procedures that can be performed quickly at the bedside, are successfully completed using anatomical landmarks, and are associated with less bleeding.

Patients with epiglottitis should be intubated by an airway specialist using the best available technology (e.g., fiberoptic video laryngoscope). If the first attempt fails, additional attempts are contraindicated. In this cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario, the airway specialist should proceed to the next step in the difficult airway management algorithm to avoid prolonged hypoxia and further compromising the airway.

answers.content: Continue bag-mask ventilation and move to intensive care unit
answers.explanation_why: In this patient, bag-mask ventilation has failed (SpO_2 is persistently < 80%). Continuing bag-mask ventilation after a failed intubation attempt in which the manipulation has possibly caused this patient's partial airway obstruction to progress to complete airway obstruction is unlikely to improve the oxygenation status. Likewise, transferring the patient to the ICU before securing the airway would sacrifice valuable time and prolong or worsen hypoxia.

Placing a laryngeal mask is contraindicated in patients with acute epiglottitis. These patients have an acute upper airway obstruction that cannot be bypassed by a supraglottic airway device, and insertion of a laryngeal mask can worsen swelling and anatomical conditions, making further attempts at airway access even more challenging.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and swelling of her right jaw over the past 8 weeks. She says that the symptoms started slowly and the pain varies in intensity. She was diagnosed with osteoporosis 15 months ago after she developed a vertebral compression fracture. Her T-score at the time of diagnosis was -3.5 and she was prescribed oral alendronate to be taken weekly. She smokes 5 cigarettes daily and drinks one beer every two to three days. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is pain and tenderness upon palpation of the right temporomandibular joint. Intraoral examination shows gingival erythema and swelling around the right lower molars without purulent discharge. A part of the alveolar bone of the mandible in the same area is exposed. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's orofacial disease?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and swelling of her right jaw over the past 8 weeks. She says that the symptoms started slowly and the pain varies in intensity. She was diagnosed with osteoporosis 15 months ago after she developed a vertebral compression fracture. Her T-score at the time of diagnosis was -3.5 and she was prescribed oral alendronate to be taken weekly. She smokes 5 cigarettes daily and drinks one beer every two to three days. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is pain and tenderness upon palpation of the right temporomandibular joint. Intraoral examination shows gingival erythema and swelling around the right lower molars without purulent discharge. A part of the alveolar bone of the mandible in the same area is exposed. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's orofacial disease?
hint: Pain, erythema, swelling of the jaw, and an area of exposed bone in a patient who has received long-term therapy with alendronate indicate medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ), a complication of antiresorptive drugs (e.g., bisphosphonates, RANKL inhibitors) and antiangiogenic drugs (e.g., VEGF inhibitors).
learning_objective: Recognize medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw, and choose the most effective measure to prevent this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Smoking cessation should be recommended in patients receiving bisphosphonates because smoking is a possible risk factor for MRONJ. However, other risk factors are more strongly associated with the development of MRONJ, and there is another more effective measure for preventing this patient's adverse effect.

Prophylactic antibiotic therapy can be used as a preventive measure in patients receiving bisphosphonate therapy prior to oral surgery and to prevent recurrence in already established MRONJ. In addition, antibiotic therapy is used in the treatment of MRONJ to promote healing. However, preventive antibiotic therapy is not generally indicated in patients receiving bisphosphonate therapy.

Preprandial medication intake (preferably in the morning 60 minutes before breakfast) is recommended in oral bisphosphonate therapy to enhance absorption. However, this strategy is not effective in preventing side effects such as MRONJ. The risk of other complications of oral bisphosphonate therapy, such as esophageal inflammation and reflux, can be minimized by swallowing bisphosphonates with a sufficient amount of water and maintaining an upright position for 30 minutes after medication intake.

Calcium supplementation is commonly provided during bisphosphonate therapy to reduce the risk of hypocalcemia. However, calcium supplementation has not been shown to reduce the risk of MRONJ. Since calcium forms complexes with bisphosphonates, it can reduce absorption, and neither supplements nor food should be taken within 60 minutes of oral bisphosphonate administration.

MRONJ is a rare but serious side effect of bisphosphonate therapy and is most commonly seen in high-dose IV administration in cancer patients, but it can also occur with oral administration (e.g., for osteoporosis). The underlying pathophysiology is not yet fully understood, but it is assumed that bisphosphonate's antiangiogenic effects in combination with the jaw's specific characteristics (e.g., high metabolism) play a role. Invasive dental procedures are a major risk factor for the development of MRONJ. Therefore, patient education and preventive measures, such as a comprehensive dental examination in conjunction with treatment of preexisting dental conditions (e.g., extraction of unrestorable teeth), are strongly encouraged prior to initiation of antiresorptive therapy. After the initiation of therapy, a daily oral care plan should be encouraged, entailing instructions on oral hygiene (e.g., daily oral rinsing, brushing, and flossing) as well as regular check-ups and cleanings.

Treatment of established MRONJ is mainly supportive and includes improved oral hygiene, antibiotic treatment, and limited debridement. Surgery should be avoided if possible.

question_text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of sore throat that is associated with difficulty swallowing. He says that his breath has recently “picked up a weird smell.” He has had no fever, weight loss, or difficulty speaking. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease and recurrent cold sores. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His medications are pantoprazole and topical acyclovir as needed. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years but quit 20 years ago. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an enlarged left tonsil with an ulcerous lesion but no purulent exudate. There is ipsilateral cervical nontender lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient’s condition?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of sore throat that is associated with difficulty swallowing. He says that his breath has recently “picked up a weird smell.” He has had no fever, weight loss, or difficulty speaking. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease and recurrent cold sores. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His medications are pantoprazole and topical acyclovir as needed. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years but quit 20 years ago. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an enlarged left tonsil with an ulcerous lesion but no purulent exudate. There is ipsilateral cervical nontender lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient’s condition?
hint: This patient's tonsillar ulceration and nontender cervical lymphadenopathy are highly suggestive of tonsillar cancer.
learning_objective: Recognize tonsillar cancer, and recall its strongest predisposing factor.

answers.explanation_why:
In the US, human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is responsible for 70% of all new cases of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the oropharynx, which includes the base of the tongue, the palatine tonsils and tonsillar pillars, the soft palate, and the pharyngeal wall. While HPV-negative oropharynx tumors are associated with dietary nitrosamine, alcohol consumption, and smoking, HPV-positive SCC is associated with the sexual transmission of high-risk HPV subtypes (e.g., types 16 and 18). These HPV subtypes produce the E7 protein, which inhibits retinoblastoma protein and consequently promotes increased cell proliferation. Patients usually present with subacute progressive sore throat, halitosis, and dysphagia.

Diagnosis of oropharynx cancers requires a biopsy (e.g., fine needle aspiration or punch biopsy) followed by panendoscopy and CT chest and/or MRI of the head and neck for staging. Management options include surgery or radiation with or without chemotherapy.

images.title: Tonsillar cancer
images.description: Exophytic lesion of the left tonsil

answers.explanation_why: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common cause of esophageal adenocarcinoma, which can also manifest with dysphagia and halitosis. Tonsillar cancer, on the other hand, is not associated with GERD.

Obesity is a risk factor for many conditions (e.g., cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis), but it is not associated with oropharyngeal cancer. Patient's diets have a small effect on oropharyngeal cancer risk: Diets with a high nitrosamine concentration (e.g., cured meats, smoked foods) increase the risk of oropharyngeal cancer while diets high in fruits and vegetables decrease the risk.
This patient's history of recurrent cold sores indicates a reactivated HSV infection. HSV infection is not a known risk factor for oropharyngeal cancer.

Tobacco use is strongly associated with HPV-negative oropharyngeal cancer but is not the strongest predisposing factor for oropharynx cancer in most developed countries. While this patient's five-pack-year smoking history could be considered a risk, a different factor likely has a much stronger impact on the development of oropharyngeal cancer in this patient.

question_text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonpainful swelling of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years, and he typically drinks two to three beers daily. He has received all scheduled immunizations until the age of 10 years but has not received any immunizations since then. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a nontender, 15-mm ulcer on the soft palate with raised, indurated borders and a shallow nonexudative base. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally but are not tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6500/mm^3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm^3. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the cervical lymph node shows reactive follicular hyperplasia. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonpainful swelling of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years, and he typically drinks two to three beers daily. He has received all scheduled immunizations until the age of 10 years but has not received any immunizations since then. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a nontender, 15-mm ulcer on the soft palate with raised, indurated borders and a shallow nonexudative base. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally but are not tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6500/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the cervical lymph node shows reactive follicular hyperplasia. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: If this patient had a rapid plasma reagin test, it would likely be positive.
learning_objective: Recognize primary syphilis, and choose the most effective measure to prevent sexually transmitted infections during oral sex.

answers.explanation_why: Completing the immunization schedule (via catch-up immunization) protects against vaccine-preventable diseases such as diphtheria and HPV infection. Diphtheria manifests acutely with sore throat, malaise, fever, pseudomembranous pharyngitis, and painful lymphadenopathy. Oral HPV infection manifests with warts or oropharyngeal squamous cell cancer (SCC). Oropharyngeal SCC can result in a nontender ulcerative lesion and painless cervical lymphadenopathy, but there is no evidence of a malignancy on this patient's lymph node biopsy. There is currently no immunization available against this patient's infection.

This patient is at increased risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection (STI) because he has multiple partners. His nontender oral ulcer with raised, indurated borders (chancre) and concomitant nontender lymphadenopathy (due to reactive follicular hyperplasia) is consistent with primary syphilis. The chancre is usually solitary, and develops at the site of inoculation after about 3 weeks. The chancre resolves without scarring after 3–6 weeks regardless of treatment. While primary syphilitic lesions most often occur in the genital region, about 5–10% of cases of primary syphilis are extragenital. Typical localizations are the oral cavity, hands and fingers, or the anus and perianal region, which reflect sexual practices, but chancres can occur wherever the skin has been in contact with Treponema pallidum from infectious sores. The use of a condom during vaginal or anal sex, and a dental dam during oral sex, can protect an individual against STIs by preventing contact with body fluids or an infectious lesion.

Smoking is one of the most important risk factors for head and neck cancers, and a nontender, ulcerative lesion with concomitant nontender cervical lymphadenopathy is also consistent with malignancy. However, fine-needle aspiration cytology shows no signs of malignancy (e.g., keratin pearls in squamous cell carcinoma, the most common mucosal head and neck cancer); reactive follicular hyperplasia suggests another etiology.

Dietary restriction of gluten is used to prevent manifestations of celiac disease (CD), which is caused by a maladaptive immune response to this protein. CD can lead to oral lesions as a result of malabsorption and nutrient deficiency. However, the oral manifestations of CD are poor dentition, atrophic glossitis, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, and cheilitis. The appearance of this patient's oral ulcer, its painless nature, and the concomitant cervical lymphadenopathy are inconsistent with any of the oral manifestations of CD. Moreover, this patient does not have signs typically seen in CD, such as chronic diarrhea, recurrent abdominal pain, and signs of malabsorption such as weight loss, fatigue, or anemia.

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which can cause oral ulceration and lymphadenopathy. However, HSV infection typically causes multiple, shallow ulcers with flat margins, and both the ulcerations and lymphadenopathy would be painful. Furthermore, herpes infections are prone to recurrence even with acyclovir therapy; previous acyclovir therapy would not have prevented a new episode. Acyclovir only decreases the duration and severity of an active episode and reduces viral shedding during the episode.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 6-hour history of persistent vertigo and nausea. She has been unable to walk due to dizziness and has vomited once since this morning. She has no history of similar symptoms and no recent trauma. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends. Medications are lisinopril, metformin, and simvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. She is alert and fully oriented. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 132/87 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows normal strength and sensation in all extremities. Reflexes are 2+ throughout. She sways towards the right side when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is able to fixate her eyes on a stable point while her head is rotated. There is vertical nystagmus that persists on gaze fixation of the right eye. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes bilaterally. She is able to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears and to repeat words whispered in her ears bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 6-hour history of persistent vertigo and nausea. She has been unable to walk due to dizziness and has vomited once since this morning. She has no history of similar symptoms and no recent trauma. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends. Medications are lisinopril, metformin, and simvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. She is alert and fully oriented. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 132/87 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows normal strength and sensation in all extremities. Reflexes are 2+ throughout. She sways towards the right side when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is able to fixate her eyes on a stable point while her head is rotated. There is vertical nystagmus that persists on gaze fixation of the right eye. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes bilaterally. She is able to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears and to repeat words whispered in her ears bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The combination of acute nausea, imbalance, and vertigo is concerning for acute vestibular syndrome (AVS). The Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew (HINTS) exam is used to differentiate between central and peripheral causes of AVS. This patient's negative head impulse test and vertical nystagmus are consistent with a central cause of AVS.
learning_objective: Recognize acute vestibular syndrome (AVS), and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Audiometry is more sensitive than a bedside examination in the diagnosis of hearing loss and would be performed if a peripheral cause of AVS such as labyrinthitis is suspected. Audiometry is not the most appropriate initial test if a central AVS is suspected. Hearing loss is usually absent in central AVS; it is only seen with certain rare causes of central AVS such as anterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke.

Patients who have at least one finding consistent with a central AVS on the HINTS examination (i.e. vertical, torsional, or gaze-evoked nystagmus, a negative head impulse test, a positive skew deviation test) should undergo an MRI of the brain. Given the sudden onset of symptoms and the presence of multiple risk factors for a cerebrovascular accident, a stroke affecting the cerebellum or brainstem is the most likely cause of central AVS in this patient. Concomitant focal neurological deficits would indicate a central AVS but these deficits may not be present in inferior or midline cerebellar infarcts or lacunar brainstem lesions due to small vessel disease. If central AVS is suspected but the initial MRI is inconclusive (which can be the case for several hours after onset of AVS due to stroke), repeat MRIs should be performed.

Demyelinating diseases of the CNS (e.g., multiple sclerosis) are a cause of central AVS in young adults and are associated with a more gradual progression of symptoms when compared to AVS due to stroke.

A Dix-Hallpike maneuver is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), a peripheral cause of vertigo and nystagmus. This patient's HINTS examination is consistent with a central cause for the patient's symptoms, for which a different test is indicated. Moreover, in BPPV, the symptoms occur in episodes that last seconds to minutes, not hours.

images.title: Dix-Hallpike maneuver
images.description:
A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

answers.explanation_why: Caloric testing was used in the past to differentiate between central and peripheral AVS, but it is no longer used because it is cumbersome, less accurate than the HINTS test, and can worsen vertigo during testing. This patient's HINTS examination already indicates a central AVS. A different diagnostic test that can further characterize the central etiology of this patient's AVS is required.

In a patient with features of central AVS, a lumbar puncture (LP) could be considered if multiple sclerosis (MS) is suspected based on the clinical presentation (e.g., in a young adult who has gradually progressing symptoms) but imaging shows no evidence of MS. The patient's smoking history, comorbidities (hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes mellitus), and sudden symptom onset suggest a different cause of the central AVS, for which LP is not indicated.

question_text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and irritability. The mother says he has been tugging on his left ear since yesterday evening. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and was exclusively breastfed until 3 months of age, when the parents introduced formula feeding. He is now eating some solid foods and receives one bottle of formula at night. He underwent cheiloplasty at 3 months of age because of an incomplete cleft lip. He and his two older siblings spend time together on weekdays when looked after by an au pair. He has been attending parent-child swimming classes for the past 2 months. His father smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily; his mother does not smoke. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination of the pharynx reveals pink tonsils. Otoscopy of the left ear shows erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks. Examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and irritability. The mother says he has been tugging on his left ear since yesterday evening. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and was exclusively breastfed until 3 months of age, when the parents introduced formula feeding. He is now eating some solid foods and receives one bottle of formula at night. He underwent cheiloplasty at 3 months of age because of an incomplete cleft lip. He and his two older siblings spend time together on weekdays when looked after by an au pair. He has been attending parent-child swimming classes for the past 2 months. His father smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily; his mother does not smoke. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination of the pharynx reveals pink tonsils. Otoscopy of the left ear shows erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks. Examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
hint: Erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks on otoscopy suggests acute otitis media (AOM).
learning_objective: Recognize acute otitis media, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: An incomplete cleft lip is a cleft on the upper lip that does not extend into the nostril. It can lead to suckling difficulties but does not increase the risk of AOM. A cleft palate, which is commonly associated with a complete cleft lip, is a risk factor for AOM.

Frequent contact with water is a risk factor for the development of otitis externa. Otitis externa manifests with severe pain, but other features are also expected, such as otorrhea, intense itching in the external auditory canal (EAC), and redness and swelling of the EAC on otoscopy. This patient's presentation is more consistent with AOM, for which frequent exposure to water is not a known risk factor.

Preterm birth is a risk factor for many conditions (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, patent ductus arteriosus, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia), and there is some evidence that it may lead to a moderately increased risk of AOM. However, another factor more strongly predisposes this patient to developing AOM.

Formula feeding and associated lack of breastfeeding increase the risk for AOM most likely because of the lack of maternal antibodies as well as physical factors (e.g., feeding position, altered pharyngeal pressure) that lead to the pooling of milk in the eustachian tube. Although this patient has only been breastfed for three months, any duration of breastfeeding is more protective than no breastfeeding at all. Another factor more strongly predisposes this child to developing AOM.

Passive tobacco exposure leads to an increased risk of AOM most likely because nicotine reduces the mucociliary clearance of the eustachian tube and increases the susceptibility of the mucosa of the middle ear to infection. The incidence of AOM in children peaks at 6–12 months of age, which might be related to a shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube and feeding in a supine position that allows nasal secretions to enter the middle ear cavity. Other risk factors include a family history of AOM, daycare attendance, lack of breastfeeding, pacifier use, and anatomical abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate).

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 2-week history of progressive hoarseness. During the past week, he has also had two episodes of cough and shortness of breath that resolved spontaneously. The mother is concerned that these episodes might be “asthmatic crises similar to the ones his grandmother has.” He has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother did not receive prenatal care but reports an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 38 weeks' gestation. She was treated for gonorrhea during the first trimester. The patient is not in acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laryngoscopy shows multiple polypoid growths distributed asymmetrically over the true and false vocal folds. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 2-week history of progressive hoarseness. During the past week, he has also had two episodes of cough and shortness of breath that resolved spontaneously. The mother is concerned that these episodes might be “asthmatic crises similar to the ones his grandmother has.” He has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother did not receive prenatal care but reports an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 38 weeks' gestation. She was treated for gonorrhea during the first trimester. The patient is not in acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laryngoscopy shows multiple polypoid growths distributed asymmetrically over the true and false vocal folds. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The absence of prenatal care increases the risk of developing this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize laryngeal papillomatosis.

answers.explanation_why:
Laryngeal papillomatosis is the most common form of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP), which develops as a result of human papillomavirus virus (HPV) infection (most commonly HPV 6 and HPV 11). Juvenile-onset RRP usually develops before the age of 5 years and is due to vertical transmission of HPV from the mother during vaginal delivery. This patient's mother has a history of a sexually transmitted infection, did not receive prenatal care, and had a vaginal birth, all of which increase the risk of vertical HPV transmission. Progressive hoarseness, cough, and dyspnea are typical of RRP. Other symptoms include dysphonia or aphonia, stridor, and dysphagia. The diagnosis is typically established using laryngoscopy, which shows raspberry-like growths located on the vocal cords. There is no definitive treatment for RRP. Management aims to limit the spread of disease via surgical excision of symptomatic lesions and potentially antiviral adjuvant therapy (e.g., cidofovir, interferon). Complications include malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma, airway obstruction, and life-threatening respiratory distress.

See “Differential diagnoses of benign laryngeal lesions” table.

images.title: Laryngeal papillomatosis
images.description: Laryngoscopy of the vocal cords.At the upper edge of the picture, at the front commissure, there are several pale pink "raspberry shaped" tumors on the mucous membrane. Below these there are other similar nodules.This appearance is characteristic of laryngeal papilomatosis.

answers.explanation_why: Vocal fold nodules are one of the most common causes of hoarseness in children and typically develop in boys. However, most vocal fold nodules are seen in boys aged 5–10 years with a history of repeated trauma or vocal abuse. Moreover, laryngoscopy usually shows symmetrically distributed, pinhead-sized pale nodules on the vocal folds, unlike the multiple polypoid asymmetrical growths seen in this patient.

images.title: Vocal cord nodules
images.description:
Laryngoscopic image of the vocal folds of an adult with increasing hoarseness of voice.Right picture: vocal folds in the respiratory position. Pinhead sized tumors lie on both sides, between the middle and anterior thirds of the vocal folds (place of the highest oscillation amplitude).
Left picture: same finding in phonation position.Diagnosis: vocal cord nodules (phonation nodules).

answers.explanation_why: Reinke edema can manifest with hoarseness and, in more severe cases, respiratory symptoms such as cough and dyspnea. However, this condition most commonly affects women aged 40–60 years with a history of smoking. In addition, laryngoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the true vocal folds, not asymmetric polypoid growths on both true and false vocal folds.

images.title: Reinke's edema
images.description: LaryngoscopyLoose, enlarged vocal cord due to a subepithelial edema between the epithelium and the vocal ligament (Reinke's space; green overlay).Diagnosis: moderate Reinke's edema

answers.explanation_why: Vocal fold retention cysts may manifest with hoarseness and possible dyspnea. However, most vocal fold retention cysts develop in adults with a history of vocal stress (e.g., professional singers). Children may develop epidermoid vocal fold cysts as a result of a congenital anomaly of the vocal cords. Both retention and epidermoid vocal fold cysts are, however, characterized by a well-defined unilateral yellow-white lesion of the vocal cords on laryngoscopy rather than polypoid asymmetrical growths like the ones seen here.

Chronic laryngitis can manifest with hoarseness and chronic cough. However, the diagnosis of chronic laryngitis is usually established if symptoms persist for more than three weeks whereas this patient has had symptoms for only two weeks. In addition, laryngoscopy usually shows mucus, erythema, and edema of the posterior laryngeal wall with possible atrophy rather than polypoid growths of the vocal folds.
