question_text: A 20-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fever and pain in the right ear for the past 2 days. The mother says her daughter had three episodes of the same symptoms that resolved with antibiotics during the past year. The patient attends daycare 5 days per week and participates in parent-child swimming classes. She has no known medication allergies. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. On examination, she cries and tugs on her right ear. Otoscopy of the right ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane with an air-fluid level in the anterosuperior quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best approach to prevent the recurrence of these symptoms in this patient?
content_preview: A 20-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fever and pain in the right ear for the past 2 days. The mother says her daughter had three episodes of the same symptoms that resolved with antibiotics during the past year. The patient attends daycare 5 days per week and participates in parent-child swimming classes. She has no known medication allergies. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. On examination, she cries and tugs on her right ear. Otoscopy of the right ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane with an air-fluid level in the anterosuperior quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best approach to prevent the recurrence of these symptoms in this patient?
hint: The combination of fever, otalgia, and fluid accumulation behind an erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane (TM) on otoscopy indicates acute otitis media (AOM).
learning_objective: Recognize recurrent acute otitis media, and choose the best approach to prevent its recurrence in a pediatric patient.

answers.explanation_why:
Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion should be considered in children with recurrent AOM (i.e., ≥ 4 episodes in 12 months or ≥ 3 episodes in 6 months). The placement of small tubes in the tympanic membrane enables the drainage of fluid and helps to maintain an air-filled space in the middle ear, which can decrease the frequency of AOM episodes. The use of prophylactic antibiotics in recurrent AOM is not recommended.

Acute management of AOM, on the other hand, consists of analgesia (acetaminophen and/or ibuprofen). Antibiotic treatment (e.g., oral amoxicillin) is indicated in patients ≤ 6 months of age, in those < 2 years of age with bilateral AOM, and in all patients with severe infections (moderate to severe otalgia, otalgia lasting > 48 hours, and/or fever ≥ 39°C). Daycare attendance is a risk factor for AOM because of increased exposure to respiratory pathogens.

images.title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
images.description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

answers.content: Application of acetic acid ear drops after swimming
answers.explanation_why: The application of acetic acid ear drops after swimming helps to dry and reacidify the ear canal and prevent skin maceration. This intervention is used to stop the recurrence of otitis externa, for which swimming is a risk factor. Although otitis externa manifests with severe pain, other features such as otorrhea, intense itching in the external auditory canal (EAC), and redness and swelling of the EAC on otoscopy would also be expected. This patient has AOM, which requires a different approach.

Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure to repair a nonhealing defect in the tympanic membrane. This procedure is indicated to prevent recurrence in patients with chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) who do not respond to conservative measures. CSOM manifests with persistent drainage from the middle ear through a perforated tympanic membrane. This patient has no ear discharge or evidence of perforation on otoscopy.

Prophylactic antibiotic treatment is not recommended to prevent recurrent AOM according to the American Academy of Pediatrics. Amoxicillin is the first-line antibiotic agent for treating antibiotic-naive patients with AOM. However, oral rather than topical administration is preferred, as topical antibiotics are generally ineffective.

Enlarged adenoids are a risk factor for mechanical obstruction of the eustachian tube, which can lead to AOM. Adenoidectomy can be used as a preventive measure in patients who develop AOM despite the presence of tympanostomy tubes. Although this patient most likely has recurrent AOM, otoscopy did not show tympanostomy tubes.

question_text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but is concerned about whitish lesions that recently appeared on his tongue. The lesions are painless and do not cause any discomfort but “look weird.” He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has been sexually active with one female partner and two male partners during the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcoholic beverages. Ten years ago, he experimented with intravenous drugs but “it was a one-time thing.” His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of his mouth is shown. The lesions are nontender and do not come off when scraped with a tongue blade. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. HIV antibody test is positive and CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 380/mm^3. Serologic studies for hepatitis B and C are negative. In addition to initiating combined antiretroviral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of the oral lesions?
content_preview: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but is concerned about whitish lesions that recently appeared on his tongue. The lesions are painless and do not cause any discomfort but “look weird.” He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has been sexually active with one female partner and two male partners during the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcoholic beverages. Ten years ago, he experimented with intravenous drugs but “it was a one-time thing.” His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of his mouth is shown. The lesions are nontender and do not come off when scraped with a tongue blade. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. HIV antibody test is positive and CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 380/mm3. Serologic studies for hepatitis B and C are negative. In addition to initiating combined antiretroviral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of the oral lesions?
hint: Nontender white oral lesions that cannot be removed by scraping in a patient with HIV are highly suggestive of oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL).
learning_objective: Recognize oral hairy leukoplakia in HIV patients, and choose the appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Intralesional chemotherapy can be used to treat oral Kaposi sarcoma, which can manifest with painless oral lesions in patients with HIV. However, the lesions in oral Kaposi sarcoma are typically dark (e.g., purple) rather than white and feathery.

images.title: Intraoral Kaposi sarcoma of the palate
images.description:
Photographs of the oral cavityImage 1 shows a single purple nodule on the palate.
Image 2 shows several purple papules on the palate.These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma.

answers.explanation_why: Topical nystatin can be used to treat oral candidiasis (thrush), which often affects patients with HIV and manifests with nontender white oral lesions. However, oral candidiasis can typically be scraped off, leaving a bleeding base on the oral mucosa. While oral candidiasis is usually a clinical diagnosis, potassium hydroxide may be applied to look for pseudohyphae (characteristic of oral candidiasis) to distinguish between oral candidiasis and OHL.

images.title: Oral candidiasis
images.description: There are extensive whitish patches that can be scraped off covering the tongue.This is the typical appearance of pseudomembranous candidiasis, and diagnosis should be confirmed by microscopy and culture of mucosal swabs.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical excision is recommended for the management of leukoplakia, which is a premalignant lesion that manifests with nontender white oral lesions that do not scrape off easily. However, leukoplakia typically manifests with uniformly white plaques, unlike the feathery plaques seen in OHL, and is strongly associated with smoking.

images.title: Oral leukoplakia
images.description: Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Oral clobetasol is typically used to treat oral lichen planus, which manifests with white oral lesions. However, oral lichen planus typically manifests with white lacy plaques and is often painful. Moreover, it is strongly associated with hepatitis C.

images.title: Oral lichen planus
images.description: Lacelike, white lesions on the oral mucous membrane that cannot be scraped off (Wickham striae) are visible.This appearance is typical for oral lichen planus.

answers.content: No additional management is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why: OHL is a benign condition that typically manifests with a feathery or hairy appearance. It is most commonly found on the lateral aspect of the tongue and, less commonly, on the floor of the mouth, palate, or buccal mucosa. OHL is strongly associated with immunosuppressive states, e.g., in patients with HIV, those undergoing chemotherapy, and organ transplant recipients. Therefore, all patients with OHL should be tested for HIV. OHL is self-limited and typically improves after antiretroviral therapy has been initiated; therefore, no additional management is indicated.

images.title: HIV patient with oral hairy leukoplakia
images.description: A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of excessive daytime fatigue and difficulty concentrating at work. She also mentions that she is having frequent headaches in the morning. Her partner reports that the patient snores loudly every night. She has hypertension treated with amlodipine and lisinopril; the dose of amlodipine was increased at her last visit 2 months ago. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine in the evenings. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 108 kg (238 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m^2. Her pulse is 74/min, and her blood pressure is 141/88 mm Hg. Neck circumference is 44 cm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of polysomnography confirm the diagnosis. In addition to recommending weight loss and adequate sleep hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of excessive daytime fatigue and difficulty concentrating at work. She also mentions that she is having frequent headaches in the morning. Her partner reports that the patient snores loudly every night. She has hypertension treated with amlodipine and lisinopril; the dose of amlodipine was increased at her last visit 2 months ago. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine in the evenings. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 108 kg (238 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. Her pulse is 74/min, and her blood pressure is 141/88 mm Hg. Neck circumference is 44 cm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of polysomnography confirm the diagnosis. In addition to recommending weight loss and adequate sleep hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Daytime fatigue, morning headaches, snoring, hypertension, and an increased neck circumference indicate obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Polysomnography is used to confirm the diagnosis of OSA and determine its severity.
learning_objective: Choose the first-line treatment for obstructive sleep apnea.

answers.explanation_why: Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UPPP) is the surgical dilation of the upper airway via resection of the uvula and redundant retrolingual, soft palate, and tonsillar tissue. Although UPPP can be used as adjunctive therapy, another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

Positive airway pressure (PAP) therapy is first-line treatment for all patients with OSA. PAP functions as a pneumatic splint, preventing airway collapse, thereby reducing the frequency of respiratory events. PAP therapy is administered via a mask that can apply continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP) with different levels for inhalation and exhalation, or a range of automatic positive airway pressure (APAP) levels. This treatment reduces disease severity, helps to control hypertension, and improves sleep-related quality of life. Alternative treatment methods (e.g., oral appliances, positional therapy) should be considered in patients unable to tolerate PAP.

images.title: Obstructive sleep apnea
images.description: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

answers.content: No additional treatment is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why: Although lifestyle modifications (e.g., adequate sleep hygiene and weight loss) are important components of supportive care, another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

Hypoglossal nerve stimulation therapy involves the implantation of a pacing device that modulates the genioglossus muscle to reduce airway collapsibility. Although hypoglossal nerve stimulation can be used as an alternative therapy, another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

answers.content: Nocturnal use of a mandibular advancement device
answers.explanation_why: Mandibular advancement devices can be used in patients with OSA to move the lower jaw forward, preventing airway collapse. Another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

hint: Hearing loss in a patient whose ear canal is obstructed with cerumen is consistent with cerumen impaction.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for symptomatic cerumen impaction.

answers.explanation_why: Cerumen removal is indicated for all individuals with cerumen impaction. Treatment options include manual cerumen removal, ear canal irrigation, and cerumenolytics, used alone or in combination. Cerumen removal is not indicated for asymptomatic cerumen accumulation, except for cases in which a thorough assessment of the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, or audiovestibular apparatus is necessary. While anyone can develop cerumen impaction, it is most common in individuals with risk factors for cerumen impaction, such as regular insertion of objects into the ear canal (e.g., cotton-tipped swabs), anatomical ear abnormalities, dermatological conditions (e.g., eczema, seborrheic dermatosis), and individuals who are unable to recognize or communicate symptoms (i.e., young children, individuals with cognitive impairment, and older adults). Prevention involves patient education on ear hygiene. In individuals with recurrent cerumen impaction, cerumen removal regimens may be considered.

Referral to an otolaryngologist is appropriate for individuals with risk factors for cerumen removal complications (e.g., nonintact tympanic membrane, risk for infection) or previous unsuccessful attempts at cerumen removal. This patient's uncomplicated cerumen impaction can be managed in a primary care setting.

Asymptomatic cerumen accumulation does not require treatment unless a thorough assessment of the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, or audiovestibular apparatus is necessary. This patient does have symptoms, necessitating an intervention.

Antibiotic ear drops are indicated in otitis externa, which can manifest with symptoms such as ear pain, itching, and hearing loss. However, the absence of otorrhea, severe pain, and typical physical examination findings (e.g., an erythematous and edematous external auditory canal) make this diagnosis unlikely.

Although olive oil ear drops can soften cerumen, they are generally ineffective for treating cerumen impaction. Ear candling, olive oil drops, cotton-tipped swabs, and at-home use of jet irrigators are not recommended because they are ineffective and can increase the risk of injury. A different management step is more appropriate.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 64 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I feel very dizzy.”
History of Present Illness:

2-day history of persistent dizziness that has been getting worse
severe nausea with 7 episodes of vomiting since yesterday
has difficulty walking in a straight line
history of upper respiratory tract infection 8 days ago

no history of recent travel or head trauma

Past Medical History:

3-year history of diabetes mellitus

5-year history of hypercholesterolemia

5-year history of hypertension

7-year history of sinus node dysfunction with symptomatic bradycardia treated with permanent pacemaker implantation

Medications: 

metformin
atorvastatin
lisinopril

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: deceased at age 56 years from myocardial infarction
mother: alive with no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:

drinks 5 beers and several shots of vodka daily
does not smoke cigarettes

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.7°C
(98.0°F)

87/min
17/min
140/90 mm Hg
97% on RA

155 cm
(5 ft 1 in)
61 kg
(135 lb)
26 kg/m^2

Appearance: alert; visibly uncomfortable
HEENT: PERRLA; spontaneous horizontal nystagmus in the right eye with the fast phase beating toward the left; nystagmus disappears when the patient looks to the right; no vertical misalignment on the alternate cover test; impaired vestibuloocular reflex in the right eye; external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane are intact bilaterally; Rinne test positive bilaterally; Weber test lateralized to the left

Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; nontender to palpation
Neurologic: fully oriented; normal muscle tone; no tremors; sensation to light touch and temperature intact; muscle strength 5/5 throughout; mild gait ataxia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

visibly uncomfortable HEENT: PERRLA; spontaneous horizontal nystagmus in the right eye with the fast phase beating toward the left; nystagmus disappears when the patient looks to the right; no vertical misalignment on the alternate cover test; impaired vestibuloocular reflex in the right eye; external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane are intact bilaterally; Rinne test positive bilaterally; Weber test lateralized to the left Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops Abdominal: nondistended; nontender to palpation Neurologic: fully oriented; normal muscle tone; no tremors; sensation to light touch and temperature intact; muscle strength 5/5 throughout; mild gait ataxia Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The presence of gait instability, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting indicate that vertigo due to acute vestibular syndrome (AVS) is the most likely cause of this patient's acute-onset dizziness. The presence of all of the following on HINTS examination strongly suggests peripheral vertigo: spontaneous unidirectional horizontal nystagmus, absent skew deviation, and abnormal head impulse test (i.e., impaired vestibuloocular reflex).
learning_objective: Distinguish labyrinthitis from other causes of dizziness.

answers.explanation_why: Labyrinthitis, a subtype of vestibular neuritis, is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and AVS from a peripheral cause. This condition is caused by inflammation of the membranous labyrinth that is usually idiopathic, autoimmune, or caused by a viral (e.g., following an upper respiratory infection) or bacterial infection (e.g., as a complication of otitis media). Labyrinthitis causes decreased vestibular activity and typically manifests with nystagmus toward the healthy ear. Diagnosis is clinical and does not routinely require neuroimaging.

Bradyarrhythmia or tachyarrhythmia resulting from pacemaker failure can lead to dizziness as a result of presyncope. However, this patient has a normal heart rate with a regular rhythm. Moreover, presyncope usually lasts seconds to minutes and is not associated with nystagmus, nausea, or vomiting. This patient's presentation is consistent with dizziness due to vertigo.

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a peripheral cause of vertigo. However, episodes of BPPV are typically sudden, brief (< 1 minute), and triggered by certain head movements. Moreover, hearing loss is not expected in BPPV.

An ischemic stroke affecting the posterior circulation can cause vertigo. However, an ischemic stroke causes central vertigo, which manifests with a normal head impulse test, central-type nystagmus (e.g., direction-changing, vertical, or torsional nystagmus), or skew deviation on the HINTS examination. This patient has a peripheral cause for vertigo.

Wernicke encephalopathy can occur in patients with a history of heavy alcohol use and manifests with ataxia and features of oculomotor dysfunction such as horizontal nystagmus. However, this condition typically causes gaze-evoked nystagmus in both eyes, unlike the spontaneous unilateral nystagmus in this patient. Moreover, hearing loss is not expected in Wernicke encephalopathy, and the patient does not present with other clinical features of this condition such as disorientation, impaired vigilance, and cognitive deficits.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 42 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My hearing is getting worse and I have liquid coming out of my ear.” 
History of Present Illness:

1-year history of progressive hearing loss

1-month history of painless unilateral fluid leakage from the right ear
no dizziness or ringing in ears

Past Medical History:
generalized anxiety disorder
Medications:
citalopram
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History:
has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

37.1°C
(98.8°F)

65/min
14/min
135/80 mm Hg
-

182 cm
(6 ft 0 in)
70 kg
(154 lb)
20.9 kg/m^2

Appearance: sitting in a chair, comfortable
HEENT: left ear canal with no erythema, discharge, or swelling and tympanic membrane is reflective of light; right ear with otorrhea and a brown, irregular mass and partial retraction of the tympanic membrane

Neurologic: no abnormalities; cranial nerves are grossly intact

Diagnostic Studies
Audiogram: shown

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 42 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: clinic History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My hearing is getting worse and I have liquid coming out of my ear.” History of Present Illness: 1-year history of progressive hearing loss 1-month history of painless unilateral fluid leakage from the right ear no dizziness or ringing in ears Past Medical History: generalized anxiety disorder Medications: citalopram Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Psychosocial History: has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37.1°C(98.8°F) 65/min 14/min 135/80 mm Hg - 182 cm(6 ft 0 in) 70 kg(154 lb) 20.9 kg/m2 Appearance: sitting in a chair, comfortable HEENT: left ear canal with no erythema, discharge, or swelling and tympanic membrane is reflective of light; right ear with otorrhea and a brown, irregular mass and partial retraction of the tympanic membrane Neurologic: no abnormalities; cranial nerves are grossly intact Diagnostic Studies Audiogram: shown Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's audiogram shows a right-sided air-bone gap as a result of an increased auditory threshold in air conduction with normal bone conduction, which is typical for conductive hearing loss.
learning_objective: Distinguish cholesteatoma from other causes of hearing loss.

answers.explanation_why: Otitis externa may lead to otorrhea and unilateral conductive hearing loss. However, otitis externa is an acute condition in which severe ear pain and intense itching are also expected. Additionally, in otitis externa, otoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous external ear canal rather than a brown irregular mass.

Acoustic neuroma manifests with unilateral sensorineural, not conductive, hearing loss, and pure tone audiometry reveals an increased threshold for both air and bone conduction. Moreover, a tumor of the vestibular nerve is likely to cause further symptoms, such as vertigo and tinnitus, and does not explain this patient's otorrhea and otoscopic findings.

Presbycusis manifests gradually with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss rather than unilateral conductive hearing loss; pure tone audiometry would therefore reveal an increased threshold for both air and bone conduction. Furthermore, patients typically present in the sixth decade of life and without otorrhea.

images.title: Sensorineural hearing loss
images.description: Pure tone audiogramBoth ears show a parallel decrease of air and bone conduction in the higher frequencies. This finding indicates cochlear or retrocochlear damage (often seen in presbycusis).

answers.explanation_why: Labyrinthitis is caused by inflammation in the inner ear and manifests with unilateral sensorineural, not conductive, hearing loss; pure tone audiometry would therefore show an increased threshold for both air and bone conduction. Furthermore, labyrinthitis typically manifests acutely or subacutely rather than gradually, and severe vertigo and tinnitus are also expected.

Cerumen impaction can manifest with otorrhea and conductive hearing loss. However, in a cerumen-impacted ear, otoscopy shows obstruction of the external auditory canal by a brownish-yellow, waxy plug, and the tympanic membrane is unlikely to be visible.

images.title: Cerumen impaction
images.description: Otoscopic image of the external auditory canalThe auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's progressive right-sided conductive hearing loss, painless otorrhea, and irregular mass on otoscopy suggest cholesteatoma of the right ear. Cholesteatomas can be congenital or acquired. Acquired cholesteatomas are classified as primary if caused by chronic negative middle ear pressure (due to eustachian tube dysfunction without middle ear infection) or secondary if caused by past injury to the tympanic membrane (typically due to chronic otitis media). The retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane and the brown, irregular mass are characteristic otoscopic findings of primary acquired cholesteatoma. The typical otoscopic appearance of secondary acquired cholesteatomas is a pearly white mass shining through the intact tympanic membrane.

Surgery is always required to excise cholesteatomas because of the risk of complications of the growing mass, which include the destruction of ear ossicles, perilymph fistula, and facial nerve paralysis.

images.title: Cholesteatoma
images.description: A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium that grows from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or mastoid. The presence of abnormal epithelium triggers an inflammatory response that can destroy surrounding structures such as the ossicles.

images.title: Conductive hearing loss
images.description: Pure tone audiogramThe diagram shows a difference of 30dB between air and bone conduction in the right ear versus the left ear. These findings are indicative of middle or external ear pathologies, such as otitis media or tympanic membrane perforation.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a high fever that began 5 hours ago. He has had a sore throat and cough for the past 3 days. Today, he refused to eat, became increasingly lethargic, and developed a fever that did not respond to acetaminophen at home. His past medical history is unremarkable. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears ill and somnolent. His temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 30/min. Physical examination shows stridor, rhinorrhea, and a productive cough with copious purulent sputum. The patient's stridor does not improve with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine. Anteroposterior and lateral neck x-rays show subglottic narrowing and irregularities of the tracheal wall. Which of the following is the most likely causal infectious agent?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a high fever that began 5 hours ago. He has had a sore throat and cough for the past 3 days. Today, he refused to eat, became increasingly lethargic, and developed a fever that did not respond to acetaminophen at home. His past medical history is unremarkable. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears ill and somnolent. His temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 30/min. Physical examination shows stridor, rhinorrhea, and a productive cough with copious purulent sputum. The patient's stridor does not improve with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine. Anteroposterior and lateral neck x-rays show subglottic narrowing and irregularities of the tracheal wall. Which of the following is the most likely causal infectious agent?
hint: The most common cause of bullous impetigo is also the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize bacterial tracheitis, and recall the most common causal pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of croup, which has a 1–2 day prodromal phase and can cause cough, subglottic narrowing (visible as a steeple sign on a neck x-ray), and stridor in moderate to severe cases. However, patients with croup typically present with a low-grade fever and a nonproductive barking cough, and stridor improves with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine.

Following the advent of the Hib vaccine, Streptococcus pyogenes is now a common cause of epiglottitis. This condition manifests with the rapid onset of high-grade fever, stridor, and a toxic appearance, and symptoms do not improve with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine. However, characteristic findings on lateral neck x-ray include thumb sign with supraglottic rather than subglottic narrowing. S. pyogenes can also cause bacterial tracheitis, but it is not the most common causal agent.

Respiratory diphtheria is a rare cause of stridor and is typically preceded by a 4–5 day prodrome of fever, sore throat, and malaise. Due to the destruction and subsequent inflammation of the upper respiratory epithelium, patients present with pseudomembranes on the tonsils and pharyngeal wall, and significant cervical lymphadenopathy (bull neck appearance). Due to widespread pediatric immunization against diphtheria, most cases now occur in adults, after the effects of childhood immunization have waned.

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection is the most common cause of bronchiolitis, which usually occurs in patients < 6 months of age and manifests with wheezing, crackles, and rhonchi on lung auscultation. Radiographic findings of bronchiolitis include peribronchial thickening and hyperinflated lungs. Stridor and irregular subglottic narrowing indicate a different diagnosis.

A rapid onset of high-grade fever, productive cough, and stridor in combination with subglottic narrowing and tracheal wall irregularities on imaging indicates bacterial tracheitis, which is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. This condition is rare but potentially life-threatening and necessitates immediate airway stabilization, followed by initiation of empiric IV antibiotics and bronchoscopy for both diagnostic confirmation and therapeutic airway debridement. Stridor caused by bacterial tracheitis does not improve with nebulized racemic epinephrine, unlike stridor due to croup. Bronchoscopy typically reveals tracheal edema, pseudomembranous exudates, and purulent secretions. Less common causes of bacterial tracheitis include Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

See “Infectious causes of airway obstruction” table.

question_text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father because of recurrent nosebleeds for the past week. Each episode lasts about 10 minutes and stops spontaneously. Today, he developed another nosebleed while at school and was sent home after the bleeding subsided. He has a history of seasonal allergies and uses intranasal corticosteroids. Family history is unremarkable. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears comfortable. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly erythematous nasal septum, and small crusts are present at the anterior-inferior portion of the septum. Dried blood is visible at the right anterior nostril. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Following examination, the patient's nose begins bleeding again. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father because of recurrent nosebleeds for the past week. Each episode lasts about 10 minutes and stops spontaneously. Today, he developed another nosebleed while at school and was sent home after the bleeding subsided. He has a history of seasonal allergies and uses intranasal corticosteroids. Family history is unremarkable. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears comfortable. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly erythematous nasal septum, and small crusts are present at the anterior-inferior portion of the septum. Dried blood is visible at the right anterior nostril. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Following examination, the patient's nose begins bleeding again. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: Episodic bleeding from the nostrils in a patient with a history of intranasal corticosteroid use and crusting at the Kiesselbach plexus suggests anterior epistaxis.
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate stepwise management of anterior epistaxis.

answers.explanation_why: Nasal cautery (i.e., chemical cautery with silver nitrate, electrocautery) is an effective treatment for clearly localized anterior epistaxis that persists despite initial conservative management. This method requires clear visualization of the bleeding site and is not the initial approach for episodes of uncomplicated anterior epistaxis due to the potential for tissue injury, infection, and septal necrosis, which can result in perforation.

Endoscopic anterior ethmoidal artery ligation targets a major artery supply to the nasal cavity and is reserved for refractory bleeding in anterior epistaxis. Ligation of the sphenopalatine artery is not indicated in patients with episodes of uncomplicated anterior epistaxis.

Anterior nasal packing (e.g., with ribbon gauze, nasal tampon) is indicated for ongoing bleeding in patients with persistent epistaxis after initial conservative measures have failed or if the bleeding site cannot be identified. Nasal packing is not the initial management for uncomplicated anterior epistaxis.

Topical vasoconstrictors (e.g., oxymetazoline) help manage nasal bleeding by promoting local vasoconstriction and reducing blood flow. While vasoconstrictors can be considered as part of the immediate management, especially in minor anterior epistaxis, they are usually not the initial step.

answers.content: Application of pressure to the nostrils
answers.explanation_why: Application of pressure to the nostrils is the initial step in the management of anterior epistaxis, particularly in hemodynamically stable patients with bleeding from the Kiesselbach plexus. Direct, uninterrupted, bilateral pressure for 15–20 minutes (e.g., by pinching the nasal ala against the nasal septum while the patient sits upright and leans forward to avoid blood aspiration) compresses the bleeding vessels and is typically sufficient to stop bleeding.
